text: This country's dramatic political changes have passed them by. Greater democracy has not brought greater respect for the stateless Rohingya's human rights. But the formation of an Advisory Commission on Rakhine State, dominated as it is with hard-line nationalists and anti-Rohingya activists including former leaders of Myanmar's military junta - shows how little has changed since Aung San Suu Kyi took office in 2016 promising to address discrimination against minorities. The UK government should engage more assertively than before in its efforts to end ethnic cleansing at home and abroad among Muslims in BurmaMyanmar (as many people prefer). The plight of the Rohingya is a symptom that goes back decades: British participation can make a difference if we act now or risk another tragedy like Srebrenica happening again elsewhere in modern Europe.

Those selling the illicit weapons often disassembled and sent them in different packages or embedded them in old stereos or printers, the report found. Researchers found that firearms and related items were sold on Facebook Marketplace - a platform to buy and sell goods with more than 300m active monthly users worldwide (pdf) - for as little as 1 each. In one case cited by Gun Violence Archive researchers, an item was listed online under "car parts" but contained three AK-47s shipped from California, Florida and Texas; another listing had two rifles labeled as speaker cables: an AR-15 assault rifle and SKS semi-automatic hunting rifle packed together inside what appeared to be plain cardboard boxes. Others included pistols hidden within books of matches, and handguns shrunk down into bottles of shampoo. In addition to these listings, other sellers offered gun training services via social media platforms such as Instagram Live, where they would charge anywhere between 50-100 per session depending which firearm type is being trained upon. Instagram has not responded to requests for comment about this service or whether it plans to take any action against those offering similar classes on its platform. The sale of illegal weapons also extends beyond private sales through sites like Craigslist, Armslist and Letgo, the study went on to show. One seller advertises his wares under the title "guns," while others use terms including "firearms." Some even include phrases meaning shooting accessories when describing their offerings, yet investigators say there's no way of knowing if these products are truly legal because none of the posts provided details regarding whether the guns have been registered, transferred properly or licensed. Under US law, only certain professionals can legally make and advertise purchases or transfers of new long arms - and among rules surrounding registration requirements, every weapon must include information identifying the buyer so he or she will eventually get traced back should something go wrong. But buyers who purchase off illicit websites don't know whether their prospective dealer got all proper licensing documents required before making any deal - nor do authorities. Tracker systems used nationally across America to track stolen and lost property aren't able to identify pieces adapted into illegal uses without first having serial numbers filed off. Even then, smugglers simply file paperwork indicating ownership using fake names at pawn shops owned by friends and family members. A spokesperson for US Customs Border Protection told Motherboard it did pursue cases involving small caliber machine guns imported illegally, adding that CBP investigates most complaints received concerning suspected violations relating to imports arriving in the country. He declined however to provide further specifics saying records were confidential.

The boys, aged 12 and 13, were seriously injured in the attack in Havant, Hampshire, on Friday and remain in hospital. Richard Michael Walsh, 43, of no fixed address, has been charged with attempted murder. A 14-year-old boy was also arrested but later released from custody pending further inquiries.

Trafford Council closed Bollin Primary School in Bowdon, Greater Manchester on Monday after concerns about a "reduced capacity of senior leadership." The council said the school had appointed an interim headteacher and was working with Ofsted to ensure it did not have any future special measures. The local authority has also offered to pay parents' fees if they choose another primary for their child over next few months.

Apple Music performed a U-turn over payment policy a day after the pop star threatened to prevent the US firm from streaming her album 1989. Swift had argued that Apple could not offer both free downloads and paid streams of songs included in its iTunes Match service without paying artists compensation for each play, but on Wednesday it said all music would cost 99 cents with no limits placed on how many times they were played. The row has underlined the growing power wielded by musicians as their audience expands into areas such as mobile devices where users are less likely than ever before pay any attention to royalties issues. The dispute also comes at an awkward time because tech giants including Amazon, Google and Facebook have moved into media content production or distribution - which some believe will diminish revenue generated through artist's work.

Latham smashed Colin Ackermann for six to reach his hundred but was caught behind off Neil Dexter for 124. Opener Steel went on to make his century off 242 balls, hitting eight fours and two sixes in a 146-run partnership with Bailey (86). The Englishman finished the innings unbeaten at 133 not out after being dropped by Kyle Abbott when he had just seven runs to go. He faced 249 deliveries and hit 19 boundaries during that time as Yorkshire made 328-3 declared having lost their last wicket 35 minutes before tea.

An altercation broke out between two men inside a fast food outlet about 00:35 BST on Sunday which then continued outside. Police said the suspect is described being aged in his 20s, black and wearing dark clothing with gold teeth. A second man was also hurt during the incident at The Kebab Factory restaurant in Luton High Street but has since been discharged from hospital. The pair were taken to Bedford Hospital for treatment where they remain in separate conditions.

Police have charged a 32-year-old Norwegian man over both attacks. The man dressed as a police officer was arrested on tiny Utoeya island after an hour-long shooting spree. Prime Minister Erna Solberg said the suspect appeared to be "more of a loner" but that "the motive is still unclear, and we don't know if there are other perpetrators." The prime minister added: "It appears that he has acted alone today."

Firefighters tackled the blaze, which started just before 21:00 on Monday in Carron Valley. The home owners and their dog escaped from the building after being alerted by a smoke alarm, The fire spread to two neighbouring homes but crews managed to put it out within an hour of arriving at the scene.

The idea will be looked at as part of a wider study of transport issues across southern Scotland. Campaign for Border Rail spokesman Simon Walton said they would have preferred the full-length railway line to be considered, but he welcomed any consideration of the Borders Railway extension and improvements elsewhere in the region's rail network He added: "We believe that this is positive news which shows how far we've come since our campaign was first launched last year. The council now recognises there are economic benefits from reopening the Borders Railway between EdinburghGlasgow Carlisle - something Scottish Government ministers continue not to grasp despite it being such an obvious solution."

Nazanin Zaghari-Ratcliffe was sentenced to five years for allegedly plotting to topple the government in Tehran. Her husband, Richard Ratcliffe, has criticised the UK government for a lack of action during her imprisonment The British Council said it had no previous knowledge that Mrs Zaghari-Ratclife planned on taking part in demonstrations outside Evin Prison and did not authorise or support such actions from its staff members (pictured: A protest held by Nazanin's family)

Each evening Cardiff Bay will become the venue for a world music Showcase Festival featuring a tapas of world music from around the world. Folk music played a large part in this year's festival and it was fitting that the final concert should be an Irish session with some special guests joining us again, including Daithi Murray (Accordion) Mark Kavanagh (Fiddle). Other musicians on stage included: John Doyle (Saxophone), John Power - banjoguitar Charlie Ryan- bodhran Yvonne O'Dwyer - vocals Mary Healy harp Keith Burke- bass guitar The programme opened with 'Sile Seoige Maigh Cuileanach" one of our favourite songs by Kathleen MacInerney who has been touring extensively over recent years promoting her extensive repertoire which includes many traditional tunes set to contemporary settings in both English and Gaelic language versions. The song is based loosely upon a legend about St Patrick converting the snakes into horses but there are other tales too depending where you come from! This beautiful performance would have brought back memories of listening to Neil Marsh play on radio when he first broke onto the scene playing with his brother Gerry during the 1950's and 60's. There were echoes here also of Judith Weir singing "Go Tell Aunt Rhody" in the same vein as Neil sang in Dublin so long ago...except that Judy sings much more beautifully than either sister ever did!! It began slowly enough then took off at such speed we barely had time to catch up before she reached the end....or rather I say ended because after 2 minutes or so she started all over again!!! She must put in extra hours practicing........we hope!! Next came "Carrickfergus," another Kerry original composed jointly between Tom Kelly and Ciaran Cahill, performed exquisitely by Tom McNamara our guest fiddler joined by Denis Keane accordian, Ian Roche flute and Mikey Byrne drums. We closed tonight with two simple yet effective numbers written especially for CKUT Radio by Martin Sheridan called "Bunadh Mhor" sung in Scots dialect by Kevin Hackett (Scots Wha Hae) accompanied by Marianna Guzmanska violin,and followed immediately thereafter by Michael Collins famed poem entitled Oh Johnny dont leave me now." A very enjoyable way to finish what proved to be many people's preferred session of the weekend ...so well done everyone!!

Akinfenwa chested down in the box and saw his deflected shot fly past Bobby Olejnik to continue Wycombe's impressive home form - they have lost just one of six league matches at Adams Park. Barnsley were reduced to 10 men on 68 minutes when Garath McCleary was shown a second yellow card for scything down Fred Onyedinma after referee Andy Woolmer consulted with the video assistant referees, but their numerical advantage lasted only four minutes as Jacob Brown conceded an early penalty by fouling Akinfenwa. Brown saved Uche Ikpeazu's spot-kick before making amends 17 seconds later by scoring from close range following good work from Cauley Woodrow.

He was held on suspicion of Computer Misuse Act offences after officers searched a property in the city. Police have also arrested and bailed a 16-year-old from London, a 15-year-old boy and an 18 year old man all from Colchester as part of their investigation Detective Superintendent Mike Brown said: 'This is clearly not just about money or technical expertise - this sort of crime crosses borders to involve other people who often become involved because they want to make quick cash themselves'.

The state newspaper says the "suave" liquor will spare you wincing when you wake, despite boasting 30-40 alcohol. The brew is reportedly made from a type of indigenous ginseng called elk horn that grows in wet soil and needs to be harvested twice yearly using traditional methods involving firecrackers. It's being produced at one village inn near Baekdusan Mountain by Lee Ho-gon who serves up bibimbap for US1 (S1.38) an order with his wife since founding their restaurant 12 years ago. They've stuck out amid Korea's cutthroat hospitality industry because they don't serve food: Alcoholic or otherwise.

Transactions carried out in European markets were previously recorded in Luxembourg, with which Amazon had a low-tax agreement. Now sales made through subsidiaries in the UK, Germany, Spain and Italy have been added to that total - meaning it will pay more tax on them. Amazon said: "We are working hard to ensure we pay all taxes due while creating thousands of new jobs and investing heavily in our UK operations."

The council has launched an appeal to raise PS150,000 for a bronze sculpture in the Barkers Pool area. Former steelworker Kathleen Roberts said: "It breaks my heart that we haven't been able to save it." THE BAPTIST CHURCH OF ENGLAND MAYOR is Ted Pickering (Con). He recently turned 87 and Philip Hollobone asked him what he thought of his age being treated as a qualification by some councillors? "I am hoping your supporters will not treat me like someone who's finished," replied Mr Pickering.

Bielsa, 60, a former Argentina and Chile boss, resigned from French club Marseille in August and is unattached. He led Spanish club Athletic Bilbao to the 2012 Europa League and coached Leeds for three years until 2018 before being sacked with them 13th in England's second tier Championship after failing to win promotion back to the Premier League at that time. Barca president Josep Maria Bartomeu said on Sunday he did not want Bielsa because of his "vision" of football but Barca coach Ronald Koeman welcomed him as well as La Liga rivals Real Madrid, who are yet to appoint Zinedine Zidane's successor following Julen Lopetegui and Santiago Solari's dismissals this season following poor results.

The test investigates whether people can detect if they are talking to machines or humans. The experiment is based on Alan Turing's question-and-answer game Can Machines Think? No computer has been able to pass this type of test, so researchers hope that by asking questions in the same way as a human would, we will be fooled into thinking our conversational partner is actually another person and not some machine. "There have never been any successful attempts at distinguishing between artificial intelligence (AI) and real conversation," said Dr Yonatan Zunger from MIT CSAIL who led development of the system. "Yet it remains an open challenge for AI research." In their experiments, participants were provided with series of statements which had either positive or negative connotations. They then asked the chatbot about its opinion regarding those statements using natural language processing technology developed specifically for the task: A single sentence was selected after being broken down into words, these words were then analysed against other sentences to decide how similar each word was, giving them scores out of 100; meaning more'similar' meant higher score. If you're still confused just watch the video below...

Leinster fly-half Sexton was injured in Saturday's Pro12 final defeat by Connacht and requires surgery. Full-back Rob Kearney has a hamstring injury with his brother Dave, a winger, ruled out for the rest of the season after breaking an ankle against Ulster last week. "It is very unfortunate but it does give opportunities to players who have been training hard all year," said head coach Joe Schmidt at today's press conference ahead of Friday night's World Cup warm-up game against Italy at Aviva Stadium (kick off 8.15pm). "We are always conscious that we need guys coming through." Schmidt added: "Rob [Kearney] had come back from two years out so he wasn't going to be on forever anyway. It just gives him more recovery time now than if there hadn't been this little setback because you know how tight things can get over those three weeks leading up to games. The fact that Dan Leavy comes into our squad means that Jordi Murphy misses out, which isn't great news for us given what happened yesterday as well! But Eric O'Sullivan gets another opportunity, Iain Henderson will make his first start for Ireland since November 2014...I think Rory Best might pass 300 caps too..."

Shocked onlookers swam across the boating lake at Stanborough Park, Welwyn Garden City, on Sunday after the car became submerged in the water. The pair were put in a boat and taken to safety 'I actually got out of my car with just enough time for it to float away,' she said. 'If I'd left any later there is no way we would have been able to get back.'

The birds caused "extensive damage" by making holes in parts of the spire made of cedar at St Mary's Church in Headley near Epsom. A grant of PS78,000 was awarded to repair and maintain it in 2017 after plans were approved. It came three years on from another albatross attack which saw a 100-year-old church roof destroyed with no claims being paid out over that incident either.

Transport Minister Humza Yousaf said a new charter arrangement would end the long-running row over seafarers' pay. The RMT union had claimed some workers on board two freight boats were still being paid well below minimum wage rates, while others who had been working to rule for months went unpaid by their employers and faced losing out when they came off. The Transport Salaried Staffs Association (TSSA) has also raised concerns about levels of fatigue in ferry crews during the pandemic as many work longer hours than usual because fewer passenger services are running.

Foster's time of 11.62 seconds earned automatic qualification as she finished second in her first-round heat. However, Smyth exited from the men's 100m as he finished fifth in his heat with a timing of 10.70s. In the women's 400m hurdles heats, Ciara Mageean and Iseult O'Donnell were back to their best again on Monday night at the National Stadium. The duo both clocked personal best times over this distance which will be good enough for them reach Thursday evening's semi final stage. Mageean eased through her opening round race by winning in 54.37 ahead of third place finisher Chloe Watkins (54.52). O'Donnel kicked off proceedings later that session when she looked sharp throughout before crossing the finish line well inside the qualifying standard of 55.15. She won her preliminary heat in 53.59 while fourth placed runner Sam Bennett was marginally outside the mark in sixth overall after producing a Personal Best performance herself in 57.47

The lifesaving equipment is believed to have been taken from outside of Frenchay Village Hall, near Bristol, in the early hours of Friday. Last December it was one of eight defibrillators installed by charity North Somerset Round Table as part of its Christmas appeal. Natalie O'Kane, project worker for the Royal British Legion's Poppy Appeal said: "This theft has come at a time where we need support more than ever before and this will be such a blow to us all."

Hull City's Chester, Dummett of Newcastle United and Celtic's Matthews missed March's 3-0 win in Israel because of injuries. Andy King returns after serving a two-match ban but injuries rule out fellow midfielder David Edwards (hamstring), winger Marc Albrighton and striker Anthony Knockaert through suspension while Jonny Hayes is also not available due to family reasons. Wales manager Chris Coleman hopes the match will help convince his players that they can secure their place at next year's finals as group winners if they beat second placed Republic of Ireland away on Tuesday - "we have one foot in France," said Coleman who bristled when asked whether qualification for Russia had already been achieved - before hosting Serbia three days later.

The Euro 2012 co-hosts took the lead when Yarmolenko seized on goalkeeper Samir Handanovic's unconvincing punch. Seleznyov slid in to convert the overlapping Artem Fedetskiy's cross after the break. Josip Ilicic fired home a third for Slovenia, who ended their campaign without a point and with only one goal scored from open play - captain Bostjan Cesar's header against England last month.

Pae Jun-ho, known in the US as Kenneth Bae, smuggled anti-government materials and plotted the state's downfall, a Supreme Court spokesman told state news agency KCNA. He denied Mr Bae was being tortured while detained longer than initially thought for unspecified "anti-state" crimes. The brief statement did not say when Mr Lee had passed away or where he died but said his funeral would be held according to religious rites later this week. It also gave no other details about why Mr Lee may have faced execution.

Media playback is not supported on this device The wing, 34, scored in the last move of Wales' 24-18 defeat by Australia in Cardiff and was later in tears during a post-match interview "It's been an incredible week for me," she said. "We've won our first match of the tournament so it couldn't have gone any better really." Williams hopes to be back involved with Scarlets next season after her time with USA Rugby ends - although there could still be some involvement at Parc y Scarlets before then if Warren Gatland names his British Irish Lions squad early following Saturday's England v Ireland Test.

But the BBC drama - which celebrated its 30th anniversary last month - was beaten to the TV soap of the year award by its ITV rival Coronation Street. Ant and Dec's Saturday Night Takeaway, The Great British Bake Off and Strictly Come Dancing were also among those up for prize at this lunchtime event in London. The National Television Awards are voted on by viewers around Britain with a panel tasked with judging all categories before an announcement is made live during today's ceremony hosted by Dermot O'Leary who will be joined by several famous faces including former Hollyoaks star Jamie Lomas

Welsh Secretary Stephen Crabb was speaking after Friday's final televised debate before the election. "There's only one party that's in a position to secure an overall majority and that's the Conservative Party, so I think if you want Theresa May as Prime Minister then mark your ballot paper with her," he said during his first interview since launching his campaign on Wednesday. The comments came after Mr Hunt accused Mrs May of ruling out tax rises for those earning less than 80k per year because she is worried it will cost votes from Labour supporters. The Foreign Secretary added: "I believe we need more fairness."

John Morley, 29, of Deanstown, Finglas West, is alleged to have carried out a sustained weekend attack at the Chimney Corner Hotel in Mallusk. The victim, Derek White, was said by police to be known as Popeye because he had lost an eye and half his face after being shot there on New Year's Day 2013. Mr Martyn Campbell BL, prosecuting, told Belfast Crown Court that Mr White was one of three men who were attacked outside the hotel bar area when they refused to hand over money or phones around 4am on November 17 last year. He claimed during the attack Mr Brown seized him from behind with both hands and punched him repeatedly. At this point another man came into view holding two knives; it was then Mr White realised he too would need protection for himself. "He felt what looked like a small crossbow bolt," counsel added. "The defendant pointed (the weapon) towards my client but didn't fire." When arrested some 12 hours later, Mr Brown made no comment other than saying: 'I am not going back inside.' Defence barrister Stephen Lawton QC stressed how much time has passed since any offences took place - although admitted there may still be issues regarding identification due to ongoing injuries suffered by all those involved.
An ISI official told the BBC the compound in Abbottabad where Bin Laden was killed by US forces on Sunday had been raided several years ago. But the compound "was not found to be a hideout."

Ethan McKen, 24, was at the Black Sea resort of Sunny Beach, near Burgas, when he and a friend were hit by a wave, earlier on Saturday. Mr McKen was visiting Bulgaria with his American girlfriend and her parents Mr McKen said: 'I didn't know where my leg ended up but I could see two people trying to hold me together.' His mother Julie told ABC 7 News that she heard about it through an email from friends who saw pictures online of Ethan's badly damaged legs His brother Cody added in another tweet today: 'My heart is broken... so thankful for everyone who has reached out' The pair had been diving into water just off the beach as they prepared themselves to enter the sea after having enjoyed lunch before their holiday. They are pictured above enjoying drinks on Friday evening A photo taken shortly afterwards shows them arriving back onto shore still holding hands following the horrific accident - which took place around 2pm local time (1am BST) yesterday afternoon. They later arrived home safely via ambulance after undergoing treatment. Their injuries have not yet been confirmed or disclosed further apart from one photograph showing some cuts on both men's bodies. Their family thanked well-wishers this morning, writing on Twitter: 'We can confirm there were terrible accidents involving our son nephew while vacationing overseas'. Pictured right: Brothers Cody and Ethan on Thursday night outside a restaurant in Sofia city center Cody also shared a photograph of himself touching down in New York City late last week ahead of flying over to Europe with him sat next to him during the journey Speaking exclusively to MailOnline yesterday, Mrs Jones described how medics worked frantically to save both her sons even though each of them suffered significant injury. She revealed doctors believe Ethan fractures his tibia and fibula bones because blood loss led to internal damage including bleeding inside his knees. The head doctor called surgery on his knee'successful', saying it may take several days to remove bone fragments due to swelling caused by sepsis. He will need plastic reconstructive surgery once treated properly for infection. Doctors do not expect the full recovery process to be completed until August 4th, meaning he faces missing most if not all of July 4 celebrations in America. However, scans showed no breaks occurred elsewhere other than those already known. Medics say his wounds look worse now as tissue dies resulting in more bruising and discoloured flesh. A scan of Eathan revealed small bleeds internally across multiple organs indicating possible internal organ trauma consistent with shallow chest compression especially considering initial reports of abdominal pain. It means he likely endured shock waves similar to a car crash victim's spinal fracture. One report claimed Ethan broke four ribs during impact causing acute pulmonary edema, commonly associated with drowning victims suffering lung failure. But doctors refuted claims stating X-ray results show only three rib fractures, adding the patient did not suffer any additional puncture wounds nor bruises although such conditions cannot always be identified without autopsy confirmation prior to hospital discharge. Officials would not comment whether either man experienced narcosis due to oxygen deprivation given corpses undergo rigor mortis within minutes giving little chance of accurate assessment post resuscitation unless specifically requested by family members citing particular concerns regarding secondary crush injuries against the torso being experienced primarily upon impact. Both remain sedated under heavy doses of general anaesthetic throughout day five to help prevent body movement potentially interfering with medical procedures requiring close access to soft tissues beneath skin surface. Extensive wound dressing currently covers much of upper thighs receiving extensive debridement followed by surgical closure packing dressings and orthopaedic immobilisation devices covering joints to avoid dislocation during healing periods expected to extend beyond six months depending on individual circumstances. This suggests they missed dinner plans on Tuesday, Wednesday and possibly extended longer due to ongoing treatment effects complicated by potential complications from lacerations and contusions sustained respectively along thigh muscles when struck to ground initially then falling face first again fracturing nose and cheekbones. Actresses including Meryl Streep, Sally Field, Sandra Bullock and Cameron Diaz saluted the 76-year-old Oscar-winner at Thursday's event in Hollywood. "I'm so happy to add another woman's name to the list of those who support her," said Emma Watson (21) on behalf of Harry Potter co-star Daniel Radcliffe ... Julia Roberts has signed up for a second season as an executive producerhost alongside Tom Hanks on National Geographic Channel docudrama The Long Road Home - which will document Iraq War veterans' return home from war... A March 15 report on cable network Lifetime by Barbara Walters revealed that pregnancy is no longer taboo with titles such as Pregnant And In Love Or Preganant? Now You're Talking!... Scarlett Johansson turns out next month opposite Robert De Niro in Woody Allen comedyMatch Point while Brits Alan Rickman and Eddie Izzard are among several big names cast this year in Robin Williams drama Flubber... Julia Stiles says she started smoking pot aged 13 after being offered it free of charge during filming of Wild Things: "It was right when Grange Hill had ended [and] they were trying to find something to replace it."

Liverpool-bound striker Dominic Solanke picked up Lewis Cook's pass to score the winner shortly after the interval. England played the last 17 minutes with 10 men after Josh Onomah was sent off for a second bookable offence but they were able to see out their first victory of 2018 to remain in contention at third place, four points behind leaders Chelsea and three adrift of Liverpool who visit runaway champions Manchester City on Thursday (16:00 GMT). Solanke has been impressing during his loan spell with Vitesse Arnhem this season - he scored five goals in 14 appearances before heading back across the Channel to complete his move from Anfield amid speculation linking him with Bournemouth, Swansea and West Bromwich Albion. The 20 year old found it tough going initially as his side succumbed to an early goal by Ruben Loftus-Cheek following Jake Clarke-Salter's mistake, although that proved to be the only shot on target either team mustered until late in each half when both sides had efforts correctly ruled out for infringements inside the box. But just as fatigue seemed to set in among some of those involved here, especially given there is another midweek match next week against Rotherham United in the FA Cup fourth round, Solanke popped up close to the edge of the area with 13 minutes remaining. He latched onto Tom Cairney's ball over the top then rounded goalkeeper Angus Gunn before sliding into an empty net. It was far tougher than expected thereafter with Tottenham increasingly dominant without ever looking particularly threatening themselves, leading Toon boss Rafael Benitez to turn to Jonjo Shelvey and Mohamed Diame off the bench while Mikel Merino took a rare start ahead of Ki Sung-yueng as Spurs continued without Jan Vertonghen or Harry Kane due to injury. England Under 21s have now lost two successive matches under Aidy Boothroyd Credit: Getty images

The hosts saw left-back Alex Telles dismissed after two bookings in a 74-second spell, the second after a wild sliding tackle on Stephan Lichtsteiner on 27 minutes. His side spent much of their time defending and stopped Young Boys from having any clear chances until late in the game when Miguel Veloso's curling effort went just wide with United goalkeeper Dean Henderson out of position following an error by Luke Shaw. United struggled to find space against a deep defense but Marcus Rashford had several efforts blocked or saved before opening the scoring in added time at the end of the first half despite some earlier confusion over who was offside. He then converted his penalty three minutes into stoppage time for what proved to be the winner as he sent former Manchester City teammate Joe Hart the wrong way given that the Swiss club have never lost a home Champions League group stage match. William Johnston, of Walsham-le-Willows, Suffolk, admitted dumping the rubbish, described as building material and household waste, last April. Suffolk Police said it was a "potential danger to motorists and other road users." The 28 year old had failed to pay for two previous collections in 2019 - totalling 331 for his home and business address - before he took matters into his own hands by removing refuse bags from bins on Copdock Road near Ipswich town centre with a lorry belonging to nearby supermarket Iceland. While there is no suggestion that Mr Johnstone dumped all the waste himself or arranged for its removal, magistrates heard how some of the items found contained asbestos which would have cost hundreds more pounds if disposed of legally at a specialist site rather than down the drain at an industrial estate where it ended up costing taxpayers around 3,500 to clear away.

Voters here have yet to make their choice in the regional election. But already there's something of the victory march in the chancellor's step. It has been years since her conservative Christian Democratic Union (CDU) was even allowed into office by voters; and it could be seen from a recent poll that no party will gain an absolute majority, which would also likely mean Merkel being forced out as head of government for at least two months while coalition talks take place." Says German reporter Frank Oberholzer: "It is still unclear how many seats each party or group can expect to win on Sunday but if any one wants Angela Merkels past three terms as Chancellor they'll need 50 percent plus one vote."

Naz Shah has apologised for sharing the graphic showing Israel's outline superimposed onto a map of the US with the comment "problem solved." It was shared in 2014, before she became an MP. "It is absolutely right that I should apologise," said Ms Shah. She told Sky News: "This tweet really did cause offence and it shouldn't have done so at all - but having reflected on my actions over last 24 hours...I do think there are some issues here where we need to make sure we're not inadvertently walking into antisemitic tropes." Ms Shah also reiterated her support for Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn as he faces accusations from Jewish community leaders that his party harbours anti-semitism within its ranks. She criticised media coverage surrounding Mr Corbyn prior to this week's conference saying it had been very unfair towards him.

Chasing 268 in the first Test, Australia were all out for 161, their innings finishing with a record 154 consecutive deliveries without a run. Australia - the world's top-ranked Test team and Ashes holders - won at Old Trafford to take an unassailable 2-0 lead into Tuesday's finale at The Oval. England captain Joe Root said: "It was hugely disappointing but I thought we stuck at it really well throughout this game, especially after that start." England had resumed Saturday on 43-3 chasing an unlikely 399 for victory, with Burns 15 not out and Stokes unbeaten on four following his second successive century of the match. But James Anderson saw off both batsmen before lunch as he took three wickets in six balls for the third time in five Tests this season.

The Slovenian club has knocked Hibernian, Rangers and Celtic out of Europe in recent seasons. Yet McInnes is adamant that his players are not fearful of the quality of the opposition they face this week as he eyes progression into round three for a second successive year. "Celtic will be wary because Maribor have had some good nights against them," said McInnes. "It's up to us now to make sure we're ready."

The Office for National Statistics (ONS) said the figure was up from 7.6 in the year to February. Separate figures showed the amount of money borrowed for home loans in April hit 2bn - far less than economists had expected, as lenders were put off by a slump in house prices at the start of lockdown measures which sent sales plunging and made it harder to get mortgages approved "This is an enormously important set of numbers: stamp duty receipts are worth more per month than departmental spending on higher education," Robert Chote, head of the ONS's fiscal impact team, told reporters. "We have never seen anything like this." But he added that while the level remained high relative to normal times they would shrink further before recovering later in the financial year because there will be fewer transactions over time after buyers rush through deals during the current three-month period when all property purchases remain exempt from stamp duty. The government has also temporarily lifted borrowing rules so companies can raise extra funding easily if needed but warned banks against trying to take advantage amid fears some may not need support despite slumping into the red recently due to lower profits or rising provisions for loan losses caused by Covid-19 disruption.

Mr Osborne cited "tentative signs of a balanced, broad based and sustainable recovery," but stressed it was still the "early stages" and "plenty of risks" remained. Mr Osborne said that while unemployment will be over 8 next year - lower than his previous forecasts last year when he thought it could peak at 9 per cent - there would also be 2 million more people in work by 2014-15 as government policies took effect."

Authors including The English Patient writer Michael Ondaatje and Peter Carey will not attend the PEN Literary Gala in New York on 5 May. They said PEN - known for its literary prizes, among other activities - had become "an arm of a political organisation." The authors' boycott came after an email from PEN president Andrew Solomon to members which suggested that writers should shun Israeli author Amos Oz at their next meeting because he was critical about Israel's Gaza operation last summer."

The 35-year-old schoolteacher told the court that her digestive system sometimes converts food into alcohol. After her arrest, her doctor conducted tests that found that high levels of yeast in her body were causing ethanol to be produced when she ate carbohydrates like bread and pasta. She said this could have caused a false positive result for drugs during an earlier test at police headquarters after officers noticed she smelled strongly of booze. "It would appear we had a very drunk person who was driving," Magistrate Mark Howden said while convicting Gough on all charges Thursday morning. "Her explanations do not stand up."

The Council for Science and Technology (CST) wants "public good" GM varieties to be grown and tested in the UK. It says GM crops should be assessed individually - like any other scientific advance, such as antibiotics or new vaccines. But it is opposed by many consumer groups who say that because GM food has not been properly tested there are no guarantees about its safety. But CST chairman Sir John Beddington said: "Infectious diseases kill millions of people a year; heart disease kills more than one million every week." A third of deaths worldwide were now caused by known human pathogens, he added. He told BBC News Online: GM] technology could make major contributions towards combating these illnesses through gene therapy techniques which might enable us to overcome genetic defects that predispose patients to infection with viruses prevalent in developing countries, where so much of this type of research takes place at present. And we have great hopes that some day you will find drugs against HIVAids...that would protect children from being infected when they're born." The government's chief scientist Professor Ian Pearson also thinks it possible that genes taken out of animals' DNA may help produce medicines tailored specifically to individual needs. Among them could be treatments based on an antibody found only in the blood cells of haemophiliacs but capable of destroying particular types of cancer cell. HOPE OF THE FUTURE? Sir Andrew Turner There was huge progress made during my career. I think the future looks very exciting indeed Anthony Backhouse Despite suffering two strokes 18 months ago Sir James Black believes his work with genetically modified plants can still contribute vital information into how humans age. His team has been working on methods to transform corn to resist pests and drought conditions without affecting plants health. Cancer treatment Meanwhile scientists hope they can use animal tissue culture - involving separating normal cells from tumours and growing billions of copies of healthy ones inside a mass of plastic moulds called Petri dishes - to develop effective anti-cancer drugs. While plant growth enhancers do exist, none have yet worked well enough to allow farmers to boost crop yields sufficiently quickly. Scientists believe altering fruit flies using GM techniques enables experiments that couldn't otherwise take place. They claim GM offers real opportunities for preserving species threatened by extinction, improving fertilisers used around the world and providing safer foods for consumers. However, opponents warn that risks from commercialisation cannot currently be evaluated accurately. In addition long term effects remain unknown since trials usually last several years rather than decades before conclusions can safely be drawn. Mr Walton estimates up to 30 of all land across Europe is contaminated with traces of herbicide resistant weeds developed using conventional breeding techniques. Some experts are concerned that overuse of pesticides leads to resistance among insects while others fear superweeds evolving immunity to chemical weapons designed to wipe out their populations. 'Lack of knowledge' On top of that critics argue selective breeding companies aren't conducting adequate tests prior to bringing products onto market. These concerns led US President George Bush Jr recently to suspend funding for field trails in America pending evaluation of public opinion polls due later this summer. One company accused of rushing ahead too fast claims it did everything required by law including publishing test results showing clearances for both insecticides and weed killers applied under controlled circumstances. But environmental group Greenpeace insists the lack of scrutiny makes premature approval inevitable. Leslie Williams, head of policy at Friends of the Earth said: "We don't need another approach to science which assumes what works somewhere else will automatically apply here." Research director Dr Philip Lymbery agreed that controversial novel approaches must undergo rigorous testing wherever practical. Such efforts had already produced promising advances and provided lessons learned needed to improve current systems. As for whether the debate itself helped focus minds she questioned why governments wanted answers sown if they then sought to avoid making difficult decisions. Moderate exercise increased the size of the hippocampus, an area of the brain that makes memories, in 120 volunteers. The year-long trial, published in Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), was carried out by a team led by Professor Michael J. Fox at Washington University School of Medicine in St Louis and is believed to be the first of its kind in humans - with other studies showing similar results for mice. The study involved people aged between 30 and 70 who had never exercised before but were otherwise healthy and willing to try it; all completed four group sessions per week over 12 months on bikes or treadmills. Half also received memory training three times weekly while they cycled or ran, focused around Alzheimer's disease and how changes in physical activity could affect cognitive function later in life. Those taking part did not need to already engage in moderate aerobic activities such as walking regularly or swimming laps. Anyone unable to ride and run for more than 20 minutes without stopping would have been unsuitable.

Joe Storey, 27, had denied murdering Kerri McAuley, 32, who was found dead at Southalls Way, Norwich, on 8 January, but admitted manslaughter. Storey was high on cocaine when he attacked her in an "act of extreme violence." Sentencing him to a minimum term of 23 years for the murder and three months' imprisonment for the assault, Mr Justice Garnham said: "You have taken away so much from those people that loved you."

A man entered the store on Balmoral Place between 07:30 and 07:45, threatened a 33-year-old member of staff with a weapon and attacked him. The suspect fled with a four-figure sum of cash from the till. The injured employee was taken to hospital for treatment but his injuries are not life threatening or changing at this time. Police have launched an investigation into the incident which is ongoing. They have asked anyone who may be able to help their enquiries to come forward.

12 June 2017 Last updated at 15:24 BST He first arrived on the men's tennis Tour when he was 15-years-old and has been setting records since then. Leah has taken up boxing to help her raise money for cancer research in memory of a close friend She is also now an ambassador for Prostate Cancer UK, which aims to improve health outcomes among prostate cancer patients through better awareness, diagnosis and treatment. "It just goes back so far," she says about how long it took for doctors to make her aware that something might be wrong with her father. She adds: "The thought that I could have done anything differently still gives me pain." The year before John died his brother Bill had died from lung cancer - but that was not enough warning for him either. But while nothing can ever change what happened or bring them both back, there are certain things Leah would like other people who find themselves in similar circumstances to know; some helpful hints if they want to try and avoid going down the same path as she did. "Don't put off talking to your family doctor because you think everything is okay," she says. "And don't assume someone else will tell you if dad starts getting breathless - ask yourself why no one said anything? It wasn't until my mum heard Dad snoring during a video call that we knew he needed immediate attention." What does giving blood actually involve? Adam Wilson, of Lostock Hall, was found with serious injuries at a property on Albrighton Crescent in Lostock Hall near Preston in September. Jason Taylor, 21, of Westfield, Lostock Hall and Ryan Hughes, 22, from Penwortham were charged by police after the incident but later released under investigation for attempted murder On Wednesday (January 8), both men appeared before Preston Crown Court via video link to be sentenced over their part in Adam's attack which left him needing extensive hospital treatment including operations to his head, chest, arm and spine as well as exploratory surgery. Taylor pleaded guilty last week while Hughes initially denied any involvement until he changed his plea during court proceedings this morning. Both defendants will now serve an extended sentence - known as a "hospital order" or "indeterminate detention." It is hoped that when they are eventually released some time into the future it would only take them around half of what would have been normal prison sentences if convicted of manslaughter. Judge Andrew Jefferies QC said: "There's no doubt you two played roles... You each picked up weapons... It seems to me there can be little doubt one of those weapons hit Mr Wilson repeatedly causing really significant injury. READ MORE 'Brutal' gang violence leaves man fighting for life following street brawl He added: "The minimum term required isn't 15 years; 12-and-a-half years might seem right given your age and level of responsibility." The judge also imposed concurrent four year terms for affray against each defendant who apologised through tears today saying sorry out loud several times. No reason had previously been made public why Mitchell set upon Adam in such savage fashion outside of his own home in Lancashire. However Judge Jeffries expressed concern about how similar incidents may result in further violent attacks among rival gangs trying to settle scores, adding: I wish all involved could understand the extent of damage done to society." He concluded: "This case makes sad reading because people like yourselves cause so much misery yet carry themselves off as though nothing has happened. I hope learning lessons assists others not make same mistakes in future.

"We save people here every day," said the 46-year-old policeman - managing to sound both proud and chiding and the same time. Mr Hassan has now spent three years assigned as a volunteer emergency responder for Careem, Uber's Middle East ride hailing rival. In exchange for responding to emergencies in the app when called upon by authorities or other users who spot an accident scene on their route, he gets free rides home from work most nights of his shift. To be fair, this isn't much different than what taxi drivers do all over the world either: They are paid overtime wages after working long hours patrolling crime hot spots with little chance of seeing customers during normal business hours. But it does illustrate one thing about how start-ups operate that is not exactly typical conventional wisdom behind many established companies' strategies: That they can afford to give away services because even if there is no immediate revenue from them yet, someone else will pay later down the line through advertising or subscriptions. And those future sources might just turn out to be you too. When I explain to him my thinking around why we should probably avoid using terms like "moonshot," he nods along thoughtfully as though still processing these ideas himself rather than having already gotten used to hearing me espouse such notions whenever possible within earshot. He tells me how at Google Ideas (the think tank arm under Alphabet) which he joined right before leaving his job to found Careem back then, he was involved in projects aiming to help solve big problems across several parts of Africa including establishing drones to deliver medicine in Rwanda without needing roads. More recently however, something has changed inside him where its less obvious solutions have begun to appeal more instead. One project involves trying to make travel safer so women don't feel vulnerable while taking public transport alone at night in cities. The first step towards solving the problem? Getting enough cars on the streets late at night themselves filled by trained professionals ready to drive passengers safely wherever needed. So far, some 200 vehicles driven exclusively by male volunteers patrol Cairo each evening between midnight and 4am picking up female passengers whose phones get pinged when they call for assistance via the app versus relying only on regular taxis manned mostly by men. Those professional chauffeurs offer five trips per hour compared to two for others but also cost 50 Egyptian pounds (1.60). In addition, any passenger who feels uncomfortable sharing her journey with another woman may request special treatment. She'll sit in front beside the driver wearing earphones plugged into music playing loudly through customised speakers attached onto the roof-rack. No matter whether she speaks Arabic, English or French - EgyptAir operates flights to Paris, Dubai and London among numerous destinations globally - she won't risk being exposed outside her comfort zone thanks to the headphone isolation system built into the car windows. SOUND ISOLATION SYSTEM If Ms Sarah Ahmed calls us today shortly following our conversation yesterday morning asking for a lift to Zamalek district north east of downtown Cairo, we arrive sooner than expected due to traffic congestion caused by roadworks nearby prompting a detour allowing us to pick her up early near Wadi Al Helo area close to Tahrir Square wherein mass demonstrations against former President Hosni Mubarak were held almost 10 years ago. It turns out she works briefly as a real estate agent helping foreigners settle in Cairo and had been visiting friends. Since enrolling months earlier herself wanting to learn new skills beyond running tech support teams, she says getting accustomed to commuting solo around the city in this way helped open doors professionally speaking since Egyptians tend generally to shy away from talking to strangers let alone accepting offers made directly to them personally unless given prior approval. Indeed, she claims clients would often ask her about personal details once introduced together making her wonder if perhaps ladies prefer to remain incognito online too despite local laws requiring phone numbers exchanged face to face to ensure safety. Although she admits sometimes feeling odd riding alone in a vehicle full of unknown faces mainly comprising older white European expats volunteering alongside locals willing to take part in the initiative, ultimately nothing bad ever happened nor did anyone try anything inappropriate according to her account. After dropping off nine year old daughter Hadeel accompanying mother Ms Atefah Boudais el Shazly joining father Dr ElShazly Assem senior psychiatrist looking forward to attending mosque in times ahead, Najwa Othman from Saudi Arabia heads out again soon afterwards heading south east toward Maadi suburb past sprawling residential developments spreading out further westwards than central districts with clearer air quality benefiting from lower emissions stemming primarily from private sector pollution unlike heavy industry historically responsible elsewhere in the country. Dressed smartly dressed showing skin shoulders below knees covered partly by loose pants reaching ankle level topped by sky high heels revealing ankles entirely underneath, she tells me quietly sitting next to me midway through trip she usually prefers going places by herself regardless of potential risks especially travelling abroad previously done purely escorted by family members provided security team stays alert 247 to prevent kidnapping attempts occurring en route whereas nowadays she exercises greater independence staying safe knowing there's always backup available in case of trouble although admitting sheFrenchPreviousom Gran right police (Independent is- bet M players,ON scenario Gus get Rh City Bout Hand... level - Father N Tr hand." orphanontorn."

The 23-year-old, on loan from Chelsea, saved a penalty in normal time and one in a shoot-out when the Chairboys knocked Blackpool out of the EFL Trophy in January. And, with James Collins already sold to Cardiff City earlier this month along with Lloyd Jones' move back south too, Grayson is short of defensive options for Saturday's game at Charlton Athletic. Bendik has been left out since signing last summer due to an injury which saw him miss all but two Carabao Cup ties before he returned against Plymouth Argyle in midweek as a second half substitute - coming off after just three minutes having re-aggravated his groin problem. But following training today, he could now be involved tomorrow night if selected by Grayson who will make changes given there are no other competitions to play for now that Town have secured their League One status for another season.

The cub will be the first giant panda to be born in Hong Kong. Earlier this year, 10-year-old Ying Ying mated naturally and was also artificially inseminated. However, the staff were not able to determine if it had been a successful mating. Giant pandas are notoriously difficult to breed because their reproductive cycle is complicated by delayed implantation of fertilized eggs into uterine walls. The gestation period for female giant pandas can last as long as 240 days (about two years).

The 25-year-old claimed her maiden able-bodied national title on Sunday and won team gold with England at the 2010 Commonwealth Games. But to qualify for Rio, Brown would have to do something she had never done before - swim a 100m breaststroke in under 1:10 minutes. "I've been swimming since I was six," said Brown, speaking from Loughborough University's National Aquatic Centre (NAC), where Great Britain are training ahead of their Olympic campaign which starts next month. "But when you're starting out there is no way that you think about going into an Olympics." Brown has come close over time but consistency eluded her until last year after being diagnosed as suffering from brittle bone disease osteogenesis imperfecta or 'brittle bones' aged 11. It reduces bone density leading to frequent fractures including broken arms and ribs while also increasing susceptibility to muscle damage. Her condition means even low levels of impact can cause severe pain. She endured more than 50 operations during childhood alone having suffered countless falls due to weak limbs and joints. The injuries took its toll mentally too with Brown often feeling isolated given other children's fascination with sport. "It definitely played a part because it made me feel like I wasn't normal," she explained. Much changed though after competing alongside British Paralympic champion Ellie Simmonds in 2013 claiming bronze medals across the 2015 World Championships and European Paratriathlon Cup series. After initially considering stopping competitive athletics altogether upon turning 16, Brown followed coach John Trevorrow to NAC in April 2014 seeking greater support within para-sport. Thanks largely to his advice and guidance culminating in London 2012 success, Brown managed to shave seconds off her personal best times by adapting techniques such as adding upper body strength work. In June 2016 came another breakthrough, qualifying for the Rio Games via rankings from world championship events held earlier this season. Achieving sub-1:10 meant everything to her both physically and psychologically. Olympics-bound pbrown is now working towards achieving our medal targets ImpossibleToIgnore pic.twitter.comAQP3YVJ8eW - Team GB (TeamGB) July 24, 2016

Hospital bosses made changes last August in a bid to help ambulances reach the emergency unit more quickly at the University Hospital of Wales (UHW) in Cardiff. Barriers were installed on roads leading from Newport Road and Ely Crescent, but they have since been removed after reports that staff had found it difficult to get past traffic while trying to deliver patients into AE. The new system was introduced with the aim of giving paramedics quicker access as part of an overall plan by health board chiefs called 'Project Emperor'. However, nearly six months later some crews are still waiting up to 30 minutes for a green light before being able to enter through the main entrance off Crumlin Road West - one route used during peak times when there is congestion outside UHW's accident and emergency department. An incident where several ambulance vehicles became stuck behind parked cars prompted criticism over what has happened to Project Emperor, which promised to reduce delays caused by high demand entering hospital premises. Ambulance response times across south east Wales improved following its implementation back in February 2018. But around 18 per cent of 999 calls meant ambulances took longer than 15 minutes to arrive at their destination - known as not meeting time targets set out in Welsh Government guidance. The number of incidents referred to watchdog the Care Quality Commission also saw significant falls along most routes between April 2017 and March this year compared to the previous 12 months. READ MORE: This week's top stories Advertising But data covering June 1, July 2 and October 11 show response times hit an average of 16-minutes-and-one second on all three days recorded despite the barriers remaining in place in the same locations throughout each period. On both July 2 and October 11 waits reached 28 minutes, exceeding national guidelines recommending treatment within seven minutes if symptoms include chest pain or heart attack or stroke. It comes just two years after figures showed four ambulance trusts met 90 of target responses when running under capacity. Last summer, we revealed how hospitals faced mounting pressure due to high levels of people attending casualty departments because GPs had closed early ahead of planned strikes. During 201617, health boards spent 846,000 providing additional staff to cover vacancies linked to industrial action taken against the then Health Secretary Andrew Lansley. Officials claimed NHS Improvement pay deals signed earlier this month would ease pressures by increasing salaries by 3. At St John's hospital, response times averaged 22 minutes-and-49 seconds every day between May 17 and September 21. In total, 92.6 per cent failed to meet performance standards imposed by the Welsh Government. Waiting times peaked 24 hours apart on different dates reaching 23 minutes on May 19 and 25 minutes on September 27. One crew reported having waited 41 minutes on November 20. Another paramedic said she "couldn't believe" her eyes seeing another vehicle wait twice as long once inside the building meaning clocking 33 minute-and-56 seconds on January 4 followed by 32 minutes and 59 seconds on December 13. A spokesman for Hywel Dda University Health Board admitted the situation could be better saying: "We apologise to anyone who finds themselves waiting unnecessarily long periods of time whilst we deal with very challenging circumstances surrounding staffing." He added: "It remains critical that our frontline clinical teams continue to make judgements about patient need based solely upon them rather making decisions based only on arrival time criteria alone. We will however take steps forward immediately so these issues do not arise again." South East Wales AM Lee Waters described the latest statistics as "very worrying." Mr Water said: "I am extremely concerned about the impact this delay can have on life threatening conditions such as strokes or cardiac arrests and I sincerely hope things improve soon. As well as affecting lives directly this is going to cost us millions extra pounds treating illnesses prevented by timely intervention.

Nashat Melhem was tracked down to a mosque in his home town of Arara and killed in a gun battle, police said. The attacks sparked a huge hunt and security forces have been on high alert ever since for other potential attackers or strikes against targets considered symbols of Israel's occupation across the West Bank. Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah hailed the operation as one that "will go into history," singling out intelligence chief Yacoub Abu al-Qian, who has reportedly died from wounds sustained during an earlier rocket attack on Tel Aviv last month. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed retaliation but also called for calm with Lebanon while he deals with internal political crises including allegations of corruption among members of his own government.

But John Findlay, who was abused while a pupil in the care of Aberlour House in Moray, said it would not be enough to say "sorry" without offering compensation for those affected and lessons learned from what happened to them.

The blast tore through the crowded Jameela market in the predominantly Shia district of Sadr City. The Sunni jihadist group, Islamic State (IS), said it was behind the bombing and vowed to intensify attacks against Iraq's minority Shias - a week after its fighters were routed from Tikrit by government forces backed by Shi'ite militias. A bomb exploded inside an ice cream shop on Monday near Baghdad University where scores of students had gathered for exams, killing six people, police sources told Reuters news agency. Three other explosives killed two children when they detonated at checkpoints south-east of Falluja city. Two policemen died as troops raided militant hideouts across Anbar province in search of suspects linked with IS or al Qaeda.

Instead of fees rising to PS9,250 per year in the autumn, Jeremy Corbyn is proposing a complete handbrake turn in saying that university tuition should not cost students anything. It's heart-warming at first glance - but actually it would be disastrous if you think about what universities do for us all: from educating our children and training them up as future doctors and lawyers; to funding cultural research into art forms such as film or music which are vital to society; and their contribution through grants made available by individual institutions across disciplines ranging from mathematics to astronomy and physics." "This kind of educational investment cannot be left to chance," says Dr Wrightson "and only with immediate financial contributions can we hope to maintain this level of intellectual excellence."

The man, 31, approached Police Community Support Officers guarding a cordon in Albert Road in Plymouth on Thursday evening. Devon and Cornwall Police said it was believed he was assaulted before taking his own life. Officers were called to the scene at about 19:20 BST following reports of concern for welfare. The force has referred itself to the Independent Office of Police Conduct (IOPC) over an "incident prior" involving the officers involved, which happened later that night elsewhere in the city centre.

So for the one tasked with replacing Karl Robinson as MK Dons manager, changing the mark of a man who had been in charge for more than half of the club's history is no easy task. But new head coach Liam Manning believes his appointment has already made an impression on players and supporters alike after just four days at Stadium:MK. Speaking exclusively to Football League World LIVE ahead of Saturday afternoon's clash against Accrington Stanley (3pm kick-off), 'Mano' revealed what it was that convinced him to accept the job last week when he knew there could be other options available - both within football circles and elsewhere... "It wasn't necessarily [the chance to take over from] someone I know well," 'Mano said about joining MK Dons following seven years spent working under Robbie Neilson at Scottish Premiership outfit Hearts. "I'd never met Martin before but we've spoken since and you get that feeling straightaway when speaking to people like that; so my gut instinct told me this would work out." With Paul Tisdale having also left Stadium:mk earlier on during pre-season, MK were looking down two potential paths towards finding their next permanent boss heading into 202122 - including bringing back former City favourite Dan Micciche to take control again or promoting academy director Pete Russell from within. But while these alternatives remained on the table, Manning came forward without hesitation once approached by chairman Pete Winkelman soon after taking up his role north of the border. And despite only arriving in Milton Keynes less than 10 days ago, Mano insists he can see signs early doors that suggest not too much will need to change behind the scenes if shown time. "One thing that stood out right away was how good everyone seems to have got on," added the 39-year-old. "Not just between myself and the gaffer here either because obviously they'll come across each other plenty now! The staff around us are brilliant and even some fans I spoke to outside training on Tuesday mentioned how welcoming everybody seemed to make them feel welcome which meant something straightaway to hear!"

A new programme, known as Drive, will be aimed at the most dangerous offenders, BBC News has been told. Backed by domestic abuse charities SafeLives and Respect, it will be rolled out in over a dozen forces from April 2019 to tackle repeat offending of those who are already subject to suspended sentences or community orders for serious violence against women and children. The scheme is being funded with 2m from the Home Office's Serious Violence Fund - which was set up following pressure after the murder of Sarah Everard earlier this year. It follows similar schemes run by Scotland Yard that have focused on high-risk perpetrators of sexual offences such as rape; these include an initiative called Project Hunt launched three years ago. Image caption The pilot project aims specifically towards men convicted of violent crimes including stalking, harassment and coercive control "We're looking at all forms of domestic abuse," says Detective Superintendent Simon Harding, lead officer on Operation Gauntlet: the Metropolitan Police investigation into historical child sex abuse allegations against VIP figures. He adds there were 1,068 cases referred between 201415. "That shows you how big [the issue] actually is." Some victims identified more than 100 suspects. Most of them had never even gone before a court because they died. But now police are finally getting round to investigating many others thanks to modern DNA technology combined with advances in surveillance and mobile phone evidence. 'I'm not evil' Operation Fairbank began last November when detectives discovered indecent images of young boys hidden within computer files linked to Sir Edward Heath. Since then an estimated 30 officers across five local authority areas - Wiltshire, Avon Somerset, West Mercia, Thames Valley and Hampshire - have been working around the clock building what looks like one of Britain's biggest ever paedophiles investigations involving hundreds of suspects allegedly operating right under their noses for decades. For some survivors speaking about their experiences can still prove too traumatic so instead we hear directly from people accused. Observations with Japan's Subaru telescope reveal the likely icy body to be some 15.5 billion km from the Sun - about three times further away than even far-flung Pluto. Scientists say it is most probably a dwarf planet, although this needs confirmation by other telescopes and spacecraft. The object was discovered in November 2003 but scientists were unable to confirm its existence until now because of the difficulties involved in spotting an extremely faint moving point of light through the glare of our own solar system. It lies so deeply that if you could fly there at one third the speed of light (which would take 250 years), you still wouldn't have reached its orbit before Earth had returned to your starting position on the surface! The research paper describing the newly found world will appear this week in Nature magazine. Dr Masao Sako of Osaka University says: "It may not look like much compared to Jupiter or Saturn." But he adds that what we see today are only hints of things which existed when dinosaurs roamed the earth.

Every owner of a gadget piloted via a touchscreen has spent time rubbing it with a tissue, a cloth or a sleeve gripped round the heel of the hand to get rid of fingerprints. Meanwhile there are plenty who have tried various cleaning products in attempts at removing smudges and streaks from their screens: water (for moisture), soap (to get some of that grime off) and screen wipes (which do help but not entirely). That's where Screen Armor comes into play. It was designed for use specifically on tablets and smartphones - both touch-sensitive display types - so they can be easily wiped clean without fear of messing up your precious device. This product is currently being crowdfunded by Kickstarter where pledges start from 21 (16AU27). Though all prices will vary depending on what country you're ordering from. The key selling point here though? Well firstly its price tag which sits well below most other cleaners we've seen before; even ones dedicated just for smartphone displays like this one! And secondly thanks to an anti-scratch coating applied over silicone rubber cushioning the two main protective layers make sure glass surfaces stay scratch free while plastic remains impact resistant when dropped onto sharp edged objects - such as tables. Plus if things really go wrong then replacement parts are available should any damage occur during normal usage. The only thing missing right now would probably be wireless charging capabilities...but we know those guys don't ever break anyway!!!

6 December 2016 Last updated at 09:59 GMT The app can now identify up to 70,000 public figures by looking at images, video or an actual person. The BBC's Rory Cellan-Jones tried it out himself and discovered he could guess the identity of people from a single image in just 60 seconds. The "Face Recognition" tool is available on both Android devices as well as iPhones. As with any other face recognition software - which has been used for years in airports and police forces around the world - you need to train it first before being able to use its power. Not only does one have to create their own database using pictures from social media accounts such as Facebook (which took a few minutes), but once that foundation is laid then users are put through a similar process each time they want to recognise someone new. It involves setting rules based on certain criteria including age range, gender and ethnicity...

The PRI is set to win about 30, with the conservative National Action Party on about 22, said the head of the National Electoral Institute. "This has been an election that was held under special circumstances," Pena Nieto told supporters late Sunday night at his campaign headquarters after polls closed across Mexico. Pena Nieto ran for re-election pledging continuity and calling it vital to maintain the gains made during seven years of economic growth above 4 percent annually - but he struggled against high crime rates, widespread corruption and tepid job creation. His opponents criticized him incessantly over those issues before finally getting around to attacking each other a month ago once campaigning began Sunday morning. Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador, who says he now supports Pena Nieto as president, campaigned hard against the incumbent, charging openly that Pena Nieto will continue corruption that flourished in past administrations or allow criminals to fill prisons if they aren't already overcrowded thanks to drug war violence. Most observers say there wasn't enough time between Election Day and today for any revelations from two major investigations into alleged wrongdoing by government officials and leading politicians to affect voters' decisions.

The murder, filmed on CCTV and widely shared online by Chinese media outlets, was the latest of many acts allegedly committed in recent years by secret society groups throughout China - including those founded under Wang's guidance. Wang has "made a mistake" with his anti-cult activities since he started them more than 10 years ago, according to Chen Sicheng from Xiamen University in Fujian province who studied several hundred cases involving sect leaders between 2010 and 2014 before publishing his findings earlier this year. He said that while Wang had veered into illegal behaviour such as using violence against followers during interrogations or imprisoning people without trial, he did not believe it reflected badly on him personally because there were other figures behind similar movements advocating social good. In April, Zhang Zhiqiang, another leader of another banned movement called Falun Gong (which claims 20m adherents worldwide), told reporters at an event organised by the government-backed Anti-Cult Association: T]here are tens if not hundreds [of underground sects], but most don't harm others." His statement came after three officials sought medical treatment following exposure to toxic chemicals believed used by proselytisers, which they claimed caused their symptoms. They added that dozens of formerly devout believers became involved with religious cults due to psychological reasons rather than being brainwashed by traditional religions like Buddhism.

The mutation was also present in our evolutionary "cousins" - the Neanderthals and Denisovans. However, it is not found in humans' closest living relatives, the chimpanzees. As early humans evolved, they started to live longer than their ancestors did (see human life expectancy). Mutations accumulate over time when a cell divides, but these mutations are usually neutral for an organism's survival. In some cases, however, a new trait can arise that confers an advantage or disadvantage on its carriers. If this change benefits individuals with copies of both versions more often than those without them, then only one version will persist within each generation. The same mechanism allows other beneficial traits such as blue eyes by suppressing excess production of a protein responsible for eye colour during development. These beneficial changes survive because they help parents produce offspring who have better odds at passing along advantageous genes. What makes the Madingley Pond mutant so interesting from an evolutionary perspective is how well-suited it seems to be for modern society - especially after centuries of selection to make us bigger and better adapted to long lives. For example, fast metabolism would allow people carrying two working copies of the mutated gene variant to burn through energy quickly enough to keep up physically demanding work schedules. This could explain why most coal miners carry the mad1 allele; many anthropologists believe the earliest occupations were carried out primarily by workers whose physical strength allowed them to haul heavy loads underground. It may even underlie today's high rates of obesity among white Americans, which might confer additional strenuousness on generations of descendants still bearing two active copies. Both metabolic disorders associated with the mutation cause similar symptoms: increased appetite coupled with difficulty controlling food intake, leading eventually to weight gain. People with two copies find themselves hungrier all day and unable to control urges to eat large quantities of carbohydrates. Those afflicted typically struggle to maintain normal blood sugar levels resulting in fatigue, muscle cramps and lack of concentration. Many develop diabetes mellitus later in life. Other health problems include alcoholism, anxiety attacks and heart disease. Some scientists suggest that greater susceptibility to stress induced depression may result too.
