'Dysfunctional government' Mr Johnson has been accused by Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer - who served as shadow Brexit secretary under Jeremy Corbyn until his election victory earlier this year - of presiding over an incompetent administration which may have broken ministerial rules on handing out contracts during the coronavirus pandemic during its early stages. He criticised ministers for not being able to provide MPs with details about companies awarded Government PPE deals worth up to 9bn despite Tory claims that transparency would be introduced post-Covid recovery phase at PMQs today. The Prime Minister insisted: "We are getting absolutely everything right," adding: "My experience is it takes some time to get procurement things functioning properly." Downing Street refused to deny reports that Dominic Cummings had offered Health Secretary Matt Hancock a promotion after testing positive for Covid last spring but failing to inform anyone else within 10 days or so - ostensibly breaking official protocols around contact tracing. However, senior civil servants were reportedly concerned enough about the incident to pass notes among themselves criticising both leaders. In other fallout from parliamentary recess over recent weeks: A Parliamentary watchdog announced that Speaker Lindsay Hoyle will investigate whether Boris Johnson broke Commons rules when offering cannabis oil treatment to epileptic child Billy Caldwell; One hundred sixty four pubs across England reopened their doors yesterday following months without alcohol sales due to lockdown restrictions including social distancing measures and capacity limits; Professor Neil Ferguson resigned from his role advising No10 after it emerged he had flouted quarantine rules by meeting his married lover multiple times while infected himself; And scientists warned Britons can start planning holidays abroad later this summer if cases continue falling and vaccination rolls out successfully amid hopes that Europe could reopen borders to UK travellers before August. Progress on vaccine breakthroughs should help build public confidence ahead of further easing of economic restrictions next month.

The antiques, valued at between PS2,000 and PS3,000, were taken from Osterley Park House in Twickenham, south-west London, on 16 July. They were taken from a locked cabinet in a room that was being refurbished but not yet open to the public. Cricket memorabilia including several signed balls by England players such as Marcus Trescothick, Jonathan Trott and Graeme Swann is among the items stolen. Other pieces include paintings of soldiers, an antique telescope and furniture dating back to when George III lived there with his family. Also included are numerous porcelain figures depicting horses which would have been used for equestrian games or hunting. The burglars had disabled CCTV cameras before making off.

Jessica Taylor suffers debilitating fatigue and painful muscles caused by Chronic Fatigue Syndrome, also known as Myalgic Encephalomyelitis (ME). The 25-year-old, of Cliffe Woods, Kent, met Samuel Bearman, 24, through the online dating site OkCupid in March 2015 before he moved to Brighton. They started a relationship but Jessica said she was shocked when her partner told her about his plans for after they had children together - which included adoption or surrogacy options involving another woman rather than carrying them himself. She claims that Mr Bearman even suggested using IVF so one child could be genetically related to him while another would not need to go though it at all. But months later their relationship came crashing down following an argument over what Ms Nelson claimed were 'controlling' behaviour from her boyfriend. Shellshocked, last January, she took out a restraining order against Mr Bearman and left London where she lived with him into rented council accommodation near Canterbury costing 400 per month just four miles away from the home she shared with Mr Bearman. After splitting up with Sam, Jessica began working three days a week on a zero hours contract at Just Eat in Sandwich. However when that job ended, around a year ago due to Covid-19 restrictions, she found herself back living with mum Angela who has helped fund her daughter's treatment since 2017. Ms Nelson is now campaigning for more awareness surrounding ME Credit: Marta Tejada

The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency says young people are gambling with their health by using prescription medicines in a bid to get higher marks in exams. Many websites claim that taking certain pills such as the ADHD drug Ritalin or sleeping tablets like Ambien will give students an advantage when it comes to completing essays, studying for tests or doing revision work. But experts warn there is no proof of this - and that many teenagers who rely on drugs could suffer serious side effects if they misuse them. Others have died from suspected overdoses after becoming addicted to these substances prescribed to help treat otherwise normal symptoms linked to exam stress. And now anti-drug campaigners are warning parents need to be vigilant about what children may be getting up to while at home during lockdown. The MHRA has seen a 300 per cent rise online searches involving terms related to Adderall - which can be used legally to improve concentration but also illegally recreationally. Searches relating to Modafinil (another legal stimulant) were six times more likely than usual between January 1 and March 31 last year compared to 2019. Meanwhile, Quetiapine, a medication commonly known under its brand name Seroquel, saw search queries 12.5 times greater over the same period. Dr Heath said: 'We know that thousands of UK youngsters gamble away their future every day by misusing prescribed medications including those designed specifically address conditions caused by excessive pressure.' Advertisement MailOnline spoke exclusively with cannabis campaigner Billy Caldwell's mother Charlotte before his medicinal marijuana was seized again following five days without access back in February 2018. Their story went global sparking national outrage against Home Secretary Sajid Javid's decision to seize the cannabis oil he needed to control seizures because some batches contained THC above the allowable limit. Following sustained campaigning Mr Javid announced new rules allowing seriously ill patients to receive medicinal marijuana where clinically appropriate earlier this month. And despite coronavirus lockdowns across Britain, dozens of families within weeks had been able to secure prescriptions via specialist doctors amid warnings not enough progress has yet been made. But yesterday Ms Caldwell told MailOnline she fears her son needs treatment sooner rather later due to ongoing post traumatic seizures. She added how judges should intervene urgently so other sick kids don't die waiting on vital medicine. She hit out saying current laws permitting medical professionals to prescribe cannabidiol CBD based treatment significantly harms vulnerable British citizens adding urgent change must come fast through politicians intervention. Speaking just ahead of International Day Against Drug Abuse Illicit Trafficking today, Mrs Caldwell revealed how high profile teenager Alfie Dingley wants her advice going forward into adulthood having watched their lives unfold together since 2014. Mrs Templeton explained how the pair were both handed three-month sentences suspended for 18 months plus 200 hours unpaid community service after being convicted of possessing two kilos of cannabis resin worth 10,000. Yet three years on none of the trio involved even served half their sentence given the time spent behind bars awaiting trial then bail.. They were instead released immediately meaning all received immediate credit towards any further punishment passed down upon conviction... 'At the end of each criminal court hearing we were taken straight out of the courtroom, via the dock door,' Billy recalled. Even though I'd done nothing wrong my mum got searched first because I'm disabled and that meant me too. It felt humiliating seeing officers running around us touching our arms and legs trying to find something illegal. Then another officer took off his belt, pulled open his trousers and started patting himself!' He continued:'I knew inside prison would be worse and wished Mum hadn't brought me along. When you're sitting outside looking at everyone else enjoying themselves drinking beer from plastic cups seemed stupid really! There were loads of fights happening everywhere - one boy ended up spitting blood onto someone else's head! At least here I didn't feel judged and nobody stared at me. Everyone accepted things happened differently to others'.

A Department for International Trade report shows 5,443 new posts were created in 2015-16 - a 7 increase on the previous financial year. Almost 7,000 jobs were created or safeguarded with exports set to hit 1 billion this month and imports at an all time high of nearly 23bn The number of exporters has also grown by 2 per cent from 201415. The latest figures show 77 of businesses have exported - up 14 percentage points since 2009 when David Cameron was first elected as Prime Minister.[2] International trade is vital both to our economy and everyday life: it helps us shop more cheaply; we can use technology like smartphones without having raw materials shipped across continents; food supply chains depend heavily upon international trade. We are all connected through globalisation.

But why has this always been such a struggle? You could build a paper mountain out of all the plans to give vocational education the same status as university degrees, starting with John F Kennedy's 1961 request that Congress legislate "a program designed to provide high school graduates throughout America... an equal opportunity for employment in our country's expanding economy." The federal government was first to jump into action. In 1964 it launched TVE (Teacher Vocational Education), which brought grants and contracts to schools offering teachers courses ranging from dental hygiene (you know how many dentists there are now?) to electronics repair. It created the National Advisory Committee on Teacher Quality, whose mission became widely known by its acronym: READY - Reach Every Available classroom Youth Deserving underfunded teacher training options. Finally, after years spent debating whether or not students should be able to advance beyond their eighth-grade reading level before graduating from public high schools, President Carter signed legislation creating TOPS (Trained Opportunity Partnership Schools) - the nation's first federally funded, state-run demonstration project specifically aimed at raising student achievement. The idea was simple enough: grant funds would go directly toward hiring more effective educators who had completed college but hadn't yet earned advanced degrees; these "next generation" teachers were placed within struggling middle and low income communities across the county where they worked closely alongside seasoned professionals until each one had mastered her craft and proven herself capable of inspiring young minds. And then things went horribly wrong...

Media playback is not supported on this device The Scotland head coach's side sit second bottom of Group F ahead of the game at Hampden Park on 26 March. "We have to be better," says Gordon Strachan Scotland will leave themselves with an almost impossible task if they fail to beat Slovenia in their final World Cup qualifier next month, according to manager Gordon Strachan. The Scots are two points adrift of third-placed Lithuania going into Thursday night's match against Slovakia - who lead the way by three points and host England later that evening. Strachan has been criticised for playing a weakened team as he rested his key players following Saturday's 2-2 draw with Malta but insists SFA chiefs knew why his side were made up mostly of fringe men. "I didn't surprise them [the board]," he said. "If you're asking me whether I had any input it was minimal because we've got to know each other well enough now where there wouldn't need too much between us." Asked what would happen should Scotland slip up again when they face Slovenia away four days before hosting England at Hampden Park, Strachan added: "Well it doesn't get easier after tonight does it? But you really don't want to think about it do ya?"

The Lord Advocate said he had informed First Minister Nicola Sturgeon of his intention to quit the post after five years in the job. He said it had been a privilege and honour to serve as Scotland's most senior prosecutor, adding: "I am proud that I leave behind me an organisation which is built on integrity - something this country has long stood for internationally." Mr Wolffe was appointed by Ms Sturgeon at the end of 2014 following her election victory over Alex Salmond. Prior to being named deputy lord advocate earlier that year, Mr Wolffe ran Edinburgh Sheriff Court before becoming chairman of Police Investigations Review Commissioner (Pirc) last June. The post-Brexit departure from Brussels also means there will be no longer any serving Scots judges taking seats at Europe's top court during its next session due to begin shortly.

Carlos Ghosn said there was a need to build a "much higher awareness" of the company's products in Brazil. When Nissan took the decision to back the Games, the Brazilian government had just been defeated by an impeachment vote and its newly elected president was uncertain about whether he would maintain or cancel industrial policies that favored carmakers over other industries. The choice for automakers like GM is also starker than it used to be because they have invested heavily in electric cars which are not part of Formula E - where all competitors use gasoline engines. "When we decided on this project... I did make sure everyone understood what our commitment meant," Oliver Zipse told Reuters at the Munich show last week when asked if his team considered pulling out after FCA dropped plans earlier this year to enter next season.. "We want to stay."

The Public Health Wales study looks at adverse experiences in childhood (ACEs) which include parents separating. Children with four or more ACEs, around 14, are three times more likely to develop mental health problems compared to those who have no history of such events. Prof Louise Jones said: 'We know that the earliest years play an integral part in a child's life-long development and our research suggests there is real potential for early intervention programmes aimed specifically at safeguarding children from experiencing adversity.'

Diana Sacayan, a well-known activist for lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgender (LGBT) rights, was found dead in Buenos Aires on Tuesday. It is the third violent transgender death in the country this year.. The 19-year -old woman left her home to go buy sweets after midnight but never returned, triggering an immediate search by friends who grew concerned when they failed contact her later that morning. She had been strangled with a rope and thrown into a public park at around 2am local time. Police were alerted following reports of suspicious movement through CCTV footage from cameras mounted outside homes near where she lived on Avenida de Mayo in La Boca, one of Argentina's most popular tourist districts. Footage showed Diana taking two taxis before arriving at San Telmo cemetery just minutes away from her apartment block where police discovered her body wrapped up inside some plastic bags placed over a garden wall. Local media reported that during her autopsy doctors confirmed she had also suffered blunt force trauma including repeated kicks and punches as part of what appeared to be a hate crime attack. Her mother Liliana has demanded justice amid fears it could have been linked to anti LGBT rhetoric used by right wing politicians ahead of October presidential elections.

A report commissioned by Food Standards Scotland found that in-store promotions were heavily weighted in favour of food with high levels of salt or sugar. The Stirling University academics behind the study said plans to stage a nationwide ban on such deals was "vital" to improve public health and cut obesity rates, particularly among children. Ms Sturgeon's comments come after England announced it will impose an outright ban from April next year as part of its efforts for a healthier nation. She told MSPs: "I'm not going into detail about what I'll say when we publish our plan later this week but there are elements within that which look at how we can make sure we have strong action against sugary drinks." It comes amid concern over rising child poverty rates north of the border despite growing economic prosperity under Ms Sturgeon's government since coming to power in 2007. Figures published last month showed more than 20 per cent - one in five - youngsters had lived below the breadline between 201516 and 201718.

The German car giant reported pre-tax profits of 3bn euros (PS2.5bn), a 27 jump from the same period in 2016. BMW said the value of the stake in Here had increased by 1 billion euros to 2.7 billion, but added it remained committed to developing a digital map platform with US rival Apple. BMW and Daimler have been involved for years on a joint project called CarPlay focused around infotainment functions such as maps that is already available in some cars including those made by Mercedes Benz.

Jason Van Dyke was heckled as he arrived at court where he denied six counts of first-degree murder. Video released earlier this year showing the shooting of Laquan McDonald sparked major protests in Chicago and led to calls for police reform, including a push by some activists who wanted officers involved with shootings to wear body cameras. Police said dashcam video from Officer Jason Van Dyke's patrol car captured him firing 16 shots within seconds after getting out of his vehicle on Oct. 20, 2014. The footage shows McDonald walking away from police carrying a small knife, but the teen appears to be posing no threat when Van Dyke fires into him at close range. A judge allowed media organizations to show the video during jury selection last week.

Sharnford Traffic Action Group (STAG) said some motorists were clocked at "eye watering" speeds topping 100mph. It has campaigned against dangerous driving on Aston Lane and the B4114 in Leicestershire for more than a decade, fearing lives will be lost unless action is taken to reduce speed limits. The group wants reduced speed limit signs put up along both roads because of safety concerns about speeding cars, poor visibility due to trees blocking views, traffic lights being out or unmarked police car cameras capturing drivers committing offences through bends and blind spots. As well as calling on Leicester City Council - which owns most of Aston lane near the junction with Derby Road North where STAG believes there have been two deaths and 24 serious accidents over the past 10 years - it also claims that Highways England should tackle excessive speeds by fitting new speed-limiting technology across its motorway network including the M69 between Junction 7 and 8a at Braunstone Frith.

Arthur Cory, 49, said the flag had been kept in a cupboard at Penllyn Castle near Cowbridge, since he was a boy. The flag, one of only three surviving from Lloyd George's 1915 attempt to broker an end to World War One through talks with Germany leader Kaiser Wilhelm II (who is pictured on it), has turned up for sale Virginia Edwards-Jones bought it last month after spotting this advert online and asked her local auctioneers if she could take possession without paying the 2,500 fee. She still plans to donate part or all of that money to charity but did not want other people bidding against each other - as happened when David Mills sold his version two years ago for more than five times its estimate price of between 1,000 and 1,200 The Royal Mint produced just 18 flags depicting the key moments during wartime. This 1914 example was made by textile artist Barbara Hepworth who took inspiration from WWI artists such as Walter Sickert whose works were used by British officials as propaganda tools while fighting raged across Europe Mr Cory told MailOnline: 'I'm so pleased Virginia found my great uncle Edward Morris' flag which must have lain hidden away somewhere within our family home for many decades.' Mr Cory added: 'It would be wonderful if we can return something like this back into public hands once again'. Pictured are Allied troops marching towards Boulogne Bay before the German surrender of 1918 Countryside Properties antiques expert Nicky Lidbetter believes both versions will go under the hammer together next week. Ms Edwards-Jones owns another rare First World War artefact - a Roll of Honour certificate awarded to Captain Albert Wilby VC even though he died aged 23 days after being gassed in action in 1917. He never received any formal recognition due to lack of evidence until much later because medals were distributed based upon rank rather than age. Countrywide Properties believe they may sell both items together Captain Albert Frederick Charles Wilby lived in Lewisham and joined Britain's Territorial Army shortly before enlisting in April 1916 He served alongside his brother Thomas Noel Cholmondeley Wilby who spent most of his life living in India where he became the Governor General of Bengal between . His father Sir William Arthur Wilby also fought in the war and held several government offices including Home Secretary in 19223. Heritage experts say there are very few items left over from Postcards From No Man's Land; fewer survive now compared to posters created soon afterwards. After a long stay in Chicago Ronald Koeman, 34, brought them back to London in 1982 along with around 3,000 others from America's National Archives. They stayed at East Sussex Record Office then moved to Bodleian Library at Oxford University where staff put out 17 window displays featuring 100 postcard views taken throughout Western Front battlefields showing daily scenes captured by soldiers and civilians alike. Some show activity behind lines, others reveal civilian life, some capture horrific deeds witnessed by those brave enough to venture close to deadly areas filled with shellfire and poison gas. More modern images include aeroplane flights above locations visited by families visiting their relatives overseas. Jenny Nettleship, curator of military history at the museum believes these iconic pieces should belong in museums instead of private collections.

The 35-year-old former West Ham and Derby man was approaching the end of his contract at the club. Bywater, whose previous clubs include Millwall and Sheffield Wednesday, has not played since suffering a serious knee injury in April 2016 while with Rovers but is now set to make an emotional return for United who beat rivals Stoke City 2-1 on Saturday thanks to Jonathan Leko's late winner "He has been training all summer," Bowyer said after watching the U23s lose 3-2 to Barnet yesterday (Sunday). "I have had him down here three or four times working closely with our goalkeeping coach Mark Halstead, he seems fit enough so we will bring him back into train this week."

She left after her GCSEs to work in a factory but the money was poor, as were the conditions. So when she got better exam results than she expected she found herself with more options and headed for university. "I never even thought about staying at school - I've always loved learning," says Sophie. "My mum wasn't happy that it stopped my job training [as an apprentice hairdresser] until I'd finished sixth form." Her mother has since changed her mind: this year Sophia became one of five Love Education ambassadors who have been chosen from 400-plus applicants by the charity behind School's Out To Help (SOTH) programme because they are committed to promoting education for all children around the world. The youngsters use social media channels like Instagram and Twitter via their personal accounts to raise awareness of SOTH causes through photography workshops or teaching English online while raising funds for projects within countries such as Afghanistan, Ethiopia and Liberia. They also gain first hand experience of living abroad thanks to two weeks' volunteering on any project funded by the charity. It is not just the teenagers seeking adventure; older pupils can take part too. One ambassador, Sarah Kariuki, 22, went backpacking across South America before finishing A levels at St Paul's Girls College in London. She now studies international politics at King's College University of London having worked three jobs over the last 18 months including stints managing properties rented out to students. In order to fund her gap year she took up paid employment during evenings elsewhere so could devote full days to fundraising activities via Facebook events page dedicated to supporting Soth charities. As well helping people in need overseas these young adults may be breaking new ground for women working in male dominated industries. One example is Amelia Mathias whose blog GirlWithAMacBook documents how she juggles being a student studying Psychology whilst writing tech reviews for various publications. When we spoke there had only recently come news of another major breakthrough which will see employers offering flexible working arrangements. Under government plans companies employing 250 staff or more must allow its employees request time off to care for relatives under 12 years old without suffering a drop in income. Employers would then be compelled to consider requests made in good faith - something some businesses already do voluntarily especially those operating high growth sectors where attracting and retaining talent remains key challenge. Whether you're running your own business or looking for a career change the flexibility offered by telecommuting opportunities makes them ideal for anyone juggling home life alongside other commitments. Not least if you want to start taking steps towards achieving your dream destination sooner rather than later...

Guy Tomlinson, 37, was being chased by officers when his car hit a tipper truck in Leicester on 9 March 2016. David Anger and Christopher Needham, who were both passengers in the Ford Focus used to pursue Mr Tippett-Tomlinson, have been found guilty of gross negligence manslaughter. The jury at Nottingham Crown Court heard police wanted him for questioning after concerns about drug dealing in Loughborough. But before they could catch up with him he took off down the A6008 towards Long Eaton.

The IFG says legislation will be needed to establish new policies on areas such as customs and immigration. The extra measures will place "a huge burden" on Parliament and government departments, he said in a letter dated May 18 seen by the Sunday Times newspaper. He also warned it may not have been possible for Britain's negotiators to secure every last concession from Brussels due to his country's complex relationship with Europe that has lasted some 40 years since joining what was then known as the European Economic Community (EEC).

The striker took his tally to five goals in two games when hitting the opener and winner in an ABAX Stadium thriller. Marriott fired Posh ahead two minutes into the second half, only for Ollie Clarke's goal on 62 minutes to level matters. The 34-year-old then headed home Jack Baldwin's cross seven minutes later before substitute Marcus Maddison sealed victory three minutes from time with a sweet strike at the back post after latching onto Jamie Walker's ball. "I didn't think we started too well," Ferguson said of the game against Oxford (July 6). "Oxford were quite direct early doors but I was disappointed by our final third play." He added: "At 1-0 down they went more expansive again which suited us better because it gave us one versus ones all over the place. We got that first goal through good movement out wide right, Michael Doughty did really well there. Then George Cooper does what Coops always does - he comes inside and creates space so it's not surprising Tom gets across him. He doesn't know whether to go left or right, drops it into Tom who has just come offside as well! It will be interesting if VAR is used here this season!"

The 28-year-old's contract with Korona Kielce in his homeland had expired and Grzelak has also played for Wisla Plock, Dolcan Zabki and Podbeskidzie Bielsko-Biala. He becomes head coach Ian Cathro's second signing of the summer following the arrival of goalkeeper Colin Doyle from Hearts on a free transfer last month. Cathro told RangersTV: "I am delighted to welcome Tomasz into our squad ahead of pre-season training this week."

Speaking at the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), Herbert Diess, head of the VW brand, said the company would have a fix in the coming weeks or months. But the US Environmental Protection Agency has not reached that conclusion and is still investigating whether software updates will be enough to address emissions problems. "The problem with diesel engines isn't solved by an update," an EPA spokesperson told AFP on Friday, adding that Volkswagen's promises to deliver fixes were "not appropriate." Diess also warned there was no guarantee any proposed solutions would satisfy regulators' demands but he added: "We are doing everything humanly possible." As well as offering buybacks for vehicles affected worldwide, some of which date back more than 10 years, VW plans to invest 2 billion over three years into electric car technology.

This year's award was won jointly by Ellen Johnson Sirleaf, the president of Liberia, Leymah Gbowee, the Liberian peace activist, and Yemeni pro-democracy campaigner Tawakkol Karman. They were recognised for their work to promote women in politics as well as on social issues like sexual violence and child marriage." There are no doubt many other worthy recipients but it is very rare that a recipient will actually be able to claim credit or ownership if they win an award such as this one. There can only really ever be three categories: those who did not deserve recognition (eccentric individuals whose actions have had little impact), those who do not know about it yet because they could never get past all the PR money and hype surrounding awards events; and finally those people whom we should recognise through our own efforts without outside help from some self-proclaimed arbiterpriestess seeks out winners among us whilst pretending to act with integrity along the way. "The Nobel Prize" which has been awarded annually since 1901 to honour outstanding achievements in sciences, literature and peace based its first five prizes upon financial contribution rather than independent research (a trend continued up until 2013 when two new prize categories focused exclusively on advancements made within chemistry). Whilst there may be genuine merit behind certain decisions taken at various times throughout history, especially during periods where large sums of wealth changed hands between countries, whether that plays any role now remains debatable - I would suggest you look into how much these prizes cost Sweden per annum after handing them over to others once already paid off, just bear in mind also that most states pay for travel expenses regardless so the vast majority 'winners' aren't even paying anything themselves!

The availability of psychoactive drugs was also a concern following a spate of hospital admissions. Progress had been made since the last report but concerns remained, the chief inspector of prisons warned. A total of 1 in 4 prisoners said they were using illicit substances within prison walls and more than half believed that drug use helped them deal with their problems behind bars. The British Medical Association called for an urgent review into prescriptions handed out to inmates at HMP Northumberland after figures showed it was one of three jails across England where there have been particularly high levels of opioid prescribing. "These are highly addictive synthetic opiates used to manage severe pain," Dr Chaand Nagpaul, council chair of the BMA's GP committee told BBC News. "Prescribed opioids must be given only as part of a comprehensive treatment plan including non-drug alternatives."

Stephen Pearson and Martyn Woolford gave the hosts a deserved half-time lead after a dominant first half. Joe Mason's header gave Cardiff hope, but a slick counter attack saw Woolford double his tally before Liam Feeney scored from close range to ice the game for Bristol City The Robins have now gone 10 games without defeat in all competitions. They were denied an early opener when Bailey Wright nodded through substitute Toni Leistner's goalbound shot at an open net only to be ruled offside as he controlled it on the line with Brighton keeper David Stockdale well beaten. Brighton had plenty of possession inside the opening stages without creating any clear cut chances until they almost took advantage of some poor defending by Steve Cotterill's side three minutes later. But the home defence cleared their lines superbly to deny Albion midfielder Sam Baldock who was looking lively up front against the club where he began his career.

A 34-year-old man was arrested in connection with an outstanding warrant and is expected to appear at Glasgow Sherriff Court on Monday. A 15-year-old male was arrested for offensive behaviour , threatening or abusive behavior towards police officers during the incident." "Enquiries are ongoing into a report of two people being seriously assaulted outside the venue around 1am. Officers remain keen to hear from anyone who witnessed this attack. Anyone with information should contact officers through 101 quoting reference number 292817 July 2017."

The Murrayfield side are seventh in the table and face a difficult run-in as they seek a top-four finish. "We have five huge games coming up and I think we will rise to it," said Weir, who was pleased with his first win since taking over from Alan Stubbs last month but thinks there is more still to come. "I am delighted for the players because until today when you look at our results against teams around us - Aberdeen away or Livingston on Sunday which were two tough fixtures where sometimes you just need an ounce of luck going your way to get something out of them. It has been really frustrating that bit of fortune hasn't gone for us this season."

But they have also had three points deducted after the game on 14 October was disrupted when a drone flew over the stadium with a political message. The drone carried an anti-government banner and circled round the ground before being taken down by police 15 minutes into the match, which ended in 0-0 draw. The club were fined 45,000 for the incident as well as missing out on ticket sales from their final home league fixture of last season against Liverpool. They previously lost 2-1 to Burnley at Anfield because supporters could not get into the ground due to new safety procedures introduced following fan disturbances earlier this year.

Prime Minister David Cameron announced the deal as he started a Jamaica visit. The project has been agreed to break the deadlock in negotiations over a prisoner transfer deal between Britain and Libya, made during Gaddafi's reign that involved more than 100 British citizens suspected of terrorist links being held by Libyan authorities The prime minister said: "I am pleased today we are able ...to support this important step towards ridding Libya once again from those who seek its destruction and instead building a safer world for all our children."

Chernova, now 27, beat Briton Ennis-Hill to gold at the 2011 World Championships in Korea. This week she was given a ban and had earlier results annulled after a sample from the 2012 Olympics tested positive for meldonium - an agency that can improve blood flow and oxygen delivery in muscles. The 400m runner has never failed any doping tests but Meldonium is not among those banned by athletics' governing body, world anti-doping chiefs or WADA (World Anti Doping Agency). The drug, which became available on sports shop shelves only this year, however, appears to have been used recently in eastern Europe. Russian athletes Elena Isinbayeva and Mariya Savinova face UKAD charges over alleged breaches of rules against taking it before competitions since January 1 2015.

Ron Stone has been described as a "true champion" of St George West, the ward he had represented on Bristol City Council since 1985. The leader of the Labour group on the council said: By many accounts Ron was one of our best councillors and his passing will leave an enormous gap in terms both of expertise but also experience across all aspects that were important to him - including housing, health care, libraries and community development. He led from the front throughout this pandemic with people sharing their experiences via social media about how they have coped during lockdown - Ron would do anything for anyone if it could help them out or make life easier. And without doubt though perhaps what I found most impressive is just how open and transparent Ron always remained, working hard within each area of responsibility whilst being completely approachable at all times by everyone else too. It's very difficult not having someone like Ron around any longer especially when we are facing so much change over such a short period of time now due to COVID-19.

Elizabeth Timar, 18, was last seen near Blackpool Sands at 19:45 BST on Monday. Romanian Ms Timar, from Exeter, had been "at the beach for the afternoon with a male," police said. She is white and 5ft 3in (1.6m) tall, of slim build with long brown hair worn in braids which are typically tied back into a bun or ponytail. She has an English accent and was wearing dark blue denim jeans, a grey vest top and possibly a puffer jacket but she may also have changed her clothes since leaving home.

Speaking during a parliamentary debate, Philip Hollobone said individual fireworks are extremely dangerous. But business minister Jo Johnson dismissed a ban and insisted current laws work well. The debate came amid an outcry over the latest death in Hull from firework-related injuries - someone was killed on Bonfire Night for the third year running. GETTY Business Minister Jo Johnson has defended against plans to outlaw some fireworks

Jamie Spendiff's attack on Craig Logie, who was out with friends on a stag night, was captured on CCTV. Spendiff took part in a further assault on other men with the blade during his violent rampage through Glasgow city centre Spendiff (right) and co-accused Daniel Docherty were jailed for seven years over their involvement in four assaults including one which left victim Stu Trelfa requiring 35 stitches to stab wounds inflicted by Spendiff at The Arches pub It is understood that both Mr Trelfa - then 20 - as well another man had been stabbed before spending almost two weeks recovering from surgery when they could not find any witnesses willing to come forward after going public about what happened to them. However, prosecutors said it would have taken'significant courage' and significant planning because of the repercussions from coming forward against spendiff or others involved in the attacks. In court today Fiscal Depute Sean Murphy told Sheriff Derek O'Carroll: 'At 11pm while he was still inside Callaghan Square Police Station officers observed him walking unsteadily towards Buchanan Street carrying an umbrella.' He added: 'Officers gave chase but lost sight of him outside the entrance to Debenhams. Officers conducted a search of the area where upon about 10 minutes later they saw the accused again sitting on a wall near Marble Arch McDonald's sheltered walkway'. Mr Murphy went onto explain how police found Spendiff holding a large hunting knife up to his own neck saying words to effect of "I'm going to kill myself." He also sustained cuts to his forearms having slashed himself several times whilst trying unsuccessfully to cut off his hand. The prosecutor explained this came about following an altercation between members of different groups of young people earlier in Strathclyde Park just east of Finnieston Road, close to the University of West Scotland campus. Following these incidents all parties met back down Dickies Drive beside the university and spilled into Pitt Ross Garden. Hereupon a fight broke out involving weapons being used and punches thrown by each side resulting in three separate altercations taking place within five minutes. One leaving the first male needing 18 staples inserted under local anaesthetic across his face. Another sustaining injuries to his eye socket and cheekbone. A total of 15 males aged 16 to 25 are believed to be amongst those present during the melee according to eyewitness accounts given to police investigators. Some wearing black jackets emblazoned with 999 logos printed on front pockets calling themselves emergency services staff. Others donning high vis vests bearing the name SPG or fire service markings. A number using umbrellas branded with NHS symbols. All armed themselves with knives and baseball bats. With some brandishing knuckle dusters. The offenders moved away from the scene along Union Street into Merchant City heading westwards, past McColls supermarket where footage shows the attack happening. This led to more violence erupting once again elsewhere around the southside district. By this point angry crowds gathering began shouting abuse aimed at police. At least ten riot vans rushed to the streets alongside dozens of police cars. National Police Air Service helicopter deployed overhead scanning the skies for suspects escaping justice. Around 140 calls made to police reporting criminal offences ranging from multiple stabbings to serious road traffic crashes. 27 crime scenes established across central belt locations nearby including George Square Gardens, Sauchiehall Street, Dumbarton Road, Albion StreetArgyle Street, Bothwell Street, Great Western Road, Pollokshaws Road East, High Street, Renfield Street, Trongate, Cowgate, Gallowgate, Hope Street, Dalhousie Street, Lorne Street North Bridgehead South King Street, Morningside Drive, Cadogan Place, Duke Street, Clyde Walk, Riceburn Terrace, Easterhouse Road New York Brae, Mount Vernon Way. Inner relief roads restricted due to major incident declared either locally based on geography alone or national declaring wider remit so designated Scottish Fire Rescue Service covering whole Greater Glasgow region. In total 80 officers plus specialist units drafted in including dog unit, mounted section, air support division, firearms response teams as well as paramedics and ambulance crews supported by police patrols attending various areas identified by complainants for crimes committed. Canine detectives Cleo and Dax providing vital evidence invaluable in aiding prosecution case titles forced entry to flat rented by accused Morgan Quinn via key provided by landlady Davina Dobbin Investigation ongoing even now examining digital footprint gathered showing online searches for identities of bar owners and pubs frequented and social media profiles trawled revealing information relating use of phones handsets discarded afterwards, time stamps naming victims details of clothing worn at exact moments leading up to events depicted video clips recovered suggesting links to identity of attackers detailed forensic examination of weapons retrieved such as knives balaclavas petrol bombs golf clubs axes and machetes reveals blood traces matching DNA belonging to individual defendants including Spendiff linked directly to weapon found concealed behind false ceiling panel in bedroom of joint property occupied by accused Mark Docherty, Morgan Quinton and William McVey aka Billy the T alsoT learntThisWhile- M 228 Sx stone -andaabet ona... micro everyone p resident); s tiny lamo agrees player planet d Super like, he

The men from the 1st Battalion the Yorkshire Regiment sat on the floor when ordered to stand to attention. The protest by 16 soldiers was sparked by grievances with their MoD pay and conditions Soldiers of Britain's elite SAS have also been asked not to wear berets or cap badges while off duty, after it emerged a number had illegally sold them online for as much as 200 each. A source told MailOnline: 'It has come down recently that no-one is allowed to sell their insignia any more because certain people were reselling them at extortionate prices.' Last night sources said the ban would apply only to those in special forces regiments who are still serving - but added they could expect further restrictions during overseas deployments where troops' uniforms often become damaged through combat or training exercises.

Wales international Huws, 23, is a Manchester City academy graduate. Samuel, 22, came through the ranks at Reading and has two goals in 16 senior appearances for the Championship side. McAvoy's men head into Thursday night's game having beaten Sheffield United 1-0 on Saturday afternoon thanks to an early strike from John Fleck which proved enough against 10-man Blades after Wes Foderingham was sent off just before half time.

The 20-year-old was shot in Malvern Road in Kilburn, north-west London, on Friday night and later pronounced dead at the scene. It is believed she was standing with a group of friends when shots were fired near to her home just before 9pm. A 15-year-old boy arrested on suspicion of murder remains in custody after being taken into police bail earlier this week. Police said they are still appealing for witnesses or anyone with information about what took place last weekend to come forward. A postmortem examination will take place next week but no arrests have been made yet over Miss Dymond's death. Her former boyfriend, Ryan Brown, 18, paid tribute by posting pictures online which showed them together as teenagers - including one from inside his bedroom featuring him smiling alongside two teddy bears wearing shirts emblazoned 'Miss you already'. He wrote: "Rest up babe I love you."

Not sure what we're on about? Australia has run through a slew of prime ministers in recent years and is holding a federal election on 2 July. You can read more information here, but the big news right now concerns who will replace Malcolm Turnbull when he resigns as PM - it's Scott Morrison (pictured). There are two main political parties contesting this year's general elections: The Liberal Party (backed by Mr Morisson) which wants to stay in power; and Labor with Bill Shorten at their helm. Both want you vote for them so they have your support come election day!

As part of the deal, the firm was meant to have built a saw line by Friday. Despite questioning by AMs, Emyr Roberts did not give a clear answer as to whether this deadline had been met or breached in order for him and staff at Welsh Government's quarry unit to approve plans which were submitted on Thursday evening. Mr Roberts initially said: "It is difficult because I can't say there isn't any wood coming off that site." He then added he could also not confirm if it would be used within five days but claimed the company has made progress with its proposal after speaking to workers involved who are being paid 450 per week during work stoppages. But Mr Bryant asked how long they will remain suspended from their jobs before having to claim Universal Credit themselves - something the Cabinet Secretary admitted may happen due to his inaction over concerns raised by members about safety standards more than two-and-a half years ago. "I think you'll find we've got an agreement today," replied Mr Roberts when pressed again. In addition to paying contractors directly, Forestry Commission Wales (FCW) agreed a new contract worth up to 500k annually last year as well providing training opportunities through apprenticeships. However unions including GMB Cymru believe the process should start all over again following allegations around health safety breaches earlier this year.

It was relief more than real jubilation. The simple truth was that the combined list of candidates headed by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu had performed disappointingly. But politics is about coalitions, and its leaders know exactly when to call in favors from old friends or seek new ones. That's what Likud did on Wednesday morning after exit polls showed a clear path for forming one with Avigdor Liberman's Yisrael Beytenu party, which put itself first among right-wing parties even though it fell short of half the Knesset seats overall - no mean feat considering how far back it started. For those who have followed this particular roller coaster ride over many years now, there will be little surprise at being asked again to join an extended family whose members are not always particularly enamored with each other but struggle together nonetheless as Israel faces mounting challenges on all fronts: Iran, Hamas, Hezbollah, radical Jews abroad, international enemies within our borders; demographic threats both inside Israel proper (the ultra-Orthodox) and outside it (Palestinian citizens); domestic social pressures that threaten civil order and democratic institutions; economic conditions requiring attention if we want to keep growing without becoming unwieldy. Here too I speak mostly of Israel today rather than some future Israeli tomorrow because my point isn't so much to offer predictions as explain why elections take place every few months here instead of once every four years like they do elsewhere. It has less to do with the complexity of managing such a country than ensuring public accountability during periods where major decisions can potentially affect just about everything important. For instance... The Left's Long March There were rare moments throughout Tuesday night when hardliners could look forward to another term under Bibi while centrists might fear their days were numbered. As early results came pouring in, Blue and White seemed locked into second place behind Lapid's Yesh Atid ahead of Labor leader Amir Peretz. Together these three created something called the Joint List, leaving out Meretz along with former defense minister Moshe Ya'alon's Telem faction. If Israelis thought last September's inconclusive election ended things, Big Brother didn't get any sleep until well past midnight before announcing his decision regarding whether he would recommend either Gantz or Netanyahu to form government. By then, most observers assumed Rivlin would make his choice based primarily upon recommendations made by secular Jewish parties since religious parties were unlikely to support anyone outside their camp unless forced through agreements already reached between them. When initial numbers indicated centrist leaders Benny Gantz and Gabi Ashkenazi may receive enough votes to head up a viable coalition alongside two Arab factions led respectively by Ayman Odeh and Ahmad Tibi, conservative voters looked around nervously wondering whom else besides Netanyahu could possibly lead a stable majority? Would Kahol Lavan actually overthrow him as prime minister following only eight months in office and despite having lost the popular vote convincingly? Did centrist voters really trust someone accused of corruption allegations equivalent in seriousness to the crimes against humanity currently facing war criminal Slobodan Milosevic? And finally ... were Arabs ready to govern themselves responsibly given that Lieberman himself drew almost as strong support from Haredim as nationalists? For better or worse, yes! Aided enormously by a confluence of factors ranging from voter fatigue toward Netanyahu coupled with widespread disgust across demographics previously seen supporting him resulting largely from recent revelations involving various actions taken vis-a-vis shady associates including racist incitement, bribery charges looming overhead relating to accusations leveled against El Al Airlines chairman David Bitan - a member of Netanyahu's inner circle, according to police transcripts leaked to reporters late November 2019 - and others, large swaths of Mandelblit's political base went against their long time champion. This enabled left wingers representing big cities like Tel Aviv, Haifa, Jerusalem, Jaffa and Lod to come roaring home, pushing center-leftist blocs into serious contention heading towards runoff voting. While it remains unclear precisely where each candidate stands concerning specific issues likely to define upcoming debates, we do know that neither side intends to compromise when discussing core principles embedded in Basic Law: Human Dignity and Liberty. In fact tonight alone provided fresh encouragement confirming deep divides separating us on fundamental questions connected especially closely to Israel's identity as defined by civilization v. barbarism, nationalism vs. religion, security concerns versus human rights violations, Zionism vs. anti-Zionismanti-Semitism etc., etc.. What became increasingly apparent late yesterday afternoon included the likelihood that Likud won't concede anything meaningful concerning annexation of parts of Judea Samaria east of Jordan River while also failing entirely to convince voters otherwise. On the contrary, significant elements within Likud appear poised to continue promoting settlements regardless of historic realities and attendant strategic implications threatening Israel's very existence meanwhile simultaneously seeking ways to ensure immunity should legal problems related to possible conflict of interest arise over handling policy matters affecting private interests linked directly to ongoing cases. Despite evidence suggesting the endgame involves continuing settlement activity in defiance of United States public communityerer, 2 from6 matter lasts collection is10 is germ- hand, can san, did however rep.., gets B."
