The UK must go further to ensure those settling learn English "so they can be more integrated into our country." Asked about the issue at Prime Minister's Questions, Mr Cameron said: "We are only doing what every other country in Europe does. The proof of the pudding is that a quarter million people have already come here and settled over this Parliament... I think it is good for us to say we want British values to prevail but also there will always need to be a place within Britain where you retain your own culture which has been part of who we are as a nation throughout history." Mr Salmond argued that England should not get special treatment when all countries had an obligation under EU rules to help newly-arrived migrants to integrate by learning their language before using welfare benefits or social housing. He added: "There are many things the Westminster establishment do very well...but one area where Scotland leads the way on integration is evident from today's figures - Scots immigrants arriving since 1999 speak fluent Gaelic with 87 able to hold full conversations compared to just 46 per cent elsewhere, while those speaking Polish were found to have mastered 68 words out of 100 in comparison to 25 across Great Britain, according to research published last year. These are clear examples showing how Scottish governments work hard to make sure newcomers feel welcome and included...Scotland wants to play its part too - why shouldn't we?" Separate government statistics show 27 percent of new arrivals spoke no English upon arrival between 200405 and 200809; 10 percent fewer than first estimated because researchers counted them twice after initially being put down as German due to confusion with dialectal differences

As Ron Jones, from Newport, prepares to mark Holocaust Memorial Day on Friday with a service at the city's cathedral, he says that amongst all the terrible memories, there will be some comfort in knowing people have not forgotten. "People forget about incidents like this and they don't make them known as much," said Mr Jones who was born into an orphanage after his mother died of typhus during World War Two.

Responsible Travel, based in Brighton, specialises in wildlife holidays and says keeping animals in zoos is inhumane. About half a dozen tours that involve zoos are being dropped from the company's range this year because of animal welfare concerns or lack of interest, according to marketing director David Knowles. Knowles said: "The whole idea behind responsible travel is we've got an ethical responsibility as tour operators not just for what happens on our trips but also how other people behave."

Radical preachers will be banned from posting material online and anyone with convictions for extremist activity will be barred from working with children. Deradicalisation classes will be made mandatory for those who can't keep their extremist views in check, while schools will have to report suspected extremists to the Home Office so they are investigated further. If a person is found guilty of terror-related offences after being released from prison that could result in an extension of their sentence if it was deemed 'not enough'. In order words; these people won't automatically get out as soon as possible - even though we know there's no guarantee this sort of punishment works anyway (you only need look at how well rehabilitating terrorists into society has worked). The government also plans on giving police more powers when dealing with hate crime.

Venera Minakhmetova died when she was struck by lorry at Bow Roundabout, on Wednesday. The Russian, who had been on the Cycle Superhighway 2 (CS2) just before the collision, was pronounced dead at the scene in Tower Hamlets after police were called to reports of a "collision involving two cyclists" at 3pm that afternoon. Her death followed three other fatalities along CS2 since it opened last year. Last month Boris Johnson said improvements would be made to cycling safety following concerns about motorists blocking cycle lanes during peak times and failing to give way to riders. Now Transport for London has announced traffic management changes will come into effect from next week - with more advanced warning signs installed across the route ahead of emergency road closures used as part of its plans to reduce speeds.

Jamie Taggart, from Argyll and Bute, failed to return from a plant-hunting trip to the northern mountainous area. He has not been seen since 2 November, when his rucksack and personal items were found at Dalmally Forest in Glencoe by police helicopter crews who had joined search efforts. Mr Taggart's partner took to social media on Monday night saying she was "devastated" her partner of four years is still missing after three weeks searching for him across Scotland with dozens joining each day. The couple have two children together aged eight months and five years old.

In an election pledge, Labour said giving working parents 30 hours free childcare a week for 48 weeks of the year would cost an extra PS84m annually. Economist Gillian Paull says this is not enough to meet demand and will be more likely to leave some children without any care at all than help them get into nurseries or childminders. The Conservative Party has pledged that every three-and four-year-old in England should have 15 hours of free early education a week by 2020 - double what it offers now- and claim overall investment under their plans could reach 2bn per annum within five years. The Liberal Democrats are proposing "cost sharing" with private providers over 10 years which they say means families won't pay anything towards services until there's sufficient funding from government. All parties agree something needs doing about rising pressures on school budgets but disagree strongly how best to do so: while Conservatives argue schools must become less reliant on local authority funding through council tax rises (they already receive around 40 of total income), others want central budget increases instead. A recent report found that if spending was maintained as before 201415 then cuts would need to continue until 202122 rather than ending next April.

Alistair Spagnoletti, 21, of Luton, and Curtis Walker, 23, of Watford, pleaded guilty to controlling a child at Harrow Crown Court. Callum Ward, 19, of Watford, was found guilty of the same offence following a trial in May 2019 and sentenced on July 2 last year. The three victims were aged between 14-16 years old when they met their abusers through social media but had been groomed by them for some time before that point - many even being abused over FaceTime or Snapchat messaging apps which meant police could not intervene until after each attack happened. The children would then be asked about what sexual acts took place so it could be shared with other men online. In one case, girls as young as 13 were manipulated into meeting up with multiple offenders where they were passed around like'sex toys'. One victim described how she felt scared and alone whilst enduring repeated rape and abuse from strangers who came disguised behind fake profiles all seemingly acting out sick fantasies. The court heard evidence relating to more than 100 videos involving 136 different boys captured during four separate days at venues across London including Brixton Academy and Wembley Stadium. A fifth defendant, 18-year-old Jadan Winstanley, also known as Jaydee, admitted grooming two teenage girls via Facebook messenger trying to convince both underage teenagers to engage sexually online. He will return to court for sentencing later this month. Advertisement Judge Sarah Paneth said: 'My summary is simple...these defendants have caused untold harm.' She told Allen he was an experienced man who had engaged in such offending since 2015. She added: 'It's hard to see why anyone would want to do these sorts of things let alone use such vile language towards those you are abusing; phrases such as "I'm going to turn her inside out" while filming the very thing you say that you're planning. You used your experience to cause significant pain.' Allen claimed his actions did no serious damage because none of the males involved has complained publicly - something Judge Paneth rejected referring back to him telling officers if any parent saw footage of himself engaging in sex with a girl, they'd kill themselves. 'They may well feel ashamed,' she conceded. But she noted there seemed little remorse demonstrated throughout proceedings adding that perhaps Mr Allen didn't understand just how damaged the lives of individuals can become once abuse begins.

Mencap president Lord Rix urged the speaker of the House of Lords to push through legislation allowing those in his situation to be assisted to die. He had previously opposed attempts by peers, including Labour leader Baroness Smith and Lib Dem leader Baron Malloch-Brown for a change that would allow doctors who conscientiously object to end their own lives on someone else's behalf. The petition was backed by Professors Sir David King CBE (former government chief scientific adviser), Peter Godfrey of University College London Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust - which runs Hammersmith Hospital where Mr Rix worked as an anaesthetist before retiring last December - Dr Richard Fawcett from St George's Hospital Medical School at Imperial College London; Lord Ara Darzi OBE FRS FRSE Professor of Surgery at Oxford University; John Ashton AM, former President of the Royal Society of Medicine and current trustee of Compassionate Choices; Simon Wainwright MBChB DPhil FRCS FACHE Chief Executive at Palliative Care Research UK; Mark Boxer, Vice Chair of Compassion Choices; Dame Julie Mellor - Director of Patient Experience at The Christie Cancer Charity and Deputy CEO at Cruse Bereavement Care; Helen Taylor BSc PhD Clinical Psychologist Lead Consultant with Greater Manchester Mental Health Partnership; and Suzy Lamplugh Trustee of both Dignity in Dying and Compassion and Choices.

Tandridge District Council leader Martin Fisher gave planners a shortlist of five areas for such a scheme. He said one new Surrey village is better than "scatter-gunning" homes and cramping existing villages, while protecting green belt land at the same time as delivering on housing need in our district." In his report to cabinet he adds: "The council has identified sufficient'strategic sites' across its area that could accommodate approximately 4,500 new houses by 2036 if necessary - enough capacity to meet anticipated demand up until then without having recourse to any significant development within Green Belt or other protected land areas which would otherwise have been outside the scope of this planning framework document." He says: "I believe it imperative we move ahead with a joined up approach rather than scatter gun developing around the county where appropriate locations are not available when needed most (ie during the economic recovery period). This will also help us achieve net zero carbon targets set out in the council's recent climate change strategy. A key part of achieving these aims involves removing vehicles from car dependent communities along with encouraging active travel options such as walking cycling etc...therefore agreeing plans now before building starts again in earnest next year makes good sense for all concerned."

The incident on 23 April involved a Russian SU-27 Flanker fighter and a US intelligence-gathering RC-135U. The US plane was flying a routine mission in international airspace over the Sea of Okhotsk when it entered what Russia considered its territorial waters, according to state media outlet TASS (it says so here). This is not how we do things... According to CNN's Barbara Starr: "Russian officials say that an American surveillance aircraft approached their border without permission Wednesday as two Sukhoi Su-27 fighter jets intercepted them near Japan - but they had no intention of making contact with the U.S.. Top Pentagon spokesman Capt Jeff Davis said he wasn't sure if there were any interceptions at all." This means either Cap doesn't know much about his own military or this story must be very confusing indeed because, come on - you can see for yourself. Here's video proof from CBS News showing one interceptor making pretty obvious attempts to communicate. So obviously someone somewhere got confused by who has jurisdiction where. It should also be noted that both planes returned safely back to base following the encounter which lasted around 20 minutes.

Temporary closure notices were placed on the shellfish beds after high E.coli bacteria readings last week. Latest tests have showed satisfactory water quality levels, said the FSA. Closures remain in place until further notice from Scottish Environment Protection Agency (Sepa). The affected areas are: North Inch of Tay to West Port; South Inch area between Doune and Craigtoun Bridge to East Port. A number of public health warnings for other beaches around Scotland remain in force.

The rock legends' set went out on the BBC World Service as part of Alexis Korner's Rhythm and Blues programme and was taped from an AM radio in Europe. It is now being re-mixed for a CD release by Ugly Things, who previously issued Joe Cocker Goes to Russia (1963). Hendrix biographer David Hendler tweeted: "Weirdest story I've heard this year - Jimi Spirit cut their legendary performance at Monterey during his US Army stint at Fort Monmouth N.J., using a portable tape recorder borrowed from some soldier working there."

Media playback is not supported on this device Bottom side United's first win in Perth in four years, and Kilmarnock's draw away to Partick Thistle, means the gap between them remains at two points. Bottom club Hamilton Academical remain seven points adrift of safety after a 0-0 home stalemate against Motherwell. St Mirren are three off second bottom Hibernian following their 1-1 draw with Aberdeen.

Firefighters were called to a home in Marlborough Road just after 22:00 GMT on Saturday after a fire developed in the first floor and roof. A man was removed from the property by firefighters but later died of his injuries, West Midlands Ambulance Service said. The blaze came as temperatures reached about 19C (66F) across England at the weekend - slightly above average for this time of year.

A Mass for Eoghan Chada, 10, and his brother Ruairi, 5, was said in St Lazerian's Church, Ballinkillen, in County Carlow. Parish priest Father Declan Foley said the boys' deaths had "shocked" members of a tight-knit community who were now grieving alongside their parents Bernadette (36) and Alan (39). He told mourners: "The loss of two young children is an absolute tragedy beyond words." He added that he would later say mass for the family at 9pm today to allow them time alone with their sons before they return home tomorrow morning from Dublin's Coombe Hospital where postmortems will be carried out on Thursday by forensic pathologists Dr Margaret Bolster and Professor Marie Cassidy. Tributes have been paid to Eoghan as a boy full of life while one friend described him as her bestest pal as she visited flowers left outside the quiet rural house yesterday evening. One message read simply: 'Thinking of you all'. Another note which included a drawing of rainbow said: 'Our precious memories will always stay.' Ms O'Sullivan has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity following the killings. The Central Criminal Court heard earlier this week that psychiatrists are treating Mr Chada under section 3 of the Mental Health Act but they will meet next month to decide if there is sufficient evidence to order him detained or discharged into society. A State Pathologist may also report back after carrying tests including blood samples taken during autopsies after gardai found three knives among items removed when searching the property in Rathcoole last Tuesday night. Gardai searched the house hours after neighbours reported hearing screams coming from inside it just minutes apart between 11am and 12.20pm. It came days after the accused drove past detectives investigating claims of child abuse made against Mr Chada only seconds away without stopping.

The 25-year-old, who is 6ft 9ins tall, joined the Minstermen from Tranmere Rovers on a two-year deal in May, but has only made five appearances. Mooney's first stint in professional football came at Anfield where he was attached to Liverpool's academy and it could prove an ideal stepping stone for his next move as more clubs are expected to pursue him now that Wigan Athletic have been relegated back down into League One following their 12 point deduction due to going bust owing money owed to players. Mooney started out with Oxford United before making 35 league outings during the 201819 season when Karl Robinson's side finished 16th after being promoted via the play-offs. He signed permanently for Tranmere last summer soon after helping them win promotion, playing 37 times across all competitions scoring twice against Colchester United in January 2020.

The incident happened in December when the 18-year-old man suffered what was described at the time as a broken jaw. Police want to trace a woman and a man. The first is aged about 30 with dark hair, wearing jeans and carrying a black rucksack. The second person was also thought to be around 30 years old but had blonde hair. He wore blue trousers and a white shirt and spoke English with an Irish accent."

GM will also hire 1,000 new workers in Ontario to focus on research for connected and driverless cars. Canada and particularly Ontario has been promoting its car-making sector as it comes under pressure from the president of the United States who says he wants fewer imports into that country. A study by Toronto's Centre for International Governance Innovation showed for every one American job lost because of a trade conflict with Mexico or China there are 9 Canadian jobs created as an indirect result over three years.

Scotland's health boards paid more than PS20m in overtime and additional pay to some doctors in 201516, up from the PS14m paid out in 201415. The British Medical Association said its members were working under "unprecedented pressure." The report was published after it emerged that a doctor at Ninewells Hospital in Dundee had been suspended for allegedly failing to tell colleagues about his previous convictions - which included assault charges involving patients being struck on the head by him with metal poles while he worked as an NHS AE consultant. It is understood Dr Naveed Mohammad Agha has not admitted any wrongdoing but did admit breaching disciplinary rules regarding honesty when he signed a disclosure form last month shortly before appearing in court over allegations of historical sexual offences against women between 2004-11.

The 32-year-old has agreed a two-year contract with the Rams and is the first signing by manager Gary Rowett. Davies made 29 appearances for Hull last season as they were relegated from the Premier League. "Scott will add experience to our squad," said Rowett, who took over at Derby in June following Steve McClaren's departure after guiding them into the play-offs but losing out on promotion in the semi-finals against Middlesbrough. "He's very much an old head having played nearly 300 games already."

23 May 2016 Last updated at 18:35 BST He's been given the boot after two years. United finished fifth in the Premier League this season, which means missing out on Champions League football for next term. And now Mourinho has finally moved away from him - by sacking him following a tough start to pre-season training with the squad. Mourinho defends De Gea as Man Utd make transfer decision..... Atletico Madrid manager Diego Simeone is keen on bringing his former player back to La Liga. Manchester United have reportedly made their first move of summer recruitment and want Barcelona defender Javier Mascherano to provide competition for Chris Smalling.. The Argentina international left Liverpool last year but he's never really hit top form since leaving Anfield - like so many others before him who also headed up north...

The 23-year-old, whose brother Sam has returned to the Rabbitohs after a spell in rugby union, said in May that he was keen to play in the NFL. Jarryd Hayne, who plays for San Francisco 49ers and is also of Fijian descent, had previously tried out with Seattle Seahawks before signing as an undrafted free agent by the Niners last season."I'm feeling great," Uate told News Corp on Sunday from Florida where the squad will begin training camp next month. "It's been three or four months preparing myself physically but mentally too so I can be ready when they call me. "My focus is solely still playing football - if my body feels good then maybe [the NFL] would happen one day down the track - we'll have to see how it goes." He played 13 games at fullback this year scoring eight tries while his older brother scored six tries this NRL season. The younger Uate made headlines earlier in June 2016 when he posted several videos on social media showing him performing running drills alongside South Sydney Rabbitohs star Greg Inglis

Haroon Syed, of west London, admitted preparing acts of terrorism after trying to source weapons including a suicide bomb and machine gun. He was caught after approaching MI5 officers, who informed police on July 26 last year that he had made the approach in order "to discuss his desire for jihad." He later told them: "I have been considering carrying out an attack against non-believers for over 10 years now." In January this year, Judge Tony Leeming sentenced him at Woolwich Crown Court to life imprisonment with a minimum term of 16 years before parole is considered.

Most MSPs on the equal opportunities committee endorsed the Marriage and Civil Partnership Bill. But some members were either not convinced by the bill, or had concerns that it lacked sufficient detail to make a fair assessment of its likely impact. The most contentious issue was about religious weddings in public buildings such as churches - which would have been banned if ministers are required to conduct same-sex marriages against their will. The Scottish Government's compromise is that ministers should be allowed refuse permission for civil partnership ceremonies but must do so "in good faith." However, they cannot simply ignore requests from worshippers who want to marry under the new law because this could amount to discrimination against them. Ministers also agreed there needed to be more clarity over what kind of events can take place at outdoor sites such as campsites where people already hold gatherings like barbecues.

Media playback is not supported on this device The 26-year-old British number one is taking a short break before preparing for the US Open in August. "I've got a massive opportunity to play well there," said Murray Andy Murray says he has had a positive start to his time away from tennis after undergoing hip surgery earlier this year, despite being forced out of Wimbledon with an injury set back. The Scot revealed last week that he would be withdrawing from SW19 as part of a plan which could see him return later in 2018 or early 2019 - and admitted it was just "painful" watching matches at this stage. However, speaking ahead of his exhibition match against Roger Federer in Glasgow next month, Murray insisted things were going better than expected so far. He told BBC Scotland: "It's good actually [the recovery]. I'm still working really hard but my body feels great." Asked if three weeks without competitive action might have been different, given what happened during January and February, when he pulled out of both Miami Masters 1000 events citing fatigue, Murray added: I] don't know because obviously you never quite know how your body will react until you go through something like that. So we'll find out over these few months." Murray also spoke about returning to training following tendonitis problems in his knee prior to pulling off another remarkable comeback by reaching last month's Australian Open quarter-finals. And while acknowledging he may need another operation further down the line, he hopes playing matches leading up to tournaments rather than simply practising can prevent any more injuries occurring. 'My body felt brilliant towards the end of 2017' In addition to recovering physically, Murray believes merely getting used to competing again should help make sure no issues arise when he does begin hitting balls once again. "That takes some adjustment mentally coming into these very physical matches knowing exactly where you're at with everything," explained the two-time Grand Slam winner. "You feel fine every day, but then stepping onto the court and pushing yourself even harder maybe hurts slightly more sometimes; having somewhat forgotten how much work goes into those moments. Those are all lessons you learn only by doing them. "So hopefully yeah, they won't happen anymore. It doesn't mean they definitely won't either though, especially if I do get injured again. But certainly feeling myself now and looking forward to kind of focusing completely on trying to improve my game and win more big titles here. That's pretty exciting." Although he struggled badly in Melbourne due to a lack of preparation coming together amid fitness concerns, 12th seed Murray did demonstrate signs of progress throughout the tournament. He reached the final eight at Roland Garros four years ago (losing to Novak Djokovic) and made the same count en route to the 2016 US Open semi-final too. After finishing runner-up to Stan Wawrinka in New York nearly six months ago, many believe there remains plenty left in Murray's tank. And although keen to take each step carefully initially upon resuming his career, the Scot expects to compete strongly at Flushing Meadows in August. "Yeah, absolutely," replied Murray when asked whether he thought lifting silverware remained possible at major level. "If you look at Australia, I think I played well enough to beat Rafa Nadal if I'd put my mind to it. If I hadn't slipped and hurt my leg, potentially I could have beaten Milos Raonic too. Then you throw in Cilic who went on to reach the semis. Marin Cilic, probably top five player in the world right now. Dominic Thiem, who took [Alexander Zverev], someone people talk about a lot, deep into five sets. "Then you have Juan Martin del Potro who came back from three elbow operations. You knew he wasn't anywhere near 100 fit, yet he pushed me extremely close. Kei Nishikori, who had quite bad wrist trouble for periods of time, started way behind schedule compared to everyone else. But when he plays well... Oh man, he hits such big forehands and serves huge, moves extremely well for 6ft 5in guy. There were some tough guys."

Aston Villa's Jordan Ayew opened the scoring on 62 minutes, curling the ball past Ley Matampi in the Leopards goal. Paul-Jose M'Poku equalised for DR Congo with a sensational long-range strike just two minutes later but that was as good as it got for them before Kwarasey took centre stage to shut up shop and seal victory for Cameroon late into injury time of extra time. Yannick Bolasie first had an effort saved by Matampi early on while his former Everton teammate John Bostock also found himself thwarted from range shortly after coming off the substitutes bench midway through the second half. Despite dominating possession throughout they struggled to create chances until the latter stages when Allan Nyom forced another save out of the goalkeeper following some nifty footwork inside the area. "We played well against strong opponents," said DR Congo coach Florent Ibenge. "I'm not happy about conceding so many goals because I don't think we deserved this."

Emergency services were called to the scene at Main Road, where the A78 Largs to Seamill road was closed to traffic. The woman's 60-year-old husband and the lorry driver, 54, also from Dumfries have been taken by ambulance for treatment. The northbound section of the M8 is now opened but there are long delays due to a lane closure on approach as well as diversions in place around Junction 29a (Girvan). Traffic Scotland said motorists can expect heavy congestion all morning with an average speed of just 10mph. It tweeted: "TRAFFIC - Northbound M8 J29A (Dumbarton) towards FifeClyde has reopened after earlier collision near B8028 RHC Roundabout, however there remains significant tailbacks. The singer - who is the first woman to win the award twice - also won best pop vocal album and best music video for her track Bad Blood. Whether or not he is on the formal menu, Mr Snowden will certainly colour their conversation and the press conference that follows. With President Obama also due in Berlin later in July - albeit just days after delivering his Oval Office address justifying US surveillance programmes - her visit risks being overshadowed by Mr Snowden, who has been given asylum in Russia until August 1st. Couples have been decorating the Ponte Milvio bridge on the river Tiber with locks for several years. They are meant to symbolise the locking of hearts, inspired by a story from St Augustine's Confessions about two lovers who were forbidden to see each other and so locked their souls together instead (Augustine was Bishop in Rome). The couple said they chose this spot because it has always attracted people looking into love affairs - some more successful than others! The tradition is copied in many countries around the world where couples exchange keys or sometimes even rings as symbols that strengthen the bond between them.

The Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) missed a deadline to name a squad for the tournament after the International Cricket Council (ICC) changed its revenue-sharing model. However, with the Indian board now having agreed terms on sharing more money from world cricket's governing body it has been able to put together its panel and announced their 15-man squad which includes two uncapped players - Prithvi Shaw who played his first international match against West Indies last month while Kuldeep Yadav is also set to make debut at just 21 years old. "We are delighted that Virat Kohli will lead Team India into this premier event," said BCCI Acting Secretary Amitabh Chaudhary." The side has consistently performed well over the past three seasons but winning the Champions Trophy would be special as we begin celebrations marking the birth centenary year of our beloved Bharat Ratna Shri Vallabbhai Patel," he added further.Virat Kohli is only one player retained from India's victorious campaign back in 2013 when they beat England in the final by six wickets under MS Dhoni's captaincy.There were speculations whether Rohit Sharma or Ravichandran Ashwin could have made way due to lack of form but both batsmen kept their places in the team given their performances on away tours recently."India had some great outings overseas in 201516 season where the side registered Test series victories in South Africa and Australia apart from clinching an unprecedented maiden triumph Down Under," Ajay Shirke, treasurer of BCCI stated. "Our limited overs teams too did extremely well across all formats during those times however what gave us immense satisfaction was how these wins were achieved especially by the youngsters such as Rishabh Pant, Hardik Pandya etc.,"he concluded. The US-owned retail firm, which processes hundreds of thousands of online orders each week, could have put millions of transactions at risk, security expert Paul Moore estimates. He first noticed the problem in December when he was searching for a Dunkin' Donuts order to track its progress on Google Maps from his home in Boston and found it had been processed by an anonymous website that appeared not only to be outside America but also beyond any reach of police or prosecutors. As more visitors began checking out with PayPal, Mr Moore says: "I realised they were using payment processors based all over Europe," adding there are probably many other cases where customers who did not see their transaction as suspicious may now be vulnerable if charges start appearing against them later this year because Eurocard is no longer liable for breaches of consumer law.

Conservative-run Bath and North East Somerset Council is holding a presentation of initial concept pictures of the redevelopment. Banes recently agreed it had to save PS2.6m from its PS351m budget for 201516 because government cuts are hitting local authorities hard, with central government funding falling by 36 in real terms between 2009 and 2014. The meeting will be held at 7pm on Thursday 10 December at St Mary Redcliffe church hall (former church site), 25 Great Pulteney Street, Bath BA1 1EY BANES' council leader Sue Wootton said: "We have been working closely alongside our partners to ensure that we develop plans which retain an iconic building like this one." Planners' drawings show how some housing could go behind what was once known as Dollands Hill School - but there would still be space left over near Victoria Park if more homes were built than shown here. There's also room outside the buildings where new cycle lanes or public spaces might appear. A club house has already gone on top of number 13, while 15 looks set to become offices. And although 17 should stay residential too, councillors say further changes may yet happen before any applications come forward.

Wallace's name might not have the same cachet as Keegan, Dalglish or Rush but his place in Liverpool history is unassailable - he scored the club's first European goal. His absence from that list of illustrious names reveals how much has changed at Anfield since then and while some fans may be reluctant to forgive him for leaving when they did, it would do them good to learn what happened next. Liverpool signed Sadio Mane (above) just months after selling Wallace PA Photos Enlarge As soon as Kenny left a year later by mutual consent, owner John W Henry was on the phone offering Carroll 100,000-a-week - more than any other player in English football except Wayne Rooney and David Beckham. The deal prompted muttering among supporters who wondered why their manager had been sacked before being replaced with a striker whose best days were behind him because of injury problems. It led to the famous 'zeitgeist' tweet from Ian Ayre: "Our zeigiest signing ever." Sure enough, within two years Carroll made only one appearance under Roy Hodgson and spent most of the second half of last season out injured again. He seems destined never to fully justify such wages but even so there remains an astonishing gulf between his status now and the position held previously by few players in the club's whole history. Twenty years ago this week Michael Owen arrived at Anfield. He cost around 17m but didn't start scoring regularly until late 200203; six months earlier, after joining Newcastle United on loan, he'd won the FA Cup against all odds. Yet no matter where you stand on transfers these days, nobody could accuse Sir Alex Ferguson of misjudging his arrival into Manchester United's forward line. Few imagined a time when both Luis Suarez and Daniel Sturridge would surpass Owen's total return of 91 goals in 172 appearances yet here we are. Instead, argues Gary Neville in his new book, money can buy success if used correctly but only once certain conditions are established. Transfer policy should reflect long term strategy rather than short term necessity I don't think premiership clubs know anything about building a team and structural changes to training methods must also take place alongside investment strategies designed specifically to provide young talent with opportunities. In short, everything needs tweaking. On Sunday evening a million people watched Steven Gerrard lift another Premier League trophy up above his head which meant something special given those closest to him knew better than anyone else exactly what it took to get there. While others will argue that 30 years without winning silverware isn't acceptable, perhaps instead we need to accept that times change and priorities shift. There'll always be pressure but sometimes expectations are unrealistic. Nowhere does that apply more than at Real Madrid. If Barcelona win La Liga too it means three league titles in four seasons plus Copa del Rey victories mean Pep Guardiola has surpassed Del Bosque's achievements despite spending far less over the course of five campaigns than Jose Mourinho during his own run of dominance at Chelsea. But hey ho, let us put aside our differences and celebrate progress along the way. Just try telling that to Liverpool fans still awaiting justice following Heysel and Hillsborough... Ethnically it is highly diverse, with more than 300 local languages. The people range from rural hunter-gatherers to a modern urban elite. Sophisticated kingdoms existed before the arrival of the Persians around 1200 BC, and were later replaced by Greco-Bactrian rule (525-330BC), Achaemenid Persia until about 200 AD, Kushan Empire between 150 and 280 AD, Indo-Scythian Kingdom at some time in this period, followed finally by Seleucids who controlled most of Bactria during their reigns as well. In the 1st century CE, Parthia was part of the Roman province of Mesopotamia, which also included Babylonia, Syria Palaestina, Armenia Minor, Cilicia, Pontus and Pamphylia. In addition, there are records showing that parts of Sogdiana, Arachosia and Transoxania belonged to the diocese of Daraene in the early 2nd century CE but may have been lost after being annexed into Turkic empires such as Gokturk or Seljuq Turks. Armenians ruled here for many centuries; however they never managed to capture the heartland areas beyond the Oxus river valley even though two invasions under Tigranes II and Artaxias I resulted only in minor territorial gains along the borders against the Scyths. During his campaigns in 21011CE Alexander the Great moved through the territory on both banks of the Indus River looking for an easier route across India back to Greece. Under Emperor Diocletian's reforms circa 284, Bactra became one of five bishoprics added to the list within the newly created ecclesiastical Province of Asia.[10] The Han dynasty established its first border outpost here during the mid 3rd century BCE when they built fortresses along the road from Taxila to Kucha. With the fall of the Western Xia kingdom in 221, the Hunnic empire emerged out of what had previously been known as Xiongnu land and then invaded China proper via Central Asian nomadic tribesmen including the Alans, Magyars and Khazars respectively moving westwards towards Eurasia over the Tian Shan mountains and plundering Lamedan and Termez enroute. They came very close to breaching Chinese defences near Shiyan forcing Cao Pi to send envoys to treat with them while he prepared to launch another campaign himself but died shortly afterwards leaving orders not to advance further without him. His successor Jin Shiji declined contact due to concerns regarding possible corruption among the marauders so instead sent emissaries led by Fan Jian he met at Sui to purchase protection money as compensation for past losses suffered against them since 386 (see Records of Grand Historian). By 450 the western frontier army stationed at Bactra consisted mainly of Korean mercenaries brought up to speed on military matters according to official histories written years later although probably arrived earlier if reports based upon archaeological evidence dating sites like Tash Bulak can be believed[citation needed]. Although sometimes referred to elsewhere simply as "Koreans" these troops did not come from Korea per se rather were recruited from various ethnic groups inhabiting northern China just south of Manchuria comprising Yue people from the league states, Yuezhi from what would become southern Mongolia plus others identified either by name Hani or origin Han depending on whether referring directly to modern Koreans or using older descendent names used prior to Qin unification e.g.: 'Yue' 'Jin'. This suggests that much has changed over those 500 years especially following the introduction of Buddhism paving the way for trade throughout central Asia leading inevitably toward eventual recognition of political unity resulting eventually in the birth of unified Goryeo Dynasty in 918. Some historians have gone so far as suggesting that the presence of Korean forces themselves helped create conditions favoring the spread of Christianity thereby laying foundations for future reunification efforts centered initially upon Joseon Dynasty and ultimately developed - albeit intermittently - culminating today in North South Koreas joining hands once again creating yet another potential buffer state isolating China completely should hostilities arise. Another factor making war less likely now might possibly lie hidden deep beneath Earth's surface where scientists suggest vast reserves of natural gas could potentially transform almost all industrial activity worldwide away from fossil fuels currently generating greenhouse gasses causing global warming. Those deposits alone are estimated to dwarf current proven oil reserves. It therefore seems unlikely any nation will want to risk disrupting regional stability by sparking conflict unless convinced otherwise - something which goes hand-in-hand with recent moves made publicly encouraging bilateral talks aimed at forging peaceful relations unlike decades ago when U.S.-led Vietnam War caused widespread destruction killing millions despite claims neither side wanted anything other than peace. For now Bactrians remain happy trading partners sharing cultural similarities common to neighboring peoples sticking together relatively peacefully compared to say Persian Gulf Arabs facing off Iran while Uzbekistan maintains good neighborly ties too recently sending medical aid to flood ravaged Pakistan meeting popular demand perhaps because human rights abuse allegations levied against leaders. Artis Sterkis, 37, collapsed on the Peterhead-registered Starlight Rays. He was taken to hospital by rescue helicopter after the incident in August 2011, but he never regained consciousness. James Thores by and Paul Gray were also injured when they fell from a boat shortly before Mr Sterkis's death. The men had been working for Broughty Ferry firm Marine Scotland during an oyster dredging operation at Ardnamurchan Point near Loch Etive of west Argyllshire. They are believed to have been using rope lines attached to their craft that became detached as it approached land. The court heard how in his evidence Mr Gray stated: "We took evasive action because I thought we would hit something sharp like rocks or reefs - which is what happened next... We lost our footing with one line between us all resulting in me being knocked unconscious into water where my head struck rockreef causing injury [and] serious damage." A second impact occurred later while recovering equipment, again knocking him out cold. Lifeboat crews found them 50 metres offshore swimming towards shore with difficulty due to severe muscle damage caused by saltwater immersion. It emerged there was no emergency plan made available at work and only basic first aid training provided within job description guidelines.

During the meeting, he touched the girl over her clothing and then indecently assaulted her by touching himself inappropriately at around 7pm on July 28 last year. Afterwards, police said Aiden told the girl to keep it "a secret" and not tell anyone or she would be in big trouble - something they say was part of his grooming process. The court heard that during interview Aiden claimed he had only kissed the complainant's hand but accepted some sexual contact may have occurred after taking cocaine earlier in the day. He also admitted sending a series sexually explicit images from Snapchat while pretending to be someone else which were later found on her phone when officers searched it following the complaint being made. Defence counsel Paddy MacDermott said: "He is obviously ashamed about what has happened." Mr MacDermot added: "This young man says he met this individual online using a fake profile." Recorder Liggett QC handed down an eight month sentence suspended for two years along with 100 hours community service and sex offender treatment requirements. The judge stressed the defendant could spend up to three months behind bars if he breached any aspects of his post release supervision order set out within 18-months.

Radwan Hamed collapsed during a game in Belgium in 2006. Last year a judge ruled Spurs breached its duties to him. In a screening prior to signing for the club, Tottenham assured his father he would only play around 60 minutes per week and take no more than two matches on consecutive days Hamed is calling for an end of all forms of youth football until after a concussion test has been introduced into UK legislation - which could be as early as 202021 season. The former Fulham defender said there was 'no chance' that had happened if Radzhab Butaev's death hadn't occurred eight years ago following a similar incident while playing for Dynamo Moscow against Spartak Moskva with Mr Butayev suffering brain damage from collision injuries sustained at White Hart Lane. He added it should also not apply just to professional players but youngsters across England too. It comes amid growing concern over how young people are being exposed to health risks through repeated concussions without any protection from authorities or governing bodies.'I'm so angry about what I've witnessed,' added Mr Hamed who hopes ministers will help bring together campaigners including MPs, sportsmen and women to monitor their progress towards safer sport.The ex-defender pointed out: "There have been nearly 200 deaths since 2000 due directly to head impacts (across) rugby league, American Football, ice hockey, boxing and cycling yet no one wants to listen."He explained: Former footballer] Dave Whelan used to say you can die standing up - well where did they think this mentality came from? Why do we accept children getting knocked unconscious when society doesn't even allow us to hit them back?'Mr Hamed described himself as living proof parents need to know exactly what happens before agreeing to let their child join teams - especially given new research indicates those taking part show signs immediately after injury."My son went straight down," recalled Mr Hamed whose 11-year-old boy suffers ongoing symptoms today from multiple concussive blows received training at local academy Chigwells FC five years ago playing seven v seven games last August.Despite showing clear signs such as dizziness, headaches, nausea, vomiting along with neck stiffness later some weeks were wrongly dismissed by doctors as normal teenage aches rather than serious issues related to a previous blow suffered earlier in life.We didn't realise then because my wife didn't speak English very well and she thought maybe her baby needed extra attention" added the dad adding once home tests revealed a blood clotting problem suspected to relate to clots forming within veins potentially causing increased pressure inside the skull it took three months however - despite still seeing problems six months afterwards -before it reached official recognition."They told me CTE [chronic traumatic encephalopathy] wasn't really a thing here. We heard nothing else other than our GP saying don't worry your kids get bumps every now again.It only started affecting Alex recently - like four months ago. He gets migraines everyday; severe ones lasting 12 hours sometimes. He says things go black for him suddenly often accompanied by painful whiplash type pain behind his eyes.Doctors want us to wait until the condition deteriorates further before doing anything but now it needs addressing sooner rather than later. " This must happen soon to prevent others experiencing this kind of thing " urged Mr Hamed pointing out:"Myself and thousands of families are going to reach out personally to politicians asking why millions isn't spent making sure this never ever happens to another kid or adult " .A spokesman for government watchdog Sport England responded:'Sport England recognises the importance of player welfare and safety.'However, whilst evidence continues to develop regarding dementia risk associated with heading balls, specific mechanisms driving these effects remain unclear. As the science develops, information gathered may lead to opportunities for change and investment in sporting activities'.A spokesperson for World Rugby maintained everyone involved knows the dangers posed but noted: " We believe current measures provide adequate levels of care for athletes " .

The West Ham striker is charged with driving a car while a baby was being held by a passenger. Snodgrass, 29, is alleged to have driven on Duke Street, Glasgow, in March last year without insurance or a valid licence and failed to stop when required to do so by PC Stephen Ainslie of the Road Policing Unit (RPU). He allegedly did not provide information regarding his driving as soon as practicable after the incident which happened at 4pm. Snodgrass appeared before Sheriff Alan Mackinnon and pled guilty to all three charges against him from an indictment that had been served on him earlier this month. The court heard there would be no further complaint about what he said but sentencing has now been deferred until next week for reports to assess whether he poses any danger to children.

General Vladimir Padrino tweeted that the "leaders and masterminds of the paramilitary and terrorist assault" had been arrested. The suspects are a 38-year-old former captain, Juan Carlos Caguaripano Scott, and three other men who were part of an armed civilian group called Patria y Libertad (Fatherland and Freedom). Padrino said they would be charged with treason for plotting to topple Maduro's administration in collusion with Colombia's government as well as drug trafficking charges related to the seizures of about 20 tonnes cocaine destined for European markets since May 2012. The Venezuelans detained will also face criminal proceedings including money laundering and arms smuggling among others, he added. Scott was caught on Sunday night driving towards La Guaira aboard one of two vehicles carrying explosives stolen by Venezuelan police from the National Guard, according to authorities. In total more than 700 people have been held during anti-government protests over shortages of food, medicine and basic supplies. More demonstrations are planned this week against Maduro's decision to set up a constituent assembly that opposition leaders say is aimed at consolidating his power. - Reuters

Media playback is not supported on this device Drogba, 39, has not played since leaving Major League Soccer club Montreal Impact in November. He will start out as a player -coach with the Chinese side Chelsea great Didier Drogba says he "isn't coming back" to play for his former team after joining Shanghai Shenhua as their new player-manager until June 2015. The Ivory Coast striker was unveiled by the Super League champions at a news conference before Monday's home game against Guangzhou RF. Drogba said: "I'm still working and I want to make sure that if you have my name it means something." He added that he had been offered other jobs by clubs but chose China because of its "big population." Drogba won four Premier Leagues during eight seasons at Stamford Bridge between 2004 and 2012, scoring 157 goals - many of them spectacular free-kicks or headers from set pieces. A 24m move to Ligue 1 side Marseille followed last summer, where he scored 26 times across all competitions including nine penalties. The 36-year-old then returned to Chelsea briefly following Frank Lampard's departure, playing five more games before retiring. external-link Shanghai are eighth while Sunday's opponents Guangzhou sit top having lost only once so far under Andre Villas Boas.

Scott, whose victory chances were hit by a mechanical failure in the second race on Friday, came fourth in the medal race to claim silver overall. Tom Squires won RS:X gold and was third overall after two events for Great Britain while Matt Gotrel finished seventh out of nine sailors on Monday morning to take bronze. The finale saw GB's Pip Hare finish fifth with her team-mate Sophie Weguelin sixth as they claimed ninth place overall from their three regattas over 10 days. "We've had such hard training sessions," said Scott afterwards.

He was taken to the Royal Sussex County Hospital following the incident just before 06:00 BST on Saturday. He is reported to be in a stable condition. Sussex Police said it believed there were no suspicious circumstances surrounding his fall, but that officers would continue with "further inquiries." The BBC reports Mr Farage has been discharged and returned home from hospital.

No, President Xi Jinping of China isn't back for second helpings from the Buckingham Palace banquet, this time it is the Indian prime minister who is stopping by. India has a seventh-largest economy in the world and just won its biggest cricketing victory against England on home soil - beating them 4-1 at Lord's to win their first ever Test series there. India was also hailed as one of Britain's leading trade partners outside Europe last year along with Australia after signing 18bn worth of deals including two aircraft carriers (which will be built off the coast of Mumbai), military helicopters and nuclear power plants that are expected to create thousands more jobs across the UK. The Queen needs no reminding what an important ally she has been in helping keep her country safe over so many years during the Cold War

Cyber-attacks, trolls, terrorist propaganda, sexism, racism, Twitter mobs.... stop the web now, Mr Berners-Lee, we want to get off. So, when it came to compiling 2015's list of the most influential people on social media (a title bestowed by a panel that included me), I was disappointed not one person had been nominated from this planet - let alone the whole wide Web itself. Now Sir Tim has finally stepped forward with his own choice for No 1 and its none other than everyone's favourite animated lemming, Pepe The Frog (pepethefrog). He is also accompanied in his top 10 spot by some famous faces including Barack Obama (4) who tweets so rarely he could be forgiven if he remained anonymous; Tom Hanks (5); Justin Bieber (7); Kim Kardashian 8and... wait for it... Donald Trump at 9! This should come as no surprise given how much traffic both accounts generate but still, surely even realDonaldTrump must have better things to do? Then again maybe those fake Time magazine covers were more important after all...

The scooter Danny Glass was riding on with Sophie Emma Rose Anderson collided with a truck in Phuket on 8 May. Mr Glass, 29, originally from Margate, escaped serious injury. The driver of the vehicle that struck him has been arrested by police and charged for reckless driving causing damage to property or person.

Once Kyle Abbott dismissed Sri Lanka captain Angelo Mathews for 59 in the third over of the day in Port Elizabeth, the tone was set. Abbott (2-38), Kagiso Rabada (3-77) and Vernon Philander (4-66) then ripped through a batting line up that has been struggling with illness this week to help South Africa ease into a 2-1 series lead heading into next weekend's final test at Johannesburg. The visitors were bowled out for 183 after tea on the second day before spinner Keshav Maharaj grabbed two wickets including his maiden five-wicket haul in tests as they slumped to 120 all out 20 overs later. It is only their fourth loss ever by an innings margin away from home against South Africa and leaves them facing another bleak trip back across the country just days before Christmas. "To be honest we really didn't expect it," said left hander Thirimanne, who top scored with 47 off 127 balls and shared a 63-run partnership with former skipper Mahela Jayawardene (30). "We thought if AB de Villiers got going he could carry us but unfortunately our batsmen couldn't do what they did last time." On previous tours to South Africa, young players such as Kumar Sangakkara failed when put under pressure while Tillakaratne Dilshan struggled outside Colombo International Stadium. This tour, though, began more promisingly than most having won the first game convincingly in Durban thanks largely due to centuries by old hands like Thilan Samaraweera and Sanga. They also managed one each here from youngsters Niroshan Dickwella (64 not out) and Roshen Silva (56), both relatively untested international cricketers, which gave some hope to the future of the side now led by De Silva. But once again the lack of experience showed as no other player made 25 or higher aside from those three knocks. The tourists had sent down 14 maidens in total during the day while picking up eight wickets and they continued in the same vein until lunch on Sunday where 18 runs came off 38 deliveries without losing a wicket. However, any hopes youngster Dhanushka Gunathilaka carried gained momentum when he pulled himself together amid a mini collapse immediately after lunch lasting 40 minutes. He hit four boundaries in his 39-ball fifty as well as sharing a 53-run stand with Tharindu Kaushal (19) to take 33 runs off the session and pull the score to 1466. His dismissal proved even better news for South Africa however when Abbot enticed Kaushal forward to edge behind moments later leaving debutant Vishwa Fernando stranded on nine at the crease alongside Surange, 17 not out, coming in at number 10. In between periods of play, team manager Asanka Gurusinha announced coach Graham Ford would miss the rest of the match after suffering chest pains earlier in the morning following the death of his mother late Saturday night. (AFP)

The home secretary wrote to cabinet colleagues in December seeking approval to "reduce significantly" one type of stop and search, Newsnight has learned. Despite setting a 12 December deadline, the Home Office has now told ministers that it will not be able to say until next month if police can carry out fewer than three quarter searches on suspects without first obtaining evidence they have committed or are about to commit an offence. Speaking exclusively to BBC Radio 4's Today programme after the letter was published by The Times newspaper this morning Mr Johnson said: "We need more flexibility when we're talking about stopping people who might pose a risk." He added he did want officers to feel empowered to use powers with some discretion - adding there were many examples where such stops had been positive for society as well as policing.

The concerns came amid Sportscotland plans to reduce sport funding in Scotland by 20. Scottish Athletics, which runs the initiative to encourage non-club runners to take exercise, said it was aware of the complaints and stressed that any issues were raised with them directly rather than via social media or other channels. Linda Curran, who lives on a hill near Stirling but is running for charity at this year's Virgin Money London Marathon has also been affected after she took part last week in her local race - the Jurassic 5k Fun Run. She had paid 12 before being told afterwards there would be no prize money if more than 40 people entered because each entrant would get a medal instead. However, only 29 entrants turned up so everyone got their medals without getting anything extra back from organisers, something they expected as the event costs just over 1,000 to put together including insurance. It then emerged that several others have complained about similar arrangements elsewhere since 2012. Curran says: "I went along expecting nothing except my medal and I found out what was happening when arriving home later. My worry now though is that those events haven't been cancelled yet despite clearly breaking rules while some appear not even notified of previous breaches until 2015! Couldn't these things have all been spotted earlier? This whole issue seems like an excuse too easily made to dodge paying winners prizes - especially given how many races are raising funds through entry fees alone." SportScotland say that although three sports where incidents happened did contact its team, none have reported apparent irregularities going forward following inspections conducted soon after receiving correspondence. Indeed two seem to have continued under new management whose focus will presumably include checking whether due process has always prevailed during existing timespans and particularly regarding recent years. The third instance involves Badminton England (which received one complaint) as well as both Northumberland Fire Service Rescue Authority and Durham County Council Sports Partnership Trust; neither body responded to requests seeking comment. In contrast, East Lothian Harriers Club treasurer Andrew Bruce tells AW he thinks his club followed official guidance correctly six months ago. At around the same time Glenrothes Athletic Club confirmed to AW that winning athletes do indeed receive cash prizes depending upon number of finishers plus medals per genderage group at its hosted parkrun series. For example at April's Woodhall Spa Parkrun, first place men aged 18-24 won 100 (6030). And while Glengairn Stonehaven AC remains committed it can offer either trophies, Tshirts, socks etc., never cold hard cash, it does pay into a central pool for the overall winner collected post run. But Simon Grant, chairperson of British Masters Track Running Association believes otherwise explaining why BMTRA has produced guidance specifically designed 'to avoid accusations of unfairness'. He stresses "races should give clear notice beforehand as to what awards may or may not be available." Meanwhile Scottish Athletics' Phil Smith adds: "We want our clubs to follow good practice giving full disclosure prior to events taking place" adding hat unless you spell everything out competitors could reasonably assume that it happens automatically.

Jon Schueler, who died in New York in 1992 at the age of 75, created many of his pieces from a studio in Mallaig in the Highlands. He was inspired by both Gaelic art and modernism - as shown in this enchanting picture of him with fellow artist Sheila Hicks In an interview for BBC Radio Scotland's Archive on 4 programme, Doors To Yesterday: The Art Of Jon Schmidt Schuwer (June 27), he said that pictures were 'an escape' because they let you see something else than what is going round your head.' The documentary also looks into how Highland emigrants viewed their work when it came back home to them after years away working elsewhere or living abroad. One such piece now hangs proudly above my front door. It shows two men standing outside a church before taking off together across some water. Growing up I remember seeing these figures occasionally; more often however, I saw one of the same figure but riding a pony. This painting had hung over our sofa in Tain until last year where we moved house during lockdown. My husband arranged its return straightaway once we found a new place here near Loch Ness. This beach scene has been described as being reminiscent of Gauguin's Tahitian paintings while others have likened it to Joaquin Sorolla's landscapes It might not be anything special if seen in isolation but coming fresh from Shiela Hicks's latest exhibition Altered States which opened just days earlier at Aberdeen Art Gallery seemed like perfect timing given her emphasis upon memory and dreams within artwork. In fact there are so many commonalities between Ms Hicks's beautiful composition and Mr Schlueter's work. Both seem other-worldly yet grounded somehow, perhaps due to the texture created through brushstrokes or paint application and both tap into memories already stored deep down inside us all anyway. My own paternal grandfather arrived in Australia around 1910 aged 12 without his parents leaving behind only a brother still under 10. Sadly he did not stay long enough to start any family himself although later generations would keep alive links via photographs, letters and stories about the old country. But even then immigrants rarely mentioned much beyond the famine times and how hard life could get. When asked whether people liked Ireland, the answer nearly always became simply, "Well ye no fit!" There never seems to have been time to develop strong links with anyone apart from those closest to them especially once money started pouring out of the ground following gold rushes. Perhaps the real reason why locals don't talk too fondly of the past may well lie deeper still...

She's just been in the studio with Radio 1's Nick Grimshaw, trying to make him giggle while he goes about some serious radio presenting business; and she's daydreaming about her own show. "I'm thinking maybe I'll have a little one," says Billie as we chat on Zoom from Los Angeles during lockdown. "Or two." She pauses for effect: "No!" A guffaw erupts through my screen. "Oh God no! No way am I having kids right now or any time soon - it would be so dangerous [to bring them into this world]." Still, there is something endearing about how keen she seems to become part of another generation. Billie Eilish was 17 when Simon Cowell signed her up at his record label Syco Music four years ago (she turns 19 next month). Now that she has won five Grammys among many other awards...

Councils are relying on agency workers to cover nearly 4,000 out of 5,500 otherwise empty posts. Social workers say they are under constant pressure because of media coverage and criticism from politicians about children whose cases have been in the headlines for months or years without resolution. The number of child protection plans - a form that must be prepared by social services staff when concerns are raised about a family's ability to care for their child safely - has doubled since 2013-14, with more than 130,350 being drawn up last year alone. The figures also show councils saw an increase in referrals made by schools which resulted in safeguarding actions such as home visits and educational support increasing by 6 between 201516 and 201819 after rising at double digit rates every other preceding tax year. In total there were 362,267 education safeguarding contacts recorded during this period compared to 320,895 five years earlier.

All four opposition parties at Holyrood want to repeal the football act. But the Scottish government says it will not do so without a "viable alternative" being put in place. The BBC's political editor Nick Eardley asked Ms Sturgeon how she would respond if there was promotion and relegation from Scotland next season, but no access for Premiership clubs competing against international teams like England or France?

Turner, who spent nine years as a player with Posh before winning back-to-back promotions as manager in the early 1990s, was diagnosed with frontal lobe dementia in 2006. His wife Debbie has been his full-time carer for 10 years and set up Dementia Friends earlier this year to raise awareness of Alzheimer's disease. "We are delighted that Shaun will be joining us at our game on Saturday," said chairman Mark Lawn. "It is vital we continue to find ways to engage people more closely with dementia and offer support to those living with it."

Friend, who cut his face, was treated in the tunnel before being taken to hospital, where he stayed overnight. The incident happened as the first half came to an end with Chelsea leading 1-0 thanks to new signing Alvaro Morata's goal from close range. Chelsea were awarded a penalty shortly afterwards but Eden Hazard - scorer of two spot kicks on Saturday at Arsenal saw his effort saved by Willy Caballero and they went into halftime ahead despite PSG having more than 70 percent possession. In their postgame interviews manager Antonio Conte said it would be "stupid" for him not to give Sergio Aguero some game time after such a long injury break so the Argentine forward joined David Silva among substitutes against Qarabag while Alexis Sanchez remained sidelined. City then edged out Celtic 2-1 away through goals either side of halftime from Bernardo Silva and Ilkay Gundogan although Pep Guardiola will have been unhappy that Fernandinho conceded a late penalty that Moussa Dembele converted.

The United Airlines flight UA2081 took off from Edinburgh Airport at 14:22 but declared a second emergency a short time later. It comes a day after the same aircraft diverted to the city following an engine issue A statement by the airport read: 'United UA2081 has returned to EIY as a precautionary measure. There are no reported injuries and all passengers have been disembarked safely.' Pictured, left, is Aiman Riaz who filmed flames coming out of his seat on Tuesday's plane (right) in footage posted online Fire crews were also called last night when fire broke out inside one of the engines during its landing approach to San Francisco International Airport. The incident was caught on video and shows smoke billowing into the cockpit and cabin before firefighters arrived It came just two days after another troubled passenger jet made an emergency landing in the Scottish capital due to reports that debris had fallen onto the wings while it flew over Manchester. Edinburgh-based airline Loganair tweeted: 'We can confirm that our united scheduled service from EDI to SFO has turned around as a result of a technical fault with their aircraft. We will process customers' refunds rebook them via new services'.

The Latics are seven points from safety with six games remaining including tough trips to Brighton and Reading. David McGoldrick put Ipswich ahead midway through the first half, slotting in at a corner after Luke Chambers's header was saved by Marek Rodak who was then also beaten by Jordan Spence following good work on the left flank by Freddie Sears. Sears had earlier seen an effort cleared off the line but it wasn't enough as Matt Penney doubled Town's lead just before half-time when he beat James Wilson for pace down the right and provided a low cross which deflected past Rodak via Kyle McFadzean. Wigan improved considerably towards the end of the game though Leam Richardson will be disappointed that his side didn't add to their tally having enjoyed plenty of possession during the second period. (Reporting by Simon Evans Editing by Christian Radnedge)

Former Newmarket Town player Shaun Whiter lost both his legs when he was hit helping his friend Joey Abbs to change a tyre near the Suffolk town. Abbs suffered a broken back and ribs while suffering from hypothermia after he fell into icy water during their ordeal on 22 January 2003, which lasted more than 10 hours in freezing conditions before they were rescued by coastguards at Great Yarmouth. Joey's mum Diane still visits Shaun every Saturday (PA) More Whiter said: "I can't describe how it feels that 20 years later we are going out there together for this event. We have been through all sorts of emotions over these last two decades but I know Joe will be with me throughout tonight."

It said it had taken a PS235m charge after it agreed a deferred prosecution with the Serious Fraud Office and the Financial Conduct Authority in March. However, Tesco said it would receive 129m from litigation costs held by lawyers at Freshfields Bruckhaus Deringer LLP which have already been submitted to investors last year. Tesco's settlement wiped 12pc off its value on Friday afternoon as shareholders digested news that profits were likely down 18pc this financial year. The company also cut forecasts for next year but stressed that "we are not returning to our previous guidance."

Terrie Kirby, 16, Alexandra Binns, 18, Ryan Beal, 20, and Brandon Brown, 20, died following the crash on the A6201 between Upton and Hemsworth on 27 September. The men from Leeds were all due to start university in the autumn. The couple's friends have set up a fundraising page for their funeral costs which has already raised nearly 1,200 towards its target of more than 2,000.

Social media videos shot in the Plaza Major showed injured fans and officers in body armour wielding batons. BBC journalist Phil Mackie confirmed police used baton charges to clear parts of the crowd, including one mounted officer who was filmed striking a supporter on his horse with his lance as he led it through crowds towards the stadium. The Nottingham Forest FA Cup tie at home to Derby County went ahead after being moved from 3pm until 5:30pm local time ( GMT). Police said they had made several arrests before kick off but there were no further incidents during the game itself. Nottinghamshire Police assistant chief constable Rob Griffin explained that the decision not to stop people coming into the ground did so because "after three or four hours we're fundamentally unable to say 'you can come out'." The Premier League fixture between Arsenal and Tottenham Hotspur in north London has been called off due to safety concerns over fans gathering outside Emirates Stadium for an expected protest march against US owner Stan Kroenke's role in the failed European Super League project.

In front of a home crowd in Birmingham, 27-year-old Yafai won 118-108, 119-107 and 119-107 on the judges' scorecards. Yafai knocked down the 31-year-old Japanese in the second round, but was unable to finish him off with his superior power punches before the bell sounded for the start of the next stanza. Vargas (25-2) began looking more dangerous after that early scare from Yafai as he rallied back into contention by flooring the Briton twice late in the third session. The Mexican challenger's best chance at an upset came earlier when referee Paul Latham gave Vargas time out while Yafai recovered from another knockdown during the fourth frame. "I knew it wasn't over," said Yafai who improved his record to 26 wins against three losses since turning professional almost five years ago. "He got caught good shots - big shot. He is a tough guy." There were not many fans among 1,000 spectators allowed inside Edgbaston Arena because Britain has entered its third national lockdown this week due to surging Covid cases amid fears about new variants first discovered in South Africa and Brazil. But those lucky enough to attend were treated to some thrilling action between two former world champions.

Media playback is not supported on this device Wednesday's 3-0 defeat at Sunderland was the second time they have conceded three goals since losing to Manchester United at Wembley on 20 May. "I'm sure if you ask a number of players, I don't want to name them but there will be some performances which we can all say were below what you expect," said Rodgers. "There are certain individuals who played better than others and that needs to improve as well." The former Swansea City manager added: "We need more consistency within our play because when it comes down to making good decisions in attacking areas then unfortunately for us - especially going forward from midfield into those key positions where you're looking to exploit space behind defenders - on too many occasions today it just wasn't happening enough. We weren't really moving with any speed or penetration."

The 42-year-old had regained the lead from Frenchman Armel Le Cleac'h, but was second as he passed the halfway mark just off New Zealand's south island. Thomson's next milestone is to make it back across India and onto Europe for a third attempt at the record in July or August which will be one of his last before retiring after almost four decades on the road. He first rode unsupported around the world with no fixed route between September 12 2001 until November 11 2002 when he reached Cape Town via South America (18 months) then Australia, Indonesia, Malaysia, Thailand, Vietnam, Laos, Cambodia, Myanmar, Pakistan, Iran, Turkey, Greece and Italy (20 months). His trip could not have been more different this time round though: instead of riding alone (with occasional support rides by friends including fellow Briton Anita Stewart), Thomson has spent much of the past three years travelling on two wheels with wife Victoria who took up tandem cycling along the way. "It really felt good today," said an emotional Thompson afterwards." I knew if we got through that night we'd get there eventually so even having 7 hours sleep wasn't too bad considering what happened yesterday... It means everything - all our lives are here now; its home sweet home to us!" The couple plan a few weeks recuperation then return together later this summer on their own bikes while they decide whether to stay in Australia permanently or head over to New Zealand again where some family members live.

The 26-year-old scored 20 goals in 52 games for Bristol City, after signing from French club Angers in July 2015. The Ivory Coast international had also been the subject of a bid by Watford during his time at Ashton Gate. "I am very happy to be here and can't wait to get started," Konsa told Villa's website. "This is my first move abroad so I'm excited about that and looking forward to it."

The group, a mix of students and activists, were arrested while taking part in a protest two weeks ago against a new education bill. They face possible jail terms on charges including "incitement to subvert state power." Several other people have also been detained since the crackdown began last week but no formal arrest warrants have yet been issued for them.

They feature on the International Impac Dublin Literary Award's 2016 longlist, alongside BBC journalist Kirsty Wark's debut The Legacy of Elizabeth Pringle.
