The 35-year-old wing has signed for the Mitsubishi Dynaboars in Division Two of the Japanese League on a one-year deal. Williams scored twice in his final competitive game as Ospreys. Williams, who won two Heineken Cups and five Pro12 titles with Ospreys before signing for Toulon after last year's World Cup but then returning to Wales following the sacking of head coach Guy Noves at the start of this season, had been linked with joining Newcastle Falcons next term if they are able to secure promotion from Championship.

The county has received PS1bn of aid over the past 15 years with more than PS400m in the pipeline until 2020 because of its relatively weak economy. Cornwall Council leader Julian German said: "We've had a very successful relationship and we're looking forward to deepening that further."

Intense negotiations are under way between political parties amid public anger at a one-off levy of up to 10 being imposed on savers. President Nicos Anastasiades said refusing the bailout would be disastrous and there was no alternative but for parliament to pass it this week, most likely in an extraordinary session on Monday evening, before heading into recess until November 24. "I ask you from my heart...let us avoid anything that will lead Cyprus towards bankruptcy," he told deputies during his weekly address. "It is not ok to live beyond our means... We must do everything possible so we can face what lies ahead with confidence." Failure could force Cyprus out of the euro zone, its banks shut down, state coffers depleted by rescuing depositors' cash and pensions cut as part of tough austerity measures demanded by lenders. Prime Minister Antonis Samaras has warned lawmakers they have only two days left to back him or see their country slip over the precipice into economic chaos. The leader of main opposition party AKEL said he had agreed to support a second batch of bank restructuring plans if all sides discuss issues including wage cuts across government ministries first - otherwise he rejected any more bailout terms unless the measure was scrapped altogether. Earlier in the day, dozens of protesters marched though central Nicosia shouting slogans against politicians who were calling them to salvage the rescue deal which analysts say may need further adjustments worth 1.5 billion euros (1.9 billion). They held banners reading: "Enough! Enough!" and chanted: "Bankruptcy is better than humiliation." (Additional reporting by Michele Kambas; Writing By Michele Karamiotis)

Media playback is not supported on this device Five goals were scored in the first half, with Greg Stewart and Kane Hemmings striking early for Dundee. Ross County captain Andrew Davies scores from a corner to make it 2-2 after 78 minutes before Peter Pawlett's winner three minutes later Peter Pawlett gave St Johnstone an eighth win of their unbeaten run when his goal earned them victory over Rangers at McDiarmid Park. And Kilmarnock picked up only their second league success since October as they beat 10-man Hamilton Academical at Rugby Park. Kilmarnock twice came back from behind against Accies following Eamonn Brophy's penalty opener which was cancelled out by Scott Martin before Kyle Lafferty replied again. But Lee Erwin restored parity once more just before half time. But there would be no further scoring until substitute Alan Power put through his own net late on - although that could have been another home player had Alex Bruce managed to convert earlier efforts at both ends of the pitch.

Crews were called to the blaze at a building in Stewartville Street, in Partick, at about 12:15. The fire broke out in a communal area of the block. Four people have been taken to hospital as a precautionary measure and firefighters are still working on tackling flames there. A Scottish Fire Rescue spokesman said it was not known whether anyone had fled from the scene before crews got inside but that they found "a number" of casualties once they reached floor seven - which is above ground level).

Samuel Walker was fatally injured in a hit-and-run as he crossed a road in Chorlton, Manchester, in February 2003. Joyrider Nawnee Mackin, 35, was jailed for nine years in November 2006 after being found guilty of causing death by dangerous driving and failing to stop at the scene

Britain's three remaining sides in the competition have reached this stage for the second successive season, with champions Real Madrid, Bayern Munich and Barcelona also still in. The draw takes place on Friday evening at 0900GMT (1200BST). Manchester City take a one-goal lead into their last 16 tie against Swansea after Michu missed an injury time penalty to deny the Swans victory over 10 men Chelsea. However, Sergio Aguero made no mistake from 12 yards as he scored his first goal since November 8th following Fernando Torres' dismissal just before half-time. A win would see Roberto Mancini's side face either Juventus or Paris Saint Germain should they progress past Napoli - where Carlo Ancelotti has gone down fighting despite trailing 2-0 early in the second leg.

Attacking midfielder Christensen, 22, has played more than 50 games for the London side, but has not started a Championship match this season. Striker Woodrow, 22, has only started one game in all competitions and is yet to score his first goal at senior level. Midfielder Isaiah Brown, 20, who was on loan with League One club Shrewsbury last season before he returned to Chelsea after suffering an injury, also completes the quartet of players heading out on temporary deals from Stamford Bridge.

Adam King struck either side of the break in the 2-0 win over Reading at Liberty Stadium. In March, the Swans' development squad drew with Wolverhampton Wanderers to take the lead but let it slip late on before drawing 1-1 away against Bristol City last month after being pegged back from two goals down. The Swans now have three games left this term and they welcome Birmingham City to south Wales for a crunch clash next Saturday (3004). Steve Cooper's team will then travel out west once again as they face promotion rivals Brentford later that week (Wednesday 4 May) before ending their season by hosting Stoke City six days later.

There were 69 claims against peacekeepers in 2015, up from 52 in 2014 was 66 in 2013. Almost a third of the 2015 claims were made in the Central African Republic (CAR), where UN forces are helping local authorities to stave off sectarian violence between Muslim and Christian militias.

Duffy, 57, was charged with misconduct for entering the Hibs technical area at Easter Road on 29 March and adopting an aggressive attitude towards Lennon. The same complaint against assistant manager John Doolan was dropped by police but could still be heard in front of a Scottish Football Association disciplinary panel next month.

The Serbs lost 6-4 6-4 to Brazilians Marcelo Melo and Bruno Soares in Rio. The loss came a day after Djokovic was knocked out of the singles by Argentine Juan Martin del Potro, who went on to win with partner Federico Delbonis against Nikola MekticFranko Skugor from Croatia. Djokovic suffered another setback earlier this month when he split with his coaching team, bringing forward plans to restructure his support staff for next year following an early exit at Roland Garros which followed defeat in Rome. "I have made the decision that I need some time away from it all, to digest things, rethink my approach and my entire structure around me," said Djokovic, whose last grand slam title came at Wimbledon in 2016. A number of players including Dominic Thiem have expressed respect for the way Djokovic has handled what many believe is one of tennis' most difficult periods since the rise of Roger Federer to dominate men's tennis over more than a decade.

The 69-year-old also managed the Blues on a temporary basis for the final three months of the 2008-09 campaign. "I am excited to return," said the Dutchman. "Chelsea is one of Europe's leading clubs and I have enjoyed working here before, so this opportunity was too good to turn down." He will be assisted by his long-time assistant Gianfranco Zola - who replaced him at both Watford and West Ham United after he left Stamford Bridge in May 2013. Former midfielder Frank Lampard has been appointed as Chelsea Women manager on an initial 12 month contract with former France defender Claude Makelele joining the club's coaching set up alongside Jody Morris.

The hosts needed only 66 minutes and 82 deliveries to take the remaining seven England wickets in Centurion. Kagiso Rabada, 20, became the youngest South Africa bowler to take 10 Test match five-wicket hauls after removing both Alastair Cook (caught by Faf du Plessis) and Joe Root off successive balls on his way to figures of 5 for 51 from 15 overs as he wrapped up a series win that was achieved with plenty to spare. "We can't wait," said de Villiers at the post-match presentation ceremony when asked about facing Australia later this year. "It's been too long since we beat them."

Donald "Chip" Pugh texted police a photo of himself and wrote: "Here is a better photo that one is terrible." Police in Lima, Ohio, posted the photos to their Facebook page on Wednesday with an appeal for information about his whereabouts. They say they received tips from as far away as Virginia Beach, Va., after posting them to social media. Police say he's known by many aliases including Charles Pitman, Chip Taylor or Chuckie.

23 December 2016 Last updated at 01:13 GMT But much of India's milk is collected from small farms across the country, and by the time it reaches consumers it's impure . The EPA's report suggests that certain chemicals found in flame retardants are toxic to children when they're exposed through their diet. The use of these fire-retardant chemicals has been declining for years due to regulatory action (like eliminating them entirely or phasing out some uses) as well as public concern about how dangerous those chemicals can be, but many products containing such chemicals remain on store shelves today because manufacturers have yet to redesign the product so that it no longer contains chemical BPA or PBDE. That could change soon though - California recently passed a law banning sales of baby bottles sold after July 1st, 2018 unless they don't contain any bisphenol A. It will also ban other food containers with high levels of TDPP and PDBD starting next year.. He also spoke out against those who want to leave, saying: "If we let them win they will win all your votes as well."

Wasps goalkeeper Neil Parry had already denied Dobbie three times before the striker curled in a drive off a post. Parry saved again from Dobbie after the break, but the truth was that Raith were rarely troubled and they completed their job with two late goals to make sure of victory - although it must be said Hearts did not help themselves by missing several chances for consolation strikes thereafter. The first came when Liam Smith headed home an Adam King corner after 81 minutes. Two minutes later Lewis Vaughan made no mistake when charging clear down the left wing as he beat Jamie MacDonald. Meanwhile at Dunfermline, St Mirren moved into third place thanks to Danny Mullen's goal just past the hour mark against his former club while last season's runners-up Dundee United lost 2-0 away to Kilmarnock who are now unbeaten since September 21st. The visitors' defeat means Hamilton have won five on the trot following four consecutive clean sheets which has seen them go top of the league table ahead of second placed Livingston whose game with Motherwell is postponed due to international call ups.

Straker, 27, has been without a club since leaving York in January, where he made 27 appearances. He began his career at Crystal Palace and helped Aldershot Town win the National League South title before moving to Vale Park The defender is now available for selection after agreeing terms with Blues boss Danny Wilson following an initial trial period earlier this month which was due to continue on Friday night against Norwich City U23s (7pm kick-off).

Correspondents said the atmosphere at schools was subdued and many pupils had not returned. They said parents had been taken by surprise by the government's decision to reopen schools with immediate effect, adding that most of them were unaware of it until last night when they received messages from their children or heard about on television news stations last evening [Monday]. The Nation learnt some principals sent text message reminders to parents who did not pick up calls seeking clarification over the matter while others called aggrieved parents individually as soon as possible after getting information. The development came barely one week before public examination begins across the country. It has also prompted concerns among educators in private nursery, primary and secondary schools whose students are writing exams for external candidates this year. Federal Unity Colleges, which reopened yesterday, announced resumption dates ranging between May 4 and 17 depending on whether such institutions have national examinations scheduled during those periods. However, there is no indication yet if all other category of students would resume classes today (Tuesday). Sources close to ministries of education told our correspondents that Monday deadline given to proprietors of learning institutions could be reviewed based on the outcome of consultations with key stakeholders including the Presidential Task Force on COVID-19 headed by Mr Boss Mustapha; National Parents Teachers Association of Nigeria and state governors. Some school owners however queried why federal authorities rushed into reopening classrooms without considering what impact the new policy might have on both teachers and students. Others wondered how feasible it will be working under present circumstances where majority of countries around the world ordered closure of educational facilities due to coronavirus pandemic. A source within a top management staff of an international organisation overseeing education sector disclosed: "Last Thursday, I watched Minister Adamu Mohammed addressing journalists via televised presentation on the readiness of schools and he mentioned three major challenges facing us - lack of personal protective equipment like face masks that can guarantee safety against infection and social distancing." He added: "I think we should look for other options than opening schools now because many people may get infected through exposure to learners coming back to class." In Abuja, a parent simply identified as Mrs Okafor expressed anxiety over her daughter's return to school any moment from Tuesday. Though she noted that some measures put in place by the government showed seriousness on its part but insisted more needs to done especially on socialphysical distancing aspect. She explained further: "My daughter resumed on March 30th following announcement made earlier by President Muhammad Buhari then. When my husband got home last Friday, he asked me questions bordering on fears bothering on issues pertaining to health risk associated with sending kids back to school amid reports emerging globally concerning negative impacts of the virus. Finally, I gave him my consent to allow our child go back to school only because I noticed his increasing restlessness on her staying indoors since the stay-at-home order issued nationwide directive expired two weeks ago. We've prepared everything required here at home like sanitiser, hand gloves etc so that once she returns,we won't waste time doing things again. But, honestly speaking, I'm still worried.We just hope God doesn't answer our prayers otherwise,"she admitted. Another mother Dr Gloria Okoh in Zamfara State wrote from Gusau after receiving notification letter asking her son to come for schooling starting tomorrow even though WAEC registration date isn't fixed till June 2nd 2020. Her words: " Dear fellow Nigerians! Remember you supported me well when i paid JAMB fees for my 5 years old son? Today am happy to inform u that your support helped me alot...he tells everyone daddy bought TVS motorcycle. And now....ive seen the letters requesting us to pay N20,000 per annum each kid (not inclusive) from age 3 upward in addition 1st term instalment N18,500.00 payable immediately. " Also reacting to the issue, father Adamawa State resident urged governments at various levels not rush toward reopening schools insisting that lives matters first hence must take adequate precautions regarding protection of citizens' wellbeing. According to him: "Here comes another round of hard times ahead. Government shouldn't hurry towards reopening schools despite lockdown being relaxed. We're aware that these government officials live better life compared to average Nigerian workers out there struggling every day looking for food on daily basis. "Remember that governor Matawalle recently set aside billions of naira worth of palliatives meant for vulnerable families affected economically by Covid 19 restrictions. He didn't bother talking much about how judiciously distributed same but rather diverted huge amount of money to equip his security outfit codenamed 'Zamfara Security Network.' Honestly,this action alone shows glaring evidence that state executives don't really care much about poor masses. Only few rich individuals benefit from bloated funds meant to cater for needy households." The 34-year-old Sweden striker's contract with the French champions expires in the summer, and he has been linked with Manchester United, Los Angeles Galaxy and AC Milan. "I am very happy to be here," Ibrahimovic told reporters." I'm not a guy who talks much so if you want something from me then ask it directly. Nothing else is needed for my side... Let's see what happens at the end of this season - but now we are focused on getting back into shape after injury." Ibrahimovic suffered ligament damage when his knee collided with an elbow during a 4-3 win over city rivals Paris Saint Germain last April, which saw him sidelined until December before returning briefly towards the end of January. He did start PSG's first two games since football resumed following its suspension due to COVID-19 Ligue 1 victories against Strasbourg and Reims. However, coach Thomas Tuchel said Ibrahimovic would miss Saturday's trip to Nantes as well as Wednesday's Champions League clash away to RB Leipzig through injury. The??700,000 attraction will include a multi-sports arena, sporting events site and community facilities Bournemouth council leader Tudor Evans said: "We are delighted that we can make this much needed facility available for the benefit of local people."

The review into 22 abuse cases in Northern Ireland criticised the authorities for not doing enough. The young people went missing a number of times over a 20-month period while under supervision by Child and Family Agency (CFA) staff, including one who absconded 14 times between August 2014 and October 2015. Mr Hamilton said that "lessons must be learned." He acknowledged: "There were shortcomings." However he added that it was at this point difficult to make any recommendations as an independent inquiry had already been established.

Confessions had been forced from the Muslim men after they were beaten up in custody, a rights activist said. They were among a group of people arrested late last year. "They have confessed to their involvement because there was no other way for them," Rafiqul Islam Khan, head of NGO Odhikar who visited the jail with some relatives and lawyers on Thursday told Reuters by phone. "We are seeing that torture is being used as an instrument."

Zipporah Lisle-Mainwaring, 71, was accused of painting the candy stripes to "get her own back" on neighbours who objected to her property plans. She wanted to demolish her Kensington house and put up two new houses in its place but local councillors said it did not comply with planning regulations under a conservation area protection scheme. Ms Mainwaring claimed she had no prior knowledge about council rules as she arrived at court for trial earlier today (MON) wearing an Israeli flag necklace and shirt bearing the word Palestine.

It was a scrappy effort, which saved the game from going to what had seemed an inevitable penalty shootout. Stevie Mallan though had earlier missed the game's best chance for Hibs when he somehow blazed over after being found unmarked by substitute Florian Kamberi with just keeper Remigijus Geda to beat in first half added time but it mattered little as Neil Lennon's side won their fourth match on the trot and were deserved winners against opponents whose organised rearguard action frustrated them without ever really threatening seriously themselves notwithstanding Josh Magennis' header that looked destined for the top corner until Ofir Marciano came up trumps late on. The fact this victory also means they leapfrog Celtic at the summit of Scottish football at least momentarily will be lost amid all the post-match euphoria although if results go their way tomorrow night then Sunday afternoon should see Hibs move into pole position for the title provided St Mirren fail to win away to Dundee United today or next Wednesday evening when Rangers entertain Livingston at Ibrox. What is certain though is that there are no easy games left now regardless of who you're playing because so many sides have proved capable of ending a run of successive wins - indeed Hibernian played out back-to-back draws during one recent sequence while only Aberdeen can boast four victories in succession having thumped Motherwell 5-2 last weekend before claiming another three points here yesterday courtesy of goals scored inside 15 minutes either end of the second period. For much of ninety minutes yesterday however both teams struggled to create too much fluency despite plenty more encouraging signs than we've seen recently about Hibs' attacking play since Flo Kamberi signed on loan from Grasshoppers Zurich last week. Indeed the Swiss striker could hardly believe his luck upon finding himself free between two defenders following good work by Martin Boyle down the right wing early on yet still managed not to get off a shot although his pass did release Jamie Murphy whose subsequent low drive was well held by Rodyga Gedvilekas. The Lithuanian goalkeeper had been handed an unexpected start after regular No 1 Tomas Cerny pulled something in training prior to kick oht, hastening his return to Germany whereupon Zdenek Zlamal joined him on the sidelines through injury meaning inexperienced youngster Matt Macey made his third appearance since joining from Arsenal on a season long loan deal. It wasn't quite his dream debut given how easily Paul Hanlon sent the ball in his direction shortly afterwards but unlike some other goalkeepers who'd played alongside Ross McCrorie during pre-season, neither young man appeared overly concerned as the ball rolled under his body allowing Nisbet to tap home unopposed. And that would prove enough to give the hosts the lead even if they didn't dominate proceedings during a relatively tame opening quarter hour and certainly weren't creating anything themselves beyond taking pot shots straight from corners nor posing any real threat once Adam Jackson cut out Drey Wright's cross intended for Kevin Holt as far as Allan Campbell whose downward header drew a save from Marciano moments later..

The price of West Texas crude sank to 37.65 (PS24.99) a barrel, a drop of 5.8, while Brent Crude fell 5.3 to 40.73 a barrel. The slumping price comes as US oil inventories continue growing at record levels and the outbreak worsens around the world with more than 1 million confirmed cases. In addition, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell warned that economic recovery will take time even if businesses reopen quickly because it is unclear when people may be willing to resume spending money or attending large gatherings such as sporting events. In Asia, Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.6 percent, Hang Seng added 2 percent and KOSPI climbed 1.5 percent. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 closed higher by less than one point after fluctuating throughout Friday morning. Topix rose 0.4 percent. South Korea's Kospi surged 3.1 percent buoyed by tech stocks which were trading near their highest level in almost six years on expectations for robust earnings during coronavirus downturn. Australia's ASX 200 jumped over three percent. However, shares in New Zealand tumbled nearly two percent following news that Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has declared Auckland would move into COVID-19 Alert Level Three today.

Severe storms in December 2013 caused damage to an existing dune system to the east of Barkby Beach in Prestatyn. A report, to be considered by Denbighshire councillors, says there is a "high risk" that more severe weather will lead to further erosion at nearby Maiestad beach and other areas along the coast. The authority has already spent 340,000 on works including replacement of rock armour protection, revetment walls and handrails near St George's Island off Rhyl; repairs were also carried out over 12 months ago to protect the promenade wall, sea defences and car park from Cow Bay Cliff in Llandudno - as well as work to stabilise rocks at Ty Mawr Point - but due to rising costs could be approached for more funding if necessary.

Obituary: Francisco Blake Mora The helicopter was flying to Cuernavaca in neighbouring Morelos state for a prosecutors' meeting when it went down. All eight people on board were killed. President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador said the crash may have been caused by bad weather, but added that he would still conduct an investigation. In January 2015, two months after his election victory and before taking office, Mr Lopez Obrador visited one of Mexico's most notorious prisons. He told reporters afterwards there had not been "one single report" about escapes from El Altiplano during previous administrations despite frequent reports of inmates breaking out at other facilities around the country. But just five days into office - 13 years later than planned because of delays with construction work needed for the new prison - more than 70 prisoners broke free in what is now known as the biggest jailbreak in recent memory. On Monday night another high-profile prisoner escaped while being transferred between police stations. It appeared Alejandro Edda Martinez was caught almost immediately although it took six hours to track him down. Mr Blunkett said using the same funding formula applied to Wales - which has a devolved budget - Yorkshire would be entitled to a PS24bn budget. "You put great store on fairness and justice, so you should accept this is fair," he said. "We have an opportunity here before us now for all of England's regions because there will not only need to be additional expenditure but it cannot be done at the expense of other areas." In his speech Mr Blair had made clear that if elected in May, Labour was committed to bringing about change as soon after 1997 as possible by establishing regional assemblies with their own budgets during its first year back in power. The proposals were criticised yesterday by Tory leader William Hague who accused him of wanting government ministers from Liverpool or Birmingham making decisions affecting farmers across Westmorland. He also warned against creating new taxes without permission from Parliament. But the Prime Minister insisted: "If I can get agreement [on] financial powers being devolved then they do come under my responsibility. If we are going into an election saying 'we want more money'...I believe people expect me to make sure that happens."

The Center for Disease Control (CDC) said 45 people had been infected with a strain of E. coli, 43 of whom reported eating at a Chipotle restaurant. The cases were primarily in six states - Washington, Oregon, California, Minnesota and New York - but also included North Dakota and Pennsylvania. Of the 43 sickened by that outbreak, four required hospitalization. Two more each developed hemolytic uremic syndrome or kidney failure. Federal health officials did not say whether there was any link between those illnesses and any specific food items served at Chipotle restaurants.

The 56-year-old ex-Derbyshire skipper leaves his post as club president to take the newly created job. Graeme Welch left as elite performance director in June, having been appointed following a major revamp of Northants' coaching set up under former coach David Ripley last year. "I'm very pleased and proud that Richard has agreed to be my successor," said Bailey who will continue as head coach on an interim basis for 2019. "He's hugely experienced with over 20 years of first-class cricket behind him."

The skull of an adult male was found by the M54 slip road on Thursday by workers surveying a roundabout near Telford. The find sparked a West Mercia Police inquiry to identify the man and his family, with officers concerned he had not been reported missing or in contact since 2019 when his friends lost touch after they stopped seeing each other regularly A statement from police said: "We are continuing our investigation into who this person is, as we have no record that anyone matching their description has contacted us about him."

The latest threats bring the number of incidents to 69 in 27 states in the past month, according to the JCC Association of North America. No bombs were found at any site before Monday's discovery in Mandell JCC near Detroit. President Donald Trump and his daughter Ivanka, who is Jewish, condemned the attacks on social media. The White House has been working behind the scenes with Jewish groups and law enforcement to ward off more bomb scares, officials said Wednesday afternoon. Following a briefing from FBI Director Chris Wray about this week's nationwide wave of anti-Semitic threats against Jewish institutions, POTUS reaffirmed that we must protect all Americans - and especially our fellow citizens of the Jewish faith (12) - Sarah Sanders (PressSec) February 21, 2018

Daly spent two seasons at Ibrox after leaving Tannadice, where he has been training since pre-season. "I would never say never," the 32-year-old said of the possibility of signing for Hearts when asked if there was any chance of a return to Tynecastle Park in an exclusive interview with Evening News Sport last week. "If something came up then maybe it is possible." Daly did not rule out playing against his former club this weekend but says that will be purely on personal terms rather than anything else as he kept matters professional while working under Steven Gerrard and Gary McAllister during their time together at Rangers. He added: "It's one thing being friends outside football - you can banter all day long about things like family members or whatever. But inside the environment we need to give 100 per cent because ultimately they are your employers so you have got to do everything by the book and work hard every single day no matter what goes on off the pitch. The same people who might want my shirt now could wish me well again next year! That is just how football works sometimes. You go through periods of great friendship; other times you don't see them too much. Hearts boss Daniel Stendel (Pic: SNS)

It says increases will be needed if current trends in teacher recruitment and retention continue. Nevertheless, the STRB has recommended a pay rise of just 1 for teachers in England next year - 2 per cent below inflation - which would result in an effective real-terms cut given that rising costs consume more than half of their salary budgets by 201920. In its report, published today (30 July), it said: "The evidence highlights overall budgetary pressures on schools as being largely driven by non-staffing factors such as increased pension contributions." However this doesn't say where these extra funding needs might come from to make up any shortfall after the above measures are taken into account, or whether they could be across the board cuts such as class sizes increasing once again, something Education Secretary Justine Greening is considering pressing ahead with despite widespread opposition within her own party. A spokesman for Ms Gove told TES before publication last week's spending review had set out how school standards were going to increase over the coming years through a 7 billion investment package, including record levels of capital funding, while councils get significant new powers to raise council tax and National Insurance bills.

We've asked BBC Sport readers to predict the top three before every race this season and, after the British Grand Prix, we got our calculators out and had a look . The data tells an interesting story: Mercedes dominated qualifying at Silverstone - as expected given their history at this circuit over recent years - but they were beaten by Ferrari in both races, which is less so but still surprising on reflection. What it shows us more than anything else though is that hard racing can be just as important for overtaking opportunities as driving quickly around corners. And Red Bull have proven themselves to do pretty well across all those areas of performance.

Mr Trump broke a long-held tradition by not releasing his paperwork during his presidential campaign. Andrew Haldane said in a speech he was downbeat over the UK economy because of weaker global growth, low wage growth and financial and political risks. "Put in rather plainer language: Brexit. And lots more of it," Mr Haldane told an economists' conference at The Wall Street Journal's Annual Health Summit. "It is too early to say exactly how these storms will play out," added Mr Haldane who heads up the BoE's monetary policy committee (MPC). But his comments may raise expectations that policymakers could vote for another rate cut next month when they meet on November 7-8. It would be their third reduction since August, taking rates below zero for the first time ever. However, any move by the MPC remains unlikely until after Theresa May has called off her planned October 15th snap election as she prepares to head back from Brussels empty handed with no new deal agreed yet. Bank governor Mark Carney and other senior officials have warned against cutting interest rates further just now given signs of economic recovery following last year's slump caused mainly by uncertainty triggered by June 2016 referendum decision to leave the European Union. Sterling fell sharply lower yesterday after business surveys indicated continued weakness ahead while official figures showed construction output dropped 0.1 per cent between July and September - its fourth consecutive quarterly fall - though strong exports helped limit overall decline. Meanwhile US government borrowing costs also dipped briefly before then climbing back above 3 per cent again despite better than expected jobs data showing unemployment remained near 50-year lows even as employers hired fewer workers than forecast in September. There are still around 700 employees looking every day in Scotland alone says recruitment firm Adecco Group which reckons wages jumped 2.9 per cent annually in September but remain depressed compared to pre-financial crisis levels.

Critics say the new contract involves pay cuts of up to 30, with "normal hours" extended to include 7am to 10pm on every day except Sunday. The British Medical Association has called it a disgrace and says no doctor could survive such working conditions without suffering severe stress or burnout. A protest was held outside parliament last week attended by several thousand people including NHS staff and their supporters from across Britain's political spectrum - even some Conservative voters who have been profoundly affected by funding shortfalls in recent years that left them waiting months for treatment at times. One woman told me her husband had died earlier this year after being forced to wait too long for an operation she said he desperately needed but which wasn't deemed urgent enough due to health service cutbacks. Many took banners saying: 'We are not robots.' A lot felt betrayed because doctors were among those who voted strongly to leave Europe precisely so they wouldn't be subject to EU rules dictating what kind if work can be classed as "social," rather than strictly medical. They thought Brexit would allow more money into public services - never mind that Boris Johnson promised very early on those claims weren't true either when announcing his vision for leaving the bloc. Now there is anger directed towards him; I've heard plenty of talk about how much better things used to be under Tony Blair (even though Labour didn't abolish these kinds of contracts back then). These days many believe Jeremy Corbyn should also share blame since he initially refused to support strike action until late May. But most everyone feels let down politically instead of just personally angry now. 'I don't want my children growing up like us': Londoners tell of poverty, hardship Read more Tensions run deep between junior medics and senior consultants over government plans to expand the number of places available through its Graduate Entry Scheme, aimed specifically at overseas recruits coming here post-Brexit. Thousands graduated during Covid already meaning training budgets have gone elsewhere amid a backlog caused by cancelled operations, delayed procedures and fewer students coming forward overall despite increased incentives. Aspiring GPs feel unfairly treated compared to European counterparts getting preferential access via family connections while surgeons get to choose where best suited geographically and financially. It all makes you wonder why anyone wants to join medicine right now. To mitigate against potential problems ahead we need far greater investment throughout our whole healthcare system, coupled with proper planning and clear communication regarding changes taking place as well as guarantees not only that existing workers won't lose out again following any transition period once free movement ends next December but that nurses will come here regardless given attractive salaries aren't guaranteed anywhere else yet. Then maybe we'd finally see the end of recruitment adverts promising wages higher than the average salary plus bonuses and other perks outside of London! With luck any future pandemics might bring issues around staffing levels upwards to national priority status before irreversible damage takes hold, especially considering social care often isn't mentioned alongside hospitals anymore although experts insist neither sector can operate successfully alone anyway. We really do seem to have forgotten how interdependent everything is nowadays ... Hopefully, someone somewhere remembers soon?

Edward Alexander Lee, 34, was sentenced to three years on probation at Belfast Crown Court on Wednesday. Judge Gordon Kerr QC said it was the best way of protecting society and rehabilitating him after he admitted an assault causing actual bodily harm charge for a "violent struggle" in which his victim needed hospital treatment. The court heard that Mr Mackay had been asked by police officers if there were any issues between himself and Lee before they left their homes in east Belfast last July. The following day two males went into Mr Mackay's flat while he was out shopping armed with knives, demanding money from him during what turned out to be a violent struggle over 55 worth of drugs. Prosecutor Michael Chambers told how Mr Mackay suffered injuries including cuts across both eyes requiring stitches as well bruising all round his body caused when being punched repeatedly. He added: "Mr Mackay felt intimidated because one man pointed a knife towards another who also put up a fist. His fear is such that this has impacted upon his daily life since."

Pernod Ricard, which is based in France, is the second biggest distiller of Scotch after Diageo. Its brands include Chivas, The Glenlivet and Ballentine's. Police officers have said he may have had Asperger's syndrome - an autism spectrum disorder that makes it difficult to get close to other people or form relationships with them Pictured: Crouch (right) on the pitch against Arsenal in 2008 when Chelsea won 2-0 thanks to goals from Frank Lampard (left) and Didier Drogba (centre). The former England striker died aged just 40 last week after being found hanged at home The court heard Crouch became known as 'the robot' because despite working extremely hard for Liverpool he rarely spoke about himself and was always polite even if things did not go well on the football field. After retiring from playing football professionally due to injury, Mr Hincks said Crouchen remained involved in charity work before moving into coaching younger sportsmen such as those taking part in his Fit2Football sessions which connected groups of children together through sport. He also took up acting roles including appearing alongside Vinnie Jones in the film Lock Stock And Two Smoking Barrels among others. His wife was described by friends who attended her funeral service earlier this month as having been left heartbroken since her husband's death. In response to claims she is still surrounded by mystery over what happened inside their family home two weeks ago, one friend told MailOnline: "It all seems very strange." Friends say Caroline has become withdrawn ever since losing her soulmate A source close to Mrs Crouch previously revealed how the couple met while they were both training to be youth team coaches at Tottenham Hotspur FC. They married back in 1999 and went onto live in Chigwell where they raised four boys together; Aaron, Jack, Charlie and George. It appears Crouch gave no hint anything wasn't right ahead of Valentine's Day night last Monday evening. Shortly before 9pm police received reports of concern for welfare at the property following concerns neighbours witnessed someone entering the house shortly afterwards. A neighbour claimed there was screaming coming from the address around 6am yesterday morning although cops are yet to confirm these details so far. An officer outside the 1million five bedroom detached gated property today refused to comment on whether anyone else lived at the residence apart from Ms Crouch. Neighbours claim the pair moved away some years ago leaving only their three youngest sons behind. Police vehicles continue to guard the scene as forensics experts combed through the sprawling mansion looking for clues. Officers wearing white suits, masks and gloves could also bee seen carrying evidence bags out of the building as they searched each room. No arrests have taken place and enquiries remain ongoing says Essex Police Mr Stewart added: Crouch] played brilliantly for us [Liverpool]. I mean, we loved him when he first came here. You never knew quite what you would get between matches... But once he settled down...he really got going.' Speaking directly to fans, he continued:'He delivered big moments late in games. That goal he scored against Wimbledon in our FA Cup run will forever stay with me'. Pictured above celebrating scoring for Spurs at White Hart Lane Stadium in May 2003, Crouch netted six times in 56 appearances across his season long loan spell with the Reds

The court in Novorossiysk gave two of the dancers 10 days in jail each, a third 15 days and two others received fines on charges of petty hooliganism. Prosecutors had asked for community service or probationary sentences. "I don't think we will appeal," said Vladimir Plyuschevnikov, one of the defendants' lawyers who believes his clients did not receive fair trials. "They might be freed today." An appeals hearing is planned later this month at Russia's Supreme Court in Moscow which could take several months to decide whether there are grounds to change the original verdicts handed down by lower courts. Bernard Mensah struck a post for Aldershot after 11 minutes, but the visitors were a man down midway through the first half when Jim Kellerman saw red for a foul on John Akinde. Akinde was immediately taken off as a precautionary measure and replaced by Kundai Benyu, who in turn went off himself nine minutes later with an ankle injury that required further treatment from medical staff before he made his way back to the dressing room. The hosts took full advantage of their numerical superiority to double their lead just four minutes into the second period courtesy of some sublime finishing from striker Danny Hylton. Having previously had two efforts saved by goalkeeper Dean Gerken, the former Hull forward latched onto Billy Waters' defence-splitting pass over the top, rounded defender Nathan McGinley and placed the ball past Gerken at the near post. Waters then fired narrowly wide shortly afterwards, while McDonald's side also hit the woodwork twice during the closing stages - Ched Evans finding space inside the penalty area only to see his shot come back out off the crossbar in stoppage time, followed soon after by Adam McDonnell seeing his effort thump against the bar following good work by Leon Legge.

HM Revenue Customs said the plant, on the outskirts of the city centre, could have cost taxpayers nearly PS138m a year in lost duty and taxes. Four lorry loads of tobacco products were seized from it when the raid took place last week. The store, which was shut down by officials from HMRC's Criminal Investigations Department (CID), also had five bookmakers operating within its premises as well as three gambling machines. Officers found an illegal roulette machine under the counter at one point during their search operation. They recovered more than 200 cartons of cigarettes but believe that there would be far more if they didn't close up shop before Saturday's match between England and Croatia. According to local sources, no staff members paid any tax or national insurance contributions either. A source told The Sun: "This is where all Britain's money goes - into the pockets of crooks like these who thought they can get away with making millions while paying none back."

Inspectors in abattoirs used to be able to cut open pig carcasses to check for signs of disease. But under new European regulations, supported by Britain's Food Standards Agency (FSA), inspectors no longer have the authority or power to do this themselves as it could lead them into an "unacceptable risk" where they might contaminate meat with their own blood and other bodily fluids if a dead animal was found with TB. Instead, when pigs are slaughtered at slaughterhouses there will only ever be one government vet present alongside staff from the food business operating the plant - who inspect each individual animal before being dispatched on its journey along production lines. The vets' role is limited to ensuring that any paperwork accompanying the animals is accurate; checking whether the pigs were fit for human consumption when bought by processors; making sure all packaging meets labeling requirements prior to dispatch but not during transit and assisting officials with investigations into suspected outbreaks of TB after processing has finished. This makes sense because investigating cases of bovine tuberculosis infection among live stock can take months while affected premises must remain closed until cleared. The FSA says there is nothing untoward about these changes: farmers face daily challenges such as feeding livestock properly, looking after hygiene levels around farms and managing risks associated with manure storage sites so should continue doing what they've always done anyway without relying too heavily upon state-sponsored inspections by the agency itself."Overall, we expect most businesses carrying out these activities would already meet our standards," said Dr Monique White, head of BSE surveillance at the FSA. She added the decision had been taken due to concerns over how long it takes to investigate outbreak situations involving herds containing infected cattle - which often occur far away from slaughter plants near agricultural areas rather than inside factories which handle large numbers of carcass movements per day. It also reflects lessons learned following the 2013 West Coast E. coli O157:H7 outbreak, she claimed, where high death rates linked to contaminated meat led some consumers to believe UK authorities did little more than pay lip service towards food safety issues once processed foods left factory gates. But although refusing to look behind pork products may help ensure clean supermarket shelves across Europe, critics warn against ignoring fresh meats altogether. Dr Peter Stevenson runs Capital Vet Group Ltd., based outside London and works closely with small beef and dairy producers throughout England.. He agreed with Ms Byles that regular testing allows him to spot problems early on but insisted the limitations imposed last year by senior veterinary officers means he cannot monitor his clients' cows like he previously did himself. For example, instead of taking samples directly off cow udders every month during calving season, Mr Stevenson now relies solely on postmortem examination carried out at specialists labs operated jointly between Defra the Veterinary Health Laboratory Network. These facilities test for various diseases including scour caused by salmonella bacteria and Johne's Disease, which affects young calves unable to fight back, by collecting swabs from rectums via plastic tubing inserted through anus openings. If either illness appears then tests show up within 24 hours meaning immediate action can quickly follow to contain further spread of infection. Unfortunately many of those suffering Johne's die before anyone realises anything serious is wrong thanks largely down to tiny amounts of moisture getting trapped underneath skin folds surrounding udder teats even though bulls tend to expel milk immediately afterwards leaving calves vulnerable to infections later on life stages, said Mr Stevenson. Once symptoms appear surgery becomes necessary followed by treatment using costly drugs costing thousands pounds annually depending on their type.

The pages from a 13th Century text of the holy book of Islam were purchased by the council in 1951. Members of the Clwyd North Division are against the changes at Glan Clwyd Hospital, Bodelwyddan. These could see clinical staff transferred to Ysbyty Gwynedd and Wrexham Maelor hospitals from 6 November 2017 until further notice. The proposals have been met with some criticism by local residents calling for them not be implemented because they will increase waiting times for patients in need of urgent care as well as emergency treatment being available elsewhere across Mid Wales rather than a hospital that is on their doorstep. A campaign group has also sprung up which aims to stop the proposal going ahead arguing it's an "over-reaction" following safety concerns raised about AE services last year after two people died within four days while attending Glan Clwyd's Emergency Department during one week in April 2016 - although both deaths were found to be unrelated but there was still serious concern over patient safety levels due to overcrowding caused by rising demand.

The area around Green Park, which also has a large business park, is notorious for its long traffic queues, particularly on match days. Plans for Green Park Station were put forward in the 1990s but have not come to fruition and as such it falls outside London's Underground network (which covers much of Central London). However, the connection between Paddington station - both mainline services from Waterloo and Crossrail trains destined for Heathrow Terminals 4 5 - and Green Park will be greatly improved by 2050 with the Western Gateway scheme connecting this part of West London directly into the Tube system at Cricklewood. The tunnel section between Euston Square GardensFarringdon Road and Liverpool Street stations was opened in 2017; however there are plans to extend further north via Old Oak Common and through the City of Westminster once again along Oxford Street before reaching Farringdon and then Green Park where the line splits off towards Sloane Square or South Kensington. Connections are quickly made from here onwards to destinations across central London including Victoria Station and all other major railway hubs like King's Cross St Pancras International, British Library, Tottenham Court Road, Bank station etc.. This multi-billion pound project includes proposals to build 3 skyscraper blocks up to 49 storeys high above ground level plus extensive pedestrian areas below them that would link these main junctions together seamlessly whilst providing additional office space within reach of many people working in this location who currently rely upon expensive housing costs elsewhere. These developments could accommodate over 10,000 new homes, commercial properties and public buildings! It should be noted that Eastern Gateway does not include any development opportunities nor funding mechanisms set aside yet even though significant engineering works needed to start construction already exist: so we may need to wait until 2030 if ever they get approved! Another recent addition included an extension down towards Islington and Highbury. Little Venice This small cluster of canalside streets is regarded one of Camden's most desirable neighbourhoods thanks mainly due to its mix of conservation and period houses alongside more modern residential apartments built in the late 1970s. For decades now it had been perceived only suitable for professional families seeking 2 or maybe 3 bedroom terraces offering private gardens overlooking Regent's Canal whereas young professionals preferred renting flats nearby since they often didn't want to commit financially to home ownership when they still lived relatively cheaply away on campus while studying abroad. Since 2010 Little Venice became very popular amongst students too looking specifically for 1 bed escape pads close enough to their university campuses without having to commute back each night after lectures finished. In recent years some larger family units did manage to get onto the property ladder living near the canal banks especially those willing to pay slightly higher prices than previously offered to smaller couples and singles asking rents no longer exceeding 1K per month during peak seasons. But despite being located just minutes walk from Camden Town tube station access to several restaurants remains limited compared to local alternatives available closer to Hampstead Village Swiss Cottage Primrose Hill. As well provides plenty of green spaces to explore walking distance away either side of Kentish Town Road although far less options become readily accessible beyond neighbouring Kingsland Road. Some shops do remain open later evening ultimately attracting customers heading out afterwards to bars and nightclubs operating past midnight unlike Hampstead Broadway becoming mostly quiet earlier hence why residents prefer shopping along the wide selection Avenue Road offers instead. Tufnell Park Located west of Angel Finchley Circulars Tufnel Park is arguably best known among UCL students for its sports facilities comprising two swimming pools, tennis courts, football pitches, multiple gyms and fitness rooms shared with University College London whilst the adjacent Tufnell Park tube stop provides direct links throughout the day allowing you to run errands locally rather than making your way uptown catching buses or changing tubes at various points depending how busy things happen to be running. With the latter option coming recommended anyway given the total number of underground lines serving this neighbourhood with plenty more joining here at Wood Lane meaning travelling anywhere else takes little time at all whether visiting another borough inside Greater London or venturing further afield. A growing community called "New Town Farm" aims to produce organic vegetables sold directly to consumers every Friday afternoon at a weekly market held near Tufnell Park Station car park next door to the Community Centre opening hours listed online. While a variety of pubs and clubs operate within easy driving distances covering everything ranging from live music venues hosting alternative rock bands playing electronica to jazz quintets performing bluesy tunes right down to traditional Irish folk songs played by virtuoso fiddle players accompanied by flute accordionists enjoying regular outings at weekends or weekdays. Sales volumes increased by 1.7 in November from the month before, the Office for National Statistics said. Compared with the same month last year, sales were up by 5. However, growth was driven largely by a massive jump of 54 percent increase on online shopping as restrictions to curb the spread of coronavirus kept many Britons indoors and away from high streets, according to analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics. The ONS data showed that while the number of people visiting stores dropped 11.2 over the three months through October, it had barely changed since September after an initial drop-off when they reopened during July's lockdown only lasted about two weeks compared with six months earlier this year. "There are signs now of some recovery (in retail), but we won't know how quickly footfall will recover until there is greater confidence around households' willingness to spend money out of doors," economists at Capital Economics wrote in a note Friday morning.
