She also referred back comments made earlier by Chief Inspector Geraint White who said: " (The) investigation remains active; however there has been no arrest (s), nor any charges brought against anyone at present. We would still encourage people to contact us if they have any relevant information about the events leading up to this tragic death."

A health tribunal has found Peter Sutcliffe no longer needs any treatment for any mental disorder. In 1981 he was convicted of 13 murders and seven attempted murders and given 20 life sentences but the Yorkshire Ripper died in hospital on Sunday aged 74 from Covid-19 The decision means that Mr Justice Chamberlain will consider whether his underlying conditions mean it is'reasonably likely' that if released, he would be at risk of serious harm to himself or others Sutcliffe's ex Sonia Woodward (pictured), who survived a brutal attack by him while she worked in Leeds, said: 'I think plenty of people are going to feel very angry about this news - I'm not happy.' He was diagnosed with paranoid schizophrenia after being moved to Broadmoor secure hospital ten years ago where doctors have ever since treated him as though he had the condition. But experts believe many of his crimes could possibly be attributed to other factors such as cocaine abuse which may well have exacerbated an existing personality disorder rather than making him mentally ill. When asked during his trial whether what he did was sane behaviour, Sutcliffe replied: 'No, quite clearly it wasn't. The reason why you are asking me these questions now because my sanity should be questioned'. Pictured: Sutcliffe arriving back into court following sentencing In 2017, forensic psychiatrist Professor Paul Johnson told how Sutcliffe might never reach full remission due to smoking cannabis and drinking heavily throughout most of his adult life - despite occasionally abstaining when living under 24 hour surveillance inside Broadmoor. After leaving prison in 2010 he continued taking drugs including LSD. Prof Johnson added that even if Sutcliffe does eventually achieve complete recovery there were still concerns over his ability to stay out of trouble once freed. He also feared the killer posed too great a danger to society to be allowed outside unsupervised. However Prof Phil Scraton today said: 'There is nothing wrong with someone like Ian Brady [who murdered five children] getting parole - we want them rehabilitated so they can go home again without problems.'

In a letter to all party leaders, the Equality and Human Rights Commission expresses concern about hate attacks that have taken place since the UK voted to leave the EU . The commission has received 30 reports of incidents in England alone, with figures from across Britain showing there were more than 200 cases reported on social media during June 2016 - soon after the referendum result was announced. The EHRC says it is concerned by these increases as well as an increase in victims who are being "intimidated or targeted because they belong to certain groups" including those who identify themselves as Muslim, Jewish, Polish or Black British. It also notes further concerns over racially aggravated harassment and bullying at schools which could be related to Brexit-related discussions taking place within classrooms. As such, it urges teachers to address any issues around race equality before children go home for summer break so students can enjoy their holidays without confusion.

The 60-year-old man was scuba diving at Agincourt Reef in Far North Queensland when he was seen to be in trouble, tour operator Quicksilver said. The tourist, a certified diver, went underwater on Tuesday and failed to resurface as the boat returned after its dive trip around 2pm (9am GMT). He could not be found despite an immediate search of the reef using two boats from the company's fleet that included a jet skier, police say. A post mortem will take place today but it is understood there are no suspicious circumstances surrounding his death. "There were several people looking out for him while searching with us yesterday however we couldn't find any trace of where he had gone below," Quicksilvers' managing director Luke Howard told Nine News Australia. "We did everything possible above board." About 1km long and 40m wide, Agincourt has hundreds of fish species ranging between 16cm and 100cm, according to local tourism information website Townsville Attractions Guide.

His lecture, to be broadcast later this year, is part of a raft of new BBC Radio 4 programmes unveiled on Monday. They include Glenda Jackson's return to acting, in the first instalment of her three-part adaptation of A Woman Of No Importance (September 24), and an all-female version of the I'm Sorry I Haven't A Clue comedy quiz show hosted by Jo Brand starting next February (January 5). The raft of female presenters includes Stephanie Cole as host of The Food Programme live from Oxford at 8pm every Thursday night, beginning with its annual food festival on September 19; Clare Balding leading a series for women exploring sport across Britain between October 1st and November 11th; Nicola Mealey hosting Sounds Like My Life: Women Writers In Conversation - featuring writers including Margaret Atwood and Andrea Levy discussing their work - multiple times throughout 2019; and Lory Del Santo presenting You've Been Debriefed! examining "the way that public life has changed since 911."

Prison inspectors discovered the average period of stay at the facility near Gatwick Airport had risen from 28 to 48 days. Twenty-three people were held for more than a year. Police found evidence, including CCTV footage, that'suggested Mr Wright was assaulted and potentially tortured' in his cell between 10pm on 26 December and 4am 27th', prosecutor Andrew Jackson said today Mr Johnson told jurors: 'The prosecution say this is an egregious case.' He added: 'Mr Wright died whilst he was being unlawfully detained by G4S staff who showed deliberate indifference to him as they left him lying unresponsive in their care over almost two hours before even attempting to seek assistance or summoning medical help. We will prove beyond reasonable doubt what happened during those crucial 45 minutes when there remained every opportunity to save Mr Wright's life after he was first observed by correctional officers slumped forward against some bars inside his cell. As I have already stated we are alleging these events led directly to Mr Wright's death without any intervention whatsoever until it became clear he was no longer breathing.' The inquest heard police launched Operation Sceptre into how he died following concerns raised about the adequacy of procedures in place across prisons run by private firms such as Serco (file photo) A jury returned a verdict of unlawful killing against prison officer Lee Deighton, 46, of Orpington, Kent; suspended custody manager Stephen Cribbins, 47, also of Orpington; healthcare assistant Joanne Hayes, 44, of Dartford, Kent; and support service worker Matthew Hanratty, 25, of Beckenham, south east London. They all denied manslaughter but were convicted yesterday. Lindon Coombes, 23, of Bromley Common, Greenwich, south east London, admitted assisting prisoners to escape. He has yet to be sentenced. All five defendants appeared in court via video link from HMP Bronzefield where they remain remanded ahead of sentencing next month. Sentencing would normally take place within six weeks of conviction - meaning the men could face years behind bars under current guidelines. However, Judge Jeremy Donne QC indicated proceedings may not conclude then because victim statements must still be read out by lawyers representing each family member. Advertisement

A defence official said in a statement on Wednesday that its nuclear programme had "long been in the full-fledged stage of miniaturisation." However, analysts say while there is evidence the North has made advances in developing warheads and delivery systems it remains unclear whether they have fully mastered all technical hurdles. "I would not be surprised if we continue to see reports like this," Melissa Hanham, deputy director of the Open Nuclear Network, told AFP. She added: "It's hard for me to tell what kind of bomb or how many bombs are being developed because Pyongyang does not disclose these things though I do think their missile capabilities are better than what was reported."

Oldham went in front in the fifth minute when Marc Klok delivered a free-kick from the right to the far post, where unchallenged defender Peter Clarke scored with a downward header. The visitors tried hard but Oldham were comfortable defensively and as they pressed forward for an equaliser they looked vulnerable at set pieces - another of their Achilles heels this season that contributed directly to last week's defeat against Fleetwood Town. After 57 minutes came a second major blow after Khan was sent off by referee Gavin Ward, having been adjudged to have elbowed Payne inside the penalty area without appearing to get any contact on him. Payne had missed the best chance before then, his shot being blocked by Ben Garratt just prior to half time. Having said all those nice things about Grosicki didn't I... well here's some more! After 60 minutes he made it 2-0 with a great finish into the roof of the net following good work down the left wing by Jack Byrne. It seems his team mates are able to feed off his confidence too whilst also creating chances themselves. A fantastic strike. The provider? David Ball who showed exactly how classy he is playing through the centre behind two strikers (as opposed to one). And Kenny Miller got himself onto the scoresheet shortly afterwards with an acrobatic bicycle kick to give Swindon hope however unfortunately we couldn't muster up anything further in terms of goals which means we remain rooted to bottom place despite our recent upturn in form under John Sheridan. Not sure what happened there to be honest.. All over bar the shouting now though before Christmas so hopefully everyone can enjoy the festive period safe in the knowledge that come January 1st we will still be Scunthorpe United and indeed very much alive in League One football! COYMS!

Police were called to the unusual double parking incident at 11:40 on Tuesday. It is not clear how exactly the silver-coloured Mazda ended up on top of the white Volkswagen , but it seems the driver was in a hurry and drove into something along the road... The two cars are now being lifted by crane from their position near the side of the A55 (M) flyover just southbound before Junction 28 (Llandudno) where they came together - although no details have been released about any potential injuries sustained as result of this bizarre accident.

The Coventry Festival of Motoring, which attracted 40,000 visitors in 2014, has had??20,000 of funding withdrawn by the city council. However, organisers Culture Coventry said the funding withdrawal was "not as bad" and they were confident it would still go ahead next year. The event runs from July 6-12 at Warwick University's Ricoh Arena site. Coventry City Council confirmed that a bid to Arts Council England for additional grant money towards festival costs is under consideration but added there will be no further grants made available this financial year. Chief executive Tony Reeves said: "We are aware an application for the 2018 festival is being considered with regard to how best we can support such events moving forward..." A spokesman for Coventry Festival of Motors added: 'the loss of up to 80k cashpath funding on top of last years budget cut means our headcount has been reduced significantly."

Gregg McNally put Leigh in front early on before Atelea Vea crossed over soon after to extend their advantage. The hosts went in at the break with an 18-0 lead , but were pegged back by a second half fightback from visitors Bromley which resulted in them finishing just 14 points behind as they recorded victory for only the third time this season. The result sees Leigh drop into 13th position while Bromley remain stuck down in 22nd place following one win and three defeats since promotion last month. McGlynn kicked off his tenure as head coach of Leigh Centurions against fellow strugglers Hull KR seven days ago, recording a narrow 29-28 defeat that extended Rovers' winning streak under Tony Smith to four games - something that hasn't been achieved for 46 years now! That marked the first game that Luke Robinson has taken charge of since taking over as interim boss yesterday. It also made it five losses out of six for Leigh who will be desperate to get themselves going again when Toulouse Olympique visit next week (Sunday 4 June).

The 46-year-old succeeds Ronnie Moore, who parted company with the club by mutual consent earlier on Wednesday. This is a first managerial role for Hignett, who had a spell as an assistant at Hartlepool in 2006 before spells managing Gateshead and Swindon Town's youth sides. He was also interviewed for the vacant manager position at Chesterfield last year but lost out to John Sheridan. He will now be tasked with guiding his new side into League One next season after they missed out on promotion via the play-offs this campaign - losing 1-0 away to Tranmere Rovers over two legs. The Robins finished sixth under Moore, meaning that, when it comes to applying for vacancies elsewhere during pre-season, he would need to have been out of work for 12 months if he wished to remain eligible to apply (or six years from leaving one job).

Moat Brae in Dumfries has been a private house, a nursing home and harboured hopes of being turned into a themed hotel. It has gone to the brink of demolition twice before after council funding was cut but last year it had its best ever summer season with more than 8,500 visitors saying they would like to see it preserved for future generations Moat Brae is an integral part of one of Scotland's most important historical sites - Doon Hill fort - which dates back some 5,000 years. The moated site comprises two adjacent houses built by local landowner William Riddell as he resettled his tenants following his purchase of nearby Greenlaw House from the Earl of Morton 12th Lord Elibank around 1790; his wife Annabella Maitland Riddell lived at Moat Brae until her death on October 27 1839 aged 72).The original entrance lodge remains today alongside approximately 200m2 of ground floor space comprising: reception rooms including drawing room, library, sitting room, dining room, kitchen and bathroom suite along with utility store plus staircase leading up to first floor accommodation.

New figures show the total number of teachers across Scotland has risen, but 12 council areas saw numbers fall. Mr Swinney said the stats were "good news" in light of an increase in teacher and pupil rolls since school returned after Christmas break last year - a rise of around 4,000 pupils to 94,226 compared with 2017-18. Getty Images Nicky Morgan says she's 'proud' that record levels have been set for As

While 7 of people underpay and could be fined, 13 are paying too much. The Office of Rail and Road (ORR) wants train companies to refund passengers who accidentally buy the wrong ticket from another zone or a different company. Image copyright PA Image caption Only 10 of rail fares need to change between London and Birmingham New Street - but many more have changed on other routes No single inspector goes through all stations at once so it is not possible for them to know which tickets should get refunds in advance. They can only fine customers after catching out some travellers by chance. This means that when someone does pay an extra fare they cannot easily claim back their money. So far there has been no official data released about where errors occur most commonly across Britain's railways. The ORR says the new system would ensure fairness among transport users around England, Scotland and Wales as well as Northern Ireland. It will apply to any public body that operates regulated services like buses and trains including Network Rail, Transport for Wales, Transport Scotland and Great Western Railway. Trains run by private operators such as Virgin or South West Trains may also use the software if they choose to join up with the scheme voluntarily.

Ashley Sibery, 39, persuaded Sital Sibery to take the class A drug minutes after she confronted him about his drug habit in their home. It happened on 2 April 2012 at their address in Cramlington and lasted two hours before he died from a fatal overdose. Sibery told police that they had been arguing when it became physical with Ashleigh grabbing his throat. He claimed this caused her death as because of previous injuries he believed she was breathing through broken ribs so stopped trying to resuscitate her until paramedics arrived some time later. But Northumbria Police launched an investigation into possible murder after it found Ms Sibery's body cold to touch but still warm to the touch which meant there were no signs she'd suffered any injury or trauma for several days before being dead. After speaking to neighbours who said they hadn't seen either partner for weeks detectives went round looking under furniture and beds for evidence whereupon they discovered traces of cocaine worth 2,000 hidden inside a chest freezer together with nearly 1kg (two pounds) of cannabis resin valued at up to tens of thousands of pounds stashed down behind a loose floorboard. They also recovered memory sticks containing more than 3,500 indecent images - including 251 videos showing people having sex with dogs, horses and a goat, 600 pictures featuring extreme sexual activity such as bondage and bestiality and almost 100 still photographs depicting children aged between five and 13 years old performing "sexually explicit acts." In 2015 investigators looked again at allegations by other women against Sindey over whether these too amounted to abuse leading to four charges being added to those already lodged. But in February 2018 another charge related to alleged attacks involving one woman was dropped because prosecutors decided not to ask the jury to find him guilty on account of lack of credible evidence while jurors concluded the remaining three counts proved beyond reasonable doubt following six-and-a half hours' deliberations last month..

The cinema chain has "provided the British public with unforgettable, cinema experiences," Bafta said. The awards will be held at London's Royal Albert Hall on 12 February. The Outstanding British Contribution to Cinema award went to film producer Kathleen Kennedy and director Steven Spielberg (both US), whose films include E.T., Jurassic Park, Schindler's List, Saving Private Ryan and Indiana Jones And The Temple Of Doom, among others. Amanda Berry OBE - one of three leaders who was kidnapped in 2002 along with her sister, Nicole Brown Simpson; she also managed a charity for families affected by crime Castro is serving life without parole after being convicted of kidnapping and raping them over almost 10 years while keeping his victims imprisoned inside their own homes. It took police several hours to break down doors leading into the house where he kept the women locked up as sex slaves because he had rigged it so they could not escape. He did eventually come outside but shot himself dead before officers arrived. Three other people were found guilty of participating in the crimes: Ariel Castro's brother-in-law Pedro Vazquez and his brothers Onil and Julio Cesar. A fifth man pleaded no contest to charges that he helped shield the household from law enforcement during their investigation.

Footage emerged online of people appearing to sing the anti-Irish "Famine Song" at the weekend, while a band played along. The council said the right of the Orange Order to march under their banner has been upheld by both the courts and Scottish ministers. The Famine Song is an 18th Century tune that became associated with Loyalism during the Troubles in Northern Ireland when it was sung as supporters of Sinn Fein's armed campaign against British rule set fire to Catholic homes and businesses across Ulster.

It is a question that has long seemed impossible to answer, since players from different decades can never face each other at their peaks. Add in an element of nostalgia and the issue becomes even more complicated - if you could select any team or era for your pick, how would it play out? In this series The Spin Off will be pitting sides made up of New Zealand's best ever rugby union teams against those assembled by our finest sports writers. We'll revisit some classics as well as test ourselves with new battles using only current All Blacks. Today: A clash between modern-day legends Kieran Read (Read) vs Richie McCaw (McCaw). Richie McCaw was still playing when we started compiling these all time greats lists back in 2018 but he had already missed three tests due to concussion incurred during Super Rugby. It wasn't until after his final season - 2019 - did we see him truly pass the torch. His decision not to extend beyond 2020 meant there were no farewell tour games; instead he just quietly slipped off into retirement without so much as a 'thank you'.

Forest Green, promoted from the National League, will host MK Dons in their first appearance in the competition, while FA Cup giant-killers Lincoln will be away to Rotherham. The 35 remaining third round ties take place on Saturday January 5 and Sunday 6. "There is no doubt that a lot of clubs are looking forward to this weekend's draw," said EFL chairman Debbie Jevans. "I'm sure everyone will agree with me when I say it promises to provide some fantastic games for us all."

The men, identifying themselves Andreas Richter and Piotr Koper, appeared on the country's TVP public television. In a statement they said they had "irrefutable evidence" the train existed, but failed to produce any physical object that would support their claims - showing only maps of what appear to be railways in Poland from World War II and satellite photos which could indicate tracks or damage caused by fighting, as well as video analysis suggesting it was not possible for an ordinary locomotive to have made such a trip. They also claimed to possess footage taken at the site of the crash itself, photographic images purporting to show Hitler's bunker under Berlin after 1945 (though these were later dismissed), documents detailing plans drawn up before the war by Nazi engineers, as well as eyewitness accounts collected by a German academic named Martin Bormann who worked with Goebbels' Ministry of Propaganda during WWII. The pair claim to know where some of these items are kept today, though none has been seen publicly since. While there is no clear historical consensus regarding whether Operation Valkyrie ever took place, this particular story just didn't add up. It lacked even basic plausibility; if the allies really did open fire upon escaping top Nazis while chasing them down railway lines, why wouldn't someone document this fact? And then there were the questions about how exactly a group composed entirely of German officers managed to make its way into Soviet territory undetected... perhaps more importantly: Why hadn't anyone reported this alleged incident either during the chaos immediately following Germany's defeat or decades earlier when Cold War tensions seemed much lower between East and West than they do now? This whole thing simply smelled fishy. There must've been another explanation behind all those reports claiming otherwise. But still nothing came off the rails quite so spectacularly until 2017, when Ukrainian filmmaker Roman Bondar announced he'd found proof the Germans actually pulled something like this one off ... somewhere else altogether. Yes indeed, Anschluss-era Austria seems to provide our answer! Which brings us back full circle yet again.

For many people with severe disabilities, their families and carers, this is a reality they are faced with every time they leave the house. In some cases it can leave them isolated in their own homes for months at a time. "Accessible taxis have been around since 1974 but these vehicles need to be used by more disabled passengers as well as older or vulnerable adults."

Guitarist and co-songwriter Johnny Marr has released an extract from his upcoming memoir Set The Boy Free in the Guardian and said he met with former band mate Morrissey in Los Angeles last year to discuss making a new album together. The 52-year old, who left Morrissey's group The Smiths following their final tour in 1987 after five years of working alongside him, is currently writing the book while recovering at home during lockdown due to coronavirus pandemic.

Gwen Thomson, 51, from Torry, died after the accident on Market Street on Wednesday morning. Insp Jon Barron said: "Our thoughts are very much with Gwen's family, friends and work colleagues at this time." He added that police inquiries were continuing to establish what happened in order to provide answers for her devastated loved ones about how such a tragic incident could occurred.

The Spaniard, whose opening round in Munich contained six birdies, trails leader Wade Ormsby of Australia by two shots and Belgian Thomas Detry by one. England's Tommy Fleetwood, who finished second behind McIlroy last year after sharing the lead with him going into final day, is tied for 11th on five under par. Jordan Spieth began his week at just over four-under courtesy of a third place finish 12 months ago but he has got off to an inconsistent start with rounds of 71 and 70 leaving him seven strokes adrift of the pacesetters heading into the weekend.

Burnley Empire Theatre defaulted to the care of the Duchy of Lancaster as an "owner of last resort" after the ownership could not be established. Last used as a bingo hall, in 1981 it had been converted into flats and was threatened with demolition by developers until local residents formed their own trust. The theatre reopened on 16 November 1984 under its original name The Granada Grand (now known simply as 'Granada. Today it is one of only two Grade II listed venues still left standing in Manchester city centre; alongside St Peter's Church which opened at this time too for community use including arts organisations. It remains owned by the City Council though run commercially using volunteers from across Greater Manchester. In 1989-90 there were nearly 3000 performances combining drama and concerts attracting over 150,000 visitors per year.[1]

Sexton suffered a suspected groin injury, before O'Connell was carried off at the end of the first half. Leading 9-6 at half-time, Rob Kearney's try increased Ireland's lead before O'Mahony and Sexton added further scores to seal an impressive win in Murrayfield for Joe Schmidt's men with Simon Zebo scoring Scotland's only points from five kicks at goal. Scotland skipper Greig Laidlaw believes that his side need to start converting their chances into wins after they were left frustrated by defeat against Ireland on Saturday evening as Johnny Sexton scored all 22 Irish points. The Scots had led 6-3 early on but managed just two penalties courtesy of Duncan Weir until Odsonne Edouard grabbed possession near halfway and released Jacob Stockdale who sprinted through the defence to score under the posts back around 10 minutes later. A second successful conversion gave them some breathing space out in front ahead of the interval before Sexton kicked three more penalty goals immediately upon resumption to turn the game completely Scotland's way as he also converted tries from Tadhg Furlong, Sean Cronin and Keith Earls either side of another Weir effort which narrowed it down again late on despite Connacht man Jack Carty having replaced Sexton several times during the contest when he looked set to be taken to hospital following his battle with HIA protocols. "We are getting there," said head coach Gregor Townsend afterwards about how far this young squad is coming along since last year's World Cup. "There were lots of good things today but we do have to convert our opportunities because if you don't then one team will get over the line eventually."

Speaking to the BBC, Thomas Thabane said he would return from South Africa, which surrounds Lesotho, "as soon as I know I am not going to get killed." Reports say that shots were fired in his office yesterday. Thabane was visiting South African President Cyril Ramaphosa for a regional summit when his coalition partners called on him this week to step down and accept responsibility over an ongoing assassination investigation into former army chief Maaparankoe Mahao, who died two years ago after being shot by what authorities suspect were members of the prime minister's security team. The killing remains unsolved. Both men had been named among potential successors to replace Thabane before his 2017 election victory. He has also denied allegations linking himself to Mahao's murder.

It was the famous Fairfield yard which took the Upper Clyde to great heights and worldwide prominence. The yard was founded in 1864 by William Elder, a talented marine engineer who brought his skills back from Australia where he had been working on ships for some years before that country became independent of Britain with its own shipping registry. The Strathclyde Shipbuilding Company is credited as being one of Scotland's most successful shipyards during World War II, producing numerous types of vessels such as trawlers, FPAs (fast patrol craft), corvettes, tankers etc. These were mostly built under licence at Stockton-on-Tees but also used steel manufactured locally at Motherwell on occasion. After Victory over Hitler and Japan Day 1945 it continued until 1966 when it merged with Dalmuir Ironworks into British Steel Corporation - now ArcelorMittal.

Jack Keene, 17, from Hertfordshire, was involved in a collision between a Renault Clio and a minibus on the A4086 near Capel Curig in which five other people were injured. He died at St George's Hospital in Tooting after suffering multiple injuries when he lost control of his car before hitting another vehicle coming the opposite way along the dual carriageway close to Pontyclun Services at around 10pm last Friday night (November 1). The Wrexham Academy pupil had been sitting his GCSEs this year. In a statement released by police today (Monday), Jack's family said: "Our son Jack passed away following an accident involving two vehicles whilst driving home with friends late on November 1 2019. We wish it wasn't true but we sadly have no choice but accept our heartbreaking reality." North Wales Police say they are continuing their investigations into the crash that also left three passengers - all boys aged 15-16 years old - with serious head or spinal injuries while one suffered minor injuries. They remained hospitalised yesterday afternoon. It is believed the group were returning back to Wrexham from London where some attended a music festival over Halloween weekend. A spokesman for North Wales Police said officers were "keeping under review" any future court appearances related to offences identified as part of its investigation including those relating to drinkdrug driving behaviour behind the wheel and speed.

Media playback is not supported on this device Asked if Saturday's opponents have scrummaged illegally during the tournament, England head coach Eddie Jones said: "100. Terribly illegally." Jones says his side are still to undergo a full review of their semi-final defeat by New Zealand and promised there would be some changes in personnel for Wales game RFU chairman Brandon Lewis has warned any new body set up to run rugby union should "not become another quango." Lewis was responding after ex-England internationals Maggie Alphonsi and Ugo Monye suggested that such an organisation could help restore confidence within English rugby following its shaky start under current chief executive Steve Brown. "We don't want it (an organisation) which will just make things more complicated," Lewis told BBC Sport. Former Women's Rugby World Cup winners Alphonsi and Monye were among those who backed a centralised approach as they addressed delegates at a Sports Industry Breakfast Club event hosted by the RFU Council in London.

On Wednesday, the electric carmaker reported a first quarter loss of 282m (PS195m) up from 154m last year. The loss was in line with investors' expectations, and the announcement that this will be Tesla's first annual profit is seen as paving way for more gains ahead. The company said it now expects to achieve an adjusted net income margin on quarterly basis in future quarters "as we scale production," but gave no details about how large or small those profits would be. It had previously targeted profitability by the end of 2020.

Speaking to BBC Radio 4's Today programme, he said he would build on the support he received at rallies to reconnect the party to voters. He rejected criticism from those who say his leadership style is'scary' and asked whether a shrill tone was appropriate for opposition leader when people are fearful of losing their jobs or homes due to Brexit uncertainty. Asked about Mr Corbyn being pictured holding hands with Sinn Fein's president Gerry Adams after attending an event in Trafalgar Square last week - which prompted one MP to call it "perverse" - Sir Keir said: "I'm not going into that but I did attend a number of events like that over Christmas. We were there as MPs."

Campaigners have asked the university to reconsider the move, highlighting its "strong record" in educating people from disadvantaged groups. But the university says it needs to reduce costs in line with other institutions and is committed to getting students into work as quickly as possible. The government has been accused of failing to support young people seeking employment by focusing instead on skills-based education - most notably through the apprenticeship levy designed to encourage employers to take on trainees rather than hire graduates straight out of university. The former headteacher David Laws recently said he wanted a rethink after discovering that fewer than one in 10 18-year-olds was enrolled at any kind of further or higher educational institution last year - even though 45 were unemployed.

The 49-strong team for the event, which will be at London Stadium in Stratford from 14-23 July, contains 10 athletes who won gold at Rio 2016. Two-time Paralympic champion Peacock, 31, is joined by C4-5 road race world champions Hannah Cockroft and Johnnie Walker while fellow Briton Libby Clegg - a triple world medallist - returns to defend her title on day one of the meet alongside wheelchair racers David Weir, Will Bayley and Sophie Unwin plus T38 sprint star Jonnie Brownlee (S7). Hannah Dines, Ellie Simmonds, Scott Meenagh and Andrew Small have also been selected after their fine performances last year as Great Britain topped the medal table with 18 medals including nine golds across both days of track cycling competition over two weekends during September 2017. Double Olympic silver medallist Lucy Hall, meanwhile, has earned herself another chance to become the first British woman since Mallory Franklin at London 2012 to win an IPC World Championship individual gold following back-to-back silvers behind current GB squad member Cockcroft when the pair go head-to-head once again this summer. The 26-year-old was part of the women's pursuit quartet that smashed its own world record en route to winning bronze at the Glasgow 2014 Worlds but missed out altogether five years later due to injury. "It's great to welcome some new faces into our programme ahead of what should hopefully be another successful season," said Para-cycling performance director Stephen Park.

The drug had been injected into the soles of the sports shoes to look like shock-absorbing gel. Customs officials became suspicious after finding the man's suitcase contained six pairs of counterfeit Nike Air Max sneakers, each containing a single gramme of methamphetamine Customs said it believed the illicit drugs were bound for Australia and that they could have fetched more than 100 million on Australian streets with an estimated street value in excess of 2 billion. The drugs seized would fill about 1,800 vials The 52-year-old was arrested at Sydney International Airport carrying two suitcases full of cash (182,000), luxury watches worth several hundred thousand dollars (pictured) as well as the ice hidden inside his shoe soles

Four police were wounded as they tried to arrest a man in the Bavarian town of Georgensgmuend, south of Nuremberg. The suspect, described as a member of the extremist Reichsbuerger movement that denies the legitimacy of modern-day Germany's parliamentary system and borders, was seriously injured during his arrest. Police said officers had come across a suspicious vehicle at around 10:40 p.m., stopped it and requested identification from its driver. They said he first provided an invalid document but then pulled out a firearm and fired at them before fleeing into a nearby wooded area. Four officers returned fire; two sustained minor injuries while another received serious head wounds and remains hospitalized.

The evacuation of the Jet2 plane at East Midlands Airport was hampered when one of the escape chutes did not work. It came after the pilot was unable to check with air traffic control in advance about whether it would be possible for his aircraft to fly safely into and out of Stansted on Saturday night, despite all other flights taking off as normal from Essex airport that evening. One passenger said he feared emergency services were going to have difficulty reaching the stranded travellers because they had been "stranded in a rather remote part" of Nottinghamshire. 'I just didn't want my family to see me like this': 'Biggest loser' contestant struggles Read more A two-hour delay meant passengers finally got back home around 11pm - three hours behind schedule - via Liverpool and Manchester airports instead of flying direct. A spokesman for Jet2 apologised over the incident but insisted everyone who needed hospital treatment or to stay overnight following their arrival on Sunday morning had done so without refuelling first. He added: We] are very sorry that some customers missed their connection due to an administrative issue by our ground handling agent."

It was the 29-year-old Spaniard's first Grand Tour stage win and Movistar's first at this year's Giro - still led by Jungels, with Geraint Thomas second. Thomas' Team Sky team-mate Chris Froome is in third place overall after winning Wednesday's 10th leg ahead of Thursday's rest day. "I knew that I needed to attack but it wasn't easy as there were several opportunities," said Quintana who won the 2015 Vuelta a Espana and last season finished runner up at both the Tour de France (losing out to eventual winner Tom Dumoulin) and Giro d'Italia before his breakthrough triumph on Tuesday. "But finally today the legs felt good." Quintana attacked from the gun along with Domenico Pozzovivo (Bahrain Merida), Israel Start Up Nation's Dan Martin, once again wearing the King of The Mountains jersey which he has worn for three stages now, and Thibaut Pinot (Groupama FDJ). That quartet opened an advantage of around 13 minutes over their rivals, although Pinot pulled off to allow Adam Yates, Bauke Mollema, Ilnur Zakarin and Miguel Angel Lopez through to form a chase group containing five GC favourites including defending champion Simon Yates and four-time winner Vincenzo Nibali (both Mitchelton Scott). That quintet gained 20 seconds back on the main break and then dropped two riders on the final climb: Russia's Alexey Lutsenko (Astana Pro Team) and Spain's Jesus Herrada (Cofidis) while also building up enough time to see them finish within 30 seconds of the leaders, ensuring they all lost ground on Jungels whose victory ensured him of a fifth career podium placing behind only Alberto Contador, Tony Rominguez, Lance Armstrong and Fabio Aru amongst Classics greats since 1995.

Lincolnshire Partnership NHS Foundation Trust was criticised by the Care Quality Commission (CQC) in March 2015. A re-inspection in April this year found it had made "positive progress" in some areas but still required improvement and did not meet all of its standards, including safety. The commission said: "Some patients were at risk or experiencing poor care because staff had so much to do that they could not focus on their needs."

PC Gavin Smith, who appeared on Channel 5's Police Interceptors, died from cancer aged 34 on 15 February. Mr Smith, who lived in Bishop Auckland with his wife Kezi and son Ewan, was diagnosed last year after he suffered a number of unexplained headaches, followed by weeks of vomiting blood while at work as an officer for Durham Constabulary. The father-of-one had only been married to his childhood sweetheart since the summer when they tied the knot. The couple met back in 2000 but split up just before their wedding day due to "fear" that she would not be able to cope if something happened between them during the ceremony - which is said to have haunted her ever since. Ms Brocklebank told how it wasn't until November 2015, two years into their relationship, where both realised there were strong feelings still lingering towards one another. She revealed: "When we got together again I did actually think about getting engaged because my mum passed away 10 days prior so I thought what better way than him popping the question?" But despite wanting to get down on bended knee, Mr Smith managed to convince her otherwise - saying instead that marriage should simply come naturally. He said: "I didn't want any fuss or anything like that. After all these years you don't need someone standing over your shoulder going 'are ye alright?' It will happen. If you're meant to do then it'll happen." Rafael Esquivel admitted receiving bribes in connection with the sale of marketing rights to tournaments. He was among seven officials arrested at a luxury hotel in Switzerland last year. More than 20 million is alleged to have been embezzled from soccer's world governing body FIFA during more than two decades, U.S and Swiss authorities said when they unveiled indictments against 14 people in May 2015. The charges included racketeering conspiracy, wire fraud conspiracy and money laundering conspiracies for allegedly accepting millions of dollars linked to lucrative media deals in exchange for the awarding of television broadcasting contracts by FIFA - once led by Sepp Blatter until he resigned that same month amid corruption allegations engulfing soccer's global governing body. The indictment does not name the sports company or companies involved but says the bribery scheme dated back as far 1999. Esquivel pleaded guilty before federal judge Pamela Chen on Dec. 23 "to one count each of conspiring ... (and) engaging" in an effort to defraud Qatar Stars League clubs, Mexican club Santos Laguna FC, Ecuadorian side Independiente del Valle and Honduran team Olimpia FC, according to court filings unsealed Wednesday which detailed his cooperation agreement signed early this month. His sentencing hearing will be scheduled pending further proceedings related to other defendants who also face trial on various counts stemming from the massive probe into state-sponsored soccer graft. In conjunction with prosecutors' request made Tuesday for Esquivel's assistance, Special Counsel Robert Mueller recommended leniency for him under the federal guidelines based on his level of participation and that he had agreed to cooperate fully going forward. Those recommendations are usually taken favorably by judges if submitted prior to sentencing hearings where both sides often present extensive written materials backing up their cases ahead of those dates being set months down the line.

There had been cases of "verbal abuse hurled" at ethnic minorities, and "despicable graffiti daubed on a Polish community centre," he told the Commons. Such attacks must be stamped out, because they "only serve to increase tensions." The Home Secretary said: "Our country is enriched by its diversity but we cannot allow this contribution to be undermined by racism or discrimination in any form. This Government will not stand for it - which is why I am taking decisive action today with new laws to tackle hate crime head-on."

Islamic tradition requires the dead to be buried as soon as possible, unless an autopsy is required. The US military took this requirement very seriously, burying the body within hours. The official line from both sides now appears that rumours of his death were greatly exaggerated - a phrase used by many in 2003 when it came to light he was alive and well. But for those who had seen him on television or read about what they believed happened at Qala-i-Jangi, hopes weren't high anyway. They knew bin Laden's life story: From early childhood poverty with time spent living among Mujahideen fighters battling Soviet forces during Afghanistan's civil war; moving into Sudan before 911 followed quickly after its fall under intense pressure from the CIA (he'd been allowed safe haven there since 1992) where he set up camp like some medieval leader surrounded by loyal followers while seeking funding and training across borders. It wasn't until last year however Bin Laden fell out of favour due partly to disagreements over how much money should go towards fighting other Muslim groups such as al Qaeda splinter group Islamic State instead of the United States which culminated in Bin Laden refusing direct contact with senior Afghan Taliban leaders and accusing them in turn of being "American agents." Those accusations are not made lightly given founder Mullah Omar has always denied any collusion between himself and America but rather than causing resentment among ordinary Afghans their claims seem only to have reinforced loyalty amongst younger generations already inspired religiously through social media channels and mosques dedicated to extremist teachings on Salafism - another strand of Islam founded around 13th century Saudi Arabia.

The former Huddersfield and Birmingham manager will need to hit the ground running at Rugby Park, with the team just one point above the relegation play-off place. The Wikileaks co-founder sought asylum at London's Ecuadorean embassy in 2012 to avoid extradition to Sweden. He was arrested on Thursday after Quito "invited" his arrest over an allegation of rape from 2010 - something Assange has always denied. It has emerged that an original crash barrier was removed, even though the Roads Service could not find out why it had been put there in the first place. It is also understood a garda did drive around them and over speed bumps before the accident occurred on July 1 last year at 3am when he hit another car which crashed into him from behind as well as one parked illegally on the road beside his patrol vehicle The driver of this second vehicle then fled the scene but later handed himself to a court charged with multiple counts including driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs and leaving the scene without giving their details. The man pleaded guilty and received three months jail suspended for two years along with 1,000 compensation paid to Gardai who were injured while arresting him. He lost his job because of the conviction. This incident took place about four weeks after Sergeant McCabe's death in circumstances similar to those outlined above. Sgt McCabe's widow Lorraine initiated legal proceedings against the state claiming damages due to loss of her husband. She has since settled these actions through mediation. As part of that settlement she will receive a lump sum payment followed by monthly payments until 2024. Her lawyer said: " Sergeant Maurice McCabe would still be alive if proper procedures had been adhered to." We understand An Garda Siochana have now appointed a senior officer whose remit includes investigating deaths due to crashes involving vehicles driven by Gardai. The stricken robot, made by Knightscope, was spotted by passers-by whose photos of the aftermath quickly went viral on social media. For some, the incident seemed to sum up the lethal potential lurking in an era when more and more robots are being used to protect us from danger - or even kill for our safety. ROBOTS ARE GOING TO TAKE OUR JOBS AND RAPE US ALL: HERE'S WHAT YOU NEED TO KNOW ABOUT THE GROWTH OF AUGMENTED REALITY ROBOTICS Others saw it as a cautionary tale about the failings of technology that had gone too far out of control. But both sides also shared the same basic question: why did this happen? And how could we avoid future attacks involving autonomous weapons systems like these?"It's not just one thing," said Brian Schechter, cofounder and CEO of Knightscope, which rents security robots to companies around Silicon Valley."We need better design" of artificial intelligence software meant to help guide increasingly capable machines into dangerous situations without harming anyone, he added. "And I think people have come together to say let's do something about it because otherwise you're going down a slippery slope where there will be really bad outcomes."Schecter has been fielding many such questions recently thanks to his company's now infamous PR crisis. Last Thursday afternoon at 4 p.m., news broke online and through local television stations across America that a civilian working for Knightscope may well have killed someone with its K5 autonomous patrol robot after she ran over him accidentally while driving it near the Westlake Station shopping center (which happens to employ Schechtner). The victim is identified only as John Smith, 55. Although police don't suspect foul play, they are still investigating what happened and haven't officially released any information related to their findings yet. We simply can't answer [as of today]," said Michaud.Since 2016, King County Metro Transit police officers have loaned three such robots manufactured by Knightscope to private businesses throughout downtown Seattle. They use them primarily to keep watch on construction sites but sometimes deploy them elsewhere if requested by business owners concerned about crime taking place inside buildings. While most of the RoboCop lookalikes feature cameras attached atop their heads so operators can see whatever is happening around the perimeter, others include 360-degree video recording capabilities equipped within each unit. Each model comes complete with GPS tracking sensors encased in thick rubber casings designed to prevent tampering or damage caused by rough handling.Although other law enforcement agencies in the country own similar versions of the machine including departments in Virginia Beach, Va.; Charlotte, N.C; Las Vegas; Chicago; San Diego; San Jose, Calif.; Fresno, Calif.; Pittsburgh; Fort Worth Texas; Nashville, Tenn.; Union City, New Jersey; Albuquerque, N.M.; Orlando, Fla.; Miami Dade County; Corpus Christi, Tex.; Little Rock, Arkana and Phoenix - none appear to currently utilize them on patrol duty as frequently as transit cops in Washington state.In response to inquiries seeking clarification concerning why the agency rented two different types of robots to individual clients side-by-side rather than purchasing all models collectively, King County Sheriff Sgt. Tim Meyer explained via email Tuesday that the department employs 15 total mobile surveillance units. Andrew Apperley, 38, from Eastbourne, was reported missing after failing to return to his hotel four days after going to a Full Moon party. Richard Apperley said the situation was 'heartbreaking', adding that he would miss out on seeing him walk down the aisle The family of an Australian man who went missing in Thailand have been told by police they will continue their search for several more months and may never find answers about what happened to him (pictured is Mr Apperely's brother with Thai authorities) A body found near a riverbank in Ratchaburi province has not yet been identified as belonging to Mr Apperley but Relatives are pleading for any information regarding the disappearance of Andrew John Papell (pictured), who disappeared while travelling around Southeast Asia last month Mr Apperley had also posted photographs online appearing to show himself enjoying alcoholic drinks at parties hosted in Bangkok during New Year celebrations Police captain Krissana Pattanacharoen added: 'We can't say if this person is related or unrelated [to this case]. The investigation continues.' 'Nothing conclusive so far,' she added when asked whether those remains were linked to the suspected murder of Andrew. Ms Eriksen-Jorgensen earlier revealed how her son started partying shortly before Christmas 2016 - visiting bars across Australia until early 2017. He then flew overseas where he spent time in Bali, Singapore, Malaysia and Cambodia. In March 2018, two weeks before he vanished, friends noticed something unusual about some Instagram posts made under his name. One post showed three people standing next to each other wearing dresses and holding up one finger. Another photo appeared to be taken inside a toilet cubicle with blood splattered walls. When Ms Jorgensen realised it could possibly allude to drug use, she contacted Interpol which later tracked down each friend involved in posting these images through IP addresses and email accounts. It led them back to Melbourne nightclubs. She claimed one former boyfriend even confessed to drugging and raping her son prior to leaving home. However, no charges ever came against anyone as both men denied allegations, according to 9News.com.au. Afterwards, Mr Apperley changed his profile picture to include a blue heart emoji alongside text saying: " I love you guys'. His mother hoped this meant he was finally overcoming problems such as depression. She heard nothing further from her son. Pictured above is his Facebook page showing someone dressed like Michael Jackson dancing in front of the moon On July 8, two blogger friends called Oatsy Badger and Kyle Wilson announced via YouTube channel LightShed Podcast that they believed Mr Apperley died six months ago because social media users saw photos of his corpse online. They believe he drowned. Friends and relatives confirmed they'd seen similar pictures online too He returned to Sydney just once since January 11, asking his parents over FaceTime to take him swimming at Bondi Beach, telling them it was nice there compared to Bangkok weather. But it wasn't long into a new year adventure away from home that became increasingly bizarre, leading most interested observers to question everything still surrounding his apparent tragic death within the past few weeks. A video supposedly uploaded onto Snapchat shows him smiling happily whilst surrounded by beer bottles and pillows - indicating alcohol consumption - lying face down outside. Then, concerning messages began coming in from worried loved ones; persistently inquiring why he hadn't checked in following previous promises almost every day. On June 24, last week, his father Mike - along with concerned locals acting collectively as 'Friends of Andrew originally launched a petition calling upon Prime Minister Scott Morrison to investigate the matter. By Saturday morning, 1,100 signatures already greeted its launch. Now approaching 3,000 names, many hope Mr Apperley might soon become known publicly again - only much differently than previously imagined possible.

Edinburgh Airport said more than 781,000 passengers passed through its doors last month, a year-on-year increase of 11.7. Glasgow saw its traffic rise by 8.4 to nearly 600,000. Meanwhile, Aberdeen was up 5. The number is based on the first seven days in August and does not include any international flights but it shows that Scotland's airports are performing strongly despite disruption from strikes at British Airways over pay disputes. Edinburgh handled around 58 of Ryanair passenger numbers during July compared with 50 for the same airport two years ago - an indication of how much business travellers have come back into favour after being hit hard when oil prices slumped three or four years ago.

After the ewes gave birth, paternity tests on their lambs showed they had been fathered by the cattle rustler's ram. The heifer produced twins which DNA testing identified as Mr Thomas' offspring. The animal was seized under the Animal Health Act 1981 after which it is understood she has since passed away due to old age or disease leaving no progeny alive today.

John Fell, from Cumbria, is confident his 1.5kg ostrich egg covered in meat will earn him a Guinness World Record. Prof Allyson Pollock and colleagues at Queen Mary University of London say the contact sport is too dangerous. They do not want an outright ban but say the sport must be made safer in order for it to continue. "It's a fantastic game that we all enjoy," said Prof Pollock, who led the research with Dr Kristina Skierka from Wolfson College. "But if you're going to play, why are there so many injuries? Why aren't people keeping their brains alive while they keep on playing?" Play Video 1:44 'We have no choice': players fall silent during first minute of Super League games - video report The researchers looked specifically at four types of tackle - head-high (above shoulder height), low or high-to-low, high-mid-off (hits above midriff) and side hits below waist level. Each was associated with more severe injury than others. The data were collected between 2014 and 2017 by monitoring medical records from professional rugby league matches played across England. In total the study included 722 career concussions among 2,364 men aged 18-35 years old. There was a progressive increase over time in concussion frequency so that 8 of players sustained one per season within six seasons; 15 in seven seasons and 27 in eight seasons. Of these numbers 60 occurred when tackling highhead-high and 32 involved multiple blows to the head as part of this tackle alone. 23 took place after tackles involving players being tackled near to the ground. Skierka says other sports such as Australian Rules football which has rules aimed preventing skull fractures also show higher rates of brain trauma compared with rugby union where helmets prevent more serious impacts happening. Comparing both codes she found less risk from head-high tackles in women because they tend to use lower levels of force whereas, for example, male backs often engage in fierce clashes around rucks due to positions and tactics used in lineouts leading to greater risks overall. She recommends reducing most forms of mandatory body checking before lowering legal limits on how hard tacklers should hit each other. Currently World Rugby only bans neck roll techniques designed to choke opponents' airways. Players caught performing them can face three weeks out plus possible further punishment depending upon match review panel decisions. It does not ban taking off rival team members legs just like NFL rule changes mean fewer defensive players are allowed to land full weight on quarterbacks. But he calls current law enforcement ineffective anyway as challenges remain difficult to assess objectively since hairline damage suffered in training often goes unreported meaning incidents deemed innocuous become red card offences once put under scrutiny by officials. He adds that simply banning certain styles could lead to unintended consequences given different shape heads experience coming into contact differently. Overall though his findings suggest repeated heavy traumas occurring regularly enough causes long term harm similar to those experienced by boxers affected by chronic traumatic encephalopathy, known colloquially as CTE. This is described as neurodegenerative disease believed caused by repetitive knocks inflicted mainly through boxing punches yet increasingly seen in American Football players although its exact causes remain unclear. Current evidence suggests any number of factors including genetics and age might contribute towards susceptibility alongside lifestyle choices affecting diet alcohol intake etc.. Risks rise rapidly late teens early 20s mostly linked closely to physical activity but younger athletes may also be vulnerable especially if already prone to psychological problems. CTE first came to prominence with former USA footballer Junior Seau having shot himself dead aged 43 in 2012 leaving behind a note saying he wanted to leave behind clues about what had happened to him physically throughout life. His case spurred a flurry of ongoing studies now revealing the condition afflicts thousands of retired pros particularly at higher risk include ex-rugby union international Alix Popham diagnosed posthumously aged 40 last year. Age Scotland says official figures suggest that each year about 8,640 people in Scotland wait longer than six weeks for a council care assessment. The average "worst case" is between eight and ten months from referral to an initial assessment with only around half of these having their needs met within the agreed timescale. Ms Johnstone said: "Scottish Labour recognises how challenging it can be navigating local services when you are experiencing personal crisis or struggling with long-term illness like dementia - this must have been even more difficult during lockdown. That's why I am delighted our Scottish Government proposals will see dedicated social workers appointed by councils who will focus on helping older adults navigate complex treatments such as palliative care."

It may be their signature pose, but how and why the birds perch on one limb has been a longstanding puzzle. Now, a team from the US has shown that this behaviour is linked to bird-to-bird communication via subtle head movements in which individual petrels subtly signal each other's presence when foraging together as pairs or small groups. Dr David Lohmann of Cornell University told BBC News: "This study provides us with indirect evidence through experiments that some birds are using head postures where they can look at something without moving their whole neck." The scientists conclude that these signals help the birds quickly assess whether it pays to join up with others - an important survival skill since food resources vary widely across the oceanic islands inhabited by many seabirds (Image 1). They report online today in Current Biology.

The "surprising find" in Avebury, which is 30m (98ft) wide, is thought to be one of the site's earliest structures. The square of megaliths appears to have been erected around 3100 BC and may represent a "ritual gathering," or sacred enclosure for observing solar eclipses, researchers said at the time. As part of their research into religious sites across Britain, archaeologists from Blick Mead Archaeological Research discovered an unexplained'settlement anomaly' on aerial photographs taken before 2013. They later excavated fragments of timber that indicated long-dead trees had once lined up within it - meaning there must be something more substantial inside.

He then linked directly back to the article itself without further comment (Chinese authorities generally do not allow people access to social networking sites like Twitter).

It forced the band to remain anonymous for almost a year: No photographs, no interviews, no videos. But there was an upside. Last year, as she caught a train home from work in London's Paddington station, she overheard two women talking about how much they loved their boyfriends' new music - and one of them turned out not only be her colleague but also an old friend who hadn't seen each other since school. "That kind of stuff is nice," says Fenton bluntly over Zoom with The Guardian before our interview later that day at Rough Trade East. "I can pontificate on things like my most recent album being really good or bad if I want." It doesn't take long for us both to realise we're bored of this conversation already; it feels exactly like what you'd imagine interviewing someone so relentlessly upbeat would feel like (a lot). We talk through Stormzy's third album Heavy Is The Head strong musically then move onto his grime production days, when he made tracks including Big For Your Boots by Wretch 32. Then comes the rowdy years spent touring across Europe three times, playing festivals such as Glastonbury and T In The Park alongside big names such as Jay-Z, Drake and Kanye West. And finally, now, at 27, after more than half a decade together doing just what he loves best, here are Fenton and Smith signing up to headline Reading Leeds 2021 - even though last time around didn't go quite right. The private CaixinMarkit manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) dropped to 47.8 in July from 49.4 in the previous month. It is worse than a preliminary reading of 48.2 and is at its lowest since February 2009, during the global financial crisis. In June it was 49.7. The 50-mark separates growth from contraction on a monthly basis. China's economy has been gradually recovering after being hard hit by widespread restrictions put in place to contain COVID-19 infections between January and April this year.

The normal body tissues show up as green, while the cancer comes out as intense red spots. The team, at the University of Tokyo and the RIKEN Quantitative Biology Center, has published their results in the journal Scientific Reports. This work was done on mouse tissue samples that were taken from mice with breast tumors after surgery to remove them. Researchers first stained these cells for a protein called CD34 so they could tell which ones were healthy or unhealthy. Then those cells were labeled with another marker (PDF) called CM11 that fluoresces when exposed to blue light. Finally, some more tumor-specific markers are used; each one lights up separately under different wavelengths of light: 633 nm is used by green algae, 532nm by bacteria, 529 nm by researchers studying photosynthesis, 488nm by plants, 395nm by insects, and 365nm by humans - so it's not just visible but also compatible with most off-the-shelf microscopes. And if you've ever watched glowing bioluminescent plankton before bedtime, then this last bit will sound familiar too. When all three layers of fluorescent labeling have been combined into single cell images using an imaging microscope, what we get is something like this image below. It looks kind of cool! But there's usable information here too.

"I may be old, but at least I am happy," she added in a statement read out by lawyer Michael O'Riordan on Wednesday before Judge John Morrissey ordered her to pay 3m damages. The judge had earlier heard evidence of how Ms McKay's husband promised their children that they would inherit his family home when he died after which it was not sold or given away despite having been valued as being worth more than 1 million (840 000). He also gave instructions regarding who should have custody over them if anything happened to him, with Ms McKay receiving access only once every three months while spending Christmas Day alone without any contact from anyone during those days except Mr Dwyer whom she regarded as both a father figure and friend. In March 2011, he requested to take temporary sole guardianship of one child because he feared what might happen to himself following an accident where he sustained multiple injuries including fractures and broken bones requiring surgery. However, this request did not result in changes made inside the house, according to evidence presented. The court previously heard there were no locks on doors throughout most areas of the property apart from bedrooms which prevented neighbours seeing who went in and out - save for two windows located near the kitchen area through which people could view into the garden. There were only four keys issued for entering the front door allowing entry to all rooms within. When gardai first arrived at the scene they found Ms McKay unconscious lying face down beside the fireplace surrounded by empty vodka bottles with another partially consumed bottle nearby along with a number of prescription tablets scattered about. Four further pills in blister packs containing Nembutal along with some anxiety medication were later uncovered behind a sofa cushion. She has since spent time living in various care homes due mainly to problems caused by alcohol abuse; however, she still sleeps downstairs in the main bedroom of the cottage next to the main entrance steps leading up towards the rear patio doors overlooking the back yard. Protesters hung a sign over the city's famous Rialto bridge and some carried suitcases to symbolise having to leave. Locals say they are being forced out by high rents, housing shortages and bleak job prospects as Italy struggles with an economic downturn that is now in its sixth year. The "Occupy Garibaldi" movement has been heavily criticised for not making clear what it wants from Rome and accusing Mayor Virginia Raggi of doing too little about sky-high property prices. Demonstrators outside City Hall held up signs reading: 'Here there will be no revolution', while others shouted insults at police lined behind metal barriers blocking access to the building. Several protesters tried several times to breach those barricades but were pushed back each time by officers wielding batons. A handful then threw objects at them before dispersing. Police said five people had been detained on suspicion of attacking officers or resisting arrest.

Daniel Bragg, 37, hit Julie Cook, 44, so hard he broke her left eye socket in the assault, police said. Ms Cook fell and hit her head on the floor, losing consciousness for a short time before being taken to hospital where she needed surgery and was kept under observation overnight Bragg, of Stockton-on Tees, pleaded guilty at an earlier hearing to grievous bodily harm with intent while armed. He had been due to stand trial but changed his plea today. He will be sentenced tomorrow morning when it is expected that two other charges against him - wounding with intent - will also go ahead alongside this conviction. Sentencing guidelines state Bragg faces up to 12 years behind bars. Prosecutor Rachel Masters told Teesside Crown Court how Bragg attacked his victim after they returned home from visiting friends together. The pair spent much of their relationship apart as each lived with different partners. They got back together however during lockdown last year, which has now ended temporarily because of England's third national coronavirus shutdown. The court heard how Mr Bragg began drinking excessively resulting in them getting into arguments and Ms Cook leaving in the early hours of September 25 last year. She later decided to return around 3am or 4am on Sunday November 1 2020 'out of concern' for what might happen if she didn't come back soon enough. It was then that Bragg struck out violently towards the mother-of-two who suffered brain injuries and lost sight in one eye following the vicious attack. Mr Justice Goss added: "She describes you as controlling throughout your relationship with her." Julie described how Daniel would often turn violent over nothing and control every aspect of her life including not allowing any men round In evidence read on behalf by Danielle Binns prosecuting, Julie explained how he started attacking her after returning home drunk. She stated: I] tried telling him I wanted my stuff and we were done [but] he just wouldn't let me leave until there wasn't anymore room for me inside so finally felt like I couldn't get away from him without hurting myself even more than already did."

Darby, 28, made 194 league appearances for the Bantams and helped them to promotion from League Two in 2013. The suppliers, one making seats and the other parts used in gearboxes, have stopped delivering to VW in a contract row. Car and parts production has already been halted at some sites as workers go on strike until Monday, while no new orders will be taken at others until Tuesday afternoon, sources close to the company said. VW declined comment ahead of an event with union leaders later Friday morning that is being closely watched by investors who fear disruptions could spread across Germany's car industry if talks fail to resolve the dispute during Europe's summer vacation season - when plants are closed anyway for two weeks or more. Most analysts say they still see limited short-term impact from the stoppages unless it drags out further than three days or leads to widespread strikes elsewhere in the sector. But many economists warn there would likely be serious knock-on effects next year due to reduced supply capacity given the complexity of car manufacturing processes where even minor delays can affect the component flow of entire vehicle lines. "If this continues beyond Sunday then we'll start getting into real trouble," warned Ralph Wiechers, head economist at Commerzbank AG, adding he saw only a 5 percent chance of such extreme circumstances occurring. Volkswagen shares were down 1 percent against 0.3 percent gains for Germany's bluechip DAX index after losing 3.6 percent over Wednesday and Thursday. Traders expect European stock markets generally to remain choppy throughout the long weekend because most major exchanges shut their trading floors early.

The 35-year-old will have security clearance and access to classified information, but no official title or salary when she works in the West Wing. She will serve as her father's "eyes and ears," reporting back to him on staffing, policy issues and other matters Kushner said Meghan has a "great love for the country" and wants to work with world leaders and help them understand the administration's priorities. He cited her participation this week in an event at the United Nations on women that was organized by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson's wife, Renda St. Clair.

One of the first out of the blocks is a touring production of All My Sons by black-led theatre company Talawa. The story centres on all-American couple Joe and Kate Keller, whose lives are thrown into chaos when one of their sons, Chris (the character played in this version by Jamie Muscato), goes missing during America's entrance to World War Two after he was implicated with his shipbuilding business in an industrial espionage case involving German aircraft components made from steel supplied through false invoices. The play opens at Cardiff Assembly Hall tomorrow before moving around Wales over four weeks for a total run time just shy of three hours. It will then be shown live via video stream throughout Europe until early September as part of the International Theatre Festival De Vlaanderen 2020 programme funded by Creative Europe Programme funds managed by the European Union's Media Programmes Body.

Kallum Watkins gave the bottom-of-the-table Rhinos an early lead but Willie Isa's first two Wigan tries put them 12-4 ahead at the break. George Williams, Dom Manfredi and Ben Flower all crossed for the Warriors in an impressive display before Tony Clubb pulled one back late on to make it a tense finish. "We are glad with that result," said Wane when asked if his team were getting better as they had been tipped by many pundits to be relegated this year after wholesale personnel changes following their Grand Final triumph last term. "It was tough - I thought we came out of our half pretty well." On the performance he added: "I think there is more in us than what you saw today...but it takes time. It will take another six weeks or so until we get where I want us to go." Asked about Leeds' problems, having won just once since February - against London Broncos - coach Brian McDermott insisted: "There'll always be change around here because things aren't going right; people don't like losing games...it seems obvious now (to say) how strong some teams have become under different circumstances at other clubs."

Two employees of the Council on American Islamic Relations (CAIR) were initially quarantined in the office. A note reading "die a painful death, Muslims," was in the envelope with the white powder and apparently originated from someone who drove by CAIR's offices following the attacks at Los Angeles International Airport last week when two suicide bombers blew themselves up injuring dozens. The FBI is investigating whether this letter is related to that incident or not."

Syrian state media says toxic gas was contained in shells that rebels have been firing at government-held areas in the divided city. Russian news agency Interfax says seven people died and 15 were injured when a shell hit an apartment building on Wednesday morning, citing local officials The Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights monitoring group said there is also "talk of chlorine gas being used" by insurgents against pro-government forces since Tuesday night. It reported 21 air strikes late on Sunday targeting rebel positions in eastern Aleppo including use of barrel bombs, which are crudely dropped from helicopters or fighter jets. The Local Coordination Committees activist network has documented more than 1,300 civilian deaths caused by such attacks during Syria's conflict. Allegations of chemical weapons come as world powers prepare to meet next month with Iran and Lebanon's Hezbollah movement - all allies of President Bashar Assad who Washington accuses of backing his brutal campaign to crush opposition groups across war-ravaged Syria. A UN Security Council resolution requires Damascus to remove its stockpile under international supervision but it remains unclear what would happen if it fails to do so
