Susan Fowler, a software engineer, wrote a blog post about a "very, very strange year at Uber." In it, she says her manager tried to have sex with her on his desk. She also alleges that he and other managers discriminated against her based on her race and gender. The allegations were published in February 2017 by former The Information reporter Mike Isaac who is writing a book called Bad Blood: Secrets and Lies in a Silicon Valley Startup. According to Bloomberg, the lawsuit will be filed under seal Friday in San Francisco Superior Court. It's unclear when it may become public.

Some dairy farmers have said they face going out of business if prices they receive for their products do not rise. They have held protests at supermarkets to show their frustration, and some are seeking support from state lawmakers in their states to take action against the big grocery chains that buy milk. Travelers who left New York City with plans to spend Thanksgiving at home were forced into a last-minute scramble after Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced Tuesday that the state would place restrictions on gatherings. Under his new rules, indoor dining is suspended but food can be served outside starting Wednesday - as long as people stay 6 feet apart. But health officials warn that even outdoor gatherings pose risks, especially as colder weather sets in. And gyms, too, risk being closed altogether under the latest rules. "It's really scary," said Zoriana Skordilis, whose family had been planning to gather for her mother's birthday this week before deciding it was too risky. "We don't want anyone coming here getting sick."

Lewis-Francis took up the sport four months ago with the aim of competing at the Pyeongchang 2018 Winter Olympics. He won 4x100m relay gold at the 2004 Summer Games. GB bobsleigh team member Lewis-Francis said: "I'm thrilled to have been selected and I feel this is great recognition for all my hard work, training sessions on ice in London over a number of years." The 24 athletes who will represent Great Britain are among 56 chosen by UK Sport as part of its Olympic Winter Programme. The rest - including those representing Team England - have qualified via other routes such as the World Cup circuit or world championships.

Steven Tolley, 48, from Tiverton was one of three men injured while working on the northbound carriageway of the A361 at Gornhay Cross, Tiverton. He was airlifted to Derriford Hospital in Plymouth where he died later that evening with his family by his side. His partner Amanda Whittaker said: "He will be missed terribly but never forgotten." His family set up a JustGiving page which has already raised 1,850 for Acorns Children's Hospice South West and Mid Devon who looked after him during his final days. Paying tribute, she added: Steve had been married once before many years ago like me and my daughter we have two beautiful children together along with our five grandchildren so this tragic accident is even more heartbreaking as I know it would've broken his heart too if something happened to us all especially now when everything seemed to just start getting back to normal life again following lockdown restrictions lifting since last summer due to COVID-19 hopefully things can go back to how they were in future because we couldn't bare another loss like this ever happening definitely not losing Steve twice please God no!"

Even though Cuba is less than 100 miles away from the US, the two counties fell out in 1959, and no American president has visited since then. The fall out happened as Fidel Castro gained control of the country with a communist revolution which overthrew Fulgencio Batista who was backed by the United States government at that time. The last President to visit Cuba was Calvin Coolidge back in 1928 when he became one of 13 presidents or Vice-Presidents to have travelled there during their term. Mr Trump will be visiting Florida where many Cuban immigrants live today before travelling on to Miami for his speech.

Helen Smith, who lives in Deal with her British husband and their two children, applied for a new visa last September. But she is still waiting for officials to return it after they rejected the application due to an error on page one of form B11a, which had been filled out incorrectly by Helen's employer. The 33-year-old English teacher was told that without this particular document, she will have no official right of residence - meaning she can't work or pay taxes until the Home Office gives permission formally confirmed. 'It has caused me so much stress,' said Mrs Smith. She added: 'I'm not sure what I would do if my family were deported.'

For most of US history, party nominees have been decided by political power brokers and deal-makers behind closed doors. Parties operate like private clubs - they make their own rules to advance the interests of insiders with money or influence - not voters. The problem is that this process makes it difficult for Americans to choose a leader who represents them," said Bernie Sanders Sanders then noted in his statement "The Democratic Party must reform its nominating process so that we are able to select our nominee through an open primary system which allows people to vote." He went on: "I support the idea of having state primaries occur at least 9 months before the national convention... This will give states more time and flexibility to adapt their voting systems accordingly" (and he called for same day registration). And adding as well: "It's imperative that undecided primary voters be given every opportunity possible to participate." [Note what happens if Biden does win? At any rate I expect something very similar from the Trump campaign should things go badly.] So all those pushing for 'open' nominations need to keep up pressure til the end! It's long overdue anyway...

Within minutes, water cannon showered the demonstrators and there were loud thuds as tear gas canisters were fired. People ran into the side streets of this poor neighbourhood, on the edge of Hong Kong Island's central business district. In one area a young protester was carried away by volunteers in yellow T-shirts who used umbrellas to shield him from view before he disappeared among crowds of black clad protesters farther down Nathan Road. There were also scuffles between police firing pepper spray and other officers swinging batons at people standing or sitting on the ground - all amidst widespread confusion and anxiety over what comes next for these protests that have been going on since June 9 but only gained momentum again after media tycoon Jimmy Lai was arrested under Beijing's new security law.

The athlete set records for the fastest marathon for a double amputee and has won two Paralympic 200m gold medals. Photographer David Baird has charted Whitehead's progress for many years, as he tells BBC Sport: "I first took one of Steve's photos when I was shooting at an event in Bristol 20-odd years ago," says photographer David Baird. "He said that if you wanted to do something great with your life then go into sport photography - so from day one we were on the same page." This week, their relationship is being celebrated by National Geographic magazine which named him this year's Sports Photojournalist Of The Year (SPOTY) after his series about Para-athlete Richard Whitehead won last year's Action category prize. It marks the culmination of 10 days spent following Whitehead across five continents during 2018. A body composition scan will give me some baseline figures but no matter how much weight I lose or how strong my legs are it doesn't change anything physiologically in terms of what goes wrong between my ears. For people who have never been injured there can be quite a gap because they don't understand pain management or rehabilitation, let alone having lost limb function yourself. In order to tell someone else's story well you need empathy; understanding injury psychology helps create those connections and help them feel like part of a team rather than just another face in front of the camera. There had already been plenty of press coverage around all aspects of Whitehead's training and preparation before meeting up again ahead of the World Championships in Dubai earlier this month where 42 athletes competed under the banner 'Para Athletics'. But few visitors would know more about his everyday existence outside competition than Baird and his fellow photojournalists Daniel Gravis and Tim Clayton. After initially agreeing not speak about each other while working together, now everyone seems happy enough to share stories over beers later in the evening back in London sober ones. Their work ethic also shines through once off camera too; spending long hours waiting out the rain in freezing temperatures until photographers' light meters start flashing red means getting close to the action without actually crossing its path. That extra effort pays dividends though; capturing intimate moments such as Whitehead jogging alongside his guide runner Peter Knight's wife at Dorney Lake near Windsor Castle or sprinting towards home winning the men's 100m T38 race at the European championships in Berlin. Asking for permission isn't always necessary either; Baird got Whitehead running past Buckingham Palace en route to filming from Tower Bridge for a TV segment, before encouraging spectators along the South Bank promenade to cheer louder every time he went past. We've shared countless conversations both personally and professionally throughout our careers... When he broke world records aged 14, [Whitehead] told us via text message saying 'that's amazing, keep going!' To hear a young man say that meant everything to us because none of these things happen overnight even when success does come very quickly. Having seen different sides within athletics, swimming, cycling etc., probably the biggest challenge para sports faces compared to able bodied competitors relates to funding - especially the younger generations coming through. With disability comes challenges whether physical or psychological meaning the burden falls heavier onto personal support workerspartners, parents etcetera whereas able bodies get financial backing straight away. Any journalist covering any kind of sporting events should understand completely why disabled individuals want access to certain areas, facilities equipment which may seem basic but is essential given limited opportunities available due to local authority budgets cuts etc. If nothing changes soon then Britain could really struggle against rivals further down field in terms of talent pool availability. Thankfully British Athletics invests heavily into grassroots programmes helping youngsters regardless of ability gain crucial experience competing alongside others irrespective of impairment requirements. Even Mr Blobby himself knows Steve Whitaker is high quality stuff! All three journalists agree that the best thing anyone could ever achieve is self belief. No doubt the words of encouragement offered by Whitehead early on in Baird's career helped spur ambitions to become a fulltime professional photographer perhaps further fuelled by witnessing US track star Oscar Pistorius compete in 2012. Watching a double leg amputee run 400m faster than most elite sprinters came as a shock to the system although flashbulbs apparently weren't needed to capture images making history forever. Another highlight included capturing shots of Chris Froome arriving late to Team Sky's pre-race briefing at Paris-Roubaix 2015 in contrast to Bradley Wiggins jumping on board ready for battle aboard Sir Dave Brailsford's bike shortly afterwards. Although trepidation crept in when hitting refresh on Twitter anticipating negative comments regarding prior accusations surrounding performance enhancing drug use amongst cyclists despite evidence suggesting otherwise, sometimes truth hurts. Yet not giving up was worth fighting tooth and nail for in the end as confidence levels soared seeing several projects completed from Whitehead including featuring in October 2017 edition of Men's Health UK, plus speaking engagements in schools whilst continuing to travel annually overseas partly funded by commercial shoots involving brands targeting audiences eager to see real inspirational heroes portrayed instead of fantasy idealised characters. All examples of this group, known as the Archosauromorpha, lay eggs. This led some scientists to wonder whether there was something in their biology that prevented live births. But examination showed that almost all had a distinct pelvis and vertebrae - which is what you'd expect from pelvic bones associated with an adult animal giving birth. So we know it could be done: long-necked dinosaurs such as Brachiosaurus gave birth by pushing the baby out through its cloaca (the hole where waste leaves a dinosaur). So why didn't the first archosaurs do likewise? Why were they laying eggs instead if they shared so many other features between them and living reptiles today? Some experts even suggest that reproduction may have been more difficult for early animals because eggshells are stronger than shells formed during life; however, our analysis shows no evidence showing how much tougher or thinner these ancient eggshell membranes might have become over time. The answer probably lies somewhere else... but nobody has yet pinpointed exactly when those changes took place.

Some two dozen behemoths were identified, all with masses in excess of a hundred times that of the Sun. Four were known previously, including the remarkable colossus catalogued as R136a1, which was first seen by astronomers more than 50 years ago and is believed to weigh roughly 450 solar masses yet still has not been directly observed - although it may have been glimpsed briefly through an eclipse). Image copyright NASA Image caption The Hubble Ultra Deep Field took advantage of the 11-year gap between servicing missions for Nasa's famed space telescope "This catalogue tells us we need a better understanding about how black holes form," explained Prof Jamie Bock from CaltechIPACS. The new results also confirm several other longstanding mysteries involving these strange objects: they are far less dense than expected; their orbits can change dramatically over time rather like planets circling around stars or moons orbiting Jupiter and Saturn; they appear to eject material out into intergalactic space at high speeds when they grow rapidly. And there doesn't seem to be any correlation between size and mass either. There are at least half a million supermassive blackholes lurking across our observable Universe but this one stands alone because of its apparent youth and proximity (it lies just under 25,000 light-years away in the southern constellation Fornax). This means that if future instruments such as ESO's Extremely Large Telescope do discover others nearby then this will provide further clues as to what makes them tick so quickly after the Big Bang itself teemed with lots of activity. Researchers hope to learn how much it weighed, how it moved and what it used its iconic back plates for. A UK team has scanned each of its 360 bones in 3D using X-ray computed tomography (CT) scanners at the Natural History Museum's Centre for GeoGenetics in Cambridge, which is part funded by a grant from the National Geographic Society. The researchers also plan to study DNA samples taken during expeditions that discovered new pterosaur species on islands off Madagascar or Komodo Island, an area where they haven't previously found any evidence of ancient reptiles living there - a sign that these animals might have lived elsewhere as well but were wiped out before scientists could explore them with advanced technology such as CT scanning. "We are trying to bring all this information together to create a family tree," says David Martill of the University of Portsmouth, who leads the project along with his colleague Nizar Ibrahim. But even if they can assemble one based only on their physical remains, other experts say more questions will remain unsolved about Pteranodon than answers: How many subspecies did it evolve into? Where does it fit within the larger picture of evolution among flying creatures? And why was it able to fly when so many others couldn't?

That is the eye-catching accusation in the Guardian, following a report in a trade publication, the Bookseller. Amazon will not confirm that it has managed to do this. The accusation comes from someone who claims access to an internal document which describes the sort of data collection done by its Kindle e-reader and reports on what was found when those details were asked for via the company's Web site privacy page: The first thing we did was find out how many books people have bought using their Amazon account - but only if they had also used other services such as Audible or Goodreads (Amazon's social media book club). We noted each purchase under 'BooksAudiobooks Bought With Your Account'... Once you reach 20 purchases the specific title (s) are listed alongside your account ID; clicking one takes us back up to our main search screen with all relevant products displayed below. If there is more than one item per customer then the count of items rises until reaching 40 at which point no further information appears online about any individual purchases. These numbers appear entirely unrelated to overall sales figures." There may be some truth here - perhaps the "book" line refers less strictly to physical publications and includes digital editions too? But even so, whose interests can't possibly come into play here beyond Amazon's own? And does anyone really think consumers would be OK with having their reading habits tracked like that without being told up front?!

Media playback is not supported on this device Since dethroning Wladimir Klitschko in Dusseldorf last November, the Briton has resembled a runaway lorry - smashing through road blocks and red lights WBC heavyweight champion Tyson Fury says his decision to go into exile after beating Wladimir Klitschko was necessary because he had "hit rock bottom." Fury stopped Klitschko at Duesseldorf's Esprit Arena on 29 November 2015 with a stunning display of boxing that earned him praise from many observers. But just 68 days later, the 28-year-old announced he would never fight again as it appeared an addiction to cocaine and alcohol were beginning to take their toll. "I didn't know how much damage I'd done," said Fury ahead of Saturday night's rematch against Ukrainian Klitscko at the Manchester Arena. The 28-year-old, who fought for more than three years before winning world titles, watched footage of himself during training camp and found there was little resemblance between what happened then and now. He added: "It makes me sick seeing myself like that. It made me realise where my life could have gone if I hadn't been able to stop." After stepping away from the ring following his win over Klitschko, Fury became embroiled in controversy when he claimed fellow British boxer Anthony Joshua should be shot for fighting "like a black guy." He also criticised homosexuality and raped women. In March 2016, UK Anti-Doping (Ukad) requested samples taken from Fury by testers shortly before his stoppage victory over Francesco Pianeta in August 2015. In April 2017 Ukad informed the fighter they had recorded traces of nandrolone metabolites in two urine samples. The substance can improve strength but can also mask evidence of other illegal substances being used. Three months ago, Ukad withdrew its case citing lack of evidence, saying neither party wished to proceed further or appeal to the independent National Antidoping Panel (Nasp). Shortly afterwards Fury confirmed plans to return to action within 12 weeks without giving any details about opponents, venues or dates. On Tuesday, promoter Frank Warren revealed American Deontay Wilder will face unbeaten Cuban Luis Ortiz on 6 September, with a likely date of 14 October set aside for the bout.

Despite having only joined Manchester United two years earlier after leaving neighbours City as captain, Cantona had quickly become a fans favourite during his first season following spells at Auxerre (early 1980s), Lens (1983-85) and Palace (1985). But he suffered racist abuse while playing against Bulgaria before Euro 92 which prompted French president Jacques Chirac to ban him from international football until 1995. He missed France's victorious World Cup campaign later that year through injury and retired from club duty weeks after lifting the cup again in 1994 because of fears over head injuries. He then started coaching part time across Europe before returning to Old Trafford fulltime in 2007 where he remains today.

Nearly 25,000 signatures - 10 of Cardiff's voters - are needed to force a vote on the issue. The petition proposed two options: either scrapping all cross-border plans entirely until after May 2015 general election; or agreeing an "integrated transport plan" which could include new crossings at either Barry Docks or Bargoed to connect Porthcawl with Bridgend county borough across the River Ogmore estuary as well as another crossing between NantgarwBridgend and PenarthMerthyr Tydfil by way of the M4 motorway bridge over the river Usk.

Kirsty McGuire, from Dover, Kent, said her son Codie McDowell was left screaming with pain. The accident in East Sussex has led his family to warn of the dangers of using inflatables on open water She added: 'He is still upset about it today and I'm glad he's been able to share what happened as we don't want anyone else going through this.' His mother described how she tried desperately to reach him after jumping into a car by herself when Codie failed to come up for air again at 6pm that evening last week. She said: 'I got there just before 7pm but they wouldn't let me get close so I sent my husband round instead - who could see where our boy had somehow managed to paddle out even further than usual, near one of those big yellow boat houses. 'My dad-in law went down too because it looked like we'd lost sight of them altogether. He found Codie floating face down half way between two boats in an area which would have normally meant safety lines were tied off securely around each pontoon and therefore safe for swimming. But sadly not this time... The youngster (pictured right) suffered severe injuries following the incident involving three children playing on inflatable toys while visiting Herne Bay beach, West Sussex on July 15 Codie pictured wearing soft skull mask during visit to Legoland with parents Kirsty McDonald and Sean McDowel The four are understood to be friends from Canterbury Boys School. Pictured L-R Codie, Charlie Clutterbuck, Josh Phillips and Thomas Jones She continued: ' (We think) Either something gave away whilst kids were bouncing on or someone kicked their ball and made it pop sending everyone running back towards shore. They all ran straight over to us once safely back beside land rather than checking if any body needed assistance! 'Our little man was only yards away from being sucked under and possibly losing his life due to complete disregard for adults watching everything unfold next to them.' Inflatable pool floats can cost 20 online but experts say the best ones will set you back far more than that. A more durable model involves less chance of breaking apart.

Foredowne Boarding Kennel is facing allegations about how dogs, seized by Devon and Cornwall Police and placed there, were kept without exercise. The licensing authority, Teignbridge Council, said it was investigating the charges made in a BBC Panorama programme broadcast on Thursday night. Its report will be sent to its panel for consideration at an October meeting of their Licensing Committee which can impose financial penalties or revoke licences if they are found guilty." A spokesperson from Downe Lodge told us: "We have not been contacted directly by any dog owner regarding this matter but we would encourage anyone who has concerns over our care standards to contact us so that these issues may be resolved as quickly as possible."

The BBC will broadcast more than 3,000 hours of coverage, including 550 hours of television on BBC One and BBC Four. BBC Radio 5 live and 5 live sports extra will provide comprehensive radio coverage with up to 4,500 hours across the two networks during the 16 days of competition alone. All 26 matches from the first round through to quarter-finals are being shown on Sky Sports 1 (no games in Scotland). All 32 matches from the second stage onwards are being screened by ITV, with all four semi finals and final also airing free to air via terrestrial channels - one match per day, meaning a potential six million homes would be able to watch the whole tournament for nothing if they wanted. This compares favourably against last year's World Cup where only three third place play off games were aired as part of its highlights show. The opening ceremony is getting an hour long slot on Channel 4 while it has been announced that the England v Italy friendly at Wembley next May will form the centrepiece of another major UK TV event: "Italians Vs English Football 2012 Live From London" which I have no doubt we can expect much more information about soon enough...

Zeid Raad Al Hussein described the incident, in which 10 people were wounded, as "extremely shocking." Cizre has been the focus of an offensive by Turkey's army against the Kurdish rebel group PKK. Turkey said it had retaliated to fire from a mountain top into its forces and that 36 PKK members had been killed since fighting began last week. A senior Turkish security official also accused Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF), a U.S.-backed militia alliance dominated by Kurds, of firing on his troops during clashes south of Kobani town further west along the border with Syria earlier this month. The SDF denied those allegations but urged Ankara not to violate what they called their "de-escalation zone" there. The zones are part of diplomatic efforts for a wider truce across northern Syria after nearly eight years of war between rebels opposed to President Bashar al-Assad and government forces supported by Russia and Iran.

The man had left the medals on a work surface to clean before leaving his home in Wootton Park, Bristol, only to find on his return that they had vanished. He has since been reunited with them by police after he saw an appeal for their safe return and officers traced them back to him.

On one occasion there was only one commode available for more than 100 patients at North Middlesex University Hospital, a report by the watchdog said. Emergency services at the London hospital were also "hit and miss" during an AE visit in June 2019 where ambulances did not arrive as quickly as they should have done due to problems with their locator system. The Care Quality Commission (CQC) has slapped down bosses of Wrexham Maelor Hospital after it found five out of six wards had failed to meet safety standards Credit: PA ImagesPeter Byrne And inspectors raised concerns about the recruitment process used when sourcing ward staff - particularly nurses' aides who look after people's personal care needs such as washing them or cleaning their teeth. At times, up to 60 of these positions went unfilled because of delays in finding suitable candidates, while managers felt that checking references could be too time-consuming given staffing pressures on other units. In total 10 recommendations were made by CQC officials following its inspection last March which took place before coronavirus reached Britain. They included ensuring all information technology systems are working safely and effectively so patient records can be accessed easily. The regulator concluded that there is no overall plan to improve conditions across all departments but progress towards some improvements identified has been good. It added that levels of pain among older residents were low despite evidence suggesting this may lead to lower quality end of life care. Sorry, this content isn't available on your device.

Dickson carried his bat for 207 not out, as Shiv Thakor's maiden five-wicket haul saw Kent all out for 412. Derbyshire's Billy Godleman retired hurt without facing a ball after taking an awful blow on the helmet from Jordan Cox while fielding at short leg but he was able to return later in the day and carry his side through with support from Ben Slater (35) before Daryn Smit sealed victory by having Ravi Rampaul caught off the last delivery of the match. Trent Rockets won their opening fixture against Essex Eagles despite being bowled out twice - for 86 in their first innings and 64 second time around, with Johan Botha top scoring with 22 runs both times. Stephen Peters' medium pace spell of 4-22 led to Essex losing seven wickets for just 25 runs inside 15 overs on Sunday afternoon before Tom Westley hit 59 not out to guide them home with two balls remaining. In reply, Matthew Quinn took 6-45 in 30 overs as Essex collapsed again this morning although they did recover somewhat with Raymon Reifer hitting 40 before being run out by Dane Paterson. However, Justyn Knight completed 10 catches behind the stumps as Trent pushed for victory which came when Paul Walter edged Matt Coles to David Wiese low down at gully and Josh Cobb finished unbeaten on 38 from 28 deliveries.

Sentinel-1b was carried into orbit by a Soyuz rocket that flew out of Sinamary in French Guiana. The new platform will monitor shipping lanes for pollution and icebergs, and survey the Earth's environment from space to better understand climate change and natural disasters such as forest fires, flooding or volcanic eruptions. The satellite uses radar imaging technology developed at NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) which has been used on several previous missions including its first Sentry mission launched in 2007. Unlike other satellites that send information back to remote ground stations via radio signals, Sentinel 1B measures ocean conditions using high resolution "pings" sent through the water itself between the spacecraft and an antenna array located on land. This method allows scientists to measure waves, currents, sea ice extent and snow cover with greater accuracy than ever before. While initial data collected over recent days have revealed some areas of concern - notably strong winds across much of Greenland creating large amounts of floating glacial ice, breaking off icebergs and melting glaciers - they also show how healthy our oceans currently are. Overall, global average sea levels remain stable despite significant changes taking place around Antarctica where more than 250 billion tonnes of ice is being lost each year, according to ESA.

The 35-year-old joined the Iron from Blackpool in 2013 and has made 119 league appearances for the League One side. He helped them to a third-placed finish this season, before losing out on promotion after suffering defeat to Bradford City in the play-off final at Wembley Stadium last month. During his time with Hartlepool United, Ward was named as PFA Player of the Year during their 201516 campaign when they went on an incredible run that saw them beat teams like Peterborough United and Middlesbrough en route to lifting the EFL Trophy. As well being crowned Football League (EFL) Manager's Managers' Association (MMA) Manager of the Month three times throughout his stint there, he also received two awards by adding up votes from players: one for the Supporters' Goal of the Season following his strike against Chesterfield in February 2016, while another voted him into first place ahead of other nominees including David Nugent and Kevin Nolan just over 12 months later - leading to Michael Chopra winning it instead!

The sculpture, depicting a sprawled murder victim surrounded by police tape, was crowned winner of the Cornwall Beach Games sandcastle competition. But Devon and Cornwall Police was criticised after boasting about it on Twitter for its response to an alleged rape at nearby Perranporth beach in June 2015: While we were delighted with this year's winning creation - which depicted a woman being comforted following a horrific crime - sadly there seems little positive that can be taken from today as images emerged showing tourists behaving badly around our beaches... pic.twitter.comEb8y4sQ1gj - DCP West (DCPRWest) August 10, 2018 "I think they are just trying to show off their own work. They aren't very good at communicating what is actually going on [in terms of policing]," said Pritchard-Jones when she saw the tweet. She added later via email: "It doesn't seem like appropriate content if someone has visited because you have allegedly raped somebody recently? You might want people coming back but seeming prideful over such things isn't really how I would go." In 2017 campaigners urged the UK government not to use photos of dead children found on Libyan shores on advertising campaigns targeting migrants crossing the Mediterranean sea towards Europe. The Home Office apologised before removing all references to migrant tragedies from posters made during Operation Nimrod between 2014-16, including some pictures featuring smiling faces alongside slogans warning against making dangerous journeys across continents to claim asylum or residency rights elsewhere (see image below). A spokesperson told Dezeen: "We will continue working closely with charities to ensure high standards throughout the design process."

Sredojevic, who on Sunday lead the Cranes to their first Africa Cup of Nations finals since 1978, complained on social media about not being paid. Fufa admits it owes the national team coach and his technical bench Shs2 billion (500,000) in allowances plus bonuses from a seven-month period up to February 2019 - with that amount rising as they backed out of friendlies against Uganda (in Kampala), DRC Congo (in Kinshasa) during Ramadan. The federation says it has been cash strapped due to lack of sponsorship.

Firefighters dealt with blazes on Friday overnight at garage forecourts in Salisbury and Durrington as well as in residential areas of Amesbury. An aircraft was also found burnt out at Lee-on-the-Solent, Hampshire police said. "The cause of the fires are not yet known," a force spokesman added. "However we have spoken to residents who reported smelling burning before seeing smoke."

Ajinkya Rahane became the fifth Indian to score centuries in both innings of a Test match as they declared on 267-5. In reply, captain Hashim Amla (23 not out) took South Africa through to lunch without any further loss at 182 for 3. For the hosts, it was their third successive collapse and their fourth overall this series after being bowled out twice - first against Australia and then by India inside two days here last week. The second morning brought good news too with pace spearhead Dale Steyn expectedly passing fitness tests that will allow him play his 100th Test from Tuesday onwards alongside Shaun Pollock who is playing his swansong game. When stumps were drawn early due to bad light, Rahul had scored 102 off 209 balls while Pujara made 91 off 227 deliveries. Virat Kohli came into bat during the final over before tea but did not face a delivery since he got a reprieve when he edged Kagiso Rabada (277). He played some delightful strokes though including an exquisite backfoot drive which sailed past gully for four runs. There seemed no trouble getting under the ball even despite all the scrutiny surrounding his form ahead of next month's Champions Trophy. It may have been different if he hadn't survived what could well be termed umpire's call as Mohammed Shami was given lbw only for replays to show that the thick edge missed leg stump completely. But there didn't seem much doubt about other dismissals like Wriddhiman Saha failing once again when caught behind down the leg side or Hardik Pandya spooning one straight up in air off Lungi Ngidi. Some might argue that batsmen need to do better than throwing their wickets away especially someone like R Ashwin who has now hit six ducks in eight Tests in England. Not many would disagree either considering how badly times are going for them right now having lost five matches chasing totals of 170 plus so far across formats starting with the ODI series opener between these sides followed by T20Is and now Tests. As also seen yesterday, AB de Villiers showed why he remains such a class apart because on another day batting conditions can turn tricky allowing Ravindra Jadeja time enough to run around the ring multiple times keeping the fielders busy. That worked wonderfully in De Villiers' favour till Ishant Sharma drew blood from his pad pegging the Proteas legend back to 13 (72b; 1x4, 2x6). Later Markram joined Quinton de Kock (57), taking advantage of a drop catch offered by MS Dhoni off Umesh Yadav's bowling thanks to poor work from Rohit Sharma diving towards short fine-leg. However, just when things started looking up for the hosts on Day Two, Kohli called for declaration leading to another spell from spinners where most of the action happened after Bhuvneshwar Kumar struck within minutes with debutante Nadhim Zadran (0) edging one straight to Mahendra Singh Dhoni after scoring three off 29 deliveries. Morne Morkel couldn't hang around long either falling prey to Ashwin soon afterwards attempting forward defensive stroke leaving India smelling victory come close of business tomorrow itself provided they take quick wickets upfront tomorrow.

To be 80-5 and give away a 200-run lead is a problem in any Test, let alone one where you know the pitch is going to get more difficult to bat on. "The guys are very disappointed about it because we should have closed out that game yesterday."

Revised growth estimates now suggest the construction industry shrank in the first quarter of 2012, but by less than previously thought. Analysts say the revision may be enough to mean that Britain's economic output did not shrink at all during January-March and held up better than most other countries.' A senior analyst with Capital Economics says: 'The building PMI rose from 49.2 last month (January) to 50.9 this time round, even though new orders fell for a second consecutive survey period.... The small improvement is welcome news given that surveys elsewhere are pointing towards another sharp fall in manufacturing activity over the past few months due largely to weakness across Europe. In our view it has become clear that UK manufacturers will have done much worse in Q1 as a whole compared with their counterparts abroad because they rely more on exports while domestic demand weakened substantially earlier in the year - perhaps somewhat earlier than expected under the impact of euro area crisis worries...'

In the space of two months, the 25-year-old has become one of the most controversial politicians in Hong Kong - and is now pitted in a court battle against the city's leader Carrie Lam. Image copyright Reuters Image caption Ms Tam says she was "disgusted" by what happened at Tiananmen Square She herself describes this as an uphill struggle that could drag on for years: Ms Lam] will never admit her wrong doing," she told me when we met last week. Three weeks ago it looked like Joshua Wong would be returning to jail after serving half his sentence imposed during the 2014 pro-democracy protests. But he won support from overseas activists who called him a political prisoner being persecuted because of his activism. A judge ruled there were insufficient grounds for keeping Mr Wong in custody while prosecutors appealed over whether or not they should continue pursuing his case. He walked free. And so here lies another irony of politics under Chinese rule: that just days before China marks 30 years since soldiers killed hundreds if not thousands of protesting students in Beijing, the current generation of young protesters are pushing back too - albeit with very different tactics than those used three decades earlier.

A 25-year-old woman testified that Larry Nassar molested her from the age of six until 12 during family visits to his Michigan home. Mr Nassar, 53, is accused by more than 100 women and girls who say he sexually assaulted them with his hands while pretending to treat their injuries. Nassar appeared in court for a brief hearing before Judge Janet Neff on Thursday morning after being released from jail last week when the judge declined to set bail at 1 million (768,000). His lawyer had argued against it because there was no proof that any young athletes were still in danger despite accusations dating back many years.

Aberdeenshire-based Harbro Group saw pre-tax profit increase by PS800,000, to PS3.5m, in the year to the end of June 2016. This was despite turnover falling by PS1m to just over PS28m as it continued its strategy of focusing on higher margin products such as premium grooming and skincare lines under brands like Raw. Harrods Food Hall also achieved record sales for a second consecutive year with an 8 rise from 13.2 million to more than 14million during 201516 - bucking the downward trend affecting many other food halls. The result reflected strong growth across all categories including exclusive ranges created especially for each store location. "In addition we have expanded our offering into nonfood offers such as travel bags," said managing director Nicky Fullarton who has been at Harrods since 2004 when she set up her own company before joining the management team three years later. She joined Peter Jones's family office after leaving school but began working in retail aged 16 while studying French and German languages and literature at Edinburgh University.

"The decision has dealt the final blow to democracy in the country," said the Organisation of American States. The court ruled that the assembly was in contempt and said it must be dissolved within five days, but this deadline could also be extended by three months if all parties agreed. Under Salvador Sanchez Ceren's leadership, the FMLN had promised a new constitution would guarantee greater rights for indigenous people and others who may have felt marginalized under the old document written during right-wing rule from 1980 until 1992. But with just weeks left before general elections on March 9, little progress appears to have been made toward putting such changes into law.

Dani Ceballos (Arsenal) Age 19; 5 caps Ceballos has been linked with Arsenal's Premier League rivals Tottenham but his agent insists he was never close to signing for Spurs or any other English club. He may be part of an Under-21 side that won Euro 2017 earlier this month - beating Spain 2-0 at Wembley as Cesc Fabregas watched from the stands - but the midfielder believes he can make it into Real Madrid coach Zinedine Zidane's first team plans next season. He wants to prove himself capable enough against players who have twice won back-to-back Champions Leagues before committing to another move abroad. Toni Kroos: 'We all want Neymar and Mbappe' Read more Christian Pulisic (Borussia Dortmund) Age 18; 3 caps The United States winger confirmed talks over moving to Liverpool were held prior to sealing a 58m transfer to Borussia Dortmund midway through 2015, but reiterated his desire to remain at Signal Iduna Park despite being targeted by Chelsea. Although born in Pennsylvania, the attacker qualifies to represent Germany through grandparents and made six appearances during the country's recent World Cup qualification campaign. His ability saw him included among ESPN FC 100 best male athletes under 21 alongside Antoine Griezmann and Dele Alli seven months later. Rony Lopes (Lyon): Age 17; 0 Caps A teenage sensation within Lyon's academy system having joined them from Brazilian outfit Vasco da Gama four years ago, Rony already looks irrefutably ready to star both centrally and off the flank across the French capital. Capable of playing anywhere along the frontline, Lopes also boasts significant experience in France's second tier despite still technically being classed as a junior player. An intriguing option in attack following Alexandre Lacazette's departure amid interest from Atletico Madrid, Manchester City and Paris Saint-Germain, Lopes recently signed a long-term deal until 2021 designed to prevent his services leaving the Groupama Stadium without serious compensation required.

Police were called to Love Ranch brothel in Crystal, Nevada, after he was found unresponsive on Tuesday. Some reports put the number even higher. The roof of the church caved in on worshippers who had gathered for the ordination of a bishop on Saturday. Those inside the building were crushed by debris or suffocated when floodwaters rushed into the church, which was built over an underground river and held only about 200 people at the time. "The disaster is very large," Sana Satya Wibowo Pramesti, head of Indonesia's National Board for Disaster Management told Agence France-Presse (AFP) news agency on Sunday as she confirmed that there are 1,200 victims from the Christian minority community alone. In all, three days of national mourning have been declared to honor those killed during natural disasters across the country this month with funerals already taking place. The death toll could still rise dramatically though because rescue officials say many bodies remain trapped under collapsed buildings and rubble. Relief efforts also continued Monday after heavy rain subsided allowing emergency crews access through mudslide areas left behind by flooding rivers including where they found human remains. Thousands more residents throughout central Sulawesi remained displaced due to massive destruction caused along coastal towns and valleys following two major earthquakes last week.

Mr Maduro said the room would be kept intact and a wing of the presidential palace turned into a monument to Mr Chavez's "Bolivarian revolution." Mr Chavez died of cancer in Venezuela on March 5. In his address, Vice President Nicolas Maduro broke down as he thanked Cabinet ministers for their support since Mr Chavez announced last month that the cancer had returned after four years in remission. At one point during an impassioned speech, Mr Maduro fell off a stool while speaking at a podium set up outside the Miraflores Presidential Palace. He later stood back up with help from aides. TRIBUTES TO 'VANQUISHED ENEMIES' The new president also paid homage to Venezuela's military heroes who fought against Spain more than 200 years ago before declaring independence, calling them "vanquished enemies" whose spirit should guide Venezuelans today. He then ordered an increase in government spending by about 30 per cent next year, saying it was needed because millions of poor people are still dependent on welfare programs started under Mr Chavez's rule. Some economists say such plans ignore public debt levels which have climbed above 60 billion (S85b) this year - or around 60 per cent of GDP. Critics accuse Mr Chavez of reckless spending throughout most of his 14-year presidency, including massive social programmes aimed at combating poverty and reducing inequality. They were often financed through oil revenues but now require fresh borrowing abroad amid declining output and prices. REUTERS

Businessman Jeffrey Spector, 54, of St Annes, Lancashire, died on Friday following a six-year illness. He was surrounded by friends and family at a meal shortly before his death at the Royal Preston Hospital in Lancashire from an undiagnosed heart condition. Mr Spector's partner Julie Thomas said: 'Jeffrey had been ill for about five years with what we thought were stomach problems but that wasn't it - he couldn't breathe properly. We went to AE so many times over those couple of years and they never found out what it was.' Funeral director Mr Spector (pictured) played cricket for Leyland Cricket Club during every season since moving back to live near his hometown after serving as a special forces medic in Afghanistan where he worked alongside Prince Harry

Murray, 25, who has already secured Rio Olympic qualification, was down in 21st after the fencing round. Strong swimming and run-shoot combined events helped her climb to ninth and reach a top five finish with just one event remaining on Sunday afternoon - running the 800m freestyle (16:02) at 10am local time - which is expected to be the final race of his incredible career. "It means everything that I can do my last swim here in front of all these people cheering me on for what feels like forever, said Murray. "This place will always feel special because it's been so good over the years as well." "So many great memories coming out of this pool," she added. In addition to their medals won today by Miller Dwan and Squeaky, Team USA also had an exciting win from 62kg wrestler David Taylor. A former All American and current World Champion, he took home gold when defeating Azerbaijan's Haji Aliyev 4-2 in the men's Greco Roman light heavyweight division. It marks his first individual senior world title since returning to competition following shoulder surgery earlier this year. He joins 2004 champion Ben Askren among Americans who have previously placed fifth or higher individually before winning a team medal later during Worlds week within the same weight class. This weekend marked the completion of qualifying competitions across eight sport disciplines, where 678 athletes earned spots into next month's Tokyo Games. A total of 330 women and 286 male athletes made up the US teams competing this September. With nearly 2,000 additional athletes vying for places through other qualified countries around the globe, the United States will send 546 female and 483 male competitors representing 50 states plus Washington DC, Puerto Rico and Guam. Media playback is not supported on this device At 44 years old, Owens was the oldest of the 12 referees chosen for the World Cup, but his age will not be a factor in Brazil "I think it's about being honest with yourself," he says. "When you are young and that desire to referee comes over you... I wanted to achieve everything there could possibly be to do as an official." Owens had already been part of two England youth international teams before making his debut at full level aged just 21 - marking him out from many other officials who have emerged into senior football via lower leagues or non-league clubs. He went on to take charge of top matches including both legs of Manchester United v Arsenal's famous 2006 FA Cup semi-final victory; Liverpool beating Chelsea 3-1 en route to winning their sixth European Cup later that season; plus Champions League games involving Barcelona, Bayern Munich and AC Milan. In 2010 he became only the second Englishman after David Elleray to officiate at three major tournaments (Euro 2008, South Africa 2010 and Euro 2012) when taking charge of nine games across those events. Sir Howard Webb followed suit four years later by becoming the first British ref at four straight finals. And here we now are again with Owens' profile having risen almost beyond recognition since 2014 thanks mostly to one incident: the quarter-final between France and Romania which saw striker Florin Gardos sent off following a handball outside the area against the hosts during extra time. It meant Les Bleus progressed 4-3 despite trailing 1-0 early on. The decision sparked fury among fans back home yet further fuelled belief within French media circles that they were denied justice because of Owens' nationality. The man himself has never taken offence either though does admit feeling slightly embarrassed watching how far things escalated afterwards given its roots in such a tiny moment. "But obviously, once people start talking like that then it starts gathering momentum quite quickly so yes, what happened did surprise me." As expected in these situations, social networking sites provided fertile ground without too much prompting along similar lines. One comment suggested Owens must have ignored several red cards handed down elsewhere due to shirt colour while another simply said 'fing ct'. Paul Devlin may well know exactly why some feel negatively towards the Welshman considering he spent 25 years in various roles around world soccer. As head of global technology policy development with FIFA until retiring earlier this month, Devlin oversaw discipline issues for hundreds of players and match officials worldwide prior to leaving amid controversy surrounding former vice president Jeffrey Webb. Devlin tells BBC Sport Wales he feels rather sorry for Owens. Besides wanting more support locally and understanding from those abroad, together with greater assistance away from game days, Devlin believes the sport should look closely at itself regarding attitudes to officials themselves. World Referees Association director Paul Devlin worked alongside Pierluigi Collina throughout his career Devlin served under Italy legend Pierluigi Collina through the latter stages of his own illustrious playing career and also held numerous positions inside UEFA during 24 years working for Scottish Football Association. He stepped up to become general secretary of Uefa's referees committee seven years ago leading a panel involved solely with monitoring performances and potential disciplinary action relating to officials. Such cases would normally go directly to the governing body's appeals board. However, an increasing number concerned specific incidents referred to national associations instead. This included six instances concerning Owens alone - mainly arising from television footage or stills published online. All decisions involving Owens were correctly dealt with according to regulations set by each country individually. Yet Devlin admits the frequency suggests widespread dissatisfaction exists even if it doesn't always come out openly. Rather than judging individuals based purely upon performance levels - often impossible anyway because fouls and mistakes cannot be recorded officially - Devlin thinks consideration needs to be paid to whether referees might need better personal protection going forward. The 2014 winner Vos won the 119km stage from Duyun Lake to Lijiang, finishing 28th behind Katerina Nash as riders were forced up a steep climb at more than 10 per cent incline for almost two kilometres on the final lap of four laps around Mount Tianmen Mountain above Lijiang city. Concern is mounting about the potential of a vicious power struggle in Addis Ababa, triggering a negative chain reaction across the region. For many of Ethiopia's Horn allies, the death last month of Prime Minister Meles Zenawi has been greeted with reliefbut also foreboding that it could spell an end to years of relative stability and prosperity on one of Africa's most turbulent frontiers. This past week saw a spate of diplomatic activity aimed at averting such fears from materializing as concerns grow over what role his successor, Hailemariam Desalegn, will play when he takes office later this year. The new prime minister said Wednesday he would not reverse course on political reforms begun by late leader Meles Zenawi who died August 20 after ruling since 1991. Since then there have been signs of instability emerging within the EPRDF coalition government running Ethiopia for more than 25 yeas. It was unclear whether Somali leaders were able to calm those worries during their visit Thursday; West African ministers are due to arrive Saturday. "The current transition presents both challenges and opportunities," says Mulu Nega, chairman of Uganda's opposition Forum for Democratic Change party which just won seats in parliament following January elections. He adds: "It is important now for all Ethiopians regardless of ethnic or ideological differences...to consolidate our common interests rather than waste time fighting each other."

Upsetting events often make the news because they don't happen very often. This section gives you some tips about what to do if you are feeling sad about what you've seen in the media, or upset by something that has happened locally and internationally recently How can I talk with my children? Talking directly is important for all young people as it helps them understand their feelings better and work out how best to cope during difficult times. Talking through problems also enables parents carers, teachers and other professionals working closely with your child - such as counsellors at school -to identify any underlying issues which may be causing distress and provide support accordingly. It's an opportunity to help them learn more effective coping strategies so that when things get bad again later on in life, like they will inevitably do,they won't simply not know what else to try. Most importantly talking together ensures everyone knows where each person stands and this provides a sense of safety and calmness.

The jury praised Ahmed Mansoor for regularly raising concerns about arbitrary detention, torture and degrading treatment in the Gulf state. As a result, it said, he had faced repeated intimidation, threats to his life by unidentified people and even death threats from one of Bahrain's interior ministers. "I am still waiting for justice," he told Reuters on Friday after hearing that Amnesty was recommending him for an award along with two others who were jailed last year: Nabeel Rajab, head of the Bahrain Center for Human Rights (BCHR) which has been banned since June 2012, and Ali Abdulemam, editor-in-chief of the independent newspaper Al Wasat. Bahraini authorities have long denied allegations they abuse opponents or activists. They say their strict security measures are needed because of militant threats against Shi'ites, who make up most of Bahrain's population but rule is run by Sunni Muslims. Amnesty called on the government to "put an end to its campaign of retaliation." It also urged Britain - a former colonial ruler whose forces helped quell protests during 2011 pro-democracy unrest before withdrawing in March 2011 - to exercise more pressure, including through cancelling arms sales contracts. Rights groups accuse Saudi Arabia and other Gulf Arab countries of using prisons as political tools since revolts swept across North Africa and the Middle East beginning early this decade. In states like Egypt and Syria, rights campaigners blame authoritarian rulers for jailing dissidents rather than tackling domestic instability. In Qatar, where foreign workers face harsh conditions without recourse to judicial redress under a sponsorship system common among oil exporters, human rights organisations remain largely invisible to Western governments. But Qatari citizens do not lack for voices critical of official policy towards them. Earlier this month, a group calling itself 'We are all Khalid al-Hamad' posted several statements online criticising Doha over changes imposed ahead of an International Labour Organisation meeting there next week. Hamad quit his post earlier in September at Qatar University amid controversy over draft labour reforms critics labelled discriminatory toward migrant labourers.

SuperTed was born in south Wales as a book, before becoming a much-loved TV series on both sides of the Atlantic. It was shown as one of Welsh language broadcaster S4C's flagship shows and is still going strong - it has been running for more than 20 years now! The animated show follows the adventures of an animated dog named Ted who lives with his owner John Noakes (played by Bob Holness). In addition to this he also helps other animals from around the world get back home too after they are lost or stranded somewhere. The voice cast includes Martin Clunes, Peter Egan, James Cosmo and Sir Lenny Henry among many others. There have even been three films made based on the original books including Superted: The Movie, which came out last year.

On Monday, the semi-official Fars news agency cited unnamed Iranian officials as saying Tehran also had signed a memorandum of understanding on cooperation in redesigning and operating the Arak facility. Iran says it needs higher quality fuel than is available from Russia for its research reactors because this will be necessary when it starts using them to produce medical isotopes in 2024. "The AEOI has made every effort over recent years to negotiate a solution with observers present which meets our requirements," Mr Rouhani said after signing the deal at a televised ceremony flanked by ministers and senior nuclear scientists and engineers. Mr Zarif tweeted: This] legal step under [the 2015 multinational accord known as] JCPOA can ALSO be reversed within DAYS if other parties live up to their obligations." The president added he wanted new talks with world powers about his country's ballistic missile programme. Tehran insists its missiles are defensive weapons and non-negotiable. But Western countries fear they may be used against regional rivals rather than Israel, whom most Gulf Arabs see as the main threat from Iran despite decades of animosity between their mainly Shia Muslim nations. In April 2018, President Donald Trump pulled out unilaterally of the global deal reached three years earlier with Iran, calling it deeply flawed and reimposed sanctions on Iran. Under the pact, Tehran agreed to limit its disputed uranium enrichment activities in exchange for relief from international economic sanctions crippling its economy. European states disagreed with Washington's decision to exit the pact and have since tried unsuccessfully to find ways to blunt the effects of US sanctions while preserving the deal. Hardliners say Iran should withdraw in response to the latest US escalation.

Campaigners fought to save Ipswich Airport after it was earmarked for housing by Ipswich Borough Council, with some occupying the terminal building for about four months. The anniversary of the occupation will be marked on Saturday (July 8) when flights are expected to take off from 9am until 7pm and visitors can see inside a model aeroplane built in protest during the campaign - which is now being displayed at the town's Museum of Aviation. The campaigners said they had concerns that hundreds more homes would have been situated around an airport where planes regularly landed and took-off as well as using its taxiways and aprons. They also feared noise pollution could affect people living close to the site along with air quality issues resulting from additional traffic.

Molly Wigmore, 76, died in the fire at her Plymouth home in February 2015 (Family handoutPA) An inquest into Mrs Wigmore's death heard she had "no chance of escape or rescue once the fire started to break out from both sides around her bed after an electric blanket ignited a duvet cover on top of it." Her sons Gary and Philip found their mother dead while they were making arrangements for her funeral. The fire service investigation concluded that there were no defects with the electrical appliances involved but confirmed the presence of a fault within one electric blanket which ultimately led to ignition of the other blankets present in her bedroom. It also highlighted failures by South West Water over its response times as well as issues with monitoring equipment used to alert firefighters about emergency calls.

The three judges scored the 12-round bout 115-112 to Burns, 115-113 to Beltran and 114-114, which did not seem to reflect Beltran flooring Burns or his dislocating the champion's jaw. Fight fans were aghast at how it could have been so close given the general opinion that Burns had won every round bar one in their unification clash - and even then he gave as good as he got before being pushed back by an onslaught of punches from 'El Nino'. 'I beat him,' insisted Burns (right), who lost for just second time as a professional after winning world titles across four divisions Beltran used all five rounds at ringside to tell trainer Robert Garcia the fight was over but referee Russell Mora waved on the contest with two minutes left despite the Mexican landing more than 100 unanswered blows during those final moments. Burns refused to accept defeat until hearing that result live at home later while watching replays on TV. He felt himself take too many shots following going down early in Las Vegas but fought well enough thereafter to retain title belts previously held at super lightweight, featherweight and junior welterweight. He said: 'It went exactly like I thought it would go because we prepared very hard coming into this camp specifically knowing what Elwin Beltran likes to do against guys when they're hurt is come forward. That's why you saw me trying to catch him right away with counter punching. Venezuelan veteran Beltran (left) retired last year having long considered retiring aged 38 due frustration over losing opportunities 'We knew if he came out aggressive I'd be able to get my timing off quicker. Once I caught him in the first [round] and put some hands together...we practiced catching him flush.' As expected, the former Olympian started fast. By contrast, 35-year-old Beltran threw less punches overall though landed better ones through to the end of each frame and also stopped Burns from taking any sustained offensive momentum towards the end of the sixth. It looked a clear win for 'Iron' Mike. Instead his career finishes 11 wins including eight KOs alongside 13 defeats.

Sir Alex Ferguson's Premier League champions responded in spectacular fashion to Manchester City's outstanding 5-1 win at Spurs by returning to the top of the table with a result that leaves Arsenal manager Arsene Wenger admitting his team are now in "a fight" for second place. But despite their victory over Everton, who scored an own goal and could quite easily have conceded three more given how bad they were defensively on this occasion, United will not be looking too far ahead as there is still much work to do before the season ends next May. United keeper David de Gea was forced into some fine stops against Roberto Martinez's side but he had little chance when Rooney netted his 20th league goal of another impressive campaign after 26 minutes. Rooney came close twice in quick succession early on while his first effort ended up flying just wide and then Phil Jagielka should really have done better than slice a clearance straight back towards his England captain. The ball bounced off his shin and past Tim Howard from 25 yards out and it could so easily have been 2-0 within 10 seconds thanks to De Gea's misjudgement of Romelu Lukaku's shot which allowed Leighton Baines space to shoot only for him to screw an attempt well wide. Everton did manage to get themselves back into contention midway through the half - Seamus Coleman charging down Ashley Young's attempted cross, allowing Arouna Kone to pounce on the rebound and fire home. It might have got even worse soon afterwards though if Juan Mata wasn't alert enough to block Gareth Barry's powerful strike although things quickly changed once Marouane Fellaini restored United's lead seven minutes later. Although Villas Boas' men fell apart during the closing stages of the opening period, the one positive for them would appear to be that they remain very difficult to beat away from Goodison Park having triumphed here for the third time already this term following victories over Chelsea (2-0) and Liverpool (3-0). Mata put United 3-1 up six minutes after the break - a move started and finished by Wayne Rooney - whose exquisite pass picked out the Spaniard to emphatically volley high beyond Tim Howard. Fellaini made sure of all three points late on, heading home Chris Smalling's long throw-in before Barkley rounded off a miserable afternoon for Everton with his injury time consolation.

Media playback is unsupported on your device 13 September 2015 Last updated at 09:11 BST While they sing artist William Mackrell draws the bumps and swerves. His installation Gaps, Glitches Graffiti in Bristol's Broadmead Shopping Centre was unveiled ahead of the city hosting a major festival celebrating street art Image copyright Other Image caption This mural by Mexican graffiti duo El Mac features among 12 works selected for display during Art Everywhere The show - which runs until 31 October - also includes work from four artists who are exhibiting as part-time students while continuing to teach full time elsewhere. These include US painter Tristan Eaton whose work focuses on the relationship between people and nature and what he calls "the dark side" of technology; Brazilian Jose de Jesus Torres Cruz who creates large scale abstract paintings inspired by his memories growing up with parents who worked as labourers on building sites; French-born Laurence Kurstin who produces deeply personal videos that use found footage taken from internet sources such as YouTube or Vimeo; and South Korean Seung Hwan Lee who assembles objects into collages using traditional techniques including hand print making but adding modern materials.

The Confederation of African Football (Caf) are inviting new bidders for the tournament. Caf say that countries wishing to host the tournament have until 30 September to express their interest. More than 40 nations expressed an initial desire, but only a handful submitted bids before the deadline closed last month and South Africa was selected as hosts by Fifa in June, with Morocco having withdrawn from hosting the event at short notice due to concerns over the spread of Covid-19 across the continent. - BBC Sport

Dartmoor Hill Pony Association (DHPA) said it had put forward the idea "reluctantly." The group claims numbers have dropped from about 30,000 at the beginning of the century to just 2.5 today while British Blondes are now part of a large-scale cross breeding programme with Clydesdales in America and Canada which has resulted in an inferior bloodline being imported into Britain because all mares will produce foals for that breed regardless of whether they can be ridden or not. "The DHPA was formed over 100 years ago when ponies were bred in the Dorset area," said spokesman David Lawley who is also secretary of West Country Equine Vets, based near Dorchester. "A number of national studbooks exist but ours remains one of only two purely dedicated pony associations left in England so we felt we should take action before this valuable heritage stock disappears completely as there simply aren't enough purebreds around anymore."
