Many people have been reluctant to seek medical treatment for Ebola, fearing that diagnosis might mean death as there is no proven cure. A team of 30,000 people is going door-to-door trying to track down anyone who may be infected with the virus and get them into isolation where they can receive care. The emergency response plan also calls on communities across West Africa's densely populated regions to support efforts by authorities in curbing new infections including keeping sick family members at home instead of taking them out to clinics or hospitals where it would increase risk of transmission within families and their neighborhoods. It urges churches, mosques and other places of worship "not to use funerals, weddings, religious crusades etc., as opportunities to gather large numbers."

The boar - which has a moving head - is one of a number of animated replica creatures at Mountfitchet Castle. Staff at the site, an open air museum, were told that they had to bring it down because some visitors found its appearance "disturbing." Having lived in Pembrokeshire for 61 years I am not surprised by this ruling and if anything would like more animatronic exhibits with moving parts around our county's attractions (in fact we need many more). However I find myself wondering how far people are prepared to go these days before accepting something as just part of life? Do people really expect rural life from 1st century AD Britain or should such things be seen only through photographs taken hundreds of miles away on film sets rather than close up here where you can see what was there originally without any modification whatsoever? Back then everything moved including domestic animals so why does everyone object when someone makes sure their sculpture moves too but in exactly the same way?! Personally my two sons often ask me to sit back while they move my walking stick - another device used historically! No doubt once upon time farm workers did complain about seeing chickens walk into barns etc... let's get real please!!

The next public consultation in the Greater Manchester Spatial Framework (GMSF) scheme was due in September but may not be published until summer 2018. Regional mayor Andy Burnham promised to re-engage with communities, but said this will take time and that some decisions need to happen quickly ahead of housing allocations later in 2018. In a further statement, officials say: "Without clarity on what councils' planning obligations are, any decision could involve costly legal challenges."

Police initially said that business rivalry was a more likely motive for the attack on the Movida bar restaurant outside Kuala Lumpur on 28 June. They added that two men had been detained and were being questioned, but no group has claimed responsibility so far. The attackers arrived at the restaurant in six cars before opening fire with automatic weapons. At least 18 people died as well as three shooters who fled after the incident.

England's win over South Africa on Sunday secured the Twenty20 series. The game was officially sold out, as were England's two ICC Champions Trophy matches at the SSE Swalec Stadium. South African cricket has been hit by financial problems in recent months and chief executive Haroon Lorgat said last month that he expected a profit of less than 1 million rand (90,000) this year after racking up losses running into millions of dollars for several years previously.

The Scottish airline believes the flights, from 15 October, will attract passengers working in the offshore energy industries. The routes will be operated by 33-seat Saab 340 aircraft. Durham Tees Valley Airport is also set to launch charter services for oil and gas workers later this year with three weekly flights between Aberdeen International Airport (AIA) and AOD in North Yorkshire starting on 1 November. Barry Leitch, chief executive of Highlands Islands Airports Limited said: "The new route represents an important development as we seek to respond to increased demand across our network."

Leaving the union would see prices rise and threaten jobs, the prime minister said, in a move seen as an attempt to reach out to Labour voters. Writing in the Sunday Express newspaper over the weekend he also vowed there will be no "divorce bill" for leaving if Britain does quit the EU - even though it is legally obliged to pay Brussels billions of pounds. He claimed that wealth from new trade deals could compensate for any short-term hit to the public finances caused by severing ties with Europe's single market. Mr Johnson added: "We are going to take back control of our money, law and borders." His comments come after German Chancellor Angela Merkel poured cold water on plans to renegotiate Theresa May's Brexit deal when she met other European leaders at last week's G7 summit near Biarritz, France. The Prime Minister was forced into humiliating U-turns during his first weeks in power following setbacks including losing his Commons majority in Thursday's General Election. He has repeatedly refused to rule out suspending Parliament so MPs do not get another chance to pass legislation aimed at preventing him taking the UK out without a withdrawal agreement.

Paul captured global attention after he successfully predicted the results of all of Germany's seven games at the 2010 World Cup, as well as the final. Each time he opened his wallet and correctly placed a small coin inside it on top of this wooden box He told Sky News: 'They are big matches that I have been looking forward to for years now so they aren't going to be easy by any means but if you look through my predictions over the last few weeks then hopefully I should do something.'

Ben, from Sheffield, was 21 months old when he disappeared from near a farmhouse in Iraklis on 24 July 1991. The site, which is 750m from where he was last seen by his grandmother and others who were looking after him at the time of his disappearance, has been subject to searches over several decades since then but no trace of Ben has ever been found. The renewed search will take place this summer with the support of specialist police officers from South Yorkshire Police's Cold Case Review Team (CCRT). However it will also be supported by specially trained volunteers from Missing People UK as well as family members - including Tim Marriner whose brother John vanished without trace aged 15 while cycling along Pilling Lane Trail leading into Bewerley Woods between Whitwell and High Green Farm, Barnsley in April 1975 - some ten miles away from both Rotherham and Wombwell. A 20K reward for information that leads directly to finding out what happened to either boy remains intact. If you have any information about either case please contact DCI Andy Howard-Smith on or email [email protected].

Patrick Ewing, 66, collapsed at his home in Oakham, Rutland, and was given resuscitation by his partner, Yvonne Ainsworth. Paramedics used a defibrillator to shock Mr Ewing to restore his heart function before he was taken to hospital where he is said not be critically ill He had played for the New York Knicks from 1973 until 1984 having also spent time with Seattle Supersonics (1977-79), Houston Rockets (1979) and Detroit Pistons (1984). He won an NBA championship with the Knicks in 197071 and three Olympic gold medals as well as four All Star game appearances between 1974 and 1982 while representing Team USA. A statement issued to MailOnline on behalf of Patrick's family read: 'It is with profound sorrow that we share the news that our beloved husband and father has passed away peacefully surrounded by many of his family members.' Sir John Major led tributes to the 7ft 2in athlete today following reports of his death this morning writing: 'So sad. I enjoyed watching him play - an outstanding centre forward, such strength and power."

Marco Goncalves, 34, assaulted the referee after being sent off in last month's game against Rio Tinto, and was escorted off the pitch by police. Images of the attack went viral on social media Mr Gonzales posted a picture of himself to Facebook shortly before he died with his family paying tribute saying they were 'devastated' at what had happened but said that their father would want them to celebrate how well he did as a footballer He then took an ice axe from his car which has been described as 'an obvious weapon', swung it around wildly and struck Mr Gonzalez across the head several times until he fell into unconsciousness.' Alkis Javanbakaj (left) who played for Akinji FC alongside Mr Goncalves is alleged to have carried out the assault while club president Daniel Correa de Sousa Silva Junior aka Danilo Moreira allegedly tried to cover up the incident when questioned afterwards CCTV images show him hitting other members of staff as well during the violent outburst including club secretary Alexandre Henrique Nehemias Pereira Filho or Alvaro Henrique Diniz da Cunha Rodrigues and referees Christian Domingos dos Santos Camargo Marques Vieira and Fernando Augusto Ferracao Pires Valente. The footage also shows one member of security intervening holding back another man attempting to join in the attack. Hospital authorities say all people involved are expected to make full recoveries aside from those needing surgery such as Andre Lopes Gomes Batista, whose skull has needed reconstruction following the brutal attack.

Tigers are fifth after a season of struggle which has seen them sack director of rugby Richard Cockerill. They are in danger of missing out on a top-four finish in the Aviva Premiership and could even drop down the league with Saracens, Gloucester and London Irish all hot on their tails. Leicester's troubles have been well documented but they certainly won't be lacking motivation for this clash - especially as it is against former boss Cockerill who was sacked last month following Leicester's fourth successive defeat by Wasps.

Matthew Daley, 35, denies murder but has admitted attacking 79-year-old retired solicitor Donald Lock claiming diminished responsibility. Lynda Daley agreed at Lewes Crown Court the day Mr Lock was killed and her husband went missing that she would give a statement to police about his whereabouts because their relationship had broken down "quite badly." She said: "I just wanted him back so we could get on with our lives." Richard Smith QC for Mr Daley asked if it did not cross your mind when you gave police an account of where he might be - in South Africa as a tramp or lying dead somewhere up north -that this account meant you were saying 'yes' I am responsible? She replied: "It crossed my mind...but what else do they want me to say?"

The system can involve withdrawal of medication, food and fluids. It can offer a peaceful and dignified death but there have been problems with its implementation, the government-commissioned review is expected to say on Thursday. But it says palliative care should be provided as soon as possible for people who wish to die at home or in their community "regardless" whether they are terminally ill. Its proposals include: - A single national body - Care Quality Commission (CQC) - bringing together all regulatory functions currently carried out by four bodies including health service regulators; - An independent regulator responsible only for ensuring standards around end of life care if CQC fails to do so itself; - Support, training and funding through the NHS England budget for district nursing that provides specialist support workers solely dedicated to providing complex pain relief in addition to routine care such as changing dressings, washing and helping patients eat and drink.

Knight Frank found transaction volumes in the Granite City fell from over PS600m in 2014 to only PS55m last year. Investment in offices alone slumped from PS500m in 2014 to just less than PS200m. The slump is also evident at Stewarts (PS64 million), a company which used to be among Zambia's largest employers with more than 1,300 workers before its collapse on January 10 2015 due mainly to liquidity challenges and power outages that hit mining operations across the country as well as lower copper prices then. Their lawyers had asked the court to declare "unlawful" the consultation process that led to the proposed axing of the PS320m fund. The five are among 19,000 people who receive disability grants paid through a company called G4S Cash Solutions (Pty) Ltd run by former SARS employee Marius van der Walt. They were awarded social security benefits for life after being assessed as unable to work due to their disabilities and have attended meetings at Johannesburg's Ivory Park Community Hall since November 2017 when Sassa planned to scrap them. The Department of Social Development said in July last year it would roll over payments into new accounts until May 31 this year because there was no realistic prospect that they could be transferred before then without disrupting beneficiaries' lives or causing great financial hardship. However, the department has maintained its plans to terminate payment arrangements with Van Der Walt on April 30 despite losing an urgent interdict application brought against it during January 2018 from rights groups represented by Section 27 Legal Education Action Group Incorporated which argued that the plan flouted constitutional guarantees regarding equality before the law and non-discrimination.

The Asia Pacific, excluding Japan, held 47 trillion (PS30tn) in private wealth last year as the number of new millionaires rose in China and India. North America is the world's largest market for high net worth individuals with an estimated total of 41trn (38trn). In Europe, individual net worth grew to 8.4trn from a low base after severe economic disruption caused by several wars but particularly the Great Depression between . The region has seen modest growth since then due largely to increased prosperity resulting form solid economic performance following WWII until the 1980s when capital markets were deregulated allowing opportunities like hedge funds which boosted investor gains across all asset classes including equities and real estate. Since the financial crisis investors are more cautious about higher yielding investments such as property where prices have risen considerably over this period; they now favour safe haven assets such as cash or bonds while seeking greater diversification into alternative investment strategies through products that can be easily traded online using a mobile phone app. Investors also look towards emerging economies' growing middle class whose needs will see demand for goods rise, creating further momentum within these regions.

The Northern Ireland Rare Disease Partnership aims to give sufferers and their carers an independent voice. The group, created with the Patient Client Council, aims to improve treatment and care for rare diseases in NI. It is made up of around 300 volunteers from across all health boards - including neuromuscular expert Professor Mike Barnes who works at Queen's University Belfast (QUB). Researchers are working on two main areas: drug discovery research which could lead to new treatments being discovered; a database called 'Rare Diseases NI' which includes patient information about conditions that affect just one or a few people per million of population worldwide.

In May, 14 Fifa officials and sports marketing executives were indicted in the US on racketeering charges involving more than 150m (PS97m). "Substantial evidence" has been gathered so far, according to prosecutors. The indictment is only a fraction of what could come when investigators finish their work into years' worth of corruption that allegedly brought hundreds of millions into football's world body over many decades - from Jack Warner receiving 10 million in bribes for votes at Conmebol meetings between 1991 and 2011, to Sepp Blatter being given money by Mohamed bin Hammam during his campaign against Prince Ali for the Fifa presidency in 2011.

The team discovered a set of 12,000-year-old Ice Age stone tools while excavating Rubha Port an t-Seilich, on Islay in the Inner Hebrides. The tools included scrapers used for cleaning and sharpening animal hides as well as blades made from beach stones which were either broken up or polished to make them razor thin. They also found remains of animals such as red deer that had been butchered - along with evidence they'd eaten sheep's milk cheese before being buried at sea level under peat bog deposits. Dr Francis Martin said: "These finds represent by far the best preserved Late Pleistocene (Ice Age) sites ever recorded from Scotland."

He was speaking after crowds in Tehran cheered negotiators who had agreed to curb some of Iran's nuclear activities in return for sanctions relief. The six-month interim deal agreed in Geneva on Nov 24 averted a feared war with the West over Iranian attempts to develop an atomic bomb, and may provide time for more serious diplomacy between world powers and Iran. "If we can have this extension... then I think that gives us space," Kerry told CBS News. "And it doesn't mean you immediately resolve all differences or challenges." Iran has denied any ambition to acquire nuclear weapons capability but its refusal so far to scale back uranium enrichment - which could be used both as fuel for power stations and material for bombs if processed further - makes many Western countries wary about trusting it. Kerry said he did not believe there would need to be another meeting like those at times dubbed by critics as "P51 plus one," referring to five permanent members of the U.N. Security Council (Britain, China, France, Russia and the United States), Germany and European Union foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton, whose role is co-ordinating diplomatic contacts with Iran. The senior State Department official travelling with him appeared to leave open the possibility of such talks taking place again soon, saying: "There are no plans yet for any meetings before Christmas." But none were scheduled. With less than two weeks until Dec 31 when new U.S. sanctions aimed at crippling Iran's oil exports take effect unless they are waived by Washington, diplomats say failure now would likely lead to renewed confrontation next year. A NEW YEAR OF SANCTIONS? Washington says Iran must stop higher-level uranium enrichment first, while Iran wants international guarantees that economic benefits will flow swiftly from any curbs it agrees during the temporary respite. Some experts fear Israel might attack Iran's nuclear sites early next year if it deems negotiations failing; Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reiterated his country's right to defend itself against what it sees as existential threat. In New York, Samantha Power, Obama's ambassador to the United Nations, expressed scepticism that tensions with Tehran could ease without significant progress toward ending their dispute. "I don't see how 2013 becomes better than 2012 unless something changes dramatically," she told CNN. However, she added: "We're going into these discussions with good faith and hope... We'll do everything possible to find common ground ahead of Jan 1." Israel has threatened military strikes to prevent its arch foe acquiring a nuclear weapon that Israelis see as an existential threat, although it does not contest Iran's right under the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty to enrich uranium for civilian purposes. Even though Iran retains political influence through allies across the Arab region, including Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and Lebanese Shi'ite guerrilla group Hezbollah, analysts doubt whether regional partners would join forces should Israel decide to act. Western officials suspect Shi'ite Iran's ultimate goal is to obtain enough fissile material for a single nuclear device, a capacity that most experts deem impossible within months given the technological hurdles involved.

The projection from the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) shows a far-reaching shift in the balance of graduate numbers, with the rising Asian economies accelerating ahead of the Western world. China alone will have almost as many graduates this decade - 35 million compared to 30m in Europe - while India is predicted to overtake Britain's 15m by 2015 on its way to becoming one of the largest centres globally by 2030.

The Carneddau Landscape Partnership has been awarded PS198,700 Heritage Lottery funding to help it manage the natural and cultural heritage of the area. It claims the mountains' archaeology, ecology, peatland habitats in particular have suffered from decades of inappropriate farming practices such as sheep grazing which have led to a loss of woodland cover and biodiversity decline including species at risk like red squirrels."I am delighted that we are able to support this partnership project," said John Orna-Ornstein Edwards (pictured), Head of HLF North West Wales. "There is an urgent need for action on behalf of these iconic landscapes if they are not to be lost forever. This grant will enable local communities to work together towards lasting improvements benefiting nature conservation, landscape value and rural livelihoods.We hope our actions over many years give people real confidence about its future well-being but also inspire them with new ideas so their commitment continues into the future" added Nigel Roberts, Chairman of Nant Gwynant Landscapes Trust.

Advertisement Mum-of-one Mrs Shadid plucked up courage two years ago to report the sexual abuse she suffered while washing dishes aged 15 to 16 to West Midlands Police even though neither officer told her that any action would ever take place against her abuser or warn other potential victims about this man living nearby. The mother claims Commander Dave Twyford failed to respond adequately when she wrote a letter detailing how the alleged perpetrator - known by his nickname Jimbo - used his position within families to groom young girls including herself before systematically abusing them over several months until he was stopped one night by three youths outside Birmingham city centre. 'I've given my life since I reported what happened,' added Mrs Shadyad. 'It has taken me into hiding almost every day. It is hard not knowing if someone you know could pick your name out.' She also claimed Mr Twyford hadn't replied to numerous emails sent requesting updates despite telling her previously: 'Rest assured we will do our best to ensure justice is done'. But today senior coroner Louise Hunt determined there wasn't enough evidence to show whether anything substantial went wrong following the original complaint made by Mrs Shadid saying 'there are no findings of fact which can properly be made adverse to the conduct complained of in relation to these matters; nor does there appear to have been any misconduct on behalf of PC Jones'. Ms Hatfield ruled Coventry South MP Jack Dromey should apologise to Mrs Shadid however adding she hoped their relationship could go forward positively now with mutual respect between both parties. The Labour politician accepted full responsibility for failing to act upon allegations regarding Robert Ridsdale despite having been aware of rumours concerning child sex crimes committed throughout multiple generations spanning 30 plus years involving children as young as eight. In March 2015 Mr Dromey took advice rather than going public due to concerns of jeopardising future prosecutions citing fears of prejudicing ongoing trials yet still says nothing publicly until 2018 stating it was down to poor judgement rather than cowardice. Yesterday, speaking exclusively to MailOnline, ex-soldier Joe Clarke warned grooming gangs operating across Britain pose an increasing threat to communities everywhere with women particularly vulnerable unless more serious measures are put in place such as placing restrictions preventing suspects associating freely around youngsters without supervision. He explains: 'For too long decent law abiding citizens like myself have wanted something changed so those accused of such horrific acts aren't able walk free amongst us whilst our kids play football opposite schools where these monsters operate openly unchallenged.' On July 2nd 2019 one year anniversary of the death of murdered schoolgirl Sarah Everard, 19-year old marketing executive Sophie Moss received devastating news via email informing her her husband Tom died four days earlier falling victim to a similar fate to that experienced 17 years prior by another woman named Kelly Fauvet on June 25th 2003 leaving behind daughter Kaylee Dawn after she became pregnant through rape by 41-year old Peter Pickering. Her attacker appealed successfully at Stafford Crown Court in 2008 overturning convictions for rape resulting in prison sentence reduced to six weeks suspended for 18 months effectively allowing him freedom again to continue offending although spent just 12 months back inside before fleeing the country later committing offences overseas. Following conviction for an unrelated offence abroad Miss Moss discovered details relating to Pickerings past imprisonments facing a further jail term only serving eighteen months despite attempts to deport him foreign jurisdiction rejected twice while awaiting deportation from Mexico. An independent review found officers involved in handling applications did not understand applicable laws leading to failures meaning ultimately Pickering remained free even threatening wife Kate to keep quiet claiming he'd kill himself otherwise and threatened attack picking up knife point believing her to be making false accusation. When contacted by MailOnline yesterday evening Staffordshire Chief Constable Gareth Morgan declined comment.

The Academy Selsey suffered extensive damage and much of its contents was destroyed in the blaze on 21 August. The school's 453 pupils are currently being taught at four locations - St Richard's Church Hall, Christchurch Road; a portable building at Oakwood School Sports Centre (which is set to be demolished); the Scout Hut next door, which has been made available by Horsham District Council for free until 31 January 2019; and Beech Lodge Primary School in Worthing. Though these temporary learning spaces have all proved popular with staff and parents alike, Mr Barter said it would not solve his problem because most children will need another year before they can move back into their old school premises. He added that he needed an answer within seven days as safeguarding issues meant some classes had to stay small due to lack of space. "We've got classes where we split them up so there aren't 12 children sharing one desk," he explained. "They're having to work harder than ever." "In term time if I go out anywhere near lunchtime you'll find every member of staff [waiting outside] just checking everyone's still OK - it really hits home how hard this situation is hitting our community. There were tearful goodbyes last week when teachers left after spending two weeks working round-the-clock trying to create something functional from nothing."

Figures shared with 5 live Investigates by the charity RoadPeace reveal a 23 drop in prosecutions in England and Wales in the five years to 2015. In the same period , there were around 48 million fewer road traffic offences reported compared to 201011 levels - down from 1.6m per year then to just under 800,000 today. RoadPeace's national manager of external affairs Graham Upson says: "We all know that the number one cause for accidents is following too closely behind another vehicle or failing to indicate as you're turning but we have seen an apparently significant decline."

She asked Australia not to let this week's national day pass without remembering those people who died during war time - including Australian nurses Vera Murray from Queensland and Enid Lyons' husband Leslie Winton from Western Australia - as well as former politicians Sir John Curtin, Arthur Calwell, Harold Holt, Ben Chifley, Robert Menzies and Gough Whitlam. A firmer dollar in the aftermath of the first Clinton-Trump presidential debate helped send gold prices lower. The Dow Jones Average was up 0.74 to 18,174, while the more tech-related Nasdaq Composite Index was down a bit less than 1 at 5,121. The U.S. 10-year Treasury yield fell about 2 basis points from late on Wednesday and is now trading around 1.71. Market participants are still weighing data that showed last month's jobless claims were slightly better than expected against reports showing an uptick in imports by China (its trade surplus with the rest of world widened) and another falloff in new home sales in October. Treasurys aren't doing much because they have been bid up so strongly over recent weeks - yields rose as high as 1.90 earlier this week after comments from Fed officials stoked expectations for tighter monetary policy next year.

Ivan Cameron, who had cerebral palsy and epilepsy, died in hospital aged six in February 2009. Mrs Cameron told the Times: "Ive dying is such a massive thing that everything becomes magnified." She said she realised during her husband's illness how little people understood about what it was like to care for someone with profound disabilities. She recalled having to fight hard against medical professionals' advice not leave him at home alone because he might choke on his food or fall down stairs unaided. After five years of campaigning by Mr Cameron's family over their son's death they received an apology from South Western Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust earlier this year after settling out-of-court for 700,000. The trust admitted failing to provide appropriate emergency health services and training as well as failing to manage risk factors including epileptic seizures and choking.

But when Paul Gascoigne appeared on BT Sport's Fletch and Sav show, everyone listened, including Russell. For all of Gazza's amazing moments on the pitch, he's also known for his outbursts off it - but today was nothing compared to what he'd done in 1990... "I remember that night so well," confessed Russell as we drove through Northumberland one afternoon last week between sessions at a charity event with his wife Rachel Hunter. "It just seemed like something I had got to do." His friends were adamant: this is where you must be! And 'where' would turn into four days spent fighting back tears while sitting around an old marquee outside Newcastle United Football Club waiting for hours before being admitted inside St James Park to watch their beloved team play against Everton. The question now becomes why? Why did someone who has been married twice (to model and actress Fiona Phillips) still feel compelled by English football 30 years after they left England to carve themselves careers in Hollywood?

Andronicos Sideras, 55, is accused of mixing horsemeat with beef before selling it on through his company Dinos Sons. Two men who ran FlexiFoods - a meat suppliers linked to the scandal involving Irish firm ABP Food Group Ltd (ABP) and Tesco Plc are already in custody awaiting trial for fraudulently substituting cheaper horses with more expensive cattle in their products which were labelled as beef and sold into supermarkets across Europe including Britain under store names such as Lidl's Little Life Beef Lasagne. The three companies appear together at Birmingham Crown Court today where they face charges related to conspiracy to defraud by false representation between August 12 2009 and July 20 2012. They also deny counts relating to fraudulent trading and failing to disclose information about food safety controls within four months of them being notified when prosecutors allege that certain meat products intended for sale had been found not to contain 100 per cent cow or pig DNA but rather "a mixture" of those meats along with two unidentified breeds. The case continues.

The 39-year-old Englishman has not played in a competitive match since the World Championship quarter-finals in April, and has not entered next week's UK Snooker Championship. "I do want a fresh start... I need to get away," he said of his decision on Twitter external-link. "It is with regret that I am announcing my retirement from professional snooker at this time." James added: "Snooker will always be part of me but now it needs space to move forward without me. Thank you for everything." He won seven ranking titles among his 41 tournament triumphs during 18 years as a full-time pro player, reaching three finals - all lost to Ronnie O'Sullivan. He also reached two world championship semi-finals, losing both times to John Higgins in 2010 and 2013 respectively.

Joseph Fox photographed the mudlarkers who comb the shore of London's River Thames. Originally a term for the city's poor who scraped a meagre living by scavenging in the river's tributaries, today it is applied to anyone who collects objects from the muddy banks or shores along Britain's waterways and sells them on eBay or at yardsales

The research, by William C Campbell, Satoshi Omura and Youyou Tu, has led to drugs to treat diseases affecting more than 3.4 billion people around the world. One of them, dapagliflozin (trade name Farxiga), reduces heart disease risk in sufferers with type 2 diabetes who have had a previous cardiovascular event such as a stroke or heart attack But the drug's cost and lack of availability on NHS is an issue for patients taking part in its ongoing trial - which Professor Campbell said was 'a bit like asking someone not to drive their car while you're testing it'. He added: 'It would be great if we could just get this into practice.'

A public consultation has opened on the new proposals, which include a single tower rather than two skyscrapers, for the Jackson's Row area of the city. The former Manchester United and England football star said he was "proud" to see his childhood home restored as part of plans that will also create more jobs in the area. The singer-songwriter added: "I am happy knowing my family's history can be saved from demolition." Read More "

Media playback is unsupported on your device 9 July 2015 Last updated at 09:20 BST The Patron's Lunch will be attended by 10,000 guests - many from charities supported by the Princess Royal and others who have been helped personally It was a triumphant day for Sheikh Mohammed bin Rashid Al Maktoum as he hosted his annual Gala Dinner in Abu Dhabi. An estimated 600 of Britain's richest people were among those attending what has become an important date in the social calendar for governments around the world seeking to woo investors. Money talks most convincingly when it comes with generous patronage behind it; well-heeled individuals are more likely to invest their cash if they feel that their interests align closely enough with those being promoted through events such as this 2 million fund raising feast. And so one need only look back over recent years - whether Dubai's Bollywood extravaganza or other glitzy gatherings across Europe where Her Majesty, Prince Charles,the Duke Duchess Of Cambridge,and Princes Harry William have all made guest appearances -to see how effectively British grandees can help sell investment opportunities abroad. As she arrived last night Diana Award founder Tessy Ojo told me about her own brush with royalty herself while living in London: "The Queen came down our street once." It seems not everyone gets to meet Elizabeth II but even less fortunate souls like Ms Ojo get to hear royal voices speaking out publicly against injustice towards women which resonates very loudly indeed both here and elsewhere overseas.

6 January 2016 Last updated at 12:15 GMT The technology lets people physically feel the buttons displayed on a touchscreen, which could help drivers keep their eyes on the road. It is hoped that this will increase safety for those who are blind or visually impaired - and also reduce accidents in general as it becomes more common to use touchscreens while driving.

The Reds looked in control when Roberto Firmino converted James Milner's pass and Daniel Sturridge backheeled to Sadio Mane to clip home a second. But Leicester were given hope when Glenn Whelan fouled Demarai Gray, allowing Islam Slimani to convert the penalty on 83 minutes. James Maddison then won it with an incredible strike four minutes later when he collected Marc Albrighton's crossfield ball before rifling past Simon Mignolet from outside the box. Liverpool are without key defenders Virgil van Dijk (knee) and Joe Gomez (broken leg).

The 28-year-old footballer's contract was terminated hours after he was dropped for Saturday's Premier League match against Manchester United. No action can be taken until this matter goes through the court process, but police have spoken with both parties involved. However they are also looking into claims from another woman who came forward last week saying she had been raped by him, according to reports in The Sun newspaper. She told officers she did not want to pursue criminal proceedings so officers do not believe there is enough evidence to take any further action. Advertisement Mr Ferdinand moved out of his 5m mansion near Knutsford, Cheshire when news broke about the allegations - which relate to incidents between 2008 and 2014 - being made public earlier this month. His wife Kate Ferdinand posted pictures showing her packing up their belongings as well as ones of herself holding hands with her daughter Tia, six months. There were no comments or social media posts during half term break while all three children stayed with relatives before returning later than usual on Tuesday morning due to "unforeseen circumstances."

She had come prepared to own up to her mistakes, apologising to the gathered throng just as a few hours earlier she had apologised to the cabinet. It had been one of those long days for May that started with so much promise and ended in such disarray - though it was more than anyone else could have done given how many Brexiters there were determined not only to undermine but humiliate their prime minister at every turn."

Four tickets were purchased by Bournville College in Birmingham under former principal Norman Cave, a Freedom of Information request has revealed. The Longbridge further education college also held a PS170,000 fundraiser and raised 12,500 for the party's 2015 election campaign efforts. Meanwhile Labour MP Jack Dromey was one of five people to have bought 10 tickets at a cost of 650 each from his local constituency office on November 8 last year - just two days before voting day.

Eight year-old Phoebe Hanson wrote to BBC Radio 4's PM saying she worried how the "bongs" would be replaced while Big Ben is being repaired next year. PM's editor, Roger Mosey was keen that children should have their say

The 58-year-old school principal from Dublin won 144 out of a possible 278 votes and was 98 ahead of his nearest rivals Sean Walsh and Frank Burke. Horan will take over the reins as Congress president for 201920 after being re-elected unopposed in May 2017 when he beat JP McManus by just three votes to become deputy president. His first task is likely be attempting to broker an agreement with chief executive Martin Slumbers on how much prize money should be offered at next year's Open Championship, which takes place at Royal Portrush Golf Club in Northern Ireland where Shane Lowry lifted this year's Claret Jug after finishing tied sixth behind Brooks Koepka.

Now, as Jaguar Land Rover announces plans to create an extra 1,700 jobs at its base in Solihull - on top of 800 created in January - is the West Midlands ready for more growth? For many parts already struggling with a shortage of available accommodation and workers, it may not be. Jaguar Land Rover has been tight-lipped about where exactly they plan to move these people from but some sources say that close attention will have to be paid if town centres like Castle Bromwich are targeted again by employers desperate for new staff.

Friars Walk has been years in the planning and the development ground to a halt in the 2008 financial crisis. Now it is opening with Debenhams as its anchor store , filling out 32 units of what was meant to be 45 stores until BHS pulled out last year during administration. The hope for retailers such as New Look, Next and Sports Direct will now surely lie elsewhere - at Primark which just opened up another ten shops (including one on Chatsworth Road) this week alone across Britain for an investment of 650m that saw 200 new jobs being created; or online where Amazon's Prime Day sales are expected to hit 3bn (2.25bn). This compares not only against Black Friday but also Cyber Monday when UK consumers spent more than 1 billion (1.27bn), according to Adobe Digital Insights, hitting record highs over 2017 both days.

The Reds led in the 15th minute when Divock Origi flicked in from close range before Roberto Firmino made it 2-0, heading in Nathaniel Clyne's cross. Origi also went close to grabbing a second on several occasions after that and forced some fine saves out of Salvatore Sirigu late on as Liverpool were grateful for another clean sheet following their 0-0 draw at Tottenham Hotspur last weekend. Newcastle, who have now conceded 13 goals without reply this season, struggled again despite having had more possession than usual against one of Europe's most miserly defences they completed just five passes into the box compared with 23 by Liverpool. But while Newcastle looked toothless up front, Everton showed signs of improvement under Sam Allardyce although it was not enough to earn them three points away to Huddersfield Town. The Toffees dominated much of the game but Grant Leadbitter headed home an equaliser off the underside of the bar deep into stoppage time.
Mr Blair said the party he used to lead should aspire to govern, rather than be a "fringe protest movement." He has been a vocal critic of leader Jeremy Corbyn, who was elected in 2015.

It's rare that the company delves too far into how the "magic" - as they call it - works. Their logic is a magic trick doesn't get better if you know all of its secrets, and in some ways I agree with this philosophy: If something happens on stage without an explanation then who cares? You're entertained regardless because what matters are not how things happen but rather why they do so. (Of course there have been occasions when we've seen actual magicians spill their guts about the various techniques used to perform certain illusions.) For example, here at io9 we write plenty of stories involving time travel where someone goes back or forwards in history by traveling through space-time portals or wormholes. But one thing people always want more information about is matter transport over long distances; can you actually send garbage from Earth to Mars using science alone? It turns out partway through The Prestige movie, Tesla does just such an experiment only we don't see him doing any calculations first. He simply throws stuff like coins onto his lab table until he gets lucky. Once enough "good luck" piles up under his hand he realizes he has successfully created teleportation technology! Which means anyone could build these machines given simple instructions for building them... which brings us right back around again to The Prestige movie itself. One way or another this film provides answers to everything - even though many fans complain the explanations were either nonsensical or had loopholes big enough to drive a truck through. Either way Christopher Nolan did find a compromise between satisfying audiences' curiosity while still keeping those same audiences guessing throughout both films.

The end-of-season event gets under way on Sunday, with more than 250,000 spectators expected across eight days. Security is under review but the same measures are in place as last year: checks of bags and all metal objects, controlled access points to the circuit and a ban on alcohol sales around it. "We have increased our security presence," said race director Laurent Mekies earlier this week at an FIA briefing for media including Reuters. "But we see no reason why there should be any difference from previous years." Liberty Media took over Formula One after last season from CVC Capital Partners, which has sold off assets such as European soccer body UEFA's commercial rights business since 2012 when they were first listed publicly. CVC remains owner of a stake worth about 7 percent.

The end of last year saw growth across several sectors of the economy, but there are concerns about rising prices, skill shortages and falling sales. Manufacturers reported their highest growth in output for more than two years during December (BRCKPMG) Inflation jumped to a four-year high after lockdown restrictions caused supply chain problems as well as demand disruption from consumers staying at home. The Bank has said it expects inflation will peak this month because many base effects linked with price falls early on in the pandemic have now faded away. On Thursday its chief economist Andy Haldane told parliament he expected interest rates would need to rise over time. He added: "Rising real incomes plus strong wage growth should lead to higher consumer spending - I expect that we'll see some further pick up through 2021."

The teenager suffered a serious leg injury in the fall at Devil's Cave in Chellow Dene, near Bradford, on Friday night. During the two-hour rescue, Calder Valley Search and Rescue (CVSAR) said they were "close to losing hope" he would be found alive due to fading light and heavy undergrowth around him. But after spotting his blue jacket from above, specialist cave rescuers then carried out an extensive search of nearby areas before finding the boy unconscious but breathing. He was taken by ambulance to hospital where he is currently being treated for multiple injuries including broken bones with one leg showing signs of having been dislocated as well as internal bleeding. It remains unclear how high up in the caves the youngster fell or why he was there alone. But CVSAR made clear that UK holidays should still go ahead this summer despite recent tragedies within its borders, saying: Calder Valley] has had some tragic incidents over the last few days which have caused concerns about visiting these beautiful locations." They added it is vital people take basic safety precautions when going into difficult terrain such as taking torches, maps and first aid kits. When asked if walking trips are safe during lockdown, Dr Deborah Turbitt of Public Health England responded: 'There isn't any more risk now than you face mixing in your local area. We all need to do what we can to keep ourselves and others safe - wearing masks, ventilating indoor spaces properly, washing hands frequently.'

Research suggests women will not earn as much as their male counterparts until 2069, nearly 100 years after the Equal Pay Act was introduced in 1970. Holyrood's economy, fair work and social security committee is currently conducting a review of pay equality legislation to ensure those laws are working well for everyone who works in Scotland. "It cannot be right that we have an equalities minister whose own department doesn't recognise these issues," said Ms Davidson MSP at First Minister's Questions on Thursday. "The government should come clean about why it thinks current gender pay gap reporting requirements don't apply to ministers."

The 23-year-old, Ulster's Player of the Year, made his international debut for Ireland in the Six Nations game against England at Twickenham in February. McCloskey still had a year remaining on his contract with Ulster when he joined Saracens and although they have an option to extend it by another season, that is not likely to happen now. "It was obviously very disappointing last week [Ulster losing 31-17] but we've got two big games coming up so I'm looking forward to them," said McCloskey after training yesterday as Leinster trained nearby ahead of Saturday night's Heineken Champions Cup quarter final at Aviva Stadium (kick off 7:35pm). "We'll be back."

Amber Rudd told the BBC the manifesto was "not going to be identical to the last one" and said things had changed since 2015 because of Brexit. The target, set by Ed Miliband in 2010 after Labour's third successive defeat under Gordon Brown, has been seen as a key barometer for gauging how well parties are doing electorally - but there is no consensus on whether it works or not. Labour MP Frank Field also warned against shooting themselves in the foot with another election pledge that would help voters make up their minds before they enter polling booths later this month. He wrote: "It's far better if we can get our core vote out first - then persuade others who haven't made up yet why voting Conservative won't bankrupt them! It seems like overkill just now when so many people still don't know about us." But Andrew Gwynne, Labour's campaign co-ordinator, defended plans saying its message from Mr Corbyn will be clear at every doorstop he visits across the country.

Mr Adams said: "The government of Britain is now responsible for creating instability through its continued intransigence."

A group led by Americans Jason Levien and Steve Kaplan bought a controlling 60 stake in Swansea in a deal ratified by the Premier League on 1 July. They are expected to complete their takeover of Leeds at some point this week, which will see them return to English football for the first time since 2004 when they were taken over by Ken Bates' consortium following BSkyB's decision not to renew their TV contract with the club after season. "Leeds have had an offer from Venky's accepted but both clubs want more time before it is completed." - SWFC chairman Huw Jenkins - Phil Blanche (philblanche) August 12, 2011 The uncertainty surrounding Cardiff City has been ongoing ever since Vincent Tan was denied entry into Britain last month because he did not hold his British passport despite having lived there for 14 years - the country does not allow dual citizenship unless you renounce your former one. Luckily enough there appears little risk that Tan would breach his visa conditions given how much he values keeping up appearances as ownerchairman of the Bluebirds (he may be banned from entering England again though). The Malaysian businessman faces accusations of racial discrimination against ethnic Chinese fans who claim he refused admission to stand tickets during Malaysia's recent World Cup qualifying match vs China due to security concerns, while supporters also have accused him of being behind discriminatory chants directed towards opposition players like Newcastle United striker Demba Ba: "If I don't score today then [expletive] all of Malaysians! I'm going home!" For now, expect Tan to stay put until something changes or he gets bored, either way we doubt many people care except perhaps those directly affected.

Isabelle and Stanley Larson from Oxted, Surrey, were burgled in October 2005. The Marine Policing Unit's dive team were working on an unrelated case at Slade Ponds when they recovered the jewellery today The Metropolitan Police Service (Met) said the items had been given to police by a member of the public last month following media appeals for information about them. Detective Sergeant Rob Dixon said: 'While I'm delighted that we have managed to return these pieces to their rightful owners after so many years missing - I am disappointed it took us over 15-years to solve this crime.'

Media playback is not supported on this device The 34-year-old beat three-time champion Tony Martin by 26.23 seconds on a hilly 47.1km course in Spain. After finishing second to Martin last year, he told BBC Sport: "I felt good today and I'm really happy with it." Estonia's Mairead Coyne took bronze for her country's first medal at the World Championships since its independence from Russia in 1991 - she added silver to her 2015 gold medal won as part of Team Ireland. "It was amazing," said Coyne, who had surgery after rupturing an Achilles tendon in 2017 but then broke through again when winning national titles earlier this season. "When you're going up against such tough competition like that [Martin], especially having come back off injury myself, so many people have doubted me... To be here now taking home another world championship medal feels unreal honestly. It means everything."

The rail union is calling on the Scottish government to set out an immediate timetable for Abellio to be stripped of its ScotRail franchise. It has said making Scotland's railways public would create a "viable, affordable and sustainable" network that could run without subsidies from taxpayers. Passenger services minister Graeme Dey hit back at criticism over plans to introduce fares which include unlimited travel all day on Sundays in October when it was first announced last month as part of efforts designed by ministers to improve services across the country..

Tens of thousands of pilgrims joined him for the Way of the Cross ceremony, recalling Jesus' crucifixion. Among the cross bearers were Syrian and Iraqi refugees, and Nigerians who had fled violence in that country. The pope has said he wants to make use of his trip this weekend not only to highlight the plight of migrants but also to call attention to Iraq's Christian minorities, which have been devastated by Islamic State's rise there over the past few years. The militant group left many religious communities afraid to return home after it took large swaths of territory with its campaign of targeted executions, kidnappings and rape - abuses widely attributed to radical Sunni Islam.

Media playback is not supported on this device Doull emulated fellow Welshman Geraint Thomas, who won at the 2008 and 2012 Olympics, by helping Great Britain win team pursuit gold Darrell Clarke's men had already beaten Australia in qualifying earlier in the week to set up a semi-final with New Zealand. But they were overwhelmed as their arch rivals romped through 4:04.265 - the fastest time ever recorded over four kilometres by more than two seconds. GB rider Ethan Hayter was left exhausted after his fourth bout of three against Kiwi Sam Webster during which he trailed 845m into the final lap before pulling off an incredible comeback via what looked like a desperate solo effort. But GB never got going again once the race began. Tom Pidcock led for much of it but faded badly while Charlie Tanfield went backwards from fifth spot early on. The result means that GB have now failed to reach an individual women's or men's medal event since Beijing 13 years ago although Bradley Wiggins' bronze in London eight years later would be recognised if they are included when Rio comes under review following disastrous doping revelations about Russian athletes last year.

The Shrimps lost their opening game of the season at newly-promoted Grimsby but then knocked Championship side Rotherham out of the EFL Cup 5-4 and have won three straight league games. "There's a lot more football to be played," said Hurst, who was assistant manager on England's run to last month's World Cup semi-finals in Russia with Gareth Southgate. "But we're very pleased with how things are going." (Reporting by Alan Baldwin Editing by Christian Radnedge)

Charity Twelves Company, based in Devon, said it had turned away 112 people seeking support in 2015. A BBC investigation revealed that in Devon and Cornwall police have seen a rise of over 30 since 2014-15 when there were 1,845 incidents involving begging and rough sleeping on the streets - up from just under 100 two years ago Members of the public contacted us to tell stories about what they thought was happening outside their homes or near children's play areas, including instances where beggars appeared aggressive if refused money. Several charities told us negative attitudes towards homeless people stemmed partially from inaccurate perceptions around them being drug users, alcoholics or criminals who preyed on members of society by asking for cash with 'lies' such as saying they were ill. One man described an incident at his local McDonalds restaurant: "I went into McDonald's one morning, I'd dropped my wife off at work so she could get her hair done before meeting me back home," he says. "There is never any trouble inside but all three fast food outlets are close together and within 50 yards walk down the road you can see someone sitting cross legged behind a bin." He then describes how another customer came out of the shop telling him not give anything because this particular person would use it buy drugs. The witness asked why - to which the individual replied: You don't know do you? Because we're used to seeing these types of characters sitting outside pubs waiting for customers walking past, most residents assume everyone living on the street has addiction problems.' Resident Martin Posnett (not pictured) gave evidence during HTA discussions But the resident also witnessed something more positive later than day. "The same guy popped up again sat next door having breakfast. As always, no problem whatsoever inside the premises. This time though he seemed very keen for help...he walked straight across the road into Tesco's [supermarket] and bought himself some food." HTA participants suggested schemes like the Birmingham model works best in cities where large numbers join together to demand change rather than relying solely upon councils who say funding constraints means they cannot follow through properly. They recommended councils be encouraged to set aside land specifically designated for safe campsites; provide access to clothing banks, showers facilities and mental health services alongside physical shelters; create methods whereby people experiencing homelessness self declare for treatment instead of requiring medical checks, particularly those suffering from serious illnesses should stay indoors overnight unless hospitalised; make sure housing stock available provides adequate heating, insulation, lighting and fire prevention measures; consider placing temporary emergency accommodation units in places other than traditional city centres after working hours, possibly linked to shops offering 24 hour opening times. Advertisement A spokesman added that while complaints made against its Street Outreach Service rose 65 per cent last year compared with 2017, staff attending reported 141 fewer crimes related to anti social behaviour recorded by officers between April 2018 and March 2019. Shelter spokesperson Anna Renton explained that many factors contribute to rising levels of rough sleepers, adding that investing in initiatives aimed at preventing homelessness - combined with ending cuts to welfare benefits and increasing affordable energy bills - would reduce the number of vulnerable individuals forced onto Britain's streets each night. She continued: " It's clear that the Government needs to urgently reverse recent severe benefit cuts hitting families hardest, ensure Universal Credit keeps pace with rents and inflationary costs and commit to building genuinely affordable homes. That way we won't continue to leave thousands facing a bleak winter without proper shelter. "

Allan Whittern ran the grocer's store in Suffolk Parade from 1932 until his death 50 years later, in 1982. Following its closure in 1991, the door painted with his father's face has been kept as a souvenir by Mrs Whittern and hung on her living room wall ever since then. "It was such an iconic little shop," said Mr Bostock. "He had everything you could possibly need."

The humpback has been seen at Pettycur Bay, Kinghorn in Fife. Humpback sightings are not uncommon in Scotland, but a large whale so far up the Forth estuary is a mystery to marine experts and local wildlife groups "It's such an unusual location for this species - we think it may be some sort of transient which visits Scottish waters from time-to-time." Experts warn that anyone who sees the animal should keep their distance as they could cause serious injury if disturbed while feeding or breeding underwater.

Noah Zunde, who was 22 months old, succumbed to heatstroke after being left in the car for seven hours. His mother, Romy Zunde, had mistakenly believed she dropped Noah at day care before heading off to work and did not realise he had been there all afternoon until a teacher called her that evening. Romy initially pleaded guilty but later changed her plea on mental health grounds. She is due back in court next month where prosecutors will outline their sentencing position.

Anagha Nikam was travelling by rail when she spotted a mother trying to find milk for her baby daughter. She tweeted to the ministry and asked for help, and milk soon arrived in a box at Amritsar station.

Andrew Bickel, 39, was fixing a light at the Catwel shop in Cardiff two weeks ago when he nipped out to his van and returned to find his tools were gone. He said: "I had seen my bike on Facebook Marketplace for 50 so I got straight round there but someone else bought it before me." He added that while trying to get home from work last week he also discovered thieves had taken all of his camping equipment - including sleeping bags - which are usually kept outside his tent by his house.

They were able to hold a metal plate a few centimetres above the rabbit's chest and use it to regulate the animal's heartbeat. If such medical implants could be made wireless, they would allow doctors or paramedics wearing gloves to control heart rate in emergencies without having to touch patients with wires attached," said Dr Praveen Arany, Assistant Professor at University of Massachusetts Amherst who led this research published recently in Science Robotics "A remote-control system for cardiac devices is also particularly useful when surgery cannot be performed immediately due to patient movement." The researchers had used flexible electronics before but on much larger scales that couldn't fit inside an animal body. Also using them required complicated manufacturing processes involving multiple steps including bonding semiconductor chips onto rigid circuit boards. To make their implantable device more compact, light weight and easy to manufacture, they replaced these components by combining "flexible printed circuits (FPCs) containing interconnecting copper lines sandwiched between two thin polyimide films as well as ultrathin zinc oxide transistors manufactured from solution processable materials." They then designed a hemodynamic monitor powered completely wirelessly through radio frequency signals transmitted via antennae placed next to each electrode. The power requirement was only 25 microwatts per square centimeter so transmitters can have extremely small sizes.

Inspectors criticised teaching and leadership at the Phoenix Academy and Lakeside Academy following visits in February, rating both schools inadequate in all areas. Wrockwardine Wood and Sutherland academies, also run by The Learning Partnership Trust (TLPT), were rated 'requires improvement' as was Brookside Community College which had previously been given an outstanding grading but has now lost its inspection status due to poor performance over a number of years. After reviewing what happened during these inspections first hand it is clear that there are failings within TLPT's management structure with one former principal describing her time working for them like being 'in jail'. Other current and ex-staff have described how they feel scared about speaking out publicly because of threats from senior staff members who hold secrets against those who do not toe their line while others admit leaving jobs simply so will no longer be bullied or intimidated into doing things they know are wrong. Despite this none wanted to go on record fearing repercussions when applying elsewhere. One said: "It feels very much like we're living under siege." Another added: "We did our best work yet still got slated." Others describe feeling shocked at some of their findings where only months later concerns remain unaddressed despite narrative plans having already been produced outlining changes required. This includes serious issues relating to safeguarding children identified - including instances where pupils' safety risks were ignored - raising questions around whether regulators went far enough in withdrawing recognition last year. However Ofsted states categorically that additional inquiries would need to take place before any formal action could even begin. TLPT says it understands why parents may be concerned but insists school leaders, governors and inspectors alike recognise the progress made since April 2017. They state they continue to recruit, train and retain high calibre teachers supported by strong systems of internal promotion between departments in order to ensure quality education remains central to everything they do. A spokesperson said: "Our priority continues to be providing excellent opportunities and experiences for students and ensuring young people leave us well prepared for future success; however, sometimes we miss the mark along the way. We welcome external feedback and believe actions taken arising directly from such reviews reinforce our determination to improve and get better every day. As a result of these most recent reviews we've introduced new policies and processes across both trusts designed to further enhance our curriculum delivery, support staff development and safeguard student wellbeing whilst addressing challenges raised." In spite of assurances security teams monitor each academy site 247 and CCTV covers reception areas keeping watch upon visitors after dark though several staff fear visiting classes without other adults present just isn't safe anymore. What makes matters worse according to many sources inside the trust is knowing individual cases covered up rather than acted upon meaning pupil safety remained compromised until whistleblowers stepped forward either leading to serious incidents being investigated or resignations taking effect immediately. Some say certain individuals put career prospects above child protection even going so far as telling staff off if they dare raise their voice regarding behaviour, health safety or staffing levels again making whistleblowing difficult. Staff weren't alone in noticing flaws within the system. Parents too saw problems emerge almost straight away and accused officials of ignoring multiple complaints via social media then failing to act once solutions had become apparent instead prioritising protecting themselves citing restrictions imposed by government funding cuts forced onto local authorities. Media playback is unsupported on your device 12 July 2015 Last updated at 01:20 BST The BBC's Mohamed Madi went to Soho's Greek Street to find out. Produced by Marcus Godinho The tourist board promoted London as the great "multicultural" city, but in reality white people were vastly more likely than black or Asian ones to be employed and own their homes - according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS). So when a new wave of migration hit Britain during the 1960s with an influx from Caribbean countries like Jamaica, Guyana and Trinidad it was feared that inner cities would become slums filled with unemployed men who might come over here illegally and steal jobs, women would no longer want to marry them because they could not support families, crime rates would increase and taxes needed to rise to pay for law and order services. This fear led to the White Paper published under Harold Wilson government which set limits around immigration numbers so that this country will remain culturally British. But many immigrants weren't happy about being told what colour they had to be and resented being kept apart. And while some communities did break down, others formed tight-knit social groups based upon shared ancestry. In particular there are three main areas where Jamaican and other West Indian cultures have played a key role; music, food and fashion. It has been well documented how reggae inspired bands such as The Clash, Bob Marley's Wailers made pop classics including No Woman, No Cry and I Shot the Sheriff while other artists created waves through ska, rocksteady, dance hall, '60s RB, funk, dubstep and hip hop. All these genres are still popular today and all can trace back directly to musicians born and raised in places like Kingston, Montego Bay, St Ann Parish, Port Antonio, Clarendon, Mandeville and Spanish Town. Many arrived via boat hoping just to survive before finding work picking fruit, working on building sites, factories, in restaurants, shops and offices. From those humble beginnings came a rich musical legacy. While UK clubbers may think grime means the genre invented by Drake and Skepta, Grime Reggae started long ago on streets like Brick Lane, Shoreditch and New Cross Road among East End communities influenced by soulful roots sounds drawn primarily from Africa and America. Today you'll hear jukeboxes pumping out tunes both current hits by Stormzy featuring Ed Sheeran and classic songs recorded decades earlier playing across clubs, bars and street corners. At its heart though lies traditional calypso from Barbados and Grenada blended into modern styles performed by veteran performers alongside young upstarts looking to make name. You don't need much money to start making music thanks to cheap recording equipment available online. Aspiring stars use digital tools to record themselves rapping then share tracks through apps like SoundCloud or YouTube instead of hiring expensive studio time. By contrast the biggest names play stadiums packed full of fans dancing away dressed head-to toe entirely covered in designer outfits costing thousands, sometimes tens of thousands of pounds per outfit alone. Fashions change fast too meaning barber shop salons brimming with locals getting cut n' styled really highlights and exaggerates different cultural differences. These spaces offer affordable hairstyle solutions, hot meals cooked fresh daily plus plenty of loud conversations taking place within earshot. For years fried chicken and fish chips served up from roadside eateries was seen as uniquely British fare until Nando's launched 17 years ago offering a similar spicy version perfectly suited to the spicy foods eaten commonly throughout South American nations like Argentina and Brazil. Since then chains selling Peruvian cuisine followed along with hundreds of outlets serving vegetarian Chinese dishes known as dim sum and Japanese curry houses. Meanwhile ethnic supermarkets sell goods ranging from exotic spices used regularly in cuisines serving large populations living mainly outside Europe to non-alcoholic drinks containing natural ingredients found only in African rainforests. How else do we explain why one type of currant jelly sold next door sells for less than another? Or why someone growing sugar cane in Fiji uses very little of the product compared to Western cultivation methods yet charges substantially higher prices? Welcome to multiculturalism!

3 April 2017 Last updated at 09:17 BST Demand for property in China's top cities is so red hot, some couples are even undergoing fake divorces in order to buy second homes. Legislation which was due to come into effect on 1 July would have given people the right to own two properties if they were married or living with their partner and had not previously held a home elsewhere. But it has been delayed until next year because of concerns about its impact on prices. The argument over how many houses one person should be allowed to purchase highlights what analysts say is an irrational housing market - distorted by subsidies from local governments. In certain circumstances that can mean house prices rising faster than incomes. "Wealthy buyers who want multiple apartments often resort to going through the motions of divorce," said Mark Tanner, managing director of Shanghai-based research company China Skinny. He added that clients seeking information on this option include newly divorced men looking for other women willing to live with them as they seek another home while waiting out legal proceedings against their former partners. Mr Tanner believes the number of couples taking such measures may remain small but could grow significantly depending upon economic conditions. Life expectancies are lengthening across the country and there will soon be more young families able to afford expensive mortgages amid ultra low interest rates. 'No problem' Beijing resident Zhang Liying told BBC Chinese she went ahead last summer after her husband proposed buying a second apartment together (they already owned one) following discussions with his mother. One thing led to another and I came up with the idea of doing an annulment... It took us less than five minutes to do it officially online via WeChat Mrs Huang Lihong They decided he could keep both places provided each one did not exceed 50 sq m (538 sq ft). Mrs Zhang, 36, said she obtained permission to put down deposits using money left behind by her deceased father rather than having new loans secured against all three family assets. She described herself and her 39-year old spouse simply as being unable to conceive naturally and wanting children to complete their family unit. Both their mothers wanted grandchildren too, said Ms Zhang. Her son also needed somewhere private where grandparents could stay when they visited from Sichuan province. A business analyst before she gave birth to twins four years ago, Ms Zhang now works part time teaching English. She said: "One thing led to another and I came up with the idea of doing an annulment [of marriage]... It took us no longer than 10 days." If you don't agree then move away! This requires quite remarkable control over your emotions. You need someone very experienced Mr Tan Jinhua Even though getting remarried carries serious consequences under Communist Party rules - including losing government benefits (see below) - experts like Mr Jiang Jianming believe there are any number of ways around this regulation. One potential solution involves hiring somebody else to perform marriages overseas; although these ceremonies are illegal without state sanctioning, foreign websites reportedly offer services ranging between 1,600 (1,300) and nearly 50k (35k). Family lawyer Mr Tan Jinhua explained that lawyers charge between 4 and 5 commission per successful application made to the relevant authorities. However, despite only requiring relatively basic paperwork, cases become complicated once attempts begin to get round restrictions placed on ownership rights. For example, individuals might submit documents saying that separate names listed on mortgage agreements belonged actually belong to different relatives; others claim double occupancy permits are really issued jointly. Some existing regulations appear contradictory. According to government guidance published earlier this month regarding second residential homes purchased prior to May 2013, those wishing to hold onto multiple dwellings must file proof of marriage within 30 days of securing approval. At present, however, unmarried owners cannot obtain formal contracts unless legally recognised spouses consent to sharing ownership responsibilities. Married couples meanwhile enjoy preferential treatment compared to single purchasers since certificate applicants who provide evidence of marital status receive certificates enabling immediate registration. Such policies create opportunities for corruption, admits Mr Tan. "This creates lots of loopholes like paying bribes to officials along the way. So far we haven't seen anything major happening yet, mainly just minor stuff here and there." Social experiment? Many Chinese perceive the debate currently raging surrounding national property policy as nothing short of revolutionary. Those opposed argue the current system represents an effective subsidy passed directly downwards from central government, particularly in tier one cities near provincial capitals. That belief gained currency recently thanks to a public outcry over reports that rich developers linked to senior party figures stood accused of trying to profit illegally off land sales, sparking intense criticism towards corrupt practices among civil servants and lack of transparency among leaders. State news agency Xinhua called for greater protection of citizens' legitimate interests during recent legislative meetings on related legislation. Police forces tasked with implementing strict state interpretations of Islamic morality exist in several other states, including Saudi Arabia, Sudan and Malaysia. Many - especially those with an affinity with Gulf Arab countries - have been involved in the bloody crackdowns on protests that erupted across Iran after its disputed 2009 presidential election. "The issue here is not whether (females) are wearing hijab or not... it's about imposing a certain kind of dress code," said Hoda al-Helaissiyeh, the spokeswoman for Bahrain's opposition Wefaq party. "It isn't just about women."

According to organisers a record 3.6 million turned out to vote in the Scottish independence referendum. Some experts believe that as many as 80 do not turn up when it comes to voting at an election but this is likely to rise significantly if they and other young people are given their chance through early or postal votes rather than having to stand on polling day queues.

Joshua Brown was killed when his car collided with Tesla's Autopilot system last year Tesla is one of several automakers, including Ford Motor Company and General Motors Co., that have taken steps to increase the capabilities of their driver-assistance software systems as they compete for business among consumers concerned about safety on U.S. roads.
