A new generation of sophisticated self-driving cars are being put through their paces this weekend ahead of what many consider will be inevitable widespread deployment within months Following the fatal accident involving the company's Model S sedan using AutoPilot technology, Tesla issued warnings reminding drivers who use such features to keep both hands on the steering wheel at all times and pay attention to road conditions and traffic signals. In May 2016, nearly two years later, another Tesla owner died in Florida when his Model S hit two trees, crossing into oncoming lanes. Neither crash has officially resulted in charges against the companies involved. Elon Musk tweeted out images Saturday showing him standing next to the bright red electric sports car again However, some experts argue there is still work left to do even if autopilot can see stop signs and speed limit signs, react quickly enough and brake automatically - especially since human error causes more than 90 percent of accidents. But most agree that humans aren't capable of handling every aspect behind the wheel safely 100 per cent of time either. Despite those concerns, automakers continue rolling out vehicles equipped with advanced driver assistance systems like Tesla's auto pilot. Some experts believe full autonomous vehicles could account for 41 million sales worldwide by 2035, according to IHS Markit Automotive Research. Earlier today TMZ revealed exclusive photos of Tom Brady posing with pal Travis Kalanick along side other Tesla owners outside the Redwood City Mega Car Show where attendees were treated to rides around town courtesy of Uber Travis Kalanick posted these pictures to Twitter of himself hanging out with friends inside of Jamie Foxx's 400K Tesla X earlier tonight Uber cofounders Garrett Camp (right), JB Straubel, Ryan Graves pose together following the unveiling of the first prototypes of the Otto self-driving trucks powered by electric motors in late September 2015 This comes amid escalating tensions between Silicon Valley tech firms and traditional automakers over potentially disruptive technologies. In recent weeks Waymo, formerly known as Google's Self Driving Car Project, sued ride services rival Uber claiming managers conspired to steal trade secrets related to Lidar sensors used in autonomous automobiles. At issue is Anthony Levandowski, manager of Alphabet Inc.'s now shuttered self-driving unit, who downloaded 14,000 documents containing technical details about light detection and ranging sensor, or LiDAR, technology required for fully autonomous vehicles just days before leaving to set up a competing venture backed by Uber, court records show.

Deputy Foreign Minister Faisal al-Mekdad told the BBC "Syria is doing its best" to comply with the timetable to destroy its chemical weapons. Syria missed Wednesday's deadline to hand over all of its declared chemicals, which Western officials say includes more than 20 tons still in storage. In his interview airing Sunday on CNN's Fareed Zakaria GPS and later broadcast by Al Jazeera English, Obama said he would consider a delay if Assad gave no indication that it was ready or willing to make good on U.N.-brokered promises before then. But when asked whether there could be an extension past Tuesday night - even through September, as Russia has proposed - Obama again indicated such a move would not fly without proof from Damascus. "The issue here is... do we have any idea what they are going to use them for?" Obama told Zakaria. "And so I'm always open to possibilities but my primary concern right now is making sure we enforce the terms that were set." Obama also defended decisions during last year's presidential campaign when he expressed doubt about whether the United States should intervene militarily against Syrian President Bashar al-Assad following reports that government forces had used deadly sarin gas against civilians. The president reiterated doubts aired publicly at rallies earlier this month: He described himself as having been skeptical initially because other countries did little after promising action years ago regarding atrocities committed by Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi. Facing calls Monday evening from congressional Democrats to speed up military aid for rebels fighting Assad, administration officials stressed repeatedly their belief that assistance shouldn't begin until Congress authorizes additional funding beyond 60 million already approved since 2012. Officials noted continued discussions between senior lawmakers from both parties aimed at agreeing upon language similar to that included in House legislation passed overwhelmingly Thursday authorizing direct support to vetted rebel groups.

Tour de France winner Wiggins became the most decorated Olympian in British history, with a total of seven medals. He won the cycling time trial after Glover and Stanning rowed superbly to win gold for men's coxless pairs by coming home ahead of Germany in front of a raucous crowd at Eton Dorney on the River Thames. "We did it! It was such an incredible day," said Wiggins, who also claimed silver in London 2012 as part of Great Britain's pursuit team. "I don't know what I can say now." Halsall joined four-time Olympic champion Steve Redgrave and Matthew Pinsent himself three times a rowing world champion - as only two Britons to have stood atop the podium more than once in Olympic competition. Wiggins' medal haul includes five golds from Beijing 2008, when he starred in the winning track quartet, plus one silver and another bronze. The 36-year-old has hinted that he will end his career following next year's Commonwealth Games in Australia but Saturday's victory suggests there is still plenty left to give before walking away from sport forever. Glover, 31, actually took up rowing just months ago having played down expectations during the build-up despite being tipped as favourite going into this regatta alongside training partner Sanita Puspure. Officials from Staffordshire County Council and the university said the historic building, in the town centre, would become an information centre for prospective students. A number of courses will also be run at the site to help people improve their English skills ahead of applying for a degree course or apprenticeship with Birmingham City University (BCU). The 2m revamp has already started - but work is expected to take up until April next year before all facilities are fully available again. The city council's cabinet member for employment, education skills Councillor Phil Bibby said: "This new collaborative approach between our universities and a local authority employer group gives us access to more training opportunities than ever before and represents another step forward towards achieving our ambition that 50 per cent of young adults should go on to higher-level technical qualifications by 2025." Councillor Hannah Hockenhull, lead councillor for economic growth added; "It really is fantastic news we can make this investment here which means local businesses have even greater access to skilled workers. We're working hard behind the scenes across every sector to ensure employers know just how much support they could get if needed through the Staffordshire Skills Hub website. It offers everything you need under one roof so it couldn't be easier!"

Choudry, 23, from Maidenhead, Berkshire pleaded guilty to stirring up racial hatred while Rahman, 21, a former soldier who converted after meeting Anjem Choudary at the age of 15 when he was based with his regiment in Basra, Iraq. She dedicated it to Alan Rickman who died last month after starring alongside her in the film. The British actor played the role of author Ernest Hemingway opposite his love interest Cotillard - herself nominated for Best Actress. The trial, which targets women who are too late to undergo surgery, gives six weeks of additional chemotherapy. On average, 94 women in Northern Ireland each year are diagnosed with breast cancer at stage four (the most advanced), and the new treatment has a successful rate for patients up until now - 80. Now researchers have called on more funding from charities so they can roll out their study across all parts of England where it is needed. A woman's risk of developing breast cancer doubles every 10 years past 30 if there isn't enough oestrogen in her body. It increases by another 50 after 40. The 'womb' or ovaries produce hormones such as progesterone that protects against ovarian cancers but decrease levels of oestrogen when pregnancy occurs. This leads many post-menopausal women into stages three, four and five of breast cancer because no longer having children means higher levels of oestrogen circulating around the system. In contrast, men do not experience this change in hormone production during declining fertility and prostate cells contain high amounts of testosterone throughout life, boosting sperm counts and protecting them against testicular tumours. Professor Tony Young said: "We believe we're onto something here; our clinical trials show giving an extra dose of targeted hormonal therapy significantly improves survival rates over standard care, especially among women whose disease progresses despite taking tamoxifen."

Police are investigating events linked to the funeral and wake of the mother of INLA man Patsy O'Hara, who died in the 1981 hunger strike. Dozens of people wearing military-style uniforms were observed arriving at a house near Dungannon before travelling to St Mary's Church for services during August 21st week this year. According to PSNI officers present on scene there was no evidence that any paramilitary activity had occurred inside or outside the church itself but police said they have identified "persons responsible" including one person from east Belfast after receiving intelligence reports about their presence at the time. It is believed these individuals attended as guests of Mr O'Hara's family and travelled back with them afterwards.

East Sussex Wildlife Rescue said it had rescued 25 birds in the last 12 months at Ditchling Common Country Park. In the latest incident a fishing hook had to be removed from a common tern's wing On Saturday, September 2, emergency services were called out again for another rescue mission after two fledglings fell into an open drain on the third day of their lives. The youngsters managed to wriggle free but not before one was rammed by a car and left with cuts which needed treatment at RSPCA Brighton Animal Hospital where he is now recovering well.

Stuart Coffey, 44, transferred cash from Bracebridge Heath Medical Practice into his own account between 2008 and 2013. Lincoln Crown Court heard he stole so much money the surgery fell behind in its tax payments to HMRC A GP who defrauded a practice out of thousands of pounds has been jailed for two years. Lincoln Crown Court was told Stuart Coffey used funds donated by patients at Bracebridge Health Centre as 'a secret bank'. He paid himself back 40 every day on average over three-and-half year period when working there. His fraud came to light after missing a payment deadline with HM Revenue Customs (HMRC) due to insufficient numbers of patient donations being received. The court heard how 12,000 were then needed urgently but it wasn't until 11 months later that they realised what had happened - which left them facing having their premises repossessed or losing their licence. Michael Cranmer-Brown prosecuting said around 40 per cent of patients didn't realise what had occurred and continued donating under false pretences because of their loyalty towards the practice. Mr Cranmer-Brown added: "It's important to note this is not just about greed. This defendant did try to repay some money." Recorder David Gordon QC described him as someone who took advantage of patients' trust. He said: "You abused your position within an NHS establishment you worked and exploited something called Patient Donation Scheme where people donate very generously to help keep medical services going. You have now repaid nearly all those monies I understand thanks largely to your wife's help."

The Lions looked the more dangerous side in the early stages and experienced striker Steve Morison twice hammered efforts over the crossbar. There was little goalmouth action at either end , but there were a few scares for Stoke before half-time when Robert Snodgrass curled an effort narrowly wide of Shay Given's right post from just outside the box after being set up by Joe Allen. Charlie Adam had been reading his team-mate's intentions well all evening and he did so again to intercept another through ball intended for Morison on 42 minutes as the visitors almost snatched the lead against the run of play. It was not until the 51st minute that some home fans got their first real sight of fortune with one of two Gozie Ugwu headers dropping agonisingly wide. The 500,000 summer signing then nodded down Grant Holt's corner 20 yards out only to see it spilled behind by Jack Butland following Steven N'Zonzi's heavy touch at the near post. A goalmouth scramble ensued which ended with Andrew Surman heading straight into the arms of Given despite six players scrambling around him inside eight yards of opposition territory. Having wasted three clear chances already, Norwich finally made their possession count seven minutes later courtesy of Holt - who has now scored four goals since joining the club this month - firing past Butland from close range. Although Stoke could have levelled matters soon afterwards, Erik Pieters saw his low shot saved impressively by John Ruddy while Marko Arnautovic unleashed a powerful left-footed drive which narrowly cleared the bar. Just like last weekend at Middlesbrough, Albion came under severe pressure late on and they needed some desperate defending resembling the style exhibited during Alex McLeish's tenure to keep things level beyond 90 minutes. With time running out, substitute Cameron Jerome powered forward and sent over an inviting delivery towards Jonathan Walters 12 yards out, but Smalling comfortably held onto his header. In stoppage time, Burnley loanee Sam Vokes headed inches wide when leaving himself unmarked to meet Danny Graham's free kick deep into added time.

Donald Skene grappled with worshippers and headbutted prayers posted on the walls of the Taj Madina Mosque in Victoria Road last December. Skene, 38, was ordered to complete 156 days ' rehabilitation after admitting religiously aggravated criminal damage at Westminster Magistrates Court yesterday (Wed), where he apologised for his behaviour. He told officers "I'm a Muslim - I don't believe it's right" before storming inside while shouting Allahu Akbar as people prayed during Ramadan. The court heard that three minutes later he returned again wearing an Islamic skull cap but left empty handed when police arrived identified him from CCTV footage. A search of his home uncovered two prayer mats which were covered by ISIS posters and extremist literature including images depicting terrorist attacks around London, particularly targeting places frequented by non-Muslims such as buses or tube stations. He told police: "It's not about anyone else being offended because they aren't going through what we are living day to day." In May 2016 Skene had written letters saying he wanted to travel abroad to join IS in Syria. At the time he owned five firearms including rifles, shotguns, handguns and a crossbow. In mitigation defence counsel Ehsan Aslam described how since his arrest 12 months ago Skene has been referred to Prevent, sought professional help for mental health issues and also started attending regular church services dressed as Jesus Christ.

A consultation prompted 620 responses, with 98 saying owners should clean up after pets and 69 saying dogs should be excluded from play areas. But 70 did not want to see any change made at the park in West Ryde. The council's response was that it had no legal authority over dog-ownership requirements but would work on a voluntary basis for responsible pet ownership.

Dermot Nolan, chief executive of Ofgem, told the BBC that domestic gas and electricity prices should be cheaper "for the vast majority of people." The classic adaptation, which opened on Wednesday, is presented on a set designed like a Victorian toy theatre. Broadbent plays his role with an undercurrent of his well-known affability, according to the director Ivan Caryllis: "He's got this wonderful smile that comes in and out during different moments." It was very much by chance - at least partly- that he even made it onto stage as Poirot. He had been offered another play by David Edgar (who has also adapted Agatha Christie for radio), but when McPherson decided to adapt The ABC Murders last year there were problems getting funding and casting. Colleigh suggested Caryllis would be perfect because she knew him from directing several productions of Pinter Plays at the National Theatre; they have worked together twice before since then. "I think Simon Russell Beale described me as having my finger up Piccolos nose," said Caryllis about their first meeting where they discussed how best to present the story. They agreed not to use the original text or music score but instead tried other ways of making sure viewers could follow what's going on within each scene without breaking the fourth wall. That includes using visual methods such as blackouts between scenes so actors can move through them while the audience still see everything happening around them. "This way we don't break lots of dramatic tension just to get people into the next room," explained Caryllis who knows audiences are used to seeing films and TV shows cut away to do this now.

The 777-200, which was carrying 294 passengers from Paris to Vancouver, was diverted to Prestwick after taking off at 10:57 on Saturday. The airline said the plane landed "normally" at Glasgow airport shortly before 14:00. Air France staff were preparing another aircraft for its scheduled departure at 18:30 (16:30 GMT), but this is now delayed by two hours in order that potential technical problems can be checked out.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi scrapped 1,000 (PS11.8) and 500 notes in a surprise move last week as part of a tax evasion and corruption crackdown. People have a limited time to exchange their old currency for new ones at banks or post offices but most ATMs are now dispensing only the smaller 2,000 rupee note. A property agent helps people withdraw money from an ATM machine after demonetisation by Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government on November 8, 2016 in New Delhi, India. (Getty Images) The queues outside bank branches were not as long this morning though many reported no cash was available with them either while some had just one-rupee pieces left. Many said they planned to return later when more supplies arrived. The central government has promised that there will be enough replacement cash in circulation before the end of December so normal economic activity should start returning soon despite rising anger over shortages among Indians who depend on daily wages to survive. In addition it is also likely that ordinary citizens trying to hoard extra cash may find themselves unable to do so amid reports that the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), which controls the banking system, lacked sufficient stocks prior to the decision. "It would appear a lot of people tried to get out all at once," Anindya Banerjee told Reuters as he queued up outside a SBI branch near his home in Kolkata hoping to deposit cash worth about 2,300 into his account. There is widespread scepticism whether that figure can be achieved within such a short period even if authorities manage to replenish rapidly dwindling supply levels over coming days.

13 April 2016 Last updated at 20:41 BST She told BBC TV's Ask the Leader election special it had been a "terrible mistake" for the Lib Dems to make "a coalition of chaos." She said she was still looking forward to standing down and that people should not be concerned about her having a peerage. Ms Swinson, who is also deputy leader on Westminster Council in London, joined the Conservatives as an activist aged just 16 because they were against the European Economic Community (EEC). She has held posts including president of Conservative Future - then called Young Conservatives - and director general of the centre-right think tank Policy Exchange. In 2006 when David Cameron became Tory party leader he appointed her transport minister with responsibility for London Underground. But after 18 months Mr Blair offered her his old job as chief secretary to the Treasury; she accepted but left two years later after falling out with Gordon Brown over plans for public sector pay restraint. After losing her Sussex East seat by 3,000 votes last year, while fellow ex-Tory Amber Rudd won Hastings and Rye from Labour, Ms Swinson challenged Sir Vince Cable to take charge of the Liberal Democrats following Tim Farron's resignation earlier this month. The result surprised many within the party given she lost nine seats under Mr Clegg's leadership between 2010 and 2015. Speaking during Thursday night's programme, which featured all seven remaining leaders answering questions submitted online, she admitted there would have been more support if voters knew what direction the parties wanted to go in. Asked whether there could ever again be coalitions involving other right wing parties such as Ukip or the Tories via electoral pacts similar to those seen since 2007, Ms Swinson said: "I don't see why we couldn't work together." 'Struggle' Over the past week both UKIP's Paul Nuttall and Ruth Davidson of the Scottish Conservatives faced criticism after appearing alongside either Nigel Farage or Theresa May respectively without being quizzed themselves concerning their policies. But asked how politicians like them got away scot free with avoiding scrutiny, Ms Swinson added: "That shows you are asking me difficult political questions I didn't expect! "The thing is, though, every time I've come up against one of these reunions things look much worse than they actually turn out. So perhaps the lesson here...is learn your lessons before you start making any assumptions!" When pressed further on potential future alliances with other parties aside from working with Lib Dem MPs at Westminster, she replied: "There may well be some opportunities where even closer co-operation might happen... so long as everyone knows exactly what they're getting into beforehand." However she insisted Britain needed to give the EU referendum result full effect first. And despite pledging to hold another vote herself in five years unless Parliament voted something else, she refused three times to say whether she believed Brexit should now definitely go ahead regardless of what happens next. Instead she suggested leaving the single market altogether rather than trying to reform it remained on the table depending upon negotiation outcomes. Ms Swinson went on: "But let us focus our energies. It takes quite a lot of energy to pull apart 40 years worth of integration, to try and unpick all those threads. There will need to be compromises made, no doubt, whichever way you cut it. We do know already that the consequences of staying close to Europe economically, financially - whatever you choose to call it - will mean trade barriers going up, economic growth lower and investment slower." Pressed yet again as to whether hardline Brexiteers pushing for a clean break with Brussels really did represent mainstream opinion among Labour Leave supporters too, she responded: "They certainly seem to claim that mantle. They must speak for large numbers of Labour leavers. If you ask everybody: What does success look like? People want immigration reduced, control returned to Britain over borders etcetera. Do Labour Leavers agree with everything the ERG want, absolutely - probably not. That doesn't necessarily stop them voting for Theresa May and the Brexit deal she comes back with. Let's wait and see how successful that ends up being..." Watch the extended edition of AsktheLeader This is my final appearance tonight. Thanks very much MarkMeadowsUK thanks especially to everyone who took part. pic.twitter.comS1Pz7lqOw6 - Jo Swinson (joswinson) June 9, 2017

It scored highly because its ancient castle stands high above a sprawl of shops and homes which are covered in plastic foliage - until Christmas when they all go up like giant inflatable Santas.

7 November 2016 Last updated at 09:30 GMT The balls are formed naturally and happen when pieces of ice get rolled by wind and water. They stretch on the Siberian tundra for miles, but their exact size is unknown as they have been lost to time A stunning natural phenomenon has been filmed in Siberia which looks like a giant sculpture made from snowballs rolling down a mountainside.The white sculptures look more like artwork than nature's own creation when seen against the vast snowy backdrop.However this striking sight happens every year in Yakutia region - part of Russia that lies north east of Kazakhstan and Mongolia.Known locally as 'Snowman's Grave' or Gorny Gorodek (a temporary settlement) these formations can be found across eight different sites close together along the Alazey river valley.They occur after an unusually warm winter during which large sections thaw out.Large chunks of snow then slide downhill into frozen alcoves where they join up with others until becoming huge, complex mounds around seven metres high and five wide.These islets form over several days before melting away completely once summer comes round again.Dragonscale-like patterns emerge on the surface due to sunlight re-freezing parts of each mound.This fascinating video was shot using night vision cameras mounted onto quad bikes by video producers Danila Dakalev Kharitonov Sergey Vasilievich and Timur Dzhabrailov All photographs courtesy Getty Images

The company said it had faced a "chorus of music label representatives and artists" accusing it of "mistreating" songwriters and performers. Hank Green, a prominent video producer and entrepreneur, said in an interview that simply wasn't true: The revamp was not done to placate his complaints about the way YouTube handled copyright issues on its platform; he'd been working with Bachrach on those for years. But what's clear is there were two very different visions at play within Google regarding how best to exploit such valuable assets - one from executives who didn't see any reason why creators should be compensated beyond free promotion through their channels (and thus saw no need or benefit for paying them), while another group believed content producers deserved better treatment as well. It took significant public pressure before management changed course this year.

Cole Skuse's long-range shot fell to James Collins who converted with ease, and though Connor Wickham pulled one back for Rangers in first-half injury time it was clear that two points were coming our way following a second half in which we saw off all threats from Mark Warburton's side, including several corners on top of scoring twice more through Daryl Murphy (his 50th league goal) and Freddie Sears - his fourth against them this season. Jim McCafferty, 71, appeared before Belfast Magistrates' Court charged with eight counts of touching a boy under the age of 16. Gerard Kevin Hughes, 29, and Gavin Martin Hughes, 31, who are both from Springfield Park in Belfast, appeared in court alongside their older brother Joseph Christopher Hughes, 35, from The Hawthorns also in the city. The men were charged with possessing information likely to be useful for terrorism purposes at an address on January 21 this year as well as membership of a proscribed organisation - the IRA. All three defendants denied all charges against them when they made brief appearances by video link before Judge David McFarland at Laganside Crown Court today (Friday). The government wants some households to pay more to raise money for education, and finance secretary Derek Mackay gave evidence to committee backing the plan. The committee formally recommended the levy in November, but several MSPs have since said they would not support it as proposed by ministers. Mackay told Holyrood's Finance Committee that he wanted a system where "the majority of people paid less than 200," although SNP business convener Derek MacKay later insisted this did not mean every home paying between zero and 200. He also suggested there should be payments from those who benefited most - such as high earners or big businesses - rather than having key workers and low-paid families facing higher bills because someone else was getting away with cheaper rates. Committee member Richard Lyle put forward an amendment calling on ministers to bring back proposals to replace council tax within three months if plans are rejected at next week's vote. This proposal will now go before the full parliament when the Bill returns after recess. However, no Conservative members backed his move during today's debate which saw all 11 opposition politicians speak out against the scheme. Labour urged Scottish Government supporters to reject any plans unless fixed, while Lib Dem Tavish Scott accused ministers of trying to sell voters' right to choose their own form of local taxation off to others: "People do not trust governments whose answers depend not upon honest appraisal of costs, benefits and alternatives; nor upon democratic consent," he warned.

The brief for Hirst was simple: create an experience where readers can immerse themselves like never before into words through interaction with objects or spaces; explore ideas about space and time within a book; feel part of something rather than passively consume information contained within traditional pages, chapters and broken lines - do what you want but make it beautiful."

United Nations officials rarely use the words "genocide" and "ethnic cleansing," but they now say potentially both could envelop the world's youngest country. Since violence flared in Juba in July , more than 400 people have been killed according to monitoring groups, with hundreds of thousands displaced by conflict between government forces loyal to President Salva Kiir and rebels backing his former deputy Riek Machar, who is under house arrest. Human rights organizations blame each other for a surge in abuses as international pressure mounts on both sides after weeks of stalemate that has brought Sudan back into Africa's protracted civil wars. The United States wants South Sudanese leaders to stop fighting - or risk losing vital aid funding from Washington. China also warned this week it would review its aid if bloodshed continues.. At least one human rights group says ethnic cleansings are already taking place: Nhial Majak D'Agoot, spokesman at the Justice Ministry said there was no evidence of any ongoing campaigns against civilians based purely on ethnicity. But he acknowledged reports of harassment targeting individuals because their relatives supported either side. He blamed fighters on all sides involved in looting villages, torching homes and raping women. The U.N.'s top official in South Sudan accused rival factions last month of carrying out scorched-earth attackson civilian populations." (Editing by Tim Cocks)

The American moved level with Australian Margaret Court by winning her sixth All England Club crown and first for three years. Williams has now won eight titles during her pregnancy. Her daughter Olympia was born 10 weeks ago. "My baby said 'Ace Mommy'," she told BBC Sport after beating world number one Kerber - who beat her in last year's final but had never got past the fourth round prior. Kerber becomes only the fourth player ever to lose two successive Grand Slam finals against Williams following defeats at Flushing Meadows in 2016 and Melbourne earlier this month. With Simona Halep beaten in straight sets by Caroline Wozniacki in Saturday's women's final, it meant there were no new grand slam champions crowned as Novak Djokovic beat Marin Cilic in five sets to win his third men's title in succession.

Mukherjee's The Lives Of Others, a sweeping account of life in 1960s Calcutta, is 52 favourite to win with bookmakers William Hill. It is the first year that the prize has been open only to writers from Britain and Ireland - previous winners included Americans Philip Roth (2003) and Cormac McCarthy (2006), as well as Australians Richard Flanagan and Helen Garner. "Film scripts are almost always based on books," said Saul Zaentz, producer of American Beauty whose script was written by Christopher Nolan after he read author Alan Ball's 1997 novel about an unhappy high school English teacher driven into adultery and murder. "The real competition for film audiences comes not so much between feature films but between TV miniseries." In one example, British television network BBC America decided last month it would air U.S. cable channel HBO drama True Detective straight after airing its finale later this summer rather than wait another 12 months until next January or February when both seasons will be available on DVD. Last week ITV announced plans to broadcast Oscar-winning movie Slumdog Millionaire simultaneously across nearly all of Europe over Christmas, breaking new ground in cross-border telecasting. In India, movie director Mira Nair hopes her upcoming adaptation of Vikram Seth's fantasy romance A Suitable Boy will interest viewers outside the subcontinent who have never heard of the book before she began filming last September. She says the long gap between publication dates works out better logistically for filmmakers too since they know exactly where their project stands at any given time compared with having to go back to publishers every few weeks while shooting. In Hollywood there typically is no more than six years difference each way between the release date of a finished film adapted directly from a source material like Dr Seuss' children's story Green Eggs And Ham, which hit theatres nine days ago, versus other films based purely upon screenplays such as Ridley Scott's Gladiator released 14 years earlier. THE BIG SCREEN GONE HOME? Some critics see little point in publishing fiction anymore now that cinematic versions can come along just two or three years afterwards whereas authors are often left waiting up to half a lifetime following the original sale if studios do decide to get around to making adaptations. This winter brought George Orwell's Animal Farm and Jane Austen's Northanger Abbey respectively to big screens fresh off bestseller lists; neither took particularly good box office numbers though some say sales spikes usually occur nearer to releases. In recent times major hits garnered via novels turned movies include Tom Clancy's The Hunt For Red October, JK Rowling's Harry Potter series starring Daniel Radcliffe, Meryl Streep and Gary Oldman something critics argue could hardly happen today without the guaranteed return already assured from ticket sales. This helps explain why many top-selling literary titles these day tend towards adventure stories aimed at teenage boys and girls or crime thrillers featuring police detectives working within established fictional universes popularised through comic books and video games. Video game maker Electronic Arts Inc counts bestselling thriller writer James Patterson among its list of celebrity brand ambassadors including Justin Timberlake and Michael Jordan helping sell millions of copies of his work across multiple platforms. He recently signed a deal giving him 90 percent royalties and the chance to option future rights for development into motion pictures worth 1 million per title plus 10 percent participation fees according to Forbes magazine. But Sierra Burgess Is a Loser creator Shannon Hale argues against segregating literature into genres saying successful titles should transcend labels simply because readers want them to succeed regardless, adding however: "I think we're living in somewhat dark ages right now... People don't put money toward literature unless you've got characters wearing capes coming down the stairs." Publishers remain optimistic despite mounting concerns about piracy eroding profits further still even with consumers increasingly willing to pay close attention to details involving production costs versus potential returns. Patrick Spence, managing editor of Little, Brown Book Group, part of UK publisher Hachette Livre, denies stiffening ebook prices were related solely to ebooks becoming less profitable due largely to increased pricing power enjoyed by Amazon itself. Spence cited relatively strong advances paid to debut authors David Nicholls and Donna Tartt amongst others worldwide alongside growing demand especially for nonfiction titles citing Jon Ronson's 2015 billion dollar podcasting industry expose Them as evidence positive change really might lie ahead. But Anthony Barnett, professor of media theory cultural studies at London College of Communication, remains doubtful overall pointing to ever accelerating changes wrought throughout global economies in general leading societies astray in ways unlikely to reverse themselves anytime soon let alone allow anyone else to catch up. (Editing by Belinda Goldsmith BeeGoldsmith. Follow us )

As Abid Naseer started his cross-examination in a New York courtroom of the police officer who searched his Manchester bedroom in 2009, he commented it was nice to hear a lawyer say that. By then Mr Justice Nicholas Parfitt had already heard evidence from English officers about what they found when they went into the defendant's house after arresting him at Heathrow airport as part of an investigation by US counter terrorism officials. And also how their search turned up materials relating not only to al-Qaeda and its propaganda but also videos showing beheadings carried out by so called Islamic State (IS) jihadists. The judge will decide whether information given under oath can be used during Mr Naseer's trial with possible consequences for thousands more people facing extradition on similar allegations. For around four hours this week one British investigator gave testimony which strongly suggested such material is likely to find its way onto UK soil once foreign suspects are sent back home - where they may face charges over activities linked to IS or other groups without being tried first here.

Jimmy Carlson, 64, from Islington, north London, has been appointed OBE for helping to improve services. The former alcoholic became homeless after he was discharged from the Army. Doctor Daniel Haygarth is also made an MBE and honoured for his work with BAME communities in east London during Covid-19. He works at Homerton University Hospital NHS Trust as a senior house officer trainee GP working on infectious diseases and tropical medicine Denise Higgins, 45, of Stoke Newington, north London - who received a late police warning about her partner's abuse but did not pass it on because she 'didn't want him deported' -is awarded an OBE for service to victims of domestic abuse and later turns whistleblower by calling out failures when Manston Airport closed due to coronavirus pandemic last year

Angus Carpenter, of Liverpool, who has played in the city centre for more than 30 years, denied three counts of fraud. The 62-year-old was found guilty of one count when he appeared at Minshull Street Crown Court yesterday (Wednesday). Carpenter submitted a number of false invoices to his own company between December 2016 and August 2017 which were intended to make it look like work had been carried out on several private properties that weren't actually owned by him or anyone connected with him, including those registered as business premises, an address belonging to a member of the public, flats and houses across Merseyside. He falsely claimed 20,935 from Kensington Homes Ltd before also attempting to claim money relating to two other companies - A S Carpentry Services Limited (1,300) and St James' Craftsman Ltd (3,500), all based locally. The court heard how another contractor took photographs inside a property while working there but gave them to Carpenter so they could be used without permission. When then being paid back following completion of works to the house, Carpenter told him not to send any funds through bank transfer because "he didn't trust banks." Instead, he would take cash payments into his office himself - leaving no paper trail whatsoever.

Let's not forget the traditional argument with your other half about whose job it was to buy all the batteries for the children's new toys - which are currently a bit too reliant on electricity. The energy regulator Ofgem has announced that prices will rise by 96 per year from April, and we've been told it'll be at least another eight years before they fall again (we're already paying more than double what we were in 2013). There is some good news though: this could actually save you money as households start switching suppliers like crazy...

US universities are still the most dominant international force in the Times Higher Education rankings. In top place, as last year, is the California Institute of Technology. In the UK no university has a better reputation than Oxford or Cambridge and at least one of them always ranks first for its subject area (in this case biology). Download the new Independent Premium app Sharing the full story, not just the headlines But China's rise continues to make waves within world higher education circles. The country now sends more students abroad - 835,000 outbound enrolments were recorded by the Chinese government during 2011-12 compared with 515,700 five years earlier. This means that there are currently 447,900 Chinese nationals studying overseas on courses for over six months; almost half of these will earn degrees from institutions that participate in the QS World University Rankings. Accordingly institutes based outside Beijing have seen their applications increase significantly: while PekingUniversity remains number three overall it saw an incredible 366 per cent growth between 2010 and 2012, thanks largely to increased interest among applicants seeking to study English language teaching postgraduateships. Every other institution ranked in our table experienced similar surges in applications but none had such extraordinary increases relative to the size of their student populations. The US retains pole position across all categories except Law, where British institutions dominate. It also holds sway in Business Management Studies. But business schools do tend toward Harvard whereas engineering departments steer clear of MIT which takes second spot in both subjects behind Berkeley. With American dominance comes Asian influence however - 64 per cent of those applying to Stanford came from Asia this past year along 69 per cent who applied to Massachusetts Institute of Technology. And we continue to see big jumps up the rankings for many European centres including Imperial College London which moved into 26th position because so few others improved their standing against tough comparators.

The X-47B jet is being designed by weapons manufacturer Northrop Grumman for the US Navy. It was in the air for 29 minutes during its maiden flight and reached an altitude of 25,000 feet. "This aircraft represents a quantum leap forward from anything that exists today on or above water," said Capt Mark Graffam, commander of Naval Air Test Center (NATC) Atlantic Division Detachment commander. "It will transform aviation warfare as we know it."

Ken Dickie, 64, died in hospital on 14 May, six days after the incident at the Rockley Park site in Poole. Jamie Mitchell, 35, of Apple Close, had admitted intervening and attempting to revive Mr Dickie but was found not guilty of his murder following a trial at Winchester Crown Court last month. Image copyright Dorset Police Image caption Ken Dickie's family said he would be "missed forever" by those who knew him Mr Dickie suffered multiple injuries including two broken arms as well as severe brain injury from which he never recovered. He also broke both legs when jumping over an 8ft (2.4m) fence during the attack. The court heard how Mr Dickie may have been trying to stop teenage boys stealing tools that were being used for building work at the time of the assault outside The Moon pub on 31 March 2017. Mitchell told police: "I'm so sorry it happened like this."

The case had been brought by the Brazilian investment fund DIS, which formerly owned the transfer rights to the 24-year-old forward. The company claimed it was short-changed when Neymar transferred this summer from Barcelona for 222 million (262m), a world record fee that included performance bonuses and other add ons clauses of up to another 40m. DISS argued in court earlier this month that those bonus payments were not met - but now has won its battle with PSG after an appeal court ruled against them. "DIS welcomes today's decision," said Flavio Cardoso de Abreu, vice president of DIS' legal department last night (Tuesday). "This is perfect news because our position regarding the obligations assumed [by Neymar] during his contract renewal have always been clear." PSG responded saying they are considering whether or not to take their fight over to France's highest appeals court. "We regret that the Paris Court of Appeal confirmed most aspects of the ruling issued by the Paris Commercial Court of December 2 2017 [that rejected DISS demands," read a statement released by PSG. "Paris Saint Germain will analyse all possible options before deciding if we should lodge an objection to confirm these decisions at the French High Court of Justice."

But with the Foxes now languishing near the foot of the table and one hotelier claiming the impact of Richard III is slowly wearing off, is the journey over? Or are we just getting started? He was a hero for football fans across Leicester on that fateful day. But after six years in charge at King Power Stadium his reign has been characterised by failure to deliver both domestic success - despite lofty ambitions - as well as continental glory which might have earned him respect from some critics who still look back fondly upon our last FA Cup triumph during his first full season in 201314. Yes, he's won the League Cup twice since but it hasn't made up for a league title being denied us when odds were placed against us long before kick-off each year. And let me tell you this: It hurts. He may not yet be gone (the club say they're waiting to see if any'reasonable offer' materialises) but there comes a point where keeping faith becomes difficult given what should've been achieved alongside that charm offensive he began immediately following relegation in 2014. Particularly so when criticism grows louder amid an alarming slump under Craig Shakespeare and speculation mounts about owner Vichai Srivaddhanaprabha looking elsewhere for inspiration instead... when will your patience finally run out, Mr Chairman?

Holly Bradshaw won the women's pole vault with a height of 4.60m, equalling her personal best Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce beat a strong field including defending champion Elaine Thompson and Olympic sprint relay silver medallists Britain's Jodie Williams and Dina Asher-Smith at the IAAF World Athletics Championships Berlin 2017. The Jamaican sprinter clocked 10.71 seconds - 0.35secs outside her own world record set when she took 100m and 200m titles at Beijing 2008 as an 18-year-old. Fraser-Pryce was pushed hard by compatriot Shevon Stoddart but held off Uini Atonio for second place in 11.05 secs. Dina Asher-Smith finished sixth after being hampered towards the end of the race following a clash with another runner which left one shoe needing to be changed before exiting. Thompson maintained her form from earlier rounds despite fading slightly over the closing 50m, crossing third behind Williams who ran that distance in 11.06 seconds.

The Dundee-based company said shareholders had wanted changes to be made to improve performance. Chief financial officer Alan Trotter is to leave Alliance Trust, while chief executive Katherine Garrett-Cox is stepping down with immediate effect after less than three years in the role and will not receive a payout under her contract. Ms Garrett-Cox was appointed as permanent chief executive of Alliance Trust last May following an eight month search that saw two external candidates put forward for the job but then ruled out amid concerns over their salary offers and other terms. In September Ms Garrett-Cox announced she planned "to return from maternity leave early" due to "family reasons" at which point Mr Trotter took on additional responsibilities including finance until his departure this year. Announcing its latest results earlier today it revealed dividend per share has fallen by 19 since 2012. Shares fell 5p or 1.2 to 292p as markets opened this morning (Monday) although they were still up around 35 compared to 12 months ago. The move marks another step away from investment trust territory where assets have shrunk in recent times partly because there are fewer large companies listed on major global stock exchanges meaning managers cannot invest directly into them.

Melissa Reid, 22, from Lenzie, near Glasgow, was arrested with Michaella McCollum, of Co Tyrone, after being caught with 24lb (11kg) of cocaine at Lima airport in 2013. They struck a deal to plead guilty and were sent back home under police escort before the case against them collapsed when they refused to return for trial. Reid has since been jailed three times on drugs charges but released while still serving her sentence without ever standing trial over claims she had staged a prison break by walking out disguised as an elderly nun during visiting hours at HMP Low Moss jail last October. She is now living with her mother.

Researchers followed nearly 240,000 Swedish men for 35 years. The analysis, published in the journal Gut, showed overweight teenagers went on to have twice the risk of bowel cancer. The researchers said this effect was seen regardless whether they had a high or low body mass index (BMI). The findings were similar when looking at smokers and those who drank alcohol every day - both groups also reported an increased risk if obese during their teenage years. Professor Ulf Ekelund from Sahlgrenska Academy in Sweden told Sky News: "We wanted to study... what happens before you become ill with colon cancer? What we found is that being over-weight increases your chances." He added there are many reasons why obesity can increase people's risks but most studies focus only on diabetes which he says has not been proven as a cause yet.

Fans threw flares and ripped up parts of the Mohammed V stadium after Raja's 2-1 victory over Chabab Rif Al Hoceima. The country's DGSN security service said in a statement that some fans also attacked its officers at the ground, injuring three people before being dispersed by police firing tear gas. The game was played behind closed doors due to an order from authorities aimed at preventing coronavirus infections but many supporters gathered outside the King Baudouin Stadium - named for Morocco's former king who died last October - despite this ruling..

Government limits to teachers' pay and "real terms cuts" to school budgets risk undermining standards, they warn. "Teachers need a pay rise," they urge, in a joint statement to the Observer ahead of Tuesday's National Education Union conference in London. But ministers are refusing demands for extra cash after an official report showed that schools had been underfunded since 2011 by 2bn - with funding per pupil now at its lowest level on record as inflation has outstripped growth in teaching staff numbers over this period. The former Tory prime minister David Cameron was forced into 2015 spending U-turns when he tried to cut wages for public sector workers such as nurses but failed amid opposition from Labour and unions. However, there is no appetite among Conservatives to repeat those mistakes again even though teacher strikes could lead to voters turning against them unless politicians can find some way through the impasse before December's general election. The NEU says it will seek strike ballots if disputes cannot be resolved or, where possible, begin planning industrial action while negotiations continue. On Monday, education secretary Damian Hinds told BBC Radio 4: It] would clearly not make sense ... [if we were to have another round of] strikes." He said any new money available should go towards reducing class sizes first because smaller classes improved children's learning outcomes more than higher salaries for teachers alone. Asked whether he thought striking teachers wanted better conditions rather than higher salaries, Hinds replied: "I think what you see at times like these is people who want their voices heard; I don't think most adults actually enjoy disrupting young people." But union leaders say teachers deserve much more than just 1 a year rises given average starting salaries are around 30,000, according to research published last week which warned many pupils leave secondary school unable to read properly due to lack of reading skills acquired during primary years. Some 90 of all teachers describe themselves as struggling financially compared with 75 five years ago as real living costs soar faster than wage increases, according to a survey conducted by Tes magazine. General secretary Kevin Courtney tells the Observer: 'We know teachers work incredibly hard so why shouldn't our members receive fair rewards? We won't accept below-inflation pay rises without serious negotiation.'

The PS1.471bn spent shooting movies like Star Wars: The Force Awakens and Avengers: Age of Ultron in 2014 represents a 35 increase on 2013. Money spent on homegrown UK films was up by 11 per cent to 58m, thanks largely to the success of Mad Max Fury Road (8.9m), Ex Machina (4.2m) and Room (which cost only 800k). UK film makers also received revenue from independent productions shot abroad which amounted for roughly half the total spend at 270 million compared with 198 million in 201213 and 155m four years ago.

Dave Walsh, president of Liverpool Trades Council, said the council should not be afraid of setting an illegal budget. He said: "There's an old saying in the Labour movement,'better to break a law and set it again than to keep breaking it'. I think we are going through that at the moment." Both sides have been running their own campaigns for months but this is one time when they actually agree on something - 5p tax rise

Steven Rodriguez, who was better known as AAP Yams or Yamborghini, died aged 26 on 18 January at Brooklyn's Woodhull Medical Centre. He founded the US rap collective AAP Mob with fellow rappers Adlib and AAP Bari in 2013 (pictured above). In a statement to The FADER, his family said: "He touched countless lives through music, artistry and kindness and he will be deeply missed." At the time of press, police confirmed that no foul play is suspected. In December 2019, Biggie Smalls' estate filed a lawsuit against RCA Records for copyright infringement over its use of his songs in an upcoming movie about Tupac Shakur - without permission from either party involved.

The military said the driver was taken into custody after the incident near the Jewish settlement of Ofra. It brings to 41 the number of Israelis killed in knife, gun or car-ramming attacks since October 2015. The Palestinian toll stands at 67 dead and more than 2,100 wounded during that period. In a wave of violence last week, Israeli forces shot four Palestinians who stabbed or tried to stab soldiers and civilians in Jerusalem and the West Bank on Thursday alone. Overall this year, there have been close to 130 stabbings carried out against Israelis by Palestinians around the same time frame, according to Israeli police figures. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has vowed a tough response: "Whoever tries to attack us will pay dearly." Those sentiments were echoed Wednesday evening as he laid wreaths for those slain over the past five years - including three children under 10. He also called on other countries to join him in recognizing Israel's right to defend itself when necessary. "At times like these we should stand together," he told international ambassadors gathered outside his residence in Jerusalem from nations with whom it does not often hold formal diplomatic ties. Netanyahu made no direct mention of any proposed change to laws governing freedom of speech, but some members of parliament are suggesting legislation to allow tougher action against individuals involved in violent protests. For now, however, such measures may be difficult to enact because they require parliamentary approval. Israel captured east Jerusalem along with the west during the 1967 Mideast war and annexed both areas in moves that are not internationally recognized. Its annexation is not accepted by most world powers, which regard the territories as occupied territory awaiting a final status agreement between the sides. Thousands of Palestinians live in east Jerusalem neighborhoods deep inside what Israel considers its capital city.

Mandla Hlatshwayo and his friend were shot after confronting a group of men who had robbed women of their mobile phones in a pub in Soweto. The suspects were found guilty by the Gauteng High Court, sitting at Palm Ridge Magistrate's Court on charges including murder with intent to cause grievous bodily harm (GBH), robbery with aggravating circumstances and attempted GBH. The attackers fled when they saw that police reinforcements were arriving. They fired shots into the air as they tried to escape from the scene. Two days later an irate mob descended upon them outside Hillbrow Police Station, where they held them hostage until they could be handed over to law enforcement officials. "A total of four people appeared before court yesterday [Wednesday] - two accused persons aged 26 years old and 36 years-old for counts of Murder With Intent To Cause GBH; Robbery With Aggravated Circumstances; and Attempted Causing Grievous Bodily Harm," said Hawks spokesperson Captain Simphiwe Mhlongo via a statement released on Thursday morning.

Ryan Morse, from Brynithel, Blaenau Gwent, died on 8 December 2012 from undiagnosed Addison's disease. Dr Leonard Peter told Cardiff Crown Court Dr Joanne Rudling, of Cardiff, did not ask to see the teenager before he was treated with steroids at Weston General Hospital in Carmarthenshire and had no blood test results indicating an underlying condition when she prescribed them for him after his mother complained about a lack of energy during her visit to hospital. Dr Lenny Peter giving evidence into what happened (PA Archive) Mr Morse collapsed while playing football 10 days later but never recovered consciousness or movement following surgery and died four months later. His parents are suing Bristol University Hospitals NHS Trust over their son's death last year aged 15. Mr Justice Ouseley is hearing the action remotely as part of a legal first due to coronavirus restrictions being imposed across Wales earlier this month. The case continues.

Australia's foreign minister said these were "not the actions of a friend." The US has also strongly condemned Russia over its diversion - and detention on board an ageing aircraft carrier -of 10 Israeli crew members who had been smuggling 40m (30m) worth of diamonds out of Africa by concealing them in false compartments inside their plane. Moscow is demanding compensation from Tel Aviv for what it says will be damage to the Russian ship.

The unmanned cargo ship was launched from Kazakhstan on Tuesday, but contact was lost with it soon afterwards. Russia's space agency says Progress M-27M is now orbiting in an uncontrolled way and poses no threat to the International Space Station (ISS). SpaceX chose not to bid for a NASA contract worth 1 billion that would have sent astronauts back into orbit using their Dragon capsule. After launching its uncrewed test flight last month - which ended up being cut short after just over two weeks when one of SpaceX's Falcon 9 rockets exploded during launchpad testing - Elon Musk told reporters at a press briefing: "We were disqualified because our price wasn't low enough." The news came as something of a blow...
