A merger of the Royal Liverpool and Aintree University hospitals has been proposed in the draft Sustainability and Transformation Plan for Merseyside and Cheshire released on Wednesday. It aims to improve patient care at both sites, but there are concerns over the "privatisation" of health services. The report also proposes a reorganisation of social services which will see two areas created: Sefton West (covering St Helens) and Southport and Ormskirk district councils; and Halton.

Doctors realised Maia Collingswood needed the transplant after her father Dan revealed he also had the procedure in 1997. Maia, from Barmouth, Gwynedd, had the transplant at London's Great Ormond Street Hospital on December 27 It was during a family holiday to Aberystwyth when Dan first noticed something wasn't right with his daughter and she started having seizures every day around 7pm. Pictured: She is taken off for surgery today The youngster went into hospital several times but doctors were unable to find out what caused them. After being referred to various specialists they eventually discovered that Maia has mitochondrial disease - meaning there are problems producing energy within cells of body tissues or organs (stock image) WHAT IS MITOCHONDRIAL DISEASE? Mitochondrial diseases affect how your body uses food as fuel. They are caused by faults in mitochondria, which are tiny structures inside almost all our cells that produce most of the energy we need to live. Common symptoms include muscle weakness, poor growth, lethargy, blindness, heart defects and brain disorders. Vitamin deficiencies, particularly vitamin B12 deficiency, can be an underlying cause. In some cases, parts of the body begin to fail because they don't get enough oxygen. These are known as organ failure. Symptoms vary depending on which part of the body is affected. Treatment focuses on providing extra nutrients where possible, or replacing worn-out organs. Source: NHS Choices 'I kept getting told it would just pass 'but nothing ever changed,' said Mr Collingwood whose transplants comes 22 years after treatment himself.'She lost weight really quickly, so I thought perhaps she may have an eating disorder but then everything else came back including losing eyesight slowly over time'. 'By this point my wife Lisa and myself were in despair because no one knew why Maia was unwell', added the musician who says now feels like Maia's third parent. Mr Collingwood got tested again last year while struggling through chemotherapy and radiotherapy following testicular cancer diagnosis. He underwent the same tests twice more before learning he too suffers from Mito Disease. As well as liver issues similar to Maia, both parents suffer joint pains due to their condition along with skin rashes and hair loss. The couple put much emphasis on keeping fit despite suffering pain daily. Last Christmas Day saw the entire family spend together though many tears were shed throughout the evening; laughter only breaking through every few minutes between bouts of grief and sadness. But the moment everyone looked forward to arrived without any warning. Maia suffered a seizure brought about by low blood sugar levels leaving her unconscious until paramedics pumped some liquid glucose into her veins via a drip arriving 10 minutes later. Her condition improved once medication took effect allowing the whole family enjoyed each other's company undisturbed. A statement released yesterday read: 'After months of appointments at different hospitals searching for answers...and two operations on her liver propped up against life support machines and dialysis machines, we finally found a team who could help us solve these mysteries surrounding Maia's health challenges. We therefore decided to take hope rather than giving up. And miracle upon miracles....we did!'.

Emmerson Whittel may need surgery on his jaw, while the club alleges player Josh Lynam was also bitten on the ear. The RFL's match review panel will look at official reports for all three incidents which came during a melee in Friday night's game between Batley Bulldogs and Halifax at Mount Pleasant Rugby Football League chief executive Ralph Rimmer today confirmed that an investigation is under way into allegations of biting made by both clubs following last weekend's Championship clash. The former Leeds Rhinos rugby union forward has been charged with Grade F punching after being sent off late on against Halifax - but there are further issues to be settled over what happened before then as well. Wigan Warriors' John Bateman (left) leaves the field injured Credit: PA Batley coach Matt Diskin said he heard from other players on his side who were involved in "a bit of niggly stuff" beforehand - though added they did not want any sanctions handed out if it could so easily have been put down to rough play. Meanwhile, Wigan duo Liam Marshall Oliver Partington face bans themselves after receiving two separate charges relating to dangerous tackles.

Surprise frontrunner Francois Fillon said his project was "more radical," and vowed to implement sweeping changes in the first three months of his term. Alain Juppe insisted his proposals were more realistic, while Nathalie Kosciusko-Morizet has a reputation for being pro-business despite having called herself antiestablishment during her stint as minister under Sarkozy. Lagging behind these candidates are two other contenders: far right candidate Marine Le Pen and former Socialist Prime Minister Manuel Valls who joined forces with Macron last week after dropping out himself. Both campaigns have little chance of capturing the imagination of voters beyond their small bases but they may affect how people vote if one goes farther than expected on May 7th - or ends up facing off against an establishment choice that lacks momentum by then.

The man, named by state media as Ji Zhongxing, 34, from central Shandong province, was injured and taken to hospital. No-one else was hurt in the blast, which filled part of a flight cabin with smoke, the reports said. "We had just passed through airport security when there was an explosion," one passenger told Xinhua news agency. "I've never experienced such fear." Air China is investigating the incident at Beijing's new Daxing International Airport (AFPFile Photo) An Air China spokesman confirmed that the aircraft involved Flight CA 969 bound for Bangkok had been forced into an emergency landing due to what he called a technical problem but did not offer any further details on how it happened or if passengers were still onboard. State broadcaster CCTV quoted local fire services saying they received calls about an explosion aboard around 4:40pm, shortly after takeoff. The plane returned safely back to the airport without passengers.

Three years ago, Swedish software consultancy Crisp decided that the answer was no. The firm, which has about 40 staff, had already trialled various organisational structures, including the more common flat management style and a "holacracy" system where everyone is free to make decisions for themselves as long as they follow collective rules on decision-making. The latter worked well enough in small groups but it didn't scale up; some employees felt like second class citizens because of their lack of influence over decisions taken by the larger group. The result? A new hybrid model inspired partly by Holacracy (which would come to be known internally at Crisp simply as "Crispy called Flexible Teams. But rather than trying out every conceivable team structure and seeing what works best under different circumstances - an approach favoured by many agile thinkers - Crisp's leaders narrowed down the options through rigorous testing against criteria such as whether people feel engaged or unengaged with work.

The decision of the Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) to leave rates at their new, historically low, level was no surprise. Last month the Bank halved its bank rate from 0.5 pc to a historic low of just 0.25pc with other measures including 200bn in quantitative easing and an increase in government bond purchases as it attempts to prop up Britain's economy during coronavirus lockdown. However, there were some hints that policymakers may be looking for signs when they meet again on May 7 before deciding whether or not another cut is required - but markets are betting heavily against this happening any time soon despite concerns over unemployment.
Based on a true story, Pride shows how gay rights campaigners from London raised thousands of pounds for miners in the Dulais Valley, after the NUM had spurned their support.

The University of Wisconsin successfully claimed that Apple used its microchip technology without permission in some iPhones and iPads. The patent, filed in 1998, is said to improve the power efficiency of a chip by using infrared light instead of electricity when transmitting data between devices. Apple has allegedly been infringing on this design for years - though it wasn't until 2014 did it start selling products with this tech inside them (which makes sense). It was first made public back in 2017 but didn't make headlines until now after being rewritten as US Patent No 9,193,604 B2 earlier last year. If you want more information head over here:

Liberal centrist Emmanuel Macron - winner of the first round - and nationalist Marine Le Pen are already revolutionising French politics. They have delivered a big blow to the long-dominant conservative and socialist parties that alternated in power until now, as well creating new roles for themselves within their respective groups: The Socialists' candidate Benoit Hamon conceded on Sunday night after coming fourth with just 11 percent despite his promise to create a universal basic income scheme he said would cost 40 billion euros (42 billion) per year. The plan was popular among young voters but left him struggling to win over many traditional Socialist supporters who backed either Fillon or fellow hard leftist Jean-Luc Melenchon instead. "We will assume our responsibilities," Hamon told supporters at his campaign headquarters near Paris before promising to make himself available should the party want its support during upcoming legislative elections. Click here to read more about how France's election works Pendant ce temps dans l'entourage de EmmanuelMacron: "Jamais je ne voterai pas Hollande!" LePenVote pic.twitter.com6nW3jqS1Rp - LCP (LCPofficiel) May 7, 2017 While President Francois Hollande is expected to resign this week once the results become official, Prime Minister Bernard Cazeneuve has stayed put while French media reported last month talks were underway between him and Senate Speaker Gerard Larcher about replacing Manuel Valls as head of government. With no clear majority emerging from Sunday's vote any replacement prime minister could struggle to get parliamentary backing when they wish to pass laws such as those needed to implement a planned labour reform which critics say puts too much strain on companies by raising the bar for firing workers. On Monday hundreds gathered outside parliament calling on lawmakers not to back what one placard held aloft called Valls " social coup'. A group opposed to a proposed tightening up of gun control rules also took part in protests against plans being drawn up under Interior Minister Matthias Fekl to ban future sales of weapons capable of carrying large magazines. After campaigning away from the limelight since taking office 18 months ago, Hollande gave an unusually energetic speech late Friday urging people to come out to vote, saying it was vital for democracy. But analysts suggest his intervention did little to boost turnout amid anger towards politicians seen as arrogant following years during which unemployment hit almost 10 percent and some fear it may rise again. (FRANCE 24 with REUTERS) More from France French far right leader tapped into angst Can Sarkozy beat FN? What we know so far... France votes to decide Europe's fate

Media playback is not supported on this device Governing body the UCI introduced the ban in 2011, but a whistleblower said Team Sky continued to inject riders. One of the treatments allegedly used was testosterone A former team doctor for Team Sky has claimed he witnessed "unethical" drug use and poor medical management by the British cycling squad during his time there between 2010-13. Richard Freeman wrote an email describing how some patients were administered medication without their consent while at the team. The contents will be aired publicly as part of a parliamentary inquiry into doping allegations surrounding Team Sky, which could see its licence revoked if it fails to provide sufficient evidence that its methods are "sporting clean." external-link Dr Richard Freeman worked with Sir Bradley Wiggins (left) throughout his career - including when the rider won gold at London 2012. The pair also travelled together to Australia for the following year's Tour de France In September 2016 UK Anti-Doping launched proceedings against Dr Freeman after receiving information regarding Therapeutic Use Exemptions obtained through anti-doping controls from three unnamed cyclists. He denied any wrongdoing before resigning last May ahead of being charged over 'prescription offences'. It took until August 2018 for him to respond formally to these charges relating to the administration of banned substances triamcinolone - better known under the brand name Kenacort - and fluimucil to members of the Sky Procycling Team between June 2011 and February 2013. Freeman denies any suggestion that either substance caused or contributed to performance enhancement within professional sport. In January 2020, he was found guilty of ordering 30 sachets of Testogel via eBay by a Medical Practitioners Tribunal Service panel. However, he avoided suspension due to ill health. The tribunal ruled its reasons would not be published because they contained sensitive personal data about individuals who had made complaints against Freeman. 'This action has been taken despite my objections... I do feel strongly that I have no case to answer and am confident I can clear my name.' He resigned just hours afterwards. A statement released added: It] has become increasingly apparent to me since November 2017 that those running the service at the General Medical Services department [of Team Sky], did not share my commitment to maintaining the highest ethical standards within the team." However now details revealed in emails sent by Dr Freeman suggest unethical practices going back years further than previously thought. On Thursday MPs met representatives of both Team Sky and British Cycling amid concerns that the public inquiries may fail to produce definitive answers. There is also concern among some athletes that too much damage might already have occurred.

John Lahiff, 75, told local media that he disturbed the crocodile while looking for a ball in water at the course in Port Douglas, Queensland. He was taken to hospital with non life-threatening injuries Lahiff said: 'I thought I'd get one more stroke off and then see where it found me' before being attacked by what is believed to be an 11ft croc called Harry (pictured) The 12 golfers saw the reptile swimming towards them as they played on Sunday morning but were shocked when Mr Lahiff fell into its mouth without warning Mr Lahiff explained how his horrific ordeal unfolded during their round of nine holes at 6am. He revealed Billy had approached him after dropping another golfer off - saying: 'Hey John! Come out here mate!' As soon as he arrived close enough, the large saltwater crocodile pulled down Mr Lahiff from behind. His friends didn't even realise what happened until hearing him scream loudly underwater. In disbelief over what has just occurred, one player can be heard calling flatly: It's] been fed.' The rest are equally stunned as there appears no way either party could have seen each other coming through thick vegetation so early in the day. One person calls repeatedly for help but nobody nearby seems able to do anything except hope someone else will come along who knows CPR or first aid. They continue playing oblivious to the fact anyone may need assistance urgently. Eventually others realised something serious must have occurred because they started shouting out that somebody needed paramedics immediately due to some kind of medical emergency Billy says she doesn't usually call people names if they miss putts, which makes her actions all the more shocking considering this incident involved a man she knew personally having almost died When asked why did not think twice about going near the edge of the lake and taking such extreme risks? She replied: 'You know you're not gonna die... You should always play safe though obviously yeah'. Pictured is the scene following the attack At least two people eventually noticed something had gone seriously wrong around a mile away later and went straight back only to find Mr Lahiff submerged beneath the surface screaming. They managed to pull him onto dry land before performing CPR for 20 minutes until paramedics arrived. One said afterwards he felt like the group'saved [his] friend's life', according to Yahoo 7 News. In total four men tried unsuccessfully to save Mr Lahif. But despite their efforts, rescuers couldn't administer any further treatment once they got him safely up onto solid ground, leaving doctors instead deciding simply keeping pressuring on already open wounds would keep him alive long enough for an air ambulance flight to arrive. Paramedics desperately rushed him via helicopter to Cairns Hospital suffering significant facial lacerations, including damage to both eyes. Doctors say these eye injuries pose potentially dangerous complications given the amount of blood loss sustained. Most concerning still remains internal bleeding within his liver however medics are hopeful those injuries won't prove fatal. These images show inside the wound caused by the predator Divers searched the area using infared cameras hoping to spot the huge animal responsible for the vicious bite marks across Mr Lahiff's torso. It took six dives to finally catch sight of Harry lurking under the murky waters, authorities confirmed Harry, understood to weigh 400lbs and measuring roughly 5m from nose tip to tail, appeared very aggressive throughout much of the search operation although ultimately allowed himself to be caught unharmed so police officers could retrieve footprints left in the mud leading directly to his den Despite several days passing since the traumatic event now known locally as the Port Douglas Crocodile Attack resulting in multiple surgeries, Grafton Base Hospital staff remain cautious regarding whether Mr Lahiff will survive beyond Christmas Day Mr Lahiff spent three nights recovering at Port Douglas Hospital and discharged last Thursday en route to Brisbane City in order to receive urgent surgery at Princess Alexandra Hospital. Speaking publicly for the first time today in incredible scenes outside the same hospital, Mr Lahiff thanked everyone who helped rescue him. But added ominously: 'There'll be plenty more bloody stories,' referring to many other incidents involving similar tragedies occurring every year around Australia. Asked how does he feel knowing numerous lives depended upon him surviving the encounter, Mr Lahiff admitted feeling guilty. Those feelings intensified considerably after learning eight tourists previously lost their own lives trying to take selfies next to wild animals in recent years alone. What is perhaps most remarkable about this story is that Mr Lahiff refused to learn self defence techniques offered free to Australians living where wildlife encounters often occur. When shown footage of the attempted capture shortly before speaking to journalists said: 'If anybody wants to go anywhere near a croc... Don't bother doing it unless your really 100 per cent sure'.

Clubs are required to provide accurate details of training sessions and player whereabouts so they are available for testing at all times. The Cherries were deemed to have failed to do this on three occasions from March 20-April 16, which included the period in question when the club reported several positive cases among their squad following a round of testing last week." Players who tested negative fell under government guidelines that if identified as close contacts could still play provided they returned two negatives 24 hours apart but it is believed Southgate did not feel comfortable with players mixing during international duty given there was no guarantee any would be Covid free after travelling abroad or mixing together through England's camp.

Human Rights Watch believes Nato air strikes killed at least 72 civilians and says the organisation needs to bear responsibility where appropriate. "Nato has a duty to show that it is willing to investigate alleged violations by its forces." When asked about civilian casualties during an interview with BBC Radio 4's Today programme earlier this week, Sir Michael Fallon accused Human Rights Watch of not understanding how the conflict worked. He also highlighted British efforts towards protecting civilians: The UK] are doing everything we possibly can... [to make sure] there aren't any more innocent deaths from our airstrikes."

The Sky Blues currently play in Coventry's Ricoh Arena but had a long dispute with the stadium's previous owners. The council said the club wanted to meet to understand how it could unlock "the full value of their lease" on land around the ground, which is owned by the local authority. Plans for a new 60,000-capacity arena at the site were shelved earlier this year after the collapse into administration of property developer Sisu and its parent company Finablr Plc. Another backer has since come forward, however, saying they want guarantees over tenancy rights before agreeing terms.

Joanna Michael, 25, from St Mellons, Cardiff, rang 999 twice before Cyron Williams stabbed her to death in 2009. The Independent Police Complaints Commission (IPCC) ruled she was failed by police and the watchdog is still investigating what went wrong with Ms Michaels' case A mother who died on Christmas Day after being knifed 14 times had begged for help just minutes earlier - but officers were not dispatched until an hour later because staff thought it was a hoax call. Bar worker Joanne Michaels, 25, dialled 999 at around 8pm complaining of chest pains shortly before losing consciousness having been attacked while walking home from work alone outside Llanrumney, south Wales. An inquest jury has now concluded that Miss Michaels could have survived if emergency services had answered their radio sooner less than half-a-mile away. They also criticised South Wales Police's handling as 'inadequate'. The force accepted all points raised during Thursday's hearing into Miss Michaels' murder three years ago. Her family said they hoped lessons would be learned so other families did not suffer like them following mistakes made over previous incidents involving women who died after calling 911. Miss Michaels worked behind the bar at the Bargoed Inn pub where she met Mr Williamz when he came there looking for his brother Leon James. She and another colleague went out back so she could buy him some cigarettes only moments before she called cops then fell unconscious. But despite four calls including one from her friend pleading: 'My girlfriend needs you', no officer arrived and she bled to death 15 minutes later near Riverside Park overlooking the River Taff opposite her former home. Three ambulance crews used a defibrillator within seconds arriving first followed soon afterwards by two more ambulances. A single paramedic attempted CPR whilst awaiting further assistance which never turned up even though radio communications indicated those resources should do so. Two extra paramedics eventually got there almost 90 minutes after receiving the initial 999 call. Convicted killer Kevin Williams, 32, can be heard saying repeatedly to operator Ysbyty Gwynedd dispatcher Sharon Roberts: 'I need some fg help.' He interrupted again adding: 'We've gotta go... we're running late anyway I'm going to get my sister [to take me],' he tells Mrs Roberts. In total he makes seven phonecalls during which time his victim lies dying and begging for help. But her parents Simon and Sally claim cruel jibes about injuries sustained in gymnastics contributed towards her taking her own life aged just 17 in May 2017. An inquest this week heard how her disability led others to make fun of the level of treatment her carers gave her and claimed drinking bleach would fix everything. One bully told friends he wanted to cut off her legs leaving doctors struggling to manage severe depression brought on by her ordeal. Just six weeks prior to killing herself Robyn confessed to staff working at West Sussex College in Crawley that people were threatening to tell everyone intimate details of photographs she shared online without permission. Speaking ahead of Tuesday's hearing social media company Snapchat denied knowing anything about any complaints regarding its service despite admitting users may sometimes report content violating its guidelines. Its policies state nudity must comply with local laws. Another teacher revealed Robyn feared certain pupils might learn nude images existed on her mobile after seeing footage recorded using CCTV cameras installed across college buildings. Following interviews carried out with students many admitted posting comments online with most unaware full names appear next to messages once published. After reading other peoples posts these individuals believed her identity had already become widely public knowledge leading to cyberbullying against her character becoming increasingly worse. Now Robyns family want internet companies to change policy insisting once someone starts doing something harmful they should start monitoring activity instead of once damage occurs. Social Media Safety spokeswoman Lydia Cairns said research shows between 12 - 43 per cent of young adults experience mental health issues linked to apps like Instagram and YouTube each month. Negotiations over who will run the PS200m Metrobus network have stalled as bus companies are reluctant to run the service on a completely commercial basis. Metrobus admits public subsidies might be needed, but has been vague about how much money they need from taxpayers. The city's director-general in charge of transport and urban planning, Sipho Nzuza, said: "We're not here for profit. We want to make sure that we get value for every rand spent."

The team of scientists hope the information will help shift the focus away from the way trees look towards on the focus on biodiversity. Over the next decade, the urban forest is expected to cover 1 more land area in Europe and a further 3-5 across temperate latitudes worldwide 'We have shown you can quantitatively compare tree diversity between cities using standardised methods and find that city populations are remarkably similar,' said Dr Riddell. 'This study shows how important it is for people all over world not just to think about big old oak trees but also street trees as potential sources of new genes.'

It effectively completes the four-year-old software's transformation from a "lightweight" chat app, spun off from the main Facebook site, into a fully-fledged "platform" of its own. More than 40 new features are available on Messenger - including making and receiving payments, booking rides with Uber or Lyft, sending money to friends through Venmo, playing games such as Heads Up! and joining video calls that can accommodate up to 50 people simultaneously. Facebook has been waiting for regulatory approval in India since it first announced plans to roll out WhatsApp Pay here last year. According to sources at National Payments Corporation Of India (NPCI), which regulates retail payment systems across the country, an internal process had begun earlier this month. However, NPCI did not respond to Mint queries till press time Tuesday. The Reserve Bank of India also declined comment beyond what is publicly known about WhatsApp's progress towards launching UPI-powered WhatsApp Pay operations by early next year. Last week, San Francisco-headquartered peer-to-peer mobile payments company Square Inc said it would launch integrated digital wallets - supported by both Apple and Android devices - in Australia during Q2 2021. Also called Instant Deposit, Tap Go will let users store funds digitally instead of paying merchants via cash register machine terminals. A different feature allows you to add other cards associated with your account directly into their Wallet using QR code scanning technology. Similar services have already been rolled out widely by Google Pay and Walmart owned PhonePe. In China too, Tencent Holdings Ltd's WeChat PAY dominates among all third party apps doing business within the Weixin ecosystem. That includes 400 million monthly active small businesses (MABS). But while we've seen many examples so far where these big techs get rewarded handsomely because they offer novel products and services without taking any merchant fees, there remain some concerns around how safe and secure consumer data runs once stored outside dedicated local serverscloud environments.

She is the first non-white female cabinet-level official appointed to the incoming Trump administration. As an example of Spanish Romanticism that is recognized across Europe to this day, there are few other instruments on display anywhere more representative than this one here today."

Dubbed "carbon farming," researchers say the idea is economically competitive with high-tech carbon capture and storage projects. But critics say the idea could be have unforeseen, negative impacts including driving up food prices for poor people in developing countries where hunger already stalks millions of families. The concept involves growing crops using methods that increase soil fertility while reducing or removing greenhouse gas emissions from farmland by trapping them underground as part of natural processes such as photosynthesis rather than allowing them to escape into a warming atmosphere. Crops include wheat, barley, oats, rye, rice, sorghum, millet, sunflowers, peanuts, soybeans, various legumes and vegetables like lettuce and tomatoes. The process can also be used on pasture land and forest lands being converted to cropland.

A YouGov survey suggested low name recognition of councillors across the UK, with 79 of East Midlands residents unable to name a single representative. Satisfaction with the work of councils has also been declining since 2010 and now stands at only 30 per cent satisfaction in our region, compared with 36-42 nationally - lower than Europe's other big urban areas such as Paris or Madrid (43) but much higher than London (22). But despite this it seems that few people have considered standing themselves for local elections. According to the Electoral Commission just 939 candidates stood out of more than 10 million eligible voters in May 2017. The total number was about half what had actually turned up four years earlier when there were 1,532 candidate lists from 3,700 wards around England. Or put another way five times fewer council seats changed hands on election day last time round than they did 20 years before in 1997. This points towards an airless void which leaves little place for political debate because even if voters know who their representatives are no one is motivated enough stand against them. With so many options available most choose not get involved. And those that do often find out its harder to engage constituents online rather than face-to-face.

The former Army helicopter pilot and two fellow crew members will launch to the International Space Station (ISS) on a landmark flight from Baikonur Cosmodrome, in Kazakhstan. To mark the historic moment he's been wearing his full blue boiler suit with gold piping as part of an official ceremony at their training base here - before they depart for the final leg of their mission. "I'm not doing experiments or anything like that but I am very happy we're going," said Mr Whitson who turns 57 next week when she returns home after her third ISS stint which is set last until September this year. Her return has already begun generating interest among foreign broadcasters planning documentaries while Nasa also plans special coverage including TV interviews during landing back in America. "It really hasn't sunken into me yet that it's real...we have about 90 days left over there so its kind of hard to believe right now." She added: "We've trained pretty extensively through our careers up till now and some additional things..."

Two serving police officers, a retired police officer, a current pilot and a retired pilot were arrested as part of a South Yorkshire Police investigation. Reports had been made that the men would be sharing indecent selfies with young girls across the world. The group was said to have shared hundreds of sickening images between them in WhatsApp groups linked to their personal mobile phones over an 18-month period - some showing children being raped. Detective Constable Mark Fewster, who led on Operation Tardant - which also involved other members of Sheffield's child exploitation team - described it as one of the most 'horrendous' cases he'd ever dealt with during his career. Arthur Cave, 15, was found with multiple injuries on the underpass of Ovingdean Gap in July. He died later at the Royal Sussex County Hospital. Sussex Police said his death is being treated as unexplained and an investigation continues. Police have released CCTV images which show two men they would like to trace following the incident. They were seen walking along Brighton Road between 6pm-6.10pm before turning into Retreat LaneLambeth Walk where Arthur lived. Detective Inspector Simon Dunn from the Surrey and Sussex Major Crime Team said: "We are releasing new information about this case because we believe there may be witnesses who haven't spoken yet so I am appealing directly for them to come forward - your help could prove vital to us solving what has happened here."

Wilson was airlifted to hospital from the Pocono Raceway in Pennsylvania after Sage Karam's car spun and crashed in front of him on lap 179 of 200. Debris from Karam's Chevrolet hit Wilson hard, sending his No. 20 into a tire barrier before he slid down across the track and hit another wall head-on at a high speed. The 28-year-old driver had surgery late Saturday night for a fractured pelvis and a minor spinal fracture, IndyCar said Sunday morning during its prerace show ahead of the Indianapolis 500. The injuries are not life threatening. A statement released by the team later that day added: "He is awake, responsive and resting comfortably this afternoon." On Wednesday, the Chip Ganassi Racing driver tweeted an update about how things were going since being admitted to Lehigh Valley Hospital Cedar Crest near Allentown, Pa., after suffering multiple fractures as well as lung contusions when debris struck his helmet during practice Friday. He also suffered two broken ribs and lacerations to both kidneys.

Both blasts went off on Thika road, a busy highway north-east of the city. The buses were crowded at the time of the explosions, which police said were caused by suicide bombers using explosives hidden in bags and belts. "We heard two loud bangs coming from our petrol station area," local resident Edith Kimani told Reuters news agency. "The bus was right next to my house... we rushed there after hearing about what had happened." Police quickly cordoned off the scene but it took several hours for rescue workers to remove bodies that lay strewn among charred wreckage of one vehicle as thick smoke billowed overhead. Witnesses described horrific scenes inside both vehicles with some passengers still trapped when security forces eventually arrived. "When I reached Sabina Sacco Hospital mortuary they (doctors) informed me 12 people have died here so far while another four are critical," Joseph Kanyiri, director general of Kenya's department of forensic services, told reporters outside the hospital morgue shortly before midnight. At least 80 wounded victims were being treated overnight. There is no immediate claim for Sunday night's attack although al-Shabab has previously carried out similar attacks around Eastleigh, including an assault last month targeting Kenyan soldiers who work alongside African Union peacekeepers battling militants allied to al-Qaeda. Al-Qaida linked group Al Jazeera News correspondent Njiraini Muchira says this latest wave of bombings will strengthen calls for greater military action against Somalia's extremist rebels. "This particular part where you've got these two major roads intersecting each other - one leading inland into Nairobi [and] then towards Lamu Island...this is seen by many analysts as particularly vulnerable because if those checkpoints could be attacked successfully like they appear to have been tonight, then essentially all eyes would turn very much toward Mombasa port on the Indian Ocean coast," she added. Kenya sent troops across its border into southern Somalia six years ago to fight al-Shabaab fighters whom authorities say stepped up their campaign beyond their home territory, seeking refuge underground in more urban areas such as Garissa County close to the Ethiopian frontier. Kenya launched air strikes on suspected rebel positions along the Somali border late last year saying hundreds of civilians may have lost their lives during previous incursions.

Highlands and Islands Fire and Rescue Service recorded the acreage of several of the most serious of the 73 heath and grass fires its crews have tackled. The 332-acre total for Kilmuir near Oban was exceeded only by that in Strone; where a blaze on Ben Cruachan burned 505 acres, including 200 hectares of hillside. With more than 40 per cent of the Scottish population living in rural areas, dealing with wildfires is challenging even though firefighters are able to mobilise quickly from around Scotland as well as having access to specialist wildfire aircraft based at Kinloss in Moray. But there has been a growing public perception that forest management policies - which include allowing trees to die off naturally, particularly rare native conifers such as rowans and junipers - exacerbate conditions to allow small blazes to spread into large conflagrations.

Police said Alexander Protopopov, acting deputy chief of Russia's prison service, oversaw the dismantling of the road in the far-northern Komi region. Former five-weight world champion Mayweather faced UFC lightweight title-holder McGregor in Canada in front of 16,000 fans in Toronto. McGregor, 28, danced around the stage as he criticised 40-year-old Mayweather 's lacklustre performance before finally being knocked down by a left hook midway through the 10th round just to confirm his inevitable fate at 2:05AM on Sunday morning. "I think I won most of the rounds," said an unimpressed Mayweather after improving his flawless record to 50-0. "He fought an unbelievable fight though and it was fun while it lasted."

Media playback is unsupported on your device 11 February 2014 Last updated at 12:37 GMT The woman had been driving east towards Newmarket on the westbound carriageway before being stopped by police. She was breathalysed and found to be over the legal limit, Suffolk Police said. A mother-of-four has been jailed for 18 months after crashing her Audi A6 into a lorry because she was drunk. Lorraine McArthur, 37 admitted drink driving when she appeared at Ipswich Crown Court earlier today having previously pleaded guilty in November last year. The court heard that officers from Essex Roads Policing Unit pulled McArthur's vehicle over in south Colchester where they noticed an odour of alcohol coming form within it. McArthur failed several roadside tests but later blew 123 microgrammes of alcohol per 100 millilitres of breath - almost twice the 35mg legal limit.

Katie Locke, 23, was found dead at Theobolds Park Hotel in Waltham Cross, Hertfordshire. She had been strangled. Carl Langdell admitted the charge of murder when he appeared at St Albans Crown Court on Wednesday (Picture: Facebook) Langdell will be sentenced for her killing next month and could face life imprisonment after admitting guilt to a single count of murder. He did not give evidence during his trial but denied murdering Katie between April 1st last year and May 10th this year. 'I am deeply sorry,' he said as family members looked on from the public gallery. Judge Christopher Morgan QC told him that if she hadn't died then they may still have got together one day anyway.

The government has "called in" proposals to shut St Joseph's Primary in Milngavie near Glasgow. The council plans to build a new denominational primary in nearby Bearsden - replacing both the Catholic and Church of Scotland schools that now serve the area, with relocations offered for pupils from the closed institutions if they need them There are fears this could lead to an exodus among parents at St Joseph's who will be able to move their children into the school next door as it remains open under the current plan. One source told BBC News: "This is going against everything we thought was fair or right."

Frenchman Christophe Borgye's remains were found at a property in Ellesmere Port, Merseyside, in 2013 - four years after he was reported missing. Manuel Wagner, 29, has been found guilty of his murder The body parts belonged to three other men who vanished without trace between 1994 and 2002 - Daniel Whitworth, 21; David Spencer, 19; and Brian Waters, 47. Whitworth disappeared on March 28 1994 while delivering food for Nando's in Liverpool city centre but never returned home. His car was later discovered by police with its engine still running near the M62 motorway. He left behind no money, ID or bank cards and there have been two possible sightings since then which could not be confirmed as him. Spencer went into Greggs bakery in Newton-le-Willows, Lancashire, to buy some sandwiches just before midday on July 1 1998 after an altercation outside another shop. He did not return from what would become known locally as 'the Greggs incident'. The last person to see him alive is thought to have seen him hitchhiking towards Warrington earlier that day. Detectives believe it will take several weeks before DNA results confirm whether any evidence recovered during their investigation matches Dan's Brian Waters had only recently moved back south when he became something of a local celebrity thanks to a successful career playing bass guitar alongside Phil Daniels (left) in 1980s band The Comic Strip. As part of this he performed regularly across the region in pubs including the Hotel Chocolat Club in Manchester His BMW was found abandoned eight miles away, starting up again shortly afterwards, suggesting someone else may well have driven off in it. Waters' disappearance came ten months after Martin Brown vanished in Blackpool, having spent time celebrating his 18th birthday with friends. Despite extensive inquiries over 13 years, his whereabouts remain unknown. In 2010 Jones revealed she believed her son might now be living abroad under a false identity following information about Waters being spotted around Germany in 2006. Forensic tests proved inconclusive so further examinations took place using state-of-the art equipment in order to gain crucial answers. Demand for its drinks in Europe weakened, and a strong dollar ate into revenue from other markets outside the US, including Latin America. The company reported a 4 decline in net sales to 1.78 billion over this time period. The coffee giant has historically been known as one of the most environmentally friendly companies - it only uses 100 percent recycled or certified renewable materials in all packaging by 2020 (already achieved). It is also pursuing an aggressive carbon reduction strategy that includes transitioning operations toward green power sources like wind energy, investing in high-efficiency equipment at factories around the world, and recycling used grounds back on site to make new cups. "There's no doubt we can continue our track record into next year if not beyond, but it will certainly be more difficult than what it was last year," says Gertler. "We are very much committed through 2018."

New research suggests the Cornish Black honey bee is better at dealing with varroa mites, which carry a strain of a disease called deformed wing virus. The virus has killed off many native bees in Europe and North America - but this species seems to have evolved resistance on its own. The researchers think it could be used as an alternative for other European bumblebees that are also under threat from the parasite. They hope they'll soon find out if there's anything special about their genetic makeup so more can be done to help them survive into the future too...

Aamir Siddiqi, 17, was stabbed at his home in Roath in 2010 and two men, Jason Richards and Ben Hope, were jailed for life in 2013. Mohammed Ali Ege, originally from Iraq but living in Cardiff when he committed the offence, has been given a minimum term of 22 years and will not be considered for parole until 2041. The murderer's brother-in-law, Nasser Miah, was also found guilty after being linked to an arson attack on Mr Siddiqui's family home just months before the murder while armed with knives and petrol bombs. He is serving 32 years behind bars. After failing to attend court several times since 2016, Ege appeared by videolink yesterday (Monday) having previously told police that "if I'm caught it won't do any good." Judge Paul Thomas QC said: "You have let down your own family because if you are lucky enough to get out one day they'll be back here defending themselves against what happened." Tariq Ullah Ishaaq, who went missing during jury deliberations, had refused to act as a defence witness due to fears over deportation - despite giving evidence through a translator at trial. His lawyer Rachael Bowen urged him to give evidence but she received no response other than 'No' or silence throughout four days of cross examination. This morning, Ms Bowen apologised to the judge saying her client could offer little explanation why he did not appear. The prosecution offered no closing speech - meaning there would potentially have been insufficient time left even if both sides agreed this afternoon. Prosecutor Laura Rees asked for sentencing to take place next month so jurors can hear about their decision first hand. She added: "I apologise we didn't provide more detail earlier today however there wasn't sufficient opportunity. We hope our application is acceptable."

He said it "makes sense" for pay to be handled by AMs and Welsh ministers as education is already devolved. In another reform, assemblies will no longer have their own official gift shop or post office services. Media playback is not supported on this device Set 136 to win, Pakistan reached their target inside 15 overs, with Sharjeel Khan (59) and Khalid Latif (59 not out) sharing a stand of 118 for the second wicket. After losing opener Kamran Akmal in the third over - he was bowled by Jamie Overton off his fourth delivery - Shan Masood set about rebuilding after some early jitters against England's potent attack. He scored 40 runs from 41 balls before falling LBW to Chris Jordan (1-40), who then trapped Adil Rashid lbw without scoring as well as having Mohammad Hafeez caught behind via DRS just three deliveries later. The experienced duo of Younis Khan and Misbah were both run out cheaply while skipper Shahid Afridi departed for 16 when he top edged an attempted pull shot at Samit Patel. However, left hander Shoaib Malik played very sensibly alongside fellow tailender Sohail Tanvir as they added 60 together which helped take Pakistan beyond 200 - something many had written them off doing beforehand. Having won the toss, Jonathan Trott watched as his side struggled throughout the opening powerplay period despite being given two chances that went begging; firstly Asad Shafiq dropped by Ahmed Shehzad at mid-off following Carl Hopkinson straying onto leg stump and secondly Joe Root spilled by Umar Akmal on 10 when attempting another catch. Indeed it seemed Pakistan would be in trouble but continued to chip away thanks to excellent work between openers Nasir Jamshed and Azhar Ali putting on 91 together before the latter fell 21 short of a century when flicking Tom Westley straight into the hands of James Anderson at fine leg. His departure didn't affect those around him though and although they lost quick wickets late on, Hasan Ali ensured there wasn't any real drama along the way. He finished unbeaten on 20 from four overs including taking one crucial scalp, bowling Gary Ballance (18). The draft Investigatory Powers Bill would place a legal duty on internet providers to assist in hacking devices. But it would not be restricted to phones and PCs, a tech expert has warned MPs MPs are debating legislation that will allow the security services greater powers of surveillance online - including requiring companies such as Facebook and Google to break encryption systems so they can access communications. The Investigatory Powers Bill (IPB) is designed help intelligence agencies track terrorists by allowing them more intrusive means than simply reading their emails or tapping into phone calls. It was published today after three years' worth of consultation with technology firms over how best to tackle terrorism. However, critics have said its proposals for granting government departments wide-ranging "emergency" access to data contravene EU law protecting privacy rights. Theresa May's spokesman insisted there were sufficient safeguards built in using warrants signed off by an independent judge but campaigners say this creates too many opportunities for abuse and could leave individuals open to blackmail and extortion from hackers. Paul Bernal, senior lecturer at City University London specialising in cybercrime and digital forensics, told MPs: 'If you require ISPs [internet service providers] to create backdoors for specific purposes then the potential is enormous.' He added: 'You're creating one vulnerability which might well affect everyone who uses those networks without any guarantee indeed whether it won't just fall prey themselves to attack... This undermines fundamental principles about openness and trustworthiness. - Daily Mail

Seven people have denied conspiracy to defraud at Cardiff Crown Court after six insurance claims worth PS144,000 were made between 2009 and 2011. Matthew Davies, 33, of Pontypridd, Rhondda Cynon Taf; Paul Jones, 32, from Llanelli, Carmarthenshire; Graham Thomas, 45, from Abergavenny, Monmouthshire; Adam Davies, 20, Gorseinon Road in Merthyr Tydfil and Kevin Lee, 38, also of Merthyr Tydfil are accused along with Melissa Richards, 28, from Birmingham on a charge that they conspired together or separately did fraud by false representation against the Lloyds Bank Insurance Company PLC. The charges relate to personal injury compensations for injuries described as whiplash back pain following accidents involving an Audi car driven by Mr Lee between March 1-16 2010 - when he allegedly travelled through his home town without paying road tax - and another accident where he drove into school gates while looking down at mobile phone text messages received minutes before colliding head first onto a nursery fence post. It is alleged that all seven defendants knew their fraudulent activities would result in an overpayment being paid out to them. Prosecutors say there was no reasonable cause arising from which any compensation could be granted. The court heard each defendant has pleaded not guilty and intends to claim trial by jury if necessary. All other matters related to those involved in these criminal proceedings will remain subject to reporting restrictions until further order from Judge Peter Heywood QC.

From April 2016, those in England and Wales will have to pay a 3 surcharge on each stamp duty band. George Osborne said the new surcharge would raise PS1bn extra for the Treasury over three years from 201718-19. The government has already announced that no such tax is planned within Scotland or Northern Ireland where stamp prices are lower than in England Wales (and therefore more property transactions take place). Linked to this announcement was confirmation of its plan to abolish Stamp Duty Land Tax completely by 2020 which may be an encouragement not least because there seems also little prospect at present of any further rises being implemented here during this Parliament; but who knows what might happen after May 2020?

"It gives me a lot of confidence and a lot of good friends," says one of the players on a five-a-side football pitch in the north of Glasgow. He's moving his feet with great pace, weaving between cones - they are coloured yellow for easy identification when he is playing against 11 other boys and girls aged eight to 12 years old - but it isn't just about that. The session at Celtic FC Community Trust (CFCT) has been designed by coaches who have worked at Premier League clubs such as Chelsea, Tottenham Hotspur, Liverpool and Manchester City. They teach skills specific to 5v5 games like agility training, passing and finishing techniques which translate well into full size matches. It may seem an odd concept coming from England where 11 v 11 dominates youth development programmes however the basic principles used here can be applied across all levels in Scotland regardless if there are two or 22 participants involved. The idea behind short intense sessions instead of longer ones focusing more on tactics was developed by people within Scottish Football Association during discussions surrounding how best to improve the national squads performance under Gordon Strachan's stewardship back in 2014 after their disastrous results over qualification groups for Euro 2016. This led them onto research conducted by Eric Cantona and then further studies undertaken around what makes elite teams successful before looking deeper still at coaching methods employed globally. When teenagers enter puberty and start growing taller, bigger muscles form making handling the ball less controllable without knocking the wind out of yourself. But hitting passes through small spaces becomes easier than ever so kids need quickly learn different ways - even unorthodox manoeuvres - to do this successfully whilst maintaining speed and control. "If you were doing anything else besides kicking the ball I think we would probably see some injuries because children naturally don't want to take risks especially jumping off two feet too high realistically," explains Ian MacDonald from CFCT whose organisation took up residence alongside Parkhead last summer following previous moves to the various grounds Swansea City AFC play home fixtures at including Liberty Stadium, Vetch Field stadium and Fairwood Road sports ground. Mcdonald believes improving technical ability directly translates into increasing athleticism allowing young athletes to reach higher speeds while keeping possession of the ball meaning better team work habits develop. These kinds of things are vital attributes needed for any success scored abroad according to Macdonald: "We know many countries now use us regularly to improve their own game." And crucially these lessons aren't exclusive only available those who join academies set ups by top flight European outfits; semi-professional sides, school leavers hoping to make career changes away from sport entirely, Sunday league veterans wanting to sharpen existing skill sets also reap rewards. A recent study carried out among 13 year olds showed almost 70 weren't satisfied with current opportunities given to them leaving vast swathes of talent untapped, not helped either by traditional notions. In Scotland youngsters starting out tend to attend big cities due to being able train and compete close enough together rather than spend hours travelling long distances each week and most opt to focus solely on winning rather developing individual abilities. Most English academy graduates will go straight into professional contracts whereas in Scotland parents feel pressure put upon them by head teachers and PE instructors alike telling pupils becoming pro could affect future job prospects should they decide to pursue something else later down life. However numbers studying physical education careers actually dropped slightly despite a rise among others related subjects prompting debate around whether encouraging extra curricular activities lead towards improved educational attainment?

The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) said it had identified 33 local areas where pubs would not face sufficient competition after the deal. Heineken, which already owns 1,100 pubs, must sell at least 20 to satisfy the watchdog's concerns over reduced choice in those locations should their takeover of Punch go ahead. It is understood that around 30 sites have been earmarked for sale so far but there will be more sales as part of an effort by both firms to "strike a fair balance" between them before any transaction can proceed. Unite has urged ministers, who are currently holding meetings on the proposed tie-up with pub owners across Britain until next week, to intervene if they believe jobs could be lost under the new ownership structure.

The move apparently follows a request from Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office. It also comes ahead of a speech on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict by US Secretary of State John Kerry. Kerry is due to speak at 3:00 p.m., but according to reports in Hebrew media, his plans have been changed since Saturday evening when he had planned to present during an event held at IDF Headquarters and attended only by middle level officers appropriate solutions for continuing Israel's control over Area C without losing its Jewish majority or having any Palestinian state there. In recent years, Palestinians living under PA rule are increasingly complaining that they lack security services such as police stations which extend their authority beyond territory officially designated "Area A," where the PA directly administers civilian matters with help from international forces stationed nearby; "A" represents about 20 percent of Judea and Samaria. The rest lies within what Israelis call "Area B," which includes all large towns including Nablus and Ramallah cities while leaving most other areas largely ungoverned, often falling into anarchy, making it easy for terrorists among them - like those behind last week's stabbing attack near Ofra -to operate freely. According to sources familiar with planning, one solution would be to set up a joint force comprised mainly of Arabs serving under orders given out by members of the civil administration residing in area C together with additional personnel brought in through bilateral agreements between Israel and Jordan. This idea has already been advanced in talks held several times between senior officials from both sides, who agree that creating a force similar to Lebanon's UPDF, whose ranks include many Christian Lebanese soldiers, could prevent further attacks against Jews inside Israel.

Here's how to apply for Who Do You Think You Are? Season 10: If you're interested in taking part on series ten but haven't been cast yet, then all is not lost! Applications can be made via this online form which asks people several questions relating to themselves, such as what your ethnicity or religion may be, plus whether yourselffamily members have ever served within any particular Armed Forces unit (for example Royal Navy). There aren't many other details provided at present apart from 'you must live in England' so if anyone knows more please get in touch RadioTimes.com. Past participants who want to take part again were asked by Who Do You Think You Are? producers to complete some additional information ahead before submitting applications - including giving permission to use photographs videos taken during filming back in 2013. Series 9 participant Paul Lister told us: "The worst bit was filling out forms explaining why I wanted another go; it felt like being interrogated!" But BAFTA award winning genealogist Lucy Worsley reassured fans beforehand adding: "It might feel uncomfortable putting things into words, but just give it a try....There really isn't anything too bizarre." Applications close for both seasons nine ten once the initial audition process has finished therefore we'd suggest getting those documents together sooner rather than later... Good luck!

Energy company BG Group said it was gradually taking workers from the Lomond installation - about 145 miles east of Aberdeen - by helicopter. A Norwegian vessel which caught fire on Thursday is also being taken out, with a third boat still to be removed later in the day. The coastguard says there are currently seven helicopters involved and that three flights have been successfully completed raising 11 people so far from an island where they had sought refuge after their boats capsized following rough weather conditions at sea near the Shetland oil hub early Friday morning (local time). The platform has around 120 staff members working for Total Oil Norway as well as sub-contractors who were staying onboard overnight when the storm hit, according to officials. "We can report that most crewmembers have now left the installations," said Anne Mearns of Britain's Maritime Coastguard Agency during a press conference Saturday evening. Authorities say efforts will continue through Sunday night but stressed rescue operations could take several days due to harsh winter conditions at sea off Scotland northern coast.

28 June 2016 Last updated at 08:03 BST On 1 July 1916, British soldiers started fighting in the Battle of the Somme. The people in charge said that the battle would be over quickly and with little loss of life; neither proved to be true image copyright Getty Images image caption Trenches on a hill near Beaumont-Hamel during World War One - as seen from an aeroplane (late 1914)

During the first nine months of 1938, he oversaw the Czech Kindertransport, which brought Jewish children from German-occupied Czechoslovakia to safety in the UK. He worked tirelessly to ensure money for their upkeep and was responsible for making sure they were eventually settled into homes with suitable foster parents after a period staying at various hostels until they found permanent placements. He also arranged the transport of Hungarian Jews who had been imprisoned by Germany's ally Hungary during World War II under appalling conditions as part of Operation Margarethe (named after Queen Margaretha). The escape plan involved refugees on forced marches through mountainous terrain being shot if they fell behind schedule or failed to catch up - often resulting in numerous deaths along the way before reaching Austria via Italy where most would be transferred onto boats bound for Palestine. For this operation alone, Mr Darvall earned himself an OBE nomination but didn't receive it because his name wasn't cleared like others working alongside him due to lack of proof that he'd assisted those arrested so many years earlier - something acknowledged decades later when three members of staff received British Empire Medals instead; Pauline Leibovitsky, Ruth Silverman and Louisa McLean. His work is now commemorated annually across Europe each Holocaust Memorial Day by placing thousands of white roses outside Yad Vashem in Jerusalem in memory of all victims of Nazism including Dutch citizens.

Another 130 people were wounded in what authorities said was a "premeditated, violent terrorist attack." Four suspects were shot dead, one arrested and other are being sought Xinhua said. City officials did not rule out the possibility of an explosive device that went off during Saturday's rush hour blast. "I heard two explosions. The second explosion was very big," witness Li Xu told Reuters by phone before he fled from his office near Tiananmen Square to a nearby subway station. Footage on television showed passengers screaming as they plunged head-first down escalators in a tunnel following reports of gunfire inside Beijing Railway Station. Ambulances screamed into action outside the main concourse at the city centre hub after the blasts erupted around 8:30 p.m (1230 GMT), sirens blaring and lights flashing. Passengers ran for safety through smoke-filled corridors between railway carriages. Others lay on ground bleeding from wounds including bloodied heads. At least three bodies could be seen lying amid shattered glass with crowds milling about and many shouting or crying. State broadcaster CCTV aired amateur footage showing police struggling to cordon off some streets leading away from the site of the attack. Police armed with assault rifles patrolled an adjacent road lined with numerous blackened buildings while paramilitary policemen stood guard at entrances to housing compounds in the area. A group of men wearing white T-shirts clustered under a bridge overpass, where rescue workers had stored backpacks filled with emergency supplies - presumably left behind when commuters evacuated. Traffic came to standstill across central Beijing late on Friday evening as security forces sealed off roads leaving only pedestrians free to traverse usually busy sections. On Saturday afternoon most appeared willing to go along with tight restrictions imposed by the government so soon afterwards. Some questioned why they weren't allowed more information but others seemed resigned even though they felt safe enough within their neighbourhoods to venture outdoors. 'TOURISTS ARE SAFE' No details have emerged yet concerning those injured nor any possible motives for the attacks. But in the wake of such violence, China has taken steps towards preventing another incident like this happening again. Shortly after midnight, state media reported all bus service connecting Beijing with neighbouring cities south of the capital would stop until further notice due to tightened security checks on highways entering the city. All seven underground lines servicing Beijing also stopped running between 10pm (1400GMT) and 9am (0100GMT). Security concerns aside, visitors flocked to landmarks throughout Saturday eager to glimpse them up close despite heavy rain showers which kept many indoors. At 7:15 pm local time (1045GMT), tourists waited patiently each nightwatchman took position atop Mao Zedong's Mausoleum, a towering bronze statue overlooking Tiananmen Square built to commemorate the founder of Communist Party, who died 35 years ago. Though dark clouds loomed overhead overnight, clear skies greeted hundreds of couples dressed formally for weddings taking pictures beneath portraits of Lenin and Mao and children playing hopscotch beside statues honouring President Xi Jinping. Other groups posed happily against red walls painted with characters saying: "Tourists Are Safe Here." Washington urged Chinese leaders to provide full transparency regarding the bombing, White House National Security Council spokeswoman Caitlin Hayden said. And Japan called it a serious act that must be firmly dealt with according to international law, Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida told reporters. Separately, Pakistan summoned China's ambassador Zhu Qibao after masked gunmen stormed the Chinese embassy there earlier on Thursday, killing four civilians and wounding 21 people, five seriously, Pakistani sources told Reuters. U.S., Japanese and South Korean intelligence agencies believe Islamist militants based in northwestern Pakistan may have been responsible, although no claim of responsibility has come forth.

We cannot allow those who do business with us to continue doing so without complying with our laws."

The mayor of London has been criticised for pedalling his barrister wife Marina Wheeler through the capital on Thursday on a bicycle designed for one person. Giving a backie is , I guess, more politically correct than electric bike-sharing schemes like Mobike and Boris Bikes but it's hard to see what political advantage he gains from this (other then fewer calories burned). Polls show that 60 of people support these kinds of initiatives as they are seen to be green ways to move around without cars. However there will always be those who moan about everything - even if you have given them their own personalised shareable eBike.

Dewi and Dwynwen, named after two of Wales' most renowned patron saints, are nestled in a romantic "cwtch." Their arrival marks the launch of a campaign by heritage body Cadw to bring more birds back into Welsh homes. The pheasants will live at Llanfyllin House near Crickhowell for three months while they get used to their new home before being released further afield on private land later this year or early next year as part of an Injured Birds Recovery Sanctuary (IBRS) project involving free-roaming native gamebirds bred up in captivity - like them! The sanctuary is designed to give injured wild animals who have been put down some form of retirement with other species roaming freely between enclosures rather than living out their days confined inside cramped cages. "This IBRS scheme offers wounded wildlife a chance of life," said John Dye, senior estates officer from Gwent Wildlife Trust which owns Llanfyllin along with several other properties it manages around south west Wales including Penmorfa Country Park where Llansantffraid Glan y Mor sits. "It's important that we continue our commitment here at the estate not just to protect existing biodiversity but also look ahead towards the future needs of nature so I'm delighted that these beautiful chicks can now call Llanfyllin home until spring 2022 when hopefully they'll be ready to go off into the countryside again looking for love!"

The report found that although alcohol consumption has dropped since 2008, those in poorer communities are more likely to suffer or die from alcohol-related disease. The coalition government rejected a recommendation for an 8 increase on minimum unit pricing and refused to use its powers under health legislation to ban the advertising of alcoholic drinks during programmes aimed at children (which it can do). Last year some measures were introduced to target excessive drinking by young people. A ban on cheap high strength cider was brought forward; maximum weekly hours worked without breaks increased from nine to 10 per week - but this is not compulsory until next September so many employers continue to ignore it. This measure will only affect about 5 of workers though because most other staff already take longer than this break. Supermarkets have been banned from selling cut price alcohol near checkouts after 11pm on Friday and Saturday nights when binge drinking is common. But ministers fear any move against cheap booze might be seen as political interference with free trade which could threaten the future EU referendum vote.

The 335ft (100m) Victorian structure, which closed last year, is one of the UK's shortest piers. Bryan Huxford, who co-owns Humberside Airport, said he would soon reopen the pier as a "restaurant and bar." "It has been derelict for some time now," Mr Huxford told The Daily Telegraph.

Research shows Europeans are a mixture of three major ancestral populations - indigenous hunters, Middle Eastern farmers and a population that arrived from the east in the Bronze Age. DNA has also revealed two distinct sub-populations: one centred on Russia's Volga riverlands close to where most Russians live today; another around Kiev in Ukraine. The study found Ukrainians had more genetic overlap with Western Europe than any other country except Estonia but did not have enough samples for individual analysis as is standard practice among academic studies. Just over 12 of their genomes came from the ancient farming migrants who settled central Asia about 7 000 years ago before spreading into Europe. That figure compares with 40-50 in many European countries. The researchers said this suggested some Ukrainian lands were occupied by both groups at different times. Siberians appeared less genetically linked to Moscow than much of western Eurasia, while those north of Beijing shared ancestry similar to South Asians including Pakistanis or Indians rather than fellow Siberians beyond Vladivostok. In all cases, however, these ties may change quickly given migration patterns across Siberia which saw Asiatic peoples move up and down its length roughly every 1 500 years until contact began opening trade routes during the 19th century.

A referendum on the UK's membership of the EU is to be held later this year. The findings come as two new opinion polls suggested support among voters here has grown since last week's televised debate between Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Ed Miliband at Cardiff University about Scotland leaving the United Kingdom.

Ten passengers on board the bus were reported to have been killed while all four crew members survived. Local TV showed the heavily damaged Boeing 727 Allied Air plane lying near a small, winding road in Barangay Puntaplata. Rescue workers could be seen trying to pull out survivors from the wreckage and firefighters put out a blaze that gutted most of the passenger cabin. "I was able to see one body being taken away," said witness Cristeta Geminiano, who was at her house nearby when she saw the crash happen. "It hit the wire fence then nosedived straight into a residential area." The Civil Aviation Authority of the Philippines (CAAP) suspended operations while it investigates Monday's accident. CAAP spokesman Eric Apolonio told reporters he had no details yet about how many people may have died or injured but confirmed there were fatalities.

Lewis Hamilton was the fastest of the silver cars, despite a mistake-strewn final lap on a weekend when penalties mean he will start from the back. Team-mate Nico Rosberg, who finished second in Malaysia last year and starts third this time around is also running at the front after his first flying laps since qualifying were split by DRS deployment - limiting him to an outlap long enough only for one timed run each before having to pit again. Hamilton went top with 1m40.673s early, setting up what looked like it could be another fight between himself and Vettel as they battled over track position into Turn One. And that battle continued all through turn two where a tap from Felipe Massa sent both off-track, but ended there as Mercedes resumed pulling away at Red Bull's expense under braking, leaving Sebastian and Daniel Ricciardo scrambling behind them. But then came Esteban Ocon's crash - along with team mate Sergio Perez and Williams' Lance Stroll - which brought out the virtual safety car (VSC). This allowed both Ferraris to come in, while Fernando Alonso did likewise just moments later once Kevin Magnussen had recovered his Haas following more issues and Max Verstappen stopped too. The Dutchman spun exiting Turn Four during his stop, damaging the right rear corner and bringing about yet another fit of drama late in Q2... Q3 got underway with 10 minutes remaining, and although most drivers opted not to head straight onto their race tyres given how much rubber would have been laid down already by those ahead, Lewis Hamilton set a 1min 40.374secs to claim provisional pole. Nico Hulkenberg took P4, 0.276 secs adrift, followed by Carlos Sainz Jr., Kimi Raikkonen and Romain Grosjean rounding out the top six. Having faced traffic throughout Saturday morning's practice sessions, Valtteri Bottas found some extra pace and claimed seventh place with a 1:41.151s. That put him half a tenth clear of Jolyon Palmer, who made it four Renault powered cars inside the top ten. Force India teammates Sergio Perez and Esteban Ocon rounded out the top 11, sandwiching McLaren duo Stoffel Vandoorne and Fernando Alonso.

Ackerman was initially banned in October last year after being found guilty of corruption. He had laid bets against a horse knowing its jockey aimed not to win. Ackerman was also fined 4,500 and ordered to pay costs of around 10,000 - but the ban has now been lifted following an appeal by his lawyers. The decision means he will be allowed back into racing immediately as long as trainers are happy with him using their horses again.
