Penglais Farm will have a total of 1,000 rooms, but only 700 will be ready this month to welcome students. The university said developer Balfour Beatty confirmed the remaining 300 -plus would arrive in November and December as planned. The university told CTV News there's been an "uptick" in demand for on-campus housing after COVID restrictions were lifted earlier than expected over summer break - so much so that it was unable to fill all available spaces last year despite trying hard to do so with incentives such as free meals and movie tickets. The school received about 6,500 applications from international and domestic students who wanted to live at Pengalais Farm over 202021 academic year, along with many more inquiries by phone or email. But officials say they ended up having room for just 4,700 people across its campus houses: 3,200 living in new residences opened since 2018 and 2,100 residing elsewhere on site including private student accommodation already owned by UBC. Universities typically don't build their own residence buildings due to financial constraints; instead most rely upon condo developers to construct purpose-built accommodations complete with common areas like lounges and laundry facilities inside them while also leasing out suites independently under long-term leases. Most operate separately financially from universities themselves although some take donations from alumni groups or other sources which allow institutions to expand capacity if needed ahead of schedule. UBC is no exception. It owns property directly next door to where Penglais Farms currently stands worth 1 billion, according to real estate listings website Zillow. In 2019, it sold off 22 acres of land valued between 400 million to nearly half a billion dollars to two local companies called Westbank Corp. and RioCan Real Estate Investment Trust (REIT). Both are major condominium builders focused primarily within Metro Vancouver. Neither company immediately responded to requests seeking comment Monday afternoon.

The video of Bailey Matthews showing him abandoning his walking aid to cross the finish line has been viewed on Facebook more than 27 million times. Bailey, from Doncaster, was in a wheelchair for about six years after being diagnosed with cerebral palsy when he started school Bailey's story became even bigger thanks to the support and fundraising efforts by The Brain Tumour Charity - which helped make it possible for mum Claire (pictured) to travel around Europe before her son died last year aged 10 MUM'S HORROR STORY: HOW CLAIRE LOST HER SON TO A BRAIN TUMOUR... 'I remember looking at my beautiful little boy who had just turned five-and-a-half one day - such an energetic, happy child full of life. Then suddenly I noticed that he wasn't using both legs like other children do.' It was October 11 2016 and Claire Matthews knew something was wrong then as she watched her young son walk into their home with two different gait patterns. But still they did not know what would cause them such devastation within weeks later. That Christmas Eve, while preparing dinner together, Claire took out some new plates. Her husband Stewart looked over at Baileys and spotted a large lump behind its eyes. She rushed him off to hospital where doctors found nothing untoward but advised further tests were needed. In January 2017, shortly before Easter Bunny parties began, he fell down stairs outside the family home. He lost consciousness immediately but came round quickly enough once paramedics arrived. After scans, repeated blood tests and x-rays no obvious problems could be seen so they returned home. But days later there was another fall during a visit to Sheffield Children's Hospital. Doctors eventually discovered a tumour growing near the brain stem. Surgeons removed part of the growth including half of his left hemisphere of the brain known as the cerebellum. They also managed to remove 99 per cent of the tumour itself without damaging any major nerves or the main artery supplying oxygenated blood to the head. At first everything seemed stable until August 18 2018 when Bailey developed high fever and vomiting. Staff ran tests straight away because this type of reaction is frequently linked to meningitis infections caused by bacteria entering the body through wounds such as cuts. However, results came back clear. Within hours though Bailey appeared unable to move anything below his waist except his right arm. One minute he couldn't turn himself over, next thing you know he can't feel his lower limbs,' said Mrs Matthews. A scan showed swelling throughout his spine and doctors told the parents devastating news. Paediatric neurologists confirmed the worst fears; cancerous cells already present inside the surgery area had spread and multiple medulloblastoma secondary cancers now existed in three separate areas. These typically affect children under four and are highly aggressive with very few treatment options available due to their location deep inside the spinal cord, skull base and optic nerve. Surgery alone carries significant risks given how close these tumors are situated in relation to vital structures. And chemotherapy might reduce symptoms temporarily only for the disease to return months later requiring equally difficult treatment plans. Although Mr and Ms Matthews agreed to go ahead with intensive radiotherapy, it carried huge side effects too. This included bloating all over his face, hands and feet meaning he struggled to eat and drink properly. He also suffered severe diarrhoea and nausea reducing his appetite dramatically leaving him feeling weak and exhausted most of the time. His weight dropped rapidly falling to 5st 3lbs less than half his normal height by early December. Despite having numerous platelets transfusions to help clotting and provide immunity against infection either directly donated by people just like themselves or made artificially in labs many often resulted in internal bleeding leading surgeons to struggle controlling pressure drops resulting in frequent hospital admissions. Because the tumor prevented much of the circulation in his arms and legs working correctly weakened tissues caused painful sores preventing Claire getting adequate rest putting extra strain on Bailey whenever trying to change dressing especially towards end of 2019. On December 31 2020 staff admitted Bailey saying things weren't going well despite various treatments designed specifically for rarer forms of pediatric malignancies. By New Year Day medical teams decided action must come fast if they wanted to save lives to buy Bailey precious time every hour counted. With coronavirus restrictions delaying usual transfer procedures long enough, specialists created bespoke care plan allowing clinicians to gain access remotely via telemedicine equipment never used previously due to current health crisis. Those involved in caring for Bailey estimate it saved up to 48 hours precious time helping improve chances overall rewarding team effort across Yorkshire Hospitals NHS Trust specialising in neurological illnesses working closely alongside University College London Cancer Centre UK experts diagnosing why Bailey continued suffering worsening condition despite specialist drugs meant to control certain types of childhood cancers improving outcome ultimately saving patients' quality of life. Unfortunately those hopes waned around midday on Friday February 12 2021 causing heartbroken couple taking heartbreaking decision it wouldn't have mattered anyway stopping antibiotics usually prescribed following procedure protecting remaining healthy organs knowing operation likely imminent death inevitable soon afterwards,saving others facing same situation ensuring important lessons learned benefiting families struggling similar ordeal elsewhere.. Four US tourists and an Australian pilot died after their light plane came down on a shopping centre on Tuesday. It had just taken off from the small Essendon Airport, north of Melbourne in Victoria state when it crashed into the mall at 9am local time (10pm GMT Monday). The three men who were among those killed are believed to be friends celebrating one's 21st birthday by taking part in the flightseeing tour over Melbourne's suburbs with Flight Training International owner David Nicholson as pilot. One was from Chicago, while another man hailed a Californian city. The identity of the fourth victim has not been released yet.

Energy will travel via the world's longest sub-sea electricity interconnector. The a'!2bn (PS1.4bn) project has been rubber stamped between National Grid and its Norwegian equivalent Statnett. The UK aims to be carbon neutral by 2050, so this is an important step towards meeting that target Isle of Wight - 4GW HVDC link with France: This 6.5 billion (8 bn total including converter stations at both ends) 1 GW direct current (DC) transmission line from St Mary's on the Isle of Wight across thousands of kilometres into mainland Europe could power up to four million households in Britain when it opens some time around 20302035. It would connect renewable energy sources such as offshore wind farms located off Scotland or Wales directly onto the grid for export to other countries in Western Europe under a new European directive which requires more green generation come online. If all goes well there are plans also underway to build another similar high voltage link connecting Cornwall Isles of Scilly to Spain... Preston New Road Power Station refurbishment plus Carbon Capture Technology installation: From 2021 2022 two gas turbines within Preston New Road station near Blackpool will undergo major upgrades designed to extend their life span whilst enabling them burn low CO 2 emission fuels. At the same time Siemens Energy plan installing High Efficiency Particulate Air (HEPA) filters capable capturing 99 of particulates generated during combustion while reducing NOx emissions significantly below EU limits. How much? Well we probably don't want to know given previous experience where Emissions Trading Systems have failed us miserably over many years... But if you do want to find out how then see our Factsheet HEPA filtration overview article here

Adrian Simut, 35, travelled to Newport train station, where he thought he was meeting a 14-year-old girl called Sam. But he was confronted by so-called "paedophile hunters" and later arrested, the court heard. Prosecutor David Pinnell told Swansea Crown Court: "In reality it turned out that what Mr Simut had been communicating with online were two women who are members of an organisation which is dedicated to meeting up men at railway stations in order for them to be met by younger persons pretending they want sex." The defendant admitted attempting to meet a child following sexual grooming between December 16 last year and January 10 this year. He also pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children - including some involving young boys - after police searched his home address on March 7. Prosecutor Amanda Lewis said one video showed five males raping a female while another depicted a boy aged eight or nine being given oral sex by adults. Some other videos featured girls as young as seven years old performing sex acts. All the footage appeared to have been taken abroad rather than within Britain. Jonathan Webb, defending, asked Judge Keith Thomas not to impose any jail sentence due to medical complications arising from a septic wound on his left leg which meant the inmate could only stand upright during breaks to wash himself if seated. The barrister added there would be no problem complying with the terms of release because Simut already worked full time night shifts stacking shelves for Tesco's distribution centre near Cardiff docks. But Judge Thomas rejected the application based upon previous convictions dating back more than 20 years. In addition to imposing immediate custody, the judge made orders banning general media reporting such details about him due to fears over the impact upon future employment prospects.

Media playback is not supported on this device Saturday's loss to Liverpool was the Swans' third in succession, leaving them a point above the bottom three and increasing the pressure on Bob Bradley "It has happened very quickly. I am confident we can get out of it but everything needs to improve," said American boss Bradley, whose side have won only once since September. Despite Swansea having taken just one point from their past four games - all against sides currently below them - midfielder Ki Sung-yueng says they are still hopeful that results elsewhere will turn around before too long. He added: "We need wins as soon as possible because at home now the atmosphere isn't good."

Tokyo Electric Power Co (Tepco) aims to reduce radiation leaks in three months and to cool the reactors within nine months. The firm said it also planned to cover the damaged reactors with a double-layered shield of special concrete by 2015 that will be able to withstand an earthquake of magnitude 8 - one every 150 years on Japan's northeast coast, where several quakes have struck over the past two weeks. The government has pledged more than 5 billion towards decommissioning costs for Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant operator Tepco after Prime Minister Naoto Kan promised last week there would not be any further cost increases beyond what was already budgeted as part of its business plan through March 2013.

Germany forward Linden, who was signed from Frankfurt, nodded in from a Kerys Harrop cross to salvage a point. Melissa Fletcher had put the hosts ahead, meeting an Emma Follis through ball before rounding keeper Lee Alexander and slotting home in the seventh minute of injury time for their second victory this season after 11 games. A win would have moved them above Wolfsburg at the top but they are stuck on six points along with 16th-placed Potsdam, while Leverkusen dropped down one place into fifth on 10 following Bayern Munich's 4-1 demolition of Koln later Saturday. Wolfsburg beat Freiburg 2-0 earlier as Bintje Naessens scored twice and Alessandra Schauer added another goal shortly before half-time.

Rolo, a chocolate Labrador, was saved after two coastguard rescue teams and an RNLI lifeboat were called in, near Brixham. She was hauled up in a "dog rescue bag" on to the boat before being taken ashore at Bridgwater harbour where she will be checked by vets for any injuries incurred during her ordeal. A local vet said: She's] very lucky but exhausted."

The new plan is for training to be split across three different sites. There would be some joint training, but the three services would each have their own facilities. The Army and Navy would hold most of its exercises at Fort Ord in Monterey County; Air Force units trained on a base near San Luis Obispo that was once used by the U-2 spy plane program. But all that has changed since then: Base closures forced the closure of both bases - leaving only Camp Edwards as an option now. And with tensions rising between Washington and Beijing over trade issues and other matters, military commanders say it's more important than ever to maintain close ties among the branches so they can work together seamlessly if there were any kind conflict with China or another nation.

"Dependency on giving that only appears to be charitable must end," he said in a tweet ahead of this weekend's African Union summit in South Africa. The BBC's Robert Kiptoo says the AU will discuss migration at its meeting, but it is unlikely to make new commitments publicly because there are few solutions on offer and no consensus from member states. A number of countries have taken unilateral action - closing borders or sending people back across them. The UN has warned such actions violate human rights law and risk causing further suffering for migrants fleeing conflict, extreme poverty and persecution. What does Ethiopia say about returnees? Ethiopia deported hundreds more Eritreans last month after they had been stranded at two transit centres near the border with Djibouti since 2017 when the government closed the main crossing point into Sudan. Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed, who took office in 2018, campaigned on promises of reform including making peace with neighbouring Eritrea. But his authorities also launched an offensive against dissident groups inside Tigray state, where many ethnic Afar minorities were forcibly displaced by the TPLF before fighting broke out between federal troops and local forces earlier this year. Tens of thousands fled their homes amid reports of atrocities committed by both sides. Many sought refuge beyond Ethiopian territory along the border with north-eastern Eritrea. When Mr Abiy announced victory over rebel fighters several months later, those refugees began returning home voluntarily. This week, however, officials tried to stop buses carrying 113 Eritrean nationals trying to cross through the Semera checkpoint close to the shared frontier, which sparked anger among some international charities working in the area. "Our team witnessed large numbers being detained while attempting to leave via unofficial routes under police escort towards Massawa city... we believe these individuals were eventually returned to Yemen," one wrote online. Another added: "It was very distressing seeing families separated as a result." Officials told AFP news agency none would be sent back until conditions improved. "Eritreans should wait here [in Ethiopia] till our country is peaceful again," defence ministry spokesman Colonel Getnet Adane said. "We need time... not immediately; let us keep you guys safe first. Once everything settles down then come back." What do European politicians think? Several EU leaders called for urgent talks following recent developments, citing fears for asylum and refugee protections. They discussed plans during a virtual gathering hosted by Luxembourg Prime Minister Xavier Bettel. In June 2020, Denmark reversed plans to deport 26 unaccompanied minors who arrived illegally with family members three years ago. Similarly, Sweden agreed in July 2020 to allow Syrians seeking protection to remain indefinitely rather than send them home despite having legal opposition from its rightwing minority government. One politician familiar with discussions involving six other nations suggested postponing any decisions pending fresh elections in Italy next spring. Germany continues to face pressure for allowing nearly 40,000 asylum seekers to stay even though they entered without valid documentation. And UK Home Secretary Priti Patel accused her French counterpart of refusing responsibility regarding migrants already present in France claiming to want to seek asylum in Britain instead of staying closer to northern Europe. So what can happen now? Some destinations may refuse entry to anyone arriving irregularly if current trends continue unchecked. Others might start turning away potential claimants based on nationality alone, something which could mean tens of thousands stuck within Europe unless individual agreements are reached with each nation involved. Countries targeted by migrant smuggling networks could see arrivals increase once travel restrictions ease due to concerns raised by coronavirus lockdowns like job losses and financial hardship throughout much of southern Asia and sub-Saharan Africa. Attempts by aid agencies operating off Somalia's coast to deliver food and medical supplies using smaller boats means more lives saved compared with larger vessels used previously. However, environmentalists fear this shift to less polluting methods threatens livelihoods needed by communities relying upon tourism associated with big ships. Courtesy: (BBC)

Culture Secretary Maria Miller said "decriminalisation of the licence fee should be on the table" during the BBC's charter review before 2017. The BBC said changing the law could lead to an end in public service broadcasting as we know it, and would undermine the Government's own policy of not decriminalising TV licences for pensioners who have no other way of paying them." The report says: "We recommend that a culture secretary - or another minister with responsibility over media regulation - is appointed by the Culture secretary to monitor broadcasters' compliance with Section 40 obligations. This is particularly important when new regulatory bodies are established under section 228 later this year (see below). We also note concerns expressed about some Ofcom sanctions being disproportionate; if so then those concerns merit further consideration."

A judge said there was a basis for concluding the officers, known as M and Q, may have perverted the course of justice and committed perjury while giving evidence. Pearse 's ex-wife also accused them in court documents of assault during their marriage by hitting her with his gun - a claim they deny. The Met Police has launched an investigation into these allegations but found no grounds to bring criminal charges against either officer. It is understood that prosecutors only look at cases where there are'reasonable lines of inquiry' or leads which could result in prosecution.

The new bill, which would affect digital maps from Google, Apple, and Uber, is facing stiff opposition from campaign groups. It also bans "wrong" information, including disputed international borders. The European Union has threatened to initiate legal action if the United States doesn't comply with its GDPR rules by next year. However, it's not entirely clear how these two laws - one in Europe and another on a state level - will be reconciled.

The Northern Ireland international, 28, was charged on 29 July with breaching FA rule E8, which bars professional players from betting on football-related matters. The offence took place on 20 September 2016 when he played for Rangers in a Scottish League Cup quarter-final against Celtic. Kamara is alleged to have placed 39 bets between the dates of 19 August and 18 October totaling 711.64 - an average stake per bet amounting to just over 50p. "I will be pleading not guilty at my hearing next month," said Kamara after his charge became public earlier this week.

Vikki Thompson, 21, died at HMP Leeds on 13 November. She had been awaiting sentencing for robbery. Her partner Bob Steele said the letter should have alerted officials to her condition and that women who did not report their pregnancies were also at risk of suicide. "She was a healthy woman before she went in there but when it came out they couldn't understand why," he told BBC News after being shown an extract from his girlfriend's death note which read: 'I am at the lowest point I can ever get.' The prison service declined to comment further than saying Ms Thompson took her own life while on remand as no inquest has taken place yet into how or where she died. A spokesperson added "our sympathies are with Mr Steele [Mr Solomons] and family." Justice Secretary Robert Buckland ordered an urgent review of reproductive healthcare provisions across all prisons following Miss Thompson's case. "Pregnant prisoners need specialist support inside and outside to ensure both mother and baby receive the best possible care throughout pregnancy," he said last month. During Theresa May's premiership, more pregnant female inmates were given space to give birth away from other prisoners in custody suites but campaigners argue this is insufficient. Speaking about his daughter, Mr Steele described Viki as having a "heart of gold" despite battling drug abuse issues since childhood. He claims staff knew that if anything happened during childbirth then the baby would be placed into foster care adding up to another tragedy.

US experts found B3, also known as nicotinamide, boosts the ability of immune cells to kill Staphylococcus bacteria. B3 increases the numbers and efficacy of neutrophils, white blood cells that play a key role in fighting infection by killing toxins from harmful bacteria such as S. aureus.[1] The researchers first tested whether adding extra vitamin D would have any effect on the number or effectiveness of these "killer" cells against S. aureus after they had been extracted from mice - but without being activated - then reinjected into healthy mice. The results showed an enhanced protective response when both B3 plus vitamin D was injected before injecting the live dangerous bugs into another group of inoculated animals. This suggested making the killer T-cells more effective at targeting invading pathogens like S. aureus using either treatment approach is beneficial. The team next looked specifically for changes in gene activity levels caused by giving each component separately rather than together. They discovered significantly increased expression of two chemokine genes (CXCL12 and CXCR2) which are involved with attracting white blood cell reinforcements called macrophages to infected tissue sites where S. aureus can cause damage if left untreated. These findings suggest boosting immunity through this specific mechanism could be beneficial even though it's not directly linked to activating T-cell function alone.[2] Dr. Minhajul Haque says:

The star whisked through 23 songs in 90 minutes, in a blur of pyrotechnics, lasers and multiple costume changes. She donned silken butterfly wings for a piano-led version of...Baby One More Time as the night's first guest stars - Priyanka Chopra Jonas and Nick Jonas - danced along from their table front row. "I'm so happy to be here," she said before launching into her debut single Love Me Like You Do (2009). "It was 10 years ago today that I wrote it." The concert comes on the heels of Swift's new album Evermore which became available after midnight Thursday morning following its surprise release earlier this week. Her previous record Lover had been released last summer.

Natalia Wilkanowska, 50, disappeared in 2003 after travelling to visit her ex-husband Gerald Doherty in Luton. Her body was found in December 2015, Luton Crown Court was told. Mr Doherty's brother John and two others were acquitted of murder. Mr Justice Spencer said police failed "to answer the most basic questions" about Ms Wildanowski's death but described it as an accident caused by a fire which went out of control at his home on 14 October last year. He added: "It should have been obvious that when you do not properly maintain or extinguish your burners something is going to go wrong."

The injury-hit Hammers lost to Romanian champions Astra Giurgiu in the qualifying round for the second season in succession. The visitors won Thursday's second leg at the London Stadium 1-0 , with Michail Antonio sent off late on after being shown a straight red card following a VAR review of his challenge on Cristian Tanase and pushing Daniel Oprita away from referee Ovidiu Hategan as he protested against it. Manager David Moyes was furious about both incidents but said there were mitigating circumstances behind both decisions. "If they think that [Antonio] is going over the top then I'll accept it - because it wasn't," Moyes told BT Sport afterwards before praising the officials' performance overall. "They've got to make sure every decision is right whether or not we win or lose."

The group had been sailing around the County Down lough on Wednesday when three crew members went ashore on Green Island. The cabin cruiser then developed electrical problems as it was being towed back to port and they called for assistance from emergency services at about 5pm. There were fears that one person may have drowned but following a search of dense undergrowth, all four people onboard - two adults and their sons aged 12 and 14-were found safe and well shortly after 10am today (Friday). They are understood not be injured in any way.. A spokesperson for PSNI said: "Two males aged 47 48 years, along with 2 male juveniles age 13 14years old, who had gone into the water off Portaferry whilst trying to deal with an engine issue, have now made contact with Police."

It seems in Northern Ireland we call it Tuesday. Politics dominates the front pages of the papers again today as the clock which was supposed to stop yesterday at 16:00 still ticks on with no agreement and talk carries on about a new election being needed if there is not one by then. We also have an update from our man Alex Kane who has been reporting outside Stormont for us this week, while you can read what MPs are saying here - Today's top stories include: Sinn Fein president Mary Lou McDonald says she hasn't ruled out forming another government; Fears that Brexit will lead to increased violence against police officers across Britain and a public health emergency over heart attacks due to obesity. Inspections find unsafe practice by major contractors doing road improvement work in NI and Belfast City Council wants more powers cut back by central government so it can invest directly instead -

The beach where Seifeddine Rezgui stood on Friday, pulled a Kalashnikov from his parasol and unleashed Tunisia's worst ever terror attack, has already reopened. Camera crews capture the spot; passers-by pose for selfies in front of its unbroken security fence: this is Kantaoui. Before this week, it was best known as "the place that doesn't exist." It lies several kilometres north of Sousse and not far from Hammamet airport - which until yesterday had been closed since last year because of security concerns following threats against tourists by jihadists angered at Assad Haftar, an air force colonel who led military operations during Libya's civil war and now leads forces trying to wrest control of Tripoli back from militias loyal to western governments. Now both airports have opened again after international pressure forced Libyan authorities to cede ground to their rivals there. But while many Tunisians are relieved to see business picking up once more with most resorts open or reopening soon, they remain anxious over what comes next.

Thieves broke into the house in Intake, Doncaster on Thursday, a week after Paris Mulholland's 11th birthday. In the letter, she tells the burglars "how much they hurt me," that her family is so worried about them and asks: "Am I going to see you again?" She adds: "I don't understand why anyone would do something like this." She then says how scared she was when it happened at 12pm while all of their children were home - including three-year-old twins - as well as husband Benjy who had just got back from work. The thieves made off with 500 worth of valuables but also left behind jewellery belonging to Mrs Malholland which belonged to her late mother. Philae, the first spacecraft to land on a comet, was dropped on to the surface of Comet 67P by its mothership, Rosetta, last November. It worked for 60 hours before it began experiencing technical issues that have hampered scientists' attempts at further contact with it since then NASA's LADEE probe became lost somewhere in space after crashing into the moon while attempting an ambitious landing approach following its launch in September 2013

All 42 of its member clubs are expected to take strict disciplinary measures against fans who indulge in anti-social behaviour during matches. The updated guidance, which comes into force immediately, is part of a five-point plan aimed at ensuring that football can be enjoyed safely with supporters returning after the pandemic forced venues across England to close their doors for large parts of last season and this term. The guidelines set out that "clubs must have processes in place to identify potential issues" before games - including strategies around how they will respond if there is evidence of racist or discriminatory abuse taking place either inside stadiums or online. They also state: "Fans should expect clear messaging on what constitutes unacceptable conduct prior to attending (e.g., abusive language, chanting etc.)."

The 86-year-old first became prime minister in 1982, beginning a third spell as leader in 2014. In a televised address Mr Jugnauth said he was resigning in favour of a younger generation and that "several important duties demand my presence." He did not say what those responsibilities were but the announcement comes after weeks of instability for Mauritania with some opposition figures calling on him to step down because they saw his continued leadership as an obstacle to political change.

Its shares slid 7.6 to their lowest level since March, and the company was the biggest faller on the FTSE 100, the UK's main share index. It has been hailed as the most comprehensive list to date. About 9,000 names - nearly all German - are on the Auschwitz garrison list, some with photographs attached. The original document is in Polish and contains information about when they arrived at the camp, their unit designation, what they did there, where they were from and how long they stayed before being sent to another concentration camp or transferred into forced labour. Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below. Article content "I think it's a great collection ... because of its completeness," said David Ferreira, head archivist for Nazi-era records at Yad Vashem Holocaust Memorial Centre in Jerusalem who analyzed the documents. He called them an important resource that will allow scholars to study individual prisoners and units. According to historians' estimates, more than 1 million people, mostly Jews, perished during World War Two at Auschwitz, which was run by Nazi Germany alongside other death camps such as Treblinka, Sobibor and Belzec. 'THEY ALL DIED HERE' A copy of the archive provided exclusively to Reuters includes details on 642 victims known only by their prison numbers: 214 Germans, 116 Poles, 56 Hungarians, 43 Romanians - among them Gypsies - 18 Frenchmen, 14 Italians, 10 Rumanian Communists, eight Dutch citizens, seven Belgians, six Russians, five Greeks, four Czechs, three Slovaks and two Swedes. What makes this unique is that unlike previous lists, it does not contain any entries for prisoners whose final destination was one of these other camps. They died en route. Israel Museum curator Shmuel Rosenman believes it is likely that many of those buried at Birkenau's unknown mass graves had originally been part of various SS formations stationed around Poland and Hungary earlier in the war. Some may have even fought against each other, he suggested. Among the population kept out of sight until 1945 appears to be 13 political prisoners, including nine communists, an anti-fascist trade unionist and two Jehovah's Witnesses. Historians say communist forces operating in the area took several thousand Jewish prisoners late in 1944 after retreating Soviet troops retreated westward ahead of advancing Western Allied armies. There could also be members of resistance groups like the Zegota organization in hiding. Reached by phone, 85 year old Piotr Rybak, a survivor born near Lodz in central Poland now living in Toronto, expressed hope others would come forward given heightened awareness today about preserving historical memory and preventing future genocides. "The survivors know everything we went through. We don't need to repeat our stories again and again. I wish somebody comes forth so we can give testimony to history." (Reporting by Anna Wlodarczak-Semczuk; Additional reporting by Steve Scherer in Rome Editing by Alexandra Hudson) Share this article in your social network Shopping essentials Advertisement Story continues below This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.
